So Alif is an abbreviation of "Allah", Lam is an abbreviation of "Jibril", and Mim is an abbreviation of Muhammad, which means that the Qur'an comes from Allah, conveyed by Jibril to Muhammad. In Alif Lam Ra, Alif is an abbreviation of "Ana" (I), Lam is an abbreviation of "Allah" and Ra is an abbreviation of "ar-Rahman" (the Most Merciful), which means "I am Allah, the Most Merciful."

b. Some believe that these letters are the names of the surahs that begin with these letters.

c. Some believe that what is meant by these alphabet letters are the alphabet letters themselves. So what is meant by Alif is "Alif", what is meant by Lam, is "Lam", what is meant by Nun is "Nun", and so on.

d. The alphabet letters are to attract attention. Some mufasir believe that these alphabet letters were brought by Allah at the beginning of some surahs of the Qur'an to attract attention. Starting a conversation with alphabet letters was a method unknown to the Arabs at that time, so this attracted their attention.

e. For a challenge. According to these mufasir, the abbreviated letters are mentioned by Allah at the beginning of some surahs of the Qur'an, the wisdom is to "challenge". The challenge reads something like this: The Qur'an was revealed in Arabic, which is your own language, which is composed of abbreviated letters, such as Alif, Lam Mim Ra, Kaf Ha Ya 'Ain Sad, Qaf, Ta Sin and others. So if you do not believe that the Qur'an comes from Allah and you claim that it comes from Muhammad, that is, made by Muhammad himself, then try to make verses like the verses of the Qur'an. If Muhammad can make it, of course you can also make it."

So there is a "challenger", namely Allah, and there is "the challenged", namely the Arabs, and there is a "challenging tool", namely the Qur'an. Even though they were people who were fluent in Arabic, and also knew the intricacies of Arabic according to their instincts, because among them there were poets, poets and orators, nevertheless they could not answer the challenge of the Qur'an by making verses like the Qur'an. There were also some among them who dared to answer the challenge of the Qur'an, by trying to make sentences like the verses of the Qur'an, but before they were laughed at by the Arabs, they were first laughed at by themselves.
text.2:
This verse explains that the Qur'an is beyond doubt, because it is a revelation from Allah SWT, revealed to the Prophet Muhammad SAW, the last prophet, through the intermediary of Jibril (Gabriel) A.S.:

"And indeed, this (the Qur'an) is a revelation from the Lord of the worlds. The Trustworthy Spirit (Gabriel) has brought it down." (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 192-193).

What is meant by "Al-Kitab" (the Book/revelation) here is the Qur'an. It is called "Al-Kitab" as an indication that the Qur'an must be written down, therefore the Prophet Muhammad SAW ordered the companions to write down the verses of the Qur'an.

The Qur'an is guidance for those who are righteous, so that they will be happy in this world and in the hereafter. The righteous are those who protect and guard themselves from the punishment of Allah by always carrying out His commands and avoiding His prohibitions. Among the signs of the righteous are as mentioned in the following verses:
text.3:
First: Believing in the unseen (ghaib). This includes truly believing in Allah, submitting oneself and surrendering to Him as required by that faith. A sign of a person's faith is carrying out all that is commanded by that faith.

Ghaib is something that cannot be reached by the five senses. Knowledge of the unseen is solely based on the guidance of Allah SWT. Because we have believed in Allah, we also believe in His words and guidance. Included in the unseen are: Allah, the angels, the Day of Judgment, Paradise, Hell, Mahsyar (the gathering place on the Day of Judgment), and so on. The foundation of belief in the unseen is belief in Allah SWT. Belief in Allah is the basis for the formation of a person's character and traits so that he becomes a true human being, in accordance with Allah's intention in creating mankind.

"sibgah Allah." And whose sibgah (religion, way of life) is better than Allah's? And we are worshippers of Him. (al-Baqarah/2: 138)

Faith shapes humans into individual beings and beings who become members of their society, who like to give, help, sacrifice, strive (jihad), and so on:

The believers are only those who believe in Allah and His Messenger, and afterward doubt not, and strive with their wealth and their lives for the cause of Allah. Such are the sincere. (al-hujurat/49: 15)

In seeking the meaning of faith, we should follow the guidance of the Messenger. For that, we need to study the life history of the Prophet Muhammad SAW, contemplate Allah's creation, use our minds, and study the teachings brought by the Prophet Muhammad SAW. Faith can increase and can also decrease. Faith will be damaged if a person's deeds are damaged, and it will increase if the value and number of deeds are also increased.

Second: Performing prayer (salat), which is to perform and fulfill the prayer by perfecting its pillars and conditions, continuously performing it every day in accordance with what Allah has commanded, both outwardly and inwardly. What is meant by "outwardly" is performing the prayer in accordance with the provisions that have been determined by the Sunnah of the Messenger, and what is meant by "inwardly" is performing the prayer with a humble heart, with all submission and obedience to Allah, and feeling the greatness and power of Allah who controls and creates this entire universe as desired by religion.

Iqamah as-salah is performing prayer perfectly; perfecting all the pillars, conditions and other provisions determined by religion. The original meaning of the word salat is "prayer," then it is used as a term for worship known in Islam because prayer contains many prayers.

Third: Spending (infak) part of the sustenance that Allah has bestowed. Sustenance (rezeki) is everything that can be benefited from. "Spending part of the sustenance" is giving part of the sustenance or wealth that Allah has bestowed to people who have been determined by religion.

The meaning of spending wealth in the way of Allah includes spending for the sake of jihad, building schools, hospitals, scientific research efforts, and so on. Also, spending for all public interests with the intention of carrying out Allah's commands is included fi sabilillah (in the path of Allah).

The wealth to be spent is only a part of it, not all of it. In this verse, it is not explained how much is meant by "part," whether it is one-half, one-third, one-quarter, and so on. In the meantime, Allah forbids being stingy and forbids being wasteful:

And do not make your hand [as] chained to your neck or extend it completely and [thereby] become blamed and regretful. (al-Isra'/17: 29)

Allah forbids extravagance or stinginess in spending wealth:

And [they are] those who, when they spend, do so not excessively or sparingly, but are ever, between that, [justly] moderate (al-Furqan/25: 67)

In another verse of Allah, it is explained that what is meant by part of the wealth is as an answer to the question of the companions:

".... They ask you what they should spend. Say, 'What is beyond your needs.'" (al-Baqarah/2: 219)

What is meant by "beyond" is after they have enough to eat and have clothes to wear. So it doesn't have to be rich, but besides what they eat and wear that day, it is included as extra. Allah has explained the ways to spend wealth and the ways to use it. It is further explained by the hadith of the Messenger of Allah SAW:

From the Prophet SAW he said, "The best charity is what is in excess of one's basic needs." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)
text.4:
Fourth: Believing in the books that He has revealed, namely believing in the Al-Qur'an and the books (revelations) of the Torah, Zabur, Injil, and the sahifah-sahifah that were revealed to the prophets before Prophet Muhammad saw. Although belief in books other than the Al-Qur'an is *ijmali* (general), belief in the Al-Qur'an must be *tafsili* (detailed). Believing in these books and *sahifah-sahifah* also means believing in the messengers whom Allah sent to past communities, without making any distinction between one and another of Allah's messengers.

Believing in the books of Allah is one of the characteristics of the God-fearing. Those who believe in the books of Allah and study their contents are the heirs of the prophets, the heirs of the teachings of Allah, both those of the past and those of the present until the end of time. This characteristic will instill in a Muslim the feeling that they are one *ummah*, their religion is one, the religion of Islam. The Lord they worship is Allah, the One, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful to His servants. This characteristic will eliminate exclusivism (the quality of being different) within a Muslim, which includes all forms of arrogance, haughtiness, group fanaticism, regionalism, and excessive nationalism.
text.5:
Fifth: Believing in the existence of the afterlife. "Akhirat" is the opposite of "dunia" (world). Akhirat is the place where humans will be after this world vanishes. "Believing in the existence of the afterlife" means truly believing in a second life after this world ends.

Those who possess the five characteristics above are the people who receive guidance and direction from Allah, and they are the people who will feel the results of their faith and deeds in the afterlife. They will obtain Allah's pleasure, and their dwelling place in the afterlife will be in Paradise, which is full of delights. In it, they will enjoy eternal happiness.
text.6: A disbeliever is someone who does not believe in Allah, as He has commanded. *Kafir*, plural *kuffar*, refers to those who do not believe in Allah, His messengers, His angels, His books, and the Day of Judgment. It is mentioned in the Qur'an that the disbelievers, namely the People of the Book and the polytheists, are those who vehemently deny the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him); they will not believe even if given warnings accompanied by threats. For them, it is all the same, whether they are given stern warnings or not.
text.7:
The reason why the disbelievers do not accept warnings is because their hearts and hearing are closed, even locked shut, unable to receive guidance, and all kinds of advice leave no impression on them. Because their sight is veiled, they cannot see, pay attention to, and understand the verses of the Qur'an that they have heard, nor can they learn from the signs of Allah's greatness that they see in the horizons, on the surface of the earth, and within themselves.

The locking of the hearts and hearing, and the veiling of the sight of the disbelievers is because they always commit forbidden acts. Each forbidden act they commit will add to the tightness and strength of the lock that closes their hearts and hearing. The more they do these acts, the stronger the lock and cover on their hearts and ears become:

"So for their breaking of the covenant and their disbelief in the signs of Allah and their killing of the prophets without right and their saying, "Our hearts are wrapped". Rather, Allah has sealed them because of their disbelief, so they will not believe except for a few." (an-Nisa'/4: 155)

"And We will turn away their hearts and their eyes just as they did not believe in it the first time, and We will leave them in their transgression, wandering blindly." (al-An'am/6: 110)

The process of the cover becoming stronger and the lock on the hearts and hearing of the disbelievers becoming stronger is explained by a hadith:

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Indeed, when a servant commits a sin, a black spot appears in his heart. If he repents, his heart becomes polished. And if he increases in evil deeds, the black spot increases." That is the word of Allah, "No! But that which they have earned has rusted upon their hearts." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi and Ibn Jarir at-Tabari from Abu Hurairah)
text.8:
In this verse, the third group is explained, namely the hypocrites, those who claim to believe, but in reality do not. Their claims are not true. They make such claims to deceive and mock the Muslims.

When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) migrated from Mecca to Medina, many residents of Medina converted to Islam from the tribes of 'Aus and Khazraj, and some Jews. Initially, this group was not yet apparent. But after the Battle of Badr in the second year of the Hijra, which brought victory to the Muslims, this group of hypocrites began to emerge.

Abdullah bin Ubay, a leader in Medina from the Khazraj tribe, the son of a man who had been a leader of the Aus and Khazraj tribes, was made a candidate for king in Medina by his followers. He said to his followers, "The current situation clearly shows victory for Muhammad." Then Abdullah bin Ubay and his followers declared their conversion to Islam, but their hearts remained full of hatred. Their aim was to destroy the Muslims from within, through various efforts and deceptions. Among them were also many Jews.

The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

"The likeness of a hypocrite is like a lamb (confused and hesitant) between two sheep, going back and forth, sometimes following one, sometimes following the other." (Narrated by Muslim from Ibn Umar)

They are not among those who truly believe and feel the greatness of Allah (SWT), nor do they realize that Allah actually knows their actions, both outwardly and inwardly. If they believed with true faith, they would not do things that hurt the heart of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and the Muslims. They perform prayers (salat) and fasting (puasa) only to deceive the general public, while their hearts and souls do not truly appreciate these acts of worship.
text.9: The hypocrites deceive Allah by deceiving His Messenger, Muhammad (peace be upon him). Deceiving Allah, His Messenger, and the believers is done by outwardly showing faith and affection while concealing animosity within. They associate with Muslims to spy on them and then convey information to the enemies of Islam. They spread animosity and slander to weaken the ranks of the Muslims. The efforts of the hypocrites are unsuccessful and futile. Their hearts become increasingly troubled, saddened, and envious, so that correct and honest considerations for judging the truth gradually disappear from them. In reality, they are not deceiving Allah, His Messenger, and the believers, but they are deceiving themselves. Consequently, their actions will befall themselves, only they do not realize it. Awareness is the power of the soul to respond to something hidden, implied from the real or unreal.
text.10:
This verse explains the evils of lying or hypocrisy and its consequences. Resentment, envy, and doubt are among the diseases of the soul. These diseases will worsen when accompanied by real actions. For example, sadness in a person will deepen if accompanied by real actions, such as crying, thrashing about, and so on. Such envious diseases are found in the souls of the hypocrites. Therefore, they are hostile to Allah and His Messenger, deceiving with pretense, and trying to harm the Messenger and his people. Then the disease increases after seeing the victories of the Messenger. Every time the Messenger gains a victory, their disease increases. Especially the disease of hesitation and doubt, causing great mental tension in the hypocrites. Their minds become weaker to respond to the truth of religion and understand it, even their senses are unable to capture objects correctly, as Allah reveals in His word:

"They have hearts with which they do not understand, they have eyes with which they do not see, and they have ears with which they do not hear. They are like cattle – rather, even more astray. Those are the heedless." (al-A'raf/7: 179)

The evidence is clear, the bright light of truth is also clear to them, but they refuse to accept it, even they hold more tightly to their old stance. The bright light becomes darkness in their eyes and becomes a disease in their hearts. Their hearts become more troubled due to the loss of their leadership. Envy and jealousy deepen as they witness the strength of Islam day by day. As a result of their lies, namely claiming to believe in Allah and the Last Day, and their deception against Allah, they will suffer a painful punishment.

In this verse and the following verses, Allah explains some of the characteristics of the hypocrites who commit destructive actions, including helping the disbelievers (enemies of Islam) by revealing the secrets of the Muslims, encouraging the disbelievers to immediately destroy the Muslims, making cooperation agreements with the opponents of Islam, creating conflicts in society, inciting Muslims to abandon the Prophet saw, and so on. Allah says:

"And when he turns away, he strives throughout the land to cause corruption therein and destroy crops and animals. And Allah does not like corruption." (al-Baqarah/2: 205)
text.11: When they are advised to abandon actions that cause corruption on earth, they always make excuses and reasons, saying that they are actually striving to make improvements. They even consider what they are doing as an effort for the good of Muslims and to create peace between Muslims and other groups. They say that their destructive actions are an effort at improvement to deceive the Muslims.
text.12: In this verse, Allah refutes the statement of the hypocrites that they are making improvements, but in reality, they are causing corruption on earth. Actually, they are the corrupters, but they do not realize the damage they have done because Satan makes them see as good what they are always doing.
text.13:
This verse continues the explanation of the characteristics and attitudes of the hypocrites from the previous verse. When invited to believe, to carry out *amar ma'ruf* (enjoining good) and *nahi mungkar* (forbidding evil), the hypocrites refuse, arguing that the believers are weak-minded, when in reality this is not the case.

The hypocrites consider the believers to be foolish and weak-minded, such as towards the *Muhajirin* who left their families and homelands, even becoming hostile towards their own families and slaves like Suhaib, Bilal, and Khabbab. They also considered the *Ansar* foolish because they shared their wealth and possessions with the *Muhajirin*.

Allah emphasizes that they are actually the ones who are weak-minded, because they do not use their intellect to respond to the truth and they are influenced by their position within their community. They do not know faith and its reality, therefore they also do not know whether the believers are foolish or intelligent. Faith will not be perfectly obtained except with certain knowledge. Likewise, worldly and hereafter happiness as the goal of faith cannot be understood except by those who know the reality of faith.
text.14:
Among the characteristics of hypocrites is being two-faced. When they meet Muslims, they declare their Islam, thus obtaining everything that Muslims generally obtain. But when they are among their friends (devils), they explain that what they have done is actually only to deceive and mock the Muslims. Their belief does not change; they remain in their religion.

The word "setan" (devil) comes from the word *syatana*, meaning "far." *Setan* means "the very far one." The hypocrites are called devils because they are very far from Allah's guidance, far from virtue and goodness. Devils can be in the form of humans or jinn, as mentioned in Allah SWT's words:

And thus We have made for every prophet an enemy - devils from mankind and jinn, inspiring to one another decorative speech as delusion. (al-An'am/6: 112)
text.15:
This verse affirms the punishment for hypocrites as a consequence of their actions mentioned in the previous verse. Allah repays their mockery by inflicting humiliation upon them, and Allah allows them to continue wallowing in error, and they will be punished on the Day of Judgment.

In another verse, Allah says:

"And We turn away their hearts and their eyes, just as they did not believe in it the first time, and We leave them wandering blindly in their transgression." (al-An'am/6: 110)

The hypocrites cannot escape the circle of error that confines them. Arrogance, selfishness, and other diseases that dwell in their hearts prevent them from seeing the reality before them, namely that Islam and its followers are growing stronger in the city of Medina.

Their failure to hinder the progress of Islam exacerbates the disease in their hearts, so that they are no longer able to find and accept the truth brought by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Therefore, they are constantly in confusion, doubt, and stubbornness, and find no way out of that circle of error. Allah Almighty says:

"...Indeed, it is not eyes that are blinded, but blinded are the hearts which are within the breasts." (al-hajj/22: 46)
text.16:
This verse affirms the previous verses about the hypocrites and clarifies their foolishness by presenting the ugliness of their behavior and words.

The hypocrites, with the bad characteristics mentioned in the verses above, are people who have made the wrong choice. They reject the guidance of the straight path and choose the path of error and lust. Ultimately, this choice harms themselves, because they are unwilling to accept the truth.

In this verse, Allah uses the word "bought" to replace the word "exchanged." So, the hypocrites exchange *hidayah* (guidance) for *dhalalah* (error), resulting in them losing guidance and gaining error. The guidance they initially possessed was in the form of human willingness to respond to the truth and achieve perfection. This willingness is like essential capital. This capital is what disappears from their hands, therefore they will not profit and cannot receive guidance again.
text.17:
This verse provides another depiction of the hypocrites, as mentioned in previous verses, through a vivid parable. The hypocrites referred to in this verse are the hypocrites from the People of the Book (the Jews). They had believed in the previous scriptures and messengers, so they should have also believed in the Qur'an and the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), because the coming of the Prophet Muhammad was mentioned in their scriptures. However, because they were influenced by their past greatness, they refused to believe. They are like someone who lights a fire to illuminate the surrounding area, but suddenly the fire goes out, leaving them in complete darkness.

That is because they indeed believed, then disbelieved, so their hearts are sealed, and they cannot understand. (al-Munafiqun/63: 3)
text.18:
This verse explains that the hypocrites are not only like people who have lost bright light, but also like people who have lost some essential senses. Unable to hear, speak, and see. People like this will certainly eventually experience destruction.

They are said to be deaf because they do not listen to advice and guidance, and they do not even understand, even though they hear. They are said to be mute because they do not want to ask about things that are unclear to them, do not ask for explanations and guidance, so they lose the opportunity to benefit from all the lessons and knowledge presented by the Messenger. They are said to be blind because they lose the benefit of observation and the benefit of lessons. They cannot learn from all the events they experience, and the experiences of other nations.

They cannot return to the right path because of the characteristics mentioned above, and they remain frozen in place.
text.19:
This verse provides another parable concerning the affairs of the hypocrites. They are likened to the state of people struck by heavy rain in pitch darkness, filled with frightening thunderous sounds, and occasionally lightning flashes that cause them to cover their ears for fear of perishing.

Similarly, the hypocrites are always in doubt and anxiety when facing the light of Islam. In their opinion, Islam only brings poverty, misery, and suffering. Sometimes their thoughts prevent them from seeing what lies behind the heavy rain (Islam), namely the element that brings life to the earth.
text.20:
This verse is closely related to the previous verse, as if it continues the question, "What is their state with the lightning?" The lightning almost snatches away their sight. How great is the difficulty they face. They walk when there is a flash of lightning, and stop when the light disappears.

Such are the hypocrites, they obtain the light of faith because of their testimony to the truths of the Divine verses and a desire arises to follow the Prophet's call. But because of strong fanaticism, anxiety about the challenges of the masses, that light of faith disappears, and finally, confusion remains frozen in its place.

Allah is capable of removing their hearing and sight so that they cannot understand a lesson and cannot benefit from guidance. However, Allah does not do so, even though He is All-Powerful.
text.21:
These verses command worship and devotion to Allah. This command to worship has been directed by Allah to all of humanity since ancient times through His messengers. Allah says:

And We certainly sent into every nation a messenger, [saying], "Worship Allah and avoid ṭāghūt." (an-Nahl/16: 36)

Every messenger began his da'wah (call) by calling his people to worship Allah alone. For example, Allah swt says:

"....He (Noah) said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a tremendous Day." (al-A'raf/7: 59)

To worship Allah is to devote oneself to Him, with complete humility, purifying obedience only to Him, because one feels that only Allah creates, controls, maintains, and educates all creatures. The worship of a servant as mentioned will be judged by Allah swt according to the intention of the servant who performs it.

In this verse, Allah swt is referred to as "rabb," then followed by the words "…who created you and those before you…" This gives the understanding that Allah created mankind, multiplied them, gave them guidance (taufik), protected and maintained them, and gave them blessings so that with these blessings mankind can carry out their duties as servants of Allah. All these mercies have been given to mankind from the beginning of their existence until the end of their lives in this world. Whoever is grateful for Allah's blessings, He will add to those blessings, but whoever denies Allah's blessings, then he will receive punishment in this world as He has inflicted upon previous nations, and in the Hereafter, a painful punishment will be prepared.

Allah swt says:

And [remember] when your Lord proclaimed, 'If you are grateful, I will surely increase you [in favor]; but if you deny, indeed, My punishment is severe.' (Ibrahim/14: 7)

By worshipping Allah as commanded, man will be spared from Allah's punishment and he will reach a high and perfect degree.
text.22:
Allah SWT explains that He created the earth as a spread and the sky as a roof, sending down rainwater, growing plants, and making those plants bear fruit. All of this was created by Allah for mankind, so that mankind would pay attention to the process of creation, contemplate, study, and cultivate it so that it would benefit mankind and humanity in accordance with what Allah has revealed. Allah clearly explains in this verse, especially in the part that expresses, "And it is He who sends down rain from the sky, and We produce thereby fruits."

Allah clearly mentions that the earth, the sky, and celestial bodies, such as the sun and stars, are creations of Allah that form a unity, and all are regulated by a unified system that in modern science is called an ecosystem. As long as it has not been damaged by the hands of humans who indulge their desires, everything runs smoothly and orderly.

The vast sea, illuminated by the heat of the sun, then causes a lot of water vapor. This water vapor rises up to become clouds and overcast skies, then is spread by the wind across the surface of the earth, so that this large amount of water vapor on the mountains becomes cold and then becomes droplets and becomes rain that can irrigate the vast surface of the earth, not only does rain arise above the sea, but also on land, because of the help of the wind that spreads it.

Because of the rain that falls from the sky, the earth then becomes fertile, various fruits, vegetables, grains, and tubers, etc., grow and provide many benefits for humans and all creatures on earth. In addition, the rainfall also creates rivers, lakes, and wells filled with water and expands the fertility of the earth. Dense forests also help channel water in the earth, help channel fresh air, cool hot air, and maintain the fertility of the earth.

Humans, by utilizing the development of science and technology, can know when there is a lot of rain and when there is little rain or even no rain at all, based on the position of the stars in the sky and the circulation of the wind. It can also be known where fish gather in the sea, which have many types and varieties, and even where birds go in certain seasons can be known.

The following is an explanation from scientists about the sky as a roof: A roof for a building is especially needed so that the residents who live in it are protected from rain and the heat of the sun. In the context of the verse above, the sky as a roof is a metaphor intended for the earth where we live.

At every moment, the earth is showered with space objects, including meteorites. However, until now the earth has not been devastated. This is because the earth is covered by a gas or air called the atmosphere. Before reaching the earth, meteoroids will break apart and be destroyed when entering the atmosphere. Before reaching the atmosphere, the rays emitted by the sun also break up existing meteoroids. It is the radiation of sunlight that can explode meteoroids on their way to earth and then be absorbed by the ozone layer. Thus, the atmosphere and the ozone layer are a protective cover or, in other words, can be called the roof of the earth. The earth could not be inhabited by living things without that roof. Another verse that states the same thing is al-Anbiya'/21: 32, which means:

And We made the sky a protected ceiling, but they are still turning away from its signs (the sun, the moon, the wind, the clouds, and others). (al-Anbiya'/21: 32)

The thickness of the atmosphere reaches 560 kilometers, measured from the surface of the earth. Research on the atmosphere began using natural phenomena that can be seen from the earth, such as the beautiful colors at sunrise and sunset, and the twinkling of stars. In recent years, using sophisticated equipment placed in satellites in outer space, we can understand better about the atmosphere and its function for the earth.

Overall, it can be said that life on earth is supported by three things, namely the existence of the atmosphere, the existence of energy that comes from sunlight, and the presence of the earth's magnetic field.

The atmosphere is known to absorb most of the energy of sunlight, recycle water and some other chemical components, and cooperate with existing electrical and magnetic charges to produce comfortable weather. The atmosphere also protects life on earth from the vacuum of space and low temperatures.

The atmosphere consists of layers of different gases. Four layers can be distinguished based on differences in temperature, differences in chemical composition, movements of chemicals within them, and differences in air density. The four layers are the Troposphere, Stratosphere, Mesosphere, and Thermosphere, or can also be divided into seven as explained in al-Baqarah/2: 29.

The composition of gases in the atmosphere mainly consists of nitrogen (78%), oxygen (21%) and argon (1%). Some components that are very influential on climate and weather are also present, although in very small amounts such as water vapor (0.25%), carbon dioxide (0.036%) and ozone (0.015%).

Regarding wind, clouds and rainwater

The relationship between wind and clouds which then produces rain can be explained by looking at the water cycle. The water cycle takes place starting with the evaporation of sea water which rises up to become clouds and then falls to earth in the form of raindrops, then the water that falls in the form of rain returns to the sea through rivers and groundwater. The Qur'an does not mention the water cycle in detail like that, however, many verses explain some parts of the whole process very accurately. Among them are the two verses below.

Allah is the one who sends the winds, then the winds move the clouds and Allah spreads them in the sky as He wills, and makes them into masses, then you see rain coming out from between them, so when He sends it down to His servants whom He wills, suddenly they rejoice. (ar-Rum/30: 48)

Do you not see that Allah makes the clouds move slowly, then gathers them together, then makes them into a heap, then you see rain coming out from between them, and He sends down hail from the sky, (that is) from (masses of clouds like) mountains, then He strikes with it whom He wills and averts it from whom He wills. The flash of its lightning almost takes away sight. (an-Nur/24: 43)

The two verses above describe the stages of cloud formation that produce rain, which in turn, is one stage in the water cycle. By looking more closely at the two verses above, it is clear that there are two phenomena. The first is the spreading of clouds and the other is the unification of clouds. Two opposite processes occur so that rain clouds can be formed. These two processes mentioned in the Qur'an were only discovered by modern meteorology about 200 years ago.

There are two types of clouds that can produce rain. Both can be classified based on their shape, namely stratus (layered type) and cumulus (stacked type).

In the layered type of cloud, two important stages that occur are the stratus and nimbostratus cloud stages (nimbo means rain). The first verse above (ar-Rum/30: 48), very clearly provides information regarding the formation of layered clouds. This type of cloud will only form in conditions where the wind blows gradually and slowly raises the clouds upwards. Furthermore, the cloud will form like widening layers ("Allah is the one who sends the winds, then the winds move the clouds and Allah spreads them in the sky.....").

If the conditions are right (including if the temperature is low enough and the water content is high enough) then the water droplets will unite and become larger water droplets. We can see this process as the darkening of the clouds. In Quraish Shihab's translation, this part is mentioned as: "......and makes them into masses....". However, in the English translation of the Qur'an, this part is translated as: ".... and makes them dark...". Finally, raindrops will fall from the clouds: ".....then you see rain coming out from between them....".

The second type of cloud that can produce rain is the stacked type of cloud. This cloud is divided based on its shape into several names, namely cumulus, cumulonimbus and stratocumulus. This cloud is characterized by its lumpy and stacked shape. Cumulus and cumulonimbus are lumpy types of clouds, while stratocumulus are not lumpy, slightly thinning and widening. The second verse (an-Nur/24: 43) explains the formation of this type of cloud.

This type of cloud is formed by strong winds that go up and down ("....that Allah moves the clouds..."). In the English translation of the Qur'an, this part of the verse is translated as: "...drives clouds with force...". Pushing clouds strongly. When cloud clumps occur, they unite into giant cloud clumps, stacked on top of each other. At this point, cumulus or cumulonimbus clouds can already produce rainwater.

The next sentence of this verse seems to specifically describe the occurrence of cumulonimbus, a cloud condition known as a storm cloud. The pile of cloud clumps that tower upwards, when viewed from below, resembles the shape of a mountain. By towering high into the sky, the water droplets that have formed will freeze into ice grains (".....then He makes them into a heap, then you see rain coming out from between them, and He (also) sends down hail from the sky, (that is) from (masses of clouds like) mountains...."), Cumulonimbus clouds also produce God's very valuable creation, namely lightning ("...the flash of its lightning almost takes away sight.")

Another verse related to the water cycle that is related to another stage outside of rain is Surah Gafir/23: 18 which means as follows:

And We send down water from the sky in a measured amount, and We cause it to remain in the earth, and indeed, We are able to take it away. (Gafir /23: 18)

This verse clearly states that rainwater is absorbed by the soil but is not lost. This means that groundwater can still be channeled. The two verses below also describe the way water flows, namely surface flow (ar-Ra'd/13: 17) and groundwater flow (az-Zumar/39: 21) which mean:

He sends down rain from the sky, and valleys flow according to their capacity, and the torrent carries a rising foam. And from what they melt in the fire, desiring adornments and tools, is a foam like it. Thus does Allah present the truth and falsehood. As for the foam, it vanishes, [done] away; but that which benefits the people remains on the earth. Thus does Allah present examples. (ar-Ra'd/13: 17)

Do you not see that Allah sends down rain from the sky and makes it flow as springs [and rivers] in the earth; then He produces thereby crops of different colors; then they dry and you see them turning yellow; then He makes them [scattered] debris. Indeed in that is a reminder for those of understanding. (az-Zumar/39: 21)

Many other verses in the Qur'an discuss the water cycle, such as Gafir /40:13; al-Mu'minÅ«n /23: 18; al-Furqan/25: 48; al-'Ankabut/29: 63, and others. All of these verses state things that are related to the various verses referenced above. Some other verses also talk about water, but with different contexts, as can be seen in Surah al-Waqi'ah/56: 68-70 which means:

Have you seen the water that you drink? Is it you who brought it down from the clouds, or is it We who bring it down? If We willed, We could make it bitter, so why are you not grateful? (al-Waqi'ah/56: 68-70)

This verse in the form of a question emphasizes the powerlessness of humans in the oldest dream, namely controlling rain. The facts show that artificial rain cannot be made if clouds with certain conditions are not available. The cloud must have various particles in certain levels, a high water content carried by the wind that rises upwards, and there is a development of cloud piles that lead upwards. If all these characteristics are present in the cloud, then artificial rain can be carried out. However, meteorologists still question the effectiveness of this method.

The next verse relating to the water cycle is the verse that explains about large rivers and oceans.

And it is He who has released [simultaneously] the two seas, one fresh and sweet and one salty and bitter, and He placed between them a barrier and prohibiting partition. (al-Furqan/25: 53)

The description of large rivers, large river estuaries and the sea is reported in the form of the taste of the water by the verse above. At the mouth of the river or estuary, there is a combination of fresh water and salt water. However, the way they mix is very unique. Fresh water that is poured into the sea will remain fresh until far into the middle of the sea, before it truly mixes with salt water. Mixing occurs far from the mouth of the river in the middle of the sea.

One more verse related (indirectly) to rainfall is at-tur/52: 44 which means:

And if they were to see a fragment from the sky falling, they would say, "[It is merely] a cloud mass." (at-tur /52: 44)

This verse was revealed to answer the challenge from some disbelievers for the Prophet Muhammad to drop the sky on their heads. They suspected that the sky was a plate or piece that was the roof of the world. Allah did not answer their challenge here and explained that they would only find clouds. Something that would not be understood by them at that time.

Believers are only ordered by Allah to maintain the conservation of this nature, because many disbelievers and disobedient people misuse knowledge to damage nature. Believers as *khalifatullah fil ardh* are tasked with preserving the environment and utilizing it to achieve the benefits of life so that prosperity and happiness can be enjoyed and gratefully received by every human being. Because Allah gives those blessings, humans are obliged to worship Allah alone.

Allah gives all those blessings so that humans are pious and carry out their duties as a servant of Allah.

These tasks can be understood from Allah's word:

And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me. (adz-dzariyat/51: 56)

Allah SWT tests humans in carrying out the tasks given to them, with His word:

[He] who created death and life to test you [as to] which of you is best in deed - and He is the Exalted in Might, the Forgiving. (al-Mulk/67: 2)

Because humans have known these commands and know about the oneness and power of Allah, Allah gives a warning, "Do not make other gods besides Allah and do not say that Allah is plural."
text.23:
In this verse, Allah SWT states: If you are still in doubt about the truth of the Qur'an and claim that the Qur'an is Muhammad's creation, then try to produce just one surah like (the verses of) the Qur'an. If it is true that Muhammad created it, then surely you would be able to create it as well, because you are certainly capable of doing everything that a human being is capable of doing. Invite also the idols you worship and your leaders to join you in creating it, because you acknowledge their power and greatness.

Then Allah affirms, if you are truthful in your claim, then surely you would be able to create it, but you are liars. The Qur'an is truly revealed from Allah, therefore it is impossible for humans to create it. This verse shows that the Qur'an is the greatest *mukjizat* for Muhammad SAW.
text.24:
This verse affirms that all of Allah's creation will be unable to produce a counterpart to even a single verse of the Qur'an. Therefore, humanity should protect itself from the fire of Hell by following the guidance of the Qur'an. This is affirmed in the word of Allah swt:

Say, "If mankind and jinn gathered in order to produce the like of this Qur'an, they could not produce the like of it, even if they were to each other assistants." (al-Isra'/17: 88)
text.25:
Allah SWT commanded Prophet Muhammad SAW to convey "good tidings" to those who believe. The characteristics of these good tidings are that they can generate genuine joy for those who receive or hear them. "Good tidings" are only intended for those who work and strive to the best of their ability in accordance with the goals outlined by religion. That is why Allah instructed Prophet Muhammad to convey these good tidings to those who believe and do good deeds.

The faith that Allah values is a living faith, that is, faith that is proven through good deeds. Conversely, Allah does not value deeds if they are not based on true faith.

"Amal" (deeds) means realizing an action or work, whether in the form of words, actions, or even a declaration of the heart, but what is usually understood from the word "amal" is the actions of the limbs. Good deeds realize good actions as determined by religion.

In the verse above, Allah SWT mentions the words "believe" and "do good," because "doing good" is the result of "faith." In the verse above, the reward that will be received by those who believe is also mentioned, namely Paradise with all the pleasures contained within it.

"Paradise" in language means a beautiful "garden" with plants of various colors, attracting the hearts of those who look at it. What is meant by "Paradise" here is a place prepared for those who believe in the hereafter.

Paradise belongs to the unseen realm, its true nature is unknown to humans, only Allah knows it. What needs to be believed is that Paradise is a place full of physical and spiritual pleasures that are prepared for those who believe. The form of that pleasure cannot be compared to worldly pleasures.
text.26:
Indeed, Allah is not ashamed to set forth an example, be it a mosquito or something even smaller. Those who believe are certain of the truth and wisdom of Allah, and they will surely accept this explanation. But the disbelievers and hypocrites refuse to understand the purpose of Allah SWT in making parables in the Qur'an. The purpose of a parable is to clarify the meaning of a word or sentence by comparing the content or meaning of the word or sentence with something that is already known and understood.

In biology, animals, plants, and even human organs are widely discussed, and all of this needs to be known by humans; some are beneficial, and some are harmful to humans. It is not only large animals such as elephants, tigers, and lions that need to be known, but also small animals such as flies, mosquitoes, and caterpillars, and their benefits and dangers need to be known.

Mosquitoes, for example, some are dangerous, like *anopheles* which spreads malaria and *aedes aegypti* which spreads dengue fever, but there are mosquitoes that are not dangerous, such as *culex*. *Anopheles* mosquitoes live in dirty water, but *aedes aegypti* mosquitoes live in clean water.

Allah is truly All-Powerful and All-Wise. For every dangerous creature, a predator has been created, which is another type of animal that likes to prey on and kill it. For mosquitoes, for example, there are several predators such as frogs, geckos, and others. We must not kill the predators, and we should know where mosquitoes breed; we need to understand the wisdom and power of Allah.

When humans are invited to pay attention to their own creation, the Qur'an in many verses encourages humans to study nature and see the signs of God in it. The universe, with its elements of living and non-living things, is a sign of creation. All of creation exists only to show the power, knowledge, and art possessed by the "creator," Allah SWT. All of creation shows such signs. Including small animals like mosquitoes, as can be seen in the verse above.

When we try to understand the life of a mosquito, we will know how intricate and complex the system is. In general, we know that this creature sucks the blood of humans and other animals. However, this knowledge is not entirely correct. Because not all individual mosquitoes live by sucking blood. Only female mosquitoes need blood in their diet. The need for blood is not related to the eating habits of this type. The main connection is with reproduction. Female mosquitoes need protein from blood in the final process of egg formation. In other words, female mosquitoes suck blood to ensure the continuation of their species.

The mosquito development process is one of the amazing aspects. This animal changes from larva to mosquito after going through several different phases. Female mosquitoes will lay their eggs on damp leaves or in damp areas around puddles of water. Before doing that, the female mosquito will check the area using an organ located in her abdomen. This organ can detect humidity and temperature. After finding a suitable area, the female mosquito lays her eggs. Eggs, less than 1 millimeter long, are laid in groups or individually. Some types of mosquitoes string together up to 300 eggs in the form of rafts and place them on stagnant water.

The eggs, which are laid very carefully, will change color. The color change occurs only a few hours after being laid. The color becomes black. With this color, the camouflage value of the eggs is quite high and escapes the observation of predators, such as birds or other predatory insects.

After hatching, the baby mosquito immediately swims in the water. The life in the water begins for the mosquito larva. This larva will get bigger. The existing skin can no longer cover its body. They shed this skin or shell and form a new shell. This change of skin or shell occurs two or three times during this period.

In aquatic life, mosquito larvae have organs that are completely different when they become mosquitoes. In aquatic life, they have a kind of hair that grows around the mouth. With the movement of this hair, the larva can direct the microorganisms in the water to its mouth. To breathe, they use a breathing apparatus in the form of a tube located on their back. They take oxygen when they are upside down on the surface of the water. To prevent water from entering the tube, the mosquito larva secretes a sticky liquid that can prevent water from entering. Without the existence of these tools, the larva would not be able to survive in the water.

In the last skin change, the shape of the larva changes drastically, into a completely different form. This period is called the "pupa" period. They are ready to become "real" mosquitoes. The change is so great that it is hard to believe that this is done by one individual and species. The change is so complex that it feels like it cannot be done perfectly by the creature itself.

During this period, two new breathing tubes or pipes will grow on the head to replace the tube on the back. If there are no new tubes on the head, with the change in the shape and position of the creature in the water, then if there is only a tube on the back, it is clear that the mosquito "pupa" will die. This is because of its position, water will enter the tube on its back.

During the "pupa" period, which lasts about three to four days, the mosquito larva living in the cocoon will fast. In this cocoon, the shape of the larva changes into a fully grown mosquito, complete with wings, chest, abdomen, legs, antennae, eyes, and so on. Then the cocoon will break open at the top. This period is a very vulnerable period for mosquitoes. The condition for a mosquito to be able to fly is that it must not get wet. Only the bottom of the legs will touch the water. That is why the cocoon that opens at the top is coated with a sticky liquid that prevents water from entering the cocoon. Half an hour after emerging from the cocoon, the mosquito will make its maiden flight.

When larvae metamorphose into mosquitoes, they are equipped with a sophisticated set of systems to live and continue their offspring. Mosquitoes are equipped with organs that can be used to detect changes in temperature, air, humidity, and also smell. In fact, mosquitoes have the ability to "see through temperature changes" which helps them when looking for prey, even in very dark conditions.

The mosquito's technique in "sucking blood" turns out to be a very complex and intricate set of systems. To slice the skin of its prey, it uses six slicing "knives" that work like saws. As the slicing process takes place, the mosquito sprays a liquid into the wound it makes. This liquid makes the wounded part of the prey's body numb, while preventing the blood from clotting. Thus, the prey will not feel disturbed, and the blood-sucking process runs smoothly.

If only one organ does not work properly, the mosquito will have difficulty obtaining its food and continuing and maintaining its species. With such a body design, even though it is "only" in a small mosquito, this is proof of the work of creation. In the Qur'an, this small mosquito is used as an example to show the power of Allah. Those who believe understand, while those who disbelieve deny it.

According to Ibn 'Abbas, this verse was revealed in connection with the accusation of the Jews that the parables in the Qur'an have no significant value, because in the parable something insignificant is mentioned, even including small and despicable animals, such as *dzubab* which means fly (al-Hajj/22:73) and *ankabut* which means spider (al-'Ankabut/29:41). But if the Jews knew the meaning of the parable, of course they would state that the parables in the Qur'an are accurate and true parables, as in al-'Ankabut/29:41:

The example of those who take protectors other than Allah is like that of the spider who takes a home. And indeed, the weakest of homes is the home of the spider, if they only knew.

In this verse, the polytheists are likened to spiders, their faith in what they worship is likened to a fragile spider's web that they make as a place to take refuge from all dangers. Even though a little wind will damage and destroy the nest.

In making parables for Allah, there is no difference between small and large, despicable and wrathful, all are creatures of Allah's creation. What is important is that the parable achieves its purpose. With the revelation of this verse, it turns out that the accusation of the Jews has no strong reason.

As for the believers, their hearts have been filled with *taufik* and *hidayah* from Allah, and they know that the parables are from Allah, but the disbelievers deny them, even they are astonished to hear the parables, the disbelievers and hypocrites become more arrogant and deny because of them.

Allah misguides the disbelievers and hypocrites by letting them choose the path of error after the path of truth has been explained to them. Because they deny and do not want to understand and think about Allah's guidance, they follow paths that are not pleasing to Him. As a result, they are afflicted with a painful punishment because of their wickedness.

People who do not use their minds and knowledge towards the parables given by Allah SWT, face them with arrogance which causes them to become more misguided. They do not receive guidance and become misguided because of their wickedness. On the other hand, people who have faith in their hearts, use their minds and thoughts, will receive guidance from the parables.
text.27:
The characteristics of the wicked and the disbelievers mentioned in the verse above are:

1.  Breaking the covenant with Allah after it has been affirmed;

2.  Severing what Allah has commanded to be joined;

3.  Causing corruption on earth.

Those who break the covenant of Allah are those who break the covenant of Allah with His creation, that all of His creation will believe only in Him, in the angels, in the messengers, in His books, in the Hereafter, and in the existence of Allah's qada and qadar, following all His commands and stopping all His prohibitions. For this, Allah SWT bestowed upon humans reason, thought, limbs, and so on, so that humans would always remember their covenant. But the wicked do not want to heed it, in accordance with Allah's word:

...They have hearts with which they do not understand, they have eyes with which they do not see, and they have ears with which they do not hear. They are like cattle - rather, they are more astray. Those are the heedless. (al-A'raf/7: 179)

"And they also sever what Allah has commanded to be joined" refers to all kinds of severing of relationships that Allah has commanded to be joined, such as severing ties of kinship among fellow Muslims (an-Nisa'/4: 1), discriminating between the prophets and messengers, namely believing in some and denying others (al-Baqarah/2: 285), and so on. Included in severing what Allah has commanded to be joined is altering, deleting, or adding to the contents of the books of Allah that have been revealed to His messengers, which results in the breaking of the connection between the religion of Allah brought by the messengers.

The wicked cause corruption on earth because they do not believe, they hinder others from believing, they mock the truth, they corrupt the aqidah, they damage or eliminate everything needed to prosper this world for the benefit of mankind, and they damage the environment. They are the losers in this world because of their actions and losers in the Hereafter by incurring the wrath of Allah.
text.28:
Before becoming a living being, humans were inanimate beings originating from the earth. After humans live, Allah continues their lineage by bringing together the sperm of a man and the ovum of a woman in the womb of a woman. After going through several processes, these two cells become a specific form. Then Allah SWT breathes the spirit into it, so it becomes a human being. At the moment a human is born into the world, Allah bestows hearing, sight, heart, and intellect (as-Sajdah/32: 7-11), making them the most perfect creature in form (at-Tin/95: 4), and the most noble in His sight (al-Isra'/17: 70). Allah made this earth for humans to benefit from, so that humans can carry out their duties as servants of Allah, providing sustenance for the continuation of their lives and livelihoods until a determined time (Hud/11: 3). Then the angel of death takes their soul, so they become dead again. In due time, Allah SWT will resurrect them to demand accountability. Those who believe are rewarded with paradise, and those who disbelieve are cast into the blazing fire of hell.

This verse reminds believers of several things:

1.  Allah is All-Powerful to give life and cause death, then resurrect them again after death. To Him alone is the return of all creatures.

2.  So that humans do not become too inclined towards the world. True life is in the Hereafter. Life in this world is a life to prepare for a better life later.

3.  Allah is the One who determines the measure and time limit of the life of creatures, such as when a creature should exist, what its condition is, when its existence ends, and so on.
text.29:
This verse affirms the warning of Allah SWT mentioned in the previous verses, namely that Allah has bestowed great favors upon mankind, creating the heavens and the earth for mankind, to be utilized, so that mankind can maintain their survival and so that mankind can be devoted to Allah their creator, to family and society.

The phrase "Then He directed Himself to the heaven, then He perfected them as seven heavens" gives the understanding that Allah created the earth and everything in it for mankind, Allah created the heavens and then He perfected them as seven heavens. This is affirmed in Allah's word:

Then He directed Himself to the heaven while it was yet smoke, and said to it and to the earth, "Come both of you willingly or unwillingly." They both said, "We come willingly." (Fussilat/41: 11)

So the first heaven that Allah created before creating the earth was still in the form of thick, swirling smoke and its temperature was very hot. Both, namely the heavens and the earth, were called, meaning that Allah established the provisions and work processes so that they would cooperate synergistically and create a harmonious universe.

In verse 29, it is explained that Allah perfected the one heaven, which was still in the form of smoke, into seven heavens. The number seven in Arabic can mean six plus one, or it can also mean a great many, more than just six plus one. If we take the first meaning (six plus one), then it means that Allah made the heaven, which was originally one layer, into seven layers, or Allah made the celestial body, which was originally only one, into seven celestial bodies. Each of these celestial bodies revolves around the sun according to its path on a fixed orbit so that none collide. But the sun only rotates and revolves on its axis because the sun is the center of this solar system. Indeed, Allah is All-Rich and All-Wise in regulating this great and vast universe.

In astronomical understanding, the heavens are the entire universe, in which there are various celestial bodies including the sun, earth, planets, galaxies, superclusters, and so on.

This is stated by Allah in Surah al-Mulk/67: 5, which means:

"And We have certainly beautified the nearest heaven with stars and have made of them what is thrown at the devils and have prepared for them the punishment of the Blaze." (al-Mulk/67: 5)

So, the heaven that contains the stars is indeed called the nearest heaven. That is the heaven that we have known so far. And that is what astronomers have been studying so far, which is estimated to be about 30 billion light-years in diameter. And it contains trillions of celestial bodies on an infinite scale.

However, it turns out that Allah calls the heaven that is so great and awesome only part of the nearest heaven, and perhaps the first heaven. So where are the second to seventh heavens located?

So far, there have been no scientific findings "that are not contrived" regarding the relationship between the number seven and "heaven" which in the world of science is known as the universe. Indeed, there are several scales of celestial bodies, for example in one solar system there is a "sun" (a star that is the center of the solar system concerned) and there are planets and their satellites. Billions of solar systems form a galaxy. Billions of galaxies form the universe. This is only six, to make it seven, it could be added with the dimension of the universe, namely that the entire universe contains a number of universes. So there are seven dimensions in nature, and this may be what is meant by the seven layers of heaven. But the problem is that during the Mi'raj of the Prophet Muhammad SAW, he passed through layer after layer of the heaven serially, from the first layer to the second layer and so on to the seventh layer and finally out of the realm of creatures towards Sidratil-Muntaha. So layer after layer of heaven is like a layered cake that is sequential, from the inside (first layer) to the seventh layer. This reality is different from scientific findings. T. Djamaluddin, an Indonesian astronomer, tends to understand the "seven heavens" as countless celestial bodies and not layered. In Arabic, the number seven is usually used to describe a very large number.

On the other hand, the seven heavens are possibly the seven layers of the atmosphere that are close to the earth, namely: (1) Troposphere, (2) Tropopause, (3) Stratosphere, (4) Stratopause, (5) Mesosphere, (6) Mesopause, and (7) Thermosphere. This division is based on the temperature of each layer of the atmosphere and its distance from the earth's surface. These layers are strong in the sense that they surround and protect our globe firmly because of the earth's gravity. (See also the scientific interpretation of Surah ar-Ra'd/13: 2, Surah an-Naba'/78: 12.) In the interpretation of Surah ar-Ra'd/13: 2, the division of the atmospheric layers is explained slightly differently from what is explained here, where the Ionosphere and Exosphere are united in the Thermosphere. However, if the understanding of the seven heavens in this case is associated with the Mi'raj of the Prophet Muhammad SAW, it seems less appropriate.

The seven heavens can also be interpreted as the Seven Dimensions of Space-Time in the Kaluza-Klein Theory (KKT). In Physics, there are four (4) Fundamental Forces in this universe, namely the Electromagnetic Force, the Weak Nuclear Force, the Strong Nuclear Force, and the Gravitational Force. If these four forces were formed from the Big Bang from a Singularity, then these four forces must have been 'united as a Single Force (Grand Unified Force), this is known in the Grand Unified Theory (GUT). KKT explains that in order to explain the unity of the four forces, the geometry of space-time in which we are now is not sufficient. The geometry of space-time in which we are now is only able to explain a little about Electromagnetic forces and in some cases Gravitational forces. To be able to explain these four forces, KKT states that there must be seven other space-time dimensions. Thus, together with the four dimensions that are already known, namely: line, plane, space and time; then the total dimensions are eleven dimensions (11 dimensions). This statement is based on Mathematical-Physics calculations. Based on this KKT, scientists have also been able to calculate the 'diameter of one of the space-time dimensions, which is 10-32 cm, so the dimension is very small. Thus, it is impossible with the instruments that exist today to penetrate the other seven space-time dimensions. Kaluza-Klein Theory has provided an overview of the Seven Dimensions of Space-Time, all of which will strengthen the geometry of the universe with its four fundamental forces. Could the seven heavens be the seven dimensions of space-time according to Kaluza-Klein Theory? Wallahu a'lam bis-sawab.

At the end of the verse, Allah mentions, "And He is All-Knowing of all things", meaning that this universe is regulated by Allah's laws, whether the object is small or large, visible or invisible. Everything is regulated, controlled and known by Allah.

This verse implies that humans should seek knowledge to think about all kinds of Allah's creations, so that they can increase their faith and purify their obedience to Allah.
text.30:
When Allah SWT informed His angels that He would make Adam AS a *khalifah* (successor, vicegerent) on earth, the angels asked why Adam would be appointed as *khalifah* on earth, when Adam and his descendants would later cause corruption and shed blood on earth. The angels considered themselves more worthy of holding that position, because they were creatures who always glorified, praised, and sanctified Allah SWT.

Allah SWT did not justify their assumption, and He answered that He knew what the angels did not know. Everything that Allah SWT would do was based on His knowledge and His Most High wisdom, even though it could not be known by them, including the appointment of Adam AS as *khalifah* on earth.

What is meant by the *khilafah* (successorship, vicegerency) of Adam AS on earth is his position as *khalifah* on this earth, to carry out His commands, and to prosper the earth and utilize everything in it. This understanding can be strengthened by the word of Allah:

"…O David! Indeed, We have made you a *khalifah* (ruler) on earth…" (Sad/38:26)

As we know, David AS, in addition to being a prophet, was also a king for his people. This verse is evidence of the obligation of Muslims to choose and appoint a supreme leader as a unifying figure among all Muslims who can lead the *ummah* to implement the laws of Allah on this earth.

The scholars have mentioned the conditions that must be possessed by the leader in question, including: being just and knowledgeable, enabling him to act as a judge and *mujtahid*, not having physical defects, having sufficient experience, and not being biased in implementing the laws of Allah.
text.31:
This verse explains that Allah SWT taught Adam A.S. names, tasks, and functions, such as those of a Prophet and Messenger, and his tasks and functions as a leader of the people. Humans are indeed educable creatures, even needing to be educated (educandus), because when a human baby is first born, it cannot do anything; its limbs, brain, and intellect are still weak. But after going through the educational process, a human baby who could not do anything then develops, and through good education, humans can do anything.

Adam, as the first human and with no other human to educate him, was directly educated and taught by Allah. Moreover, Adam was being prepared to be a khalifah, a leader on earth. However, Allah's way of educating and teaching Adam was not like humans teaching each other, but rather by teaching directly and giving him potential that could develop in the form of his thinking power, thus enabling him to know all the names before him.

After He taught Adam those names, Allah showed those objects to the angels and commanded them to mention the names of those objects that had been taught to Adam, but it turned out that they could not mention them. This was to show the limitations of the angels' knowledge and so that they would know Adam's superiority as a human over them, and so that they would know the height of Allah's wisdom in choosing humans as khalifah. This also shows that the position of khalifah, which is to regulate everything and uphold truth and justice on this earth, requires a great deal of knowledge and strong abilities and thinking power.
text.32:
After the angels realized the deficiency of their knowledge, because they could not name the attributes of the creatures before them, they frankly acknowledged their weakness and said to Allah that He is glorified from all attributes of deficiency, which are not befitting for Him, and they declared repentance to Him. They were also certain that everything Allah does is based on His Most High and Most Perfect knowledge and wisdom, including the matter of appointing Adam as a caliph. They knew that their knowledge was only limited to what He had taught them. Thus, their doubts about Allah's wisdom in appointing Adam as a caliph on earth vanished.

From this acknowledgment of the angels, it can be understood that the question they initially asked, "Why did Allah appoint Adam a.s. as a caliph," was not a rejection of Allah's will, but merely a question seeking clarification. After the explanation was given, they acknowledged their weakness, and with humility and full obedience, they complied with Allah's will, especially in the appointment of Adam a.s. as a caliph. They praised Allah swt, because He had given them knowledge according to their capabilities. Furthermore, they acknowledged with full conviction and surrendered to Allah's vast knowledge and His Most High wisdom. Then they affirmed that only Allah is the All-Knowing and All-Wise.

This contains a lesson that humans who have been endowed with more knowledge than that given to the angels and other creatures should always be grateful for this blessing, and not become arrogant and conceited because of the knowledge they possess, as well as their strength and intellect. Because, no matter how advanced human knowledge and technology are in our time, there are still many secrets of Allah's creation that cannot be reached by human knowledge, for example, the essence of the soul that exists within humans themselves. Allah has warned that the knowledge bestowed upon humans is only a small amount compared to Allah's knowledge and His essence.

"…and you have not been given of knowledge except a little." (al-Isra'/17: 85)

As long as humans remain aware of the deficiency of their knowledge, they will certainly not become arrogant and conceited, and they will not hesitate to admit their lack of knowledge about something if they truly do not know it, and they will not be ashamed to learn it from those who know. Conversely, if they have knowledge about something beneficial, then that knowledge will not be hidden, but rather taught and developed to others, so that they too can benefit from it.
text.33:
After the angels turned out to be unaware and unable to name the objects that Allah showed them, Allah commanded Adam a.s. to inform them of those names. Adam carried out the command and informed them of the names.

Then, after Adam a.s. finished informing the angels of the names, and explained the characteristics and advantages of each creature, Allah said to the angels that He had previously told them that He also knew what they expressed with their words and the thoughts they hid in their hearts. He does not create anything in vain, but based on His knowledge and wisdom.

In the matter of Adam a.s.'s appointment as a caliph on earth, there is a high meaning of divine wisdom that the angels did not know. They could not know the secrets of nature, as well as the characteristics of each creature, because the angels are very different in condition from humans. They have no needs, such as clothing, food, and possessions. So, if angels were made inhabitants and rulers of this earth, there would be no rice fields and farms, no factories and mines, no towering buildings. Nor would there be born various kinds of knowledge and technology as humanity has achieved until now, which are almost countless.

With the power of his mind, man can possess knowledge and abilities that continue to develop and can do things that are almost countless. With that power, man can discover new things that did not exist before. He can cultivate barren land into fertile land. With the materials available on this earth, man can make new variations that have never existed before. The mating between a horse and a donkey gives birth to a new type of animal that has never existed before, namely an animal called a "mule". By mating or crossing plants with white flowers with those with red flowers, new types of plants are born, which have red and white flowers. The processing of metals into various kinds of jewelry and tools for daily life and the processing of various kinds of plants into clothing and food for their welfare. In this day and age, millions of kinds of objects can be witnessed as human inventions, both small and large, as a result of the power of his mind.

As for the angels, they do not have desires that will encourage them to work to process these natural objects and utilize them for their life interests. Therefore, if those who have been endowed with such intellectual power and talents and abilities are appointed as caliphs on earth, then this is natural, and also shows the perfection of knowledge and the height of Allah SWT's wisdom in regulating His creatures.

The series of verses above affirms that the task of humans on earth is to be caliphs. When knowing Allah's intention to make a caliph on earth, the angels wondered why Allah wanted to make humans as caliphs, even though they do a lot of damage and shed blood? Allah answered that He knows what the angels do not know.

It turns out that what makes humans worthy of carrying out the task as caliphs on earth is because of the gift that Allah gives to humans in the form of the ability to know the names of all objects and remember them and explain them, while the angels do not have such abilities.

If examined more deeply, the ability to identify and give names is essentially a basic ability that humans need to develop knowledge. Activities of analysis and synthesis to produce knowledge cannot be done without the ability to identify and name. Therefore, the chapter or topic that is the initial discussion of the science of logic and the philosophy of science is about "name", about the essence of the name and the relationship between the name and the concept referred to by it. The ability to give names, both concrete and abstract, is essentially the ability to make concepts which in turn facilitate the ability to see the relationship between various concepts and synthesize various concepts into new concepts. This process occurs continuously and in this way knowledge continues to accumulate and develop.

It is very difficult to imagine the development of knowledge if humans do not have the ability to give names or build concepts.

If the ability to develop knowledge makes humans worthy of carrying out the task of caliph on earth, then it can be understood if Allah SWT gives a high degree to knowledgeable people. Allah says, which means:

¦ Allah will raise those who have believed among you and those who were given knowledge degrees. (al-Mujadalah/58: 11)

Furthermore, see also Surah al-hijr/15: 26, 28 and 33 related to the creation of man, which means:

And We have certainly created man from sounding clay, from mud molded into shape. (al-hijr/15: 26)

And [mention, O Muhammad], when your Lord said to the angels, "Indeed, I am going to create a human being from sounding clay, from mud molded into shape. (al-hijr/15: 28)

He (Iblis) said, "Never would I prostrate to a human whom You created from sounding clay, from mud molded into shape." (al-hijr/15: 33)

The question is why was Adam able to explain the names of those objects, while the Angels were not able to? In several surahs, including Surah al-hijr above, Allah SWT explains that humans are made of earth. Earth contains many atoms or elements of metal (metals) and metalloids (semi-metals) which are very necessary as catalysts in the process of chemical and biochemical reactions to form more complex organic molecules. Examples of elements in the soil include iron (Fe), copper (Cu), cobalt (Co), manganese (Mn), etc. Also, with the presence of elements of carbon (C), hydrogen (H), nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P) and oxygen (O), the metal and metalloid elements above are able to become catalysts in the biochemical reaction process to form more complex molecules such as urea, amino acids or even nucleotides. These molecules are known as organic molecules, supporting a life process. The human brain, which is an important organ for receiving information, then storing it, and retrieving it; is made of the chemical elements above, which are arranged into macro-molecules and brain networks. Another information storage instrument possessed by humans is a chemical compound known as DNA or deoxyribonucleic acid. Both human brain networks and DNA molecules consist of the main elements C, H, O, N and P.

Prof. Carl Sagan from Princeton University, USA in his book The Dragon of Eden gives an overview that humans are indeed superior when compared to other creatures of Allah SWT. One of its advantages is that humans are equipped with an information/memory storage system. There are two types of information storage systems in humans, namely: (1) Brain Network, which stores any information that can be recorded by it. The human brain has the ability to store information as much as 1013 bits or 107 Gbits. The second information storage is (2). DNA-Chromosomal, namely DNA molecules in chromosomes, which store human genetic information. This information will be transferred or passed on to his descendants. Human DNA-chromosomal is able to store memory as much as 2x1010 bits or about 2x104 Gbits. The capacity to store human DNA-chromosomal information is comparable to a book with a thickness of 2,000,000 pages, or equivalent to 4000 volumes of books @ 500 pages. These two sophisticated memory storage devices are made of elements in the soil, *subhanallah*. This is the answer, why Adam was able to capture and understand all that Allah SWT taught, in the form of the names of objects; and express it again correctly; because Adam was equipped with an instrument for storing and re-expressing memory: the Brain network and DNA consisting of those soil elements; while the angels are not. Iblis boasted, because of his ignorance in understanding Allah SWT's creation, by belittling the element of earth.
text.34:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah commanded the angels to prostrate or pay homage to Adam, peace be upon him. The angels obeyed the command, except for Iblis. This means that after Adam, peace be upon him, finished informing the angels of the names of the creatures, Allah commanded them to prostrate or pay homage to Adam, peace be upon him. So the angels prostrated to Adam, peace be upon him. This command was not a prostration of worship to him, but rather a prostration of respect only, and as an acknowledgment of their recognition of the advantages and privileges that he possessed.

In Islam, prostration of worship is only permitted to Allah Almighty alone. In essence, there are two types of prostration to Allah.
