First, the prostration of humans to Allah in worship, namely the prostration in prayer (salat), the prostration of recitation (sujud tilawah), and the prostration of gratitude (sujud syukur) according to the methods that have been determined in the teachings of the Sharia. Second, the prostration of all creatures to Allah, meaning submission and obedience to Him. The original meaning of the word "sujud" is "submission and obedience."

And the herbs and the trees - both prostrate. (ar-Rahman/55:6)

And to Allah prostrates whoever is within the heavens and the earth, willingly or by compulsion... (ar-Ra'd/13:15)

The prostration of the angels to Adam, peace be upon him, was as a sign of respect and a declaration of submission to him, not for worship. Allah Almighty's command to them to prostrate to Adam indicates Adam's superiority over them, so that he was truly more worthy of being made a caliph on earth. Regarding the origin of the creation of Adam, the angels, and Iblis, it is mentioned that Adam, peace be upon him, was created by Allah from clay, and the angels were created from light (nur), while the jinn, Iblis, and the devils were created from fire (nar).

Iblis and the devils always whisper untrue things to humans to tempt them and lead them astray from the straight path. Even Adam and Eve, as the first humans, were tempted to violate Allah Almighty's prohibition.

Iblis is not one of the angels, but rather a creature from the jinn. Iblis was initially among the angels, associating with them and having characteristics like them, even though his origin was different from the origin of the angels. The proof is Allah Almighty's statement at the end of the verse, which explains that when Allah Almighty commanded the angels to prostrate to Adam, peace be upon him, they all obeyed, except for Iblis. So it is clear that Iblis was not from among the angels, because the angels are always obedient and submissive to Allah's commands and never disobey. The literal meaning of "Iblis" is "despairing," "disobedient," "silent," or "regretful."

In another verse, Allah says:

And [mention] when We said to the angels, "Prostrate to Adam," and they prostrated, except for Iblis. He was of the jinn and departed from the command of his Lord... (al-Kahf/18:50)

Iblis, like the jinn and devils, was created by Allah from fire. Iblis considered fire to be more noble than clay. Therefore, he considered himself more noble than Adam, because Adam was created by Allah from clay. That is why Iblis refused to prostrate to Adam.

There is another opinion that says that Iblis is also one of the angels, because Allah's command to the angels to prostrate to Adam, peace be upon him, was addressed to all the angels. Then it was mentioned that all the angels prostrated to Adam, peace be upon him, except for Iblis. It is true that the original nature of the angels is to be obedient and submissive to Allah Almighty. However, it is not impossible that some or one of them may be disobedient, as a characteristic that came later. That is Iblis.

In another verse, it is mentioned that Allah asked Iblis what his reason was for not prostrating to Adam. Allah says:

[Allah] said, "O Iblis, what prevented you from prostrating to that which I created with My hands? Were you arrogant [then], or were you [already] among the exalted?" (sad/38:75)

Allah recounts Iblis's answer:

He said, "I am better than him. You created me from fire and created him from clay." (sad/38:76)

Iblis refused to obey Allah's command to prostrate to Adam, and he was arrogant because he felt that he was more noble and more worthy than Adam to be made a caliph. Because Iblis rejected Allah's command based on his assumption, he is among the creatures who disbelieve in Allah. There is even an opinion that says that Iblis was the first creature to deny Allah's command. There is also an opinion that says that Iblis is the origin of all jinn, just as Adam is the origin of all humans. The jinn have offspring. They were the inhabitants of the earth before Adam was created by Allah, and they had caused corruption on earth. That is why, when Allah informed the angels that He would make Adam a caliph on earth, the angels said, "Will You place upon it one who causes corruption therein and sheds blood...?" So the angels thought that humans would also act like the jinn when they ruled the earth.
text.35:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah commanded Adam a.s. and his wife to dwell in the paradise that had been prepared for them. Regarding the paradise mentioned in this verse, the majority of *mufassir* (Quran commentators) say that the paradise referred to in this verse is the paradise in the heavens that Allah promised as a reward for those who believe and do good deeds. According to other *mufassir*, the paradise mentioned in that verse is a garden, a place where Adam and his wife resided and were given sufficient enjoyment of life.

In this verse, it is explained that Adam a.s. and his wife were permitted to enjoy any food, anywhere in that paradise, safely and freely. However, Allah swt forbade them from approaching and eating the fruit of a certain tree, which was only one tree among the many trees in that paradise. Satan called that tree the tree of eternity, because according to him, if Adam a.s. and his wife ate the fruit of that tree, they would be able to remain forever in paradise. However, the truth was the opposite, namely that if he and his wife ate the fruit of that tree, they would be expelled from paradise, because it would be a violation of Allah swt's prohibition. If they violated that prohibition, they would be among the wrongdoers against themselves, and would receive punishment from Allah swt which would cause them to lose the honor and happiness they had obtained.

In this verse, Allah swt does not explain the true nature of that tree. One cannot determine it without definitive evidence. Moreover, the main purpose of this story has already been achieved without providing information about the true nature of the tree. But it can be said that Allah swt's prohibition to Adam a.s. and his wife from approaching that tree and eating its fruit, was certainly based on a wisdom from Him, namely it was a test from Allah swt for Adam a.s. and his wife.
text.36:
In this verse, it is explained that Satan tempted Adam, peace be upon him, and his wife, so that they were eventually seduced and violated Allah's prohibition against eating the fruit of that tree. In another verse, it is also mentioned how Satan persuaded Adam, peace be upon him, and his wife.

Then Satan whispered (evil thoughts) to him, saying, "O Adam! Shall I show you the tree of eternity and a kingdom that will never perish?" (Taha/20: 120)

In His other words, Satan's persuasion is also mentioned:

"And (Satan) said, "Your Lord has only forbidden you two from approaching this tree, lest you become angels or become immortal (in Paradise)." (al-A'raf/7: 20)

In carrying out the temptation, Satan tried to convince Adam, peace be upon him, that he was truly only giving good advice, and for that, he swore:

"Indeed, I am to you both a sincere advisor." (al-A'raf/7: 21)

Because of the mistake that Adam and his wife had made, Allah SWT removed them from the pleasure and glory they had obtained so far, then Allah SWT ordered them to descend from that Paradise to Earth. Since then, they and Satan have always been in a state of enmity with each other.

Furthermore, Allah explains that they will obtain a place to live and the pleasures of life on Earth until their respective appointed times. Thus, no one will live eternally on Earth. It is clear the falsehood of Satan's whispers to Adam, peace be upon him, and his wife, that by eating the fruit of that tree they would be eternally in Paradise.

In the verse, there is an indication that Adam, peace be upon him, was expelled with his wife from Paradise to Earth not to destroy them, but so that they would work to prosper this Earth, and not to keep them away from the pleasures of life, because they are still blessed with pleasures on Earth; and not to live eternally, because one day they will meet their death and leave this fleeting world.
text.37:
In this verse, it is explained that after Adam a.s. was expelled from Paradise, he received inspiration from Allah swt, teaching him the words to repent. Then Adam repented and sought forgiveness from Allah using those words, which are as follows:

"They said, "Our Lord, we have wronged ourselves, and if You do not forgive us and have mercy upon us, we will surely be among the losers." (al-A'raf/7: 23)

After Adam prayed for forgiveness from Allah by uttering those words, Allah accepted his repentance and bestowed His mercy upon Adam. Indeed, Allah is the Acceptor of Repentance and the Most Merciful. Because Allah always grants forgiveness and mercy to those who repent from their mistakes.

Repentance that is accepted by Allah is repentance that fulfills the following:

1. Regretting and abandoning all the mistakes that have been made.

2. Avoiding and not repeating those kinds of mistakes and actions.

3. Following up the sinful act with good deeds.

In this regard, the Messenger of Allah saw has said:

"Follow up a bad deed with a good deed, and it will erase it." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from Abi Dharr)

In this verse, two kinds of attributes of Allah swt are mentioned simultaneously, namely "Acceptor of Repentance" and "Most Merciful." This is an indication of Allah's guarantee to every person who repents according to the ways mentioned above, that Allah swt will bestow upon him His goodness and forgiveness.
text.38:
In this verse, Allah reiterates His command for Adam and Eve to leave Paradise, a place full of enjoyment and the pleasures of life, and move to Earth, which requires hard work and struggle. Two paths are laid out before them. First, the path that can lead humanity to a happy life in this world and the Hereafter, which is by believing in Allah and following His guidance. Second, the path that will lead humanity to loss and misery in this world and the Hereafter, which is the path of those who disbelieve and disobey Him, and follow the temptations of Satan.

Those who follow the guidance conveyed by Allah through His messengers will obtain happiness and tranquility. They will not feel anxious, because of their firm faith and obedience to Allah's power and mercy. They will not feel sad or regretful over past events that caused loss of property or the loss of family members, etc., because for those who believe and always adhere to Allah's guidance, it is easy for them to face all kinds of calamities and trials that befall them. This is because they believe that patience and submission to Allah are the best way to obtain His pleasure, in addition to the reward and recompense they receive from Allah as a better replacement for what was lost.

Religion forbids some delicious foods from being enjoyed by humans. This prohibition is due to the damage it can cause, both to the individual who does it, and to others and the general public. So, whoever can imagine the dangers that may arise from enjoying the forbidden pleasures, and can also picture in their mind the negative influences and traces that will befall them because of that action, both on themselves and on their community, will surely avoid every forbidden pleasure, like healthy people fleeing from leprosy. Especially those who believe in Allah and the Last Day, they will see that what is forbidden by religion will cause shame and impurity in themselves and will distance them from happiness and glory on the Day of Judgment. People who are clean from sinful deeds in this world will later have radiant faces, while people who are always wallowing in sin will have dark, gloomy faces.
text.39:
In this verse, Allah SWT affirms that those who refuse to follow His guidance, those who disbelieve in His verses, and those who deny those verses with their words, then their recompense is Hell. Disbelief in the verses of Allah SWT is a form of disbelief, whether that disbelief is due to not believing in the truthfulness of the Messenger of Allah, or disbelief caused by arrogance and pride that drives them to deny the Messenger. Regarding these people, Allah SWT says to His Messenger:

"…(do not grieve) for indeed, they do not deny you, but it is the verses of Allah that the wrongdoers reject." (al-An'am/6: 33)

The believers have faith in their hearts and express it with their tongues. There are also those who disbelieve in their hearts, but their tongues utter that they believe. These are the hypocrites. Their words are different from their hearts, and different from their actions.
text.40:
Allah begins this verse by mentioning Bani Israil (the Jews), because they were the first nation to bear the divine scriptures, and because among them were the most vehement enemies of those who believed in Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). If they had embraced Islam, it would have been a strong argument that could be directed towards the Christians and other disbelievers who refused to believe, because the Jewish people were the first to promise Allah that they would believe in every prophet He sent, once clear evidence had been presented.

Israil is a title given to Prophet Yaqub (Jacob). Therefore, his descendants are called Bani Israil. Prophet Yaqub was known as a very pious, patient, and reliant servant of Allah. Thus, Allah calls the descendants of Yaqub at the beginning of this verse by the name "Bani Israil" to remind them to emulate their ancestor in faith, obedience, piety, righteousness, patience, and other commendable qualities. This is because at the time of the revelation of the Qur'an to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), there were signs that the behavior of Bani Israil had gone too far and deviated greatly from the teachings and characteristics of their ancestors, especially their attitude towards the Qur'an which Allah revealed to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). They refused to believe that the Qur'an was a revelation from Allah, and they even denied the prophethood and apostleship of Muhammad (peace be upon him). They should have been the first to believe in Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), because news of his coming had already been mentioned in their holy book, the Torah.

In this verse, there are three kinds of commands from Allah to Bani Israil:

1.  That they should always remember the blessings of Allah that have been bestowed upon them, and be grateful for them with their tongues and actions. The specific forms of these blessings are not explained in this verse. But what is meant, among other things, is that Allah chose His prophets from among them. This happened for a long time, so they were given the title *Sya'bullah al-Mukhtar*, which means "Allah's chosen people." All of this they must remember and be grateful for. One way to be grateful is to believe in every prophet that Allah sends to guide mankind. But in reality, they used these blessings as a reason not to accept the call of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), even mocking him and saying that Allah's blessings and favors were only for them.

2.  Their promise to Allah is of two kinds: first, a promise that applies to all mankind, which is that they must weigh all matters with the scales of reason and thought and investigation that will lead them to know the reality of everything, as a way to know Allah. Second, the promise that they will only worship Allah alone, and will not associate anything with Him; and that they will believe in His messengers. If the Bani Israil of that time had paid attention to these promises, including that Allah would send a prophet from the descendants of their ancestor's brother (who gave rise to a new nation, the Arab nation), they would have believed in Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and they would certainly have followed the guidance that Allah revealed to him. Thus, they would be among those who achieve victory. Conversely, if they fulfilled their promise to Allah, then Allah would allow them to settle in the holy land of Palestine, and they would be given glory and a prosperous life. The reality shows that they did not fulfill their promises, among other things because of fear and worry about each other.

3.  That they should only fear Allah alone. This command was given by Allah, because the reality shows that Bani Israil did not fulfill their promises to Allah, among other things, they did not want to believe in Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). This was because of their fear of each other. So Allah commanded them to only fear Allah alone, and not to fear anyone other than Allah. Because only Allah controls all matters. He is the One who has given them such great blessings, He is also the One who is able to take back those blessings from their hands, and He is also the One who will punish them for not being grateful for those blessings. They should not need to be afraid of each other for fear of losing some of their advantages, or that disaster will befall them for following the truth and opposing the will of their leaders. Allah is more powerful than those leaders.
text.41:
In this verse, there are two types of Allah's commands and two prohibitions addressed to the Children of Israel, namely:

1.  That they believe in the Qur'an which Allah revealed to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), the last Messenger sent by Allah to all of mankind.

Although this obligation is essentially included in Allah's command mentioned in the previous verse, which is that they fulfill their covenant, which includes believing in every messenger and the book he brought, Allah specifically emphasizes this command again, to show that believing in the Qur'an is very important, because the Qur'an confirms what has been stated in their holy book, namely the Torah, and also confirms the holy books that Allah has revealed to the prophets before. The commands brought by the Qur'an include: the command to carry out da'wah, abandon vile deeds, both apparent and hidden, the exhortation to do good, the prohibition of doing evil, and believing in the existence of the hereafter, as the day of recompense. This is the same as what Prophet Musa (Moses) (peace be upon him) proclaimed to them, and also by the prophets before him, namely: to uphold the truth, provide guidance to all creatures, and eradicate the errors that have tainted the true creed.

2.  That they should not hastily deny the Qur'an so that they become the first to deny it, when they should be the first to believe in it, because they already know about it, as it has been foretold in their holy book.

3.  That they should not sell the verses of Allah for a small price. Meaning: that they should not turn away from the guidance of the Qur'an to pursue a small profit, in the form of wealth or position. The expected profits are very small, because in doing so they will not obtain Allah's pleasure, but on the contrary, they will be afflicted by His punishment in this world and in the hereafter.

4.  That they should have taqwa only towards Allah alone, namely by believing in Him and following the truth, and abandoning worldly pleasures if it turns out that worldly pleasures hinder actions and work to achieve happiness in the hereafter.
text.42:
In this verse, there are two types of prohibitions from Allah directed at the Children of Israel (Bani Israil):

1.  That they should not mix truth with falsehood. This means that the leaders of the Bani Israil were fond of inserting personal opinions into the Torah, making it difficult to distinguish what was true. Especially in their rejection of belief in the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), they fabricated reasons to denigrate him and misinterpreted the words of their ancestors, so that they adhered more to the words of their leaders and their traditions than to accepting the teachings brought by the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him). Although the command was directed at the Bani Israil, its content can also be directed at Muslims from all walks of life, especially leaders and those in positions of power, so that this verse seems to say, "O you who hold power, do not mix justice with oppression; O judges, do not mix law with bribery; O officials, do not mix duty with corruption; O scholars, do not mix knowledge with wealth, and so on."

2.  That they should not conceal the truth, while they knew it. This means: The Bani Israil concealed the truth that they knew from their holy book. Among other things, it was the news from Allah about the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) who would be sent as the seal of all the messengers of Allah for all mankind. They deliberately concealed this from the general public, and even tried to denigrate the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) to prevent people from believing in him. This verse condemns their actions, and anyone who deliberately conceals something that is true. After Allah conveyed the call to them to believe in the Qur'an, then in the following verse Allah commanded them to always carry out what has been determined by the Sharia, especially performing prayer (salat), paying zakat, and submitting and obeying the commands of Allah.
text.43:
In this verse, there are three types of commands from Allah directed to the Children of Israel, namely:

1.  That they perform prayer (salat) at every time in the best possible way, fulfilling all its conditions and pillars, and guarding its appointed times, directing their whole hearts to Allah with sincerity and humility, in accordance with the law brought by Prophet Musa (peace be upon him).

2.  That they pay zakat, because zakat is one expression of gratitude to Allah for the blessings He has bestowed, and fosters close relationships between people, and purifies the heart, because zakat is a sacrifice of wealth to help the poor and needy, and through zakat, cooperation and mutual assistance can be carried out in society, where the poor need help from the rich and vice versa, the rich need the help of the poor. In this regard, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

    "The believer to another believer is like a building whose different parts enforce each other." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

3.  That they bow (ruku') with those who bow (ruku'). The meaning is that they should embrace Islam and perform congregational prayer (salat) like the Muslims. In this regard, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

    "Prayer in congregation is twenty-seven degrees more excellent than prayer alone." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

We already know that prayer (salat) according to Islam consists of various physical movements, such as bowing (ruku'), prostrating (sujud), rising from bowing (i'tidal), and so on. But at the end of this verse, the prayer is only expressed with the words "bow (ruku')". This is intended to emphasize that they should perform prayer correctly as required by Islamic law as taught by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), not prayer according to their old ways, which was prayer without bowing (ruku').
text.44:
According to Ibn 'Abbas, the background of this verse is that some Jews in Medina advised their family and close relatives who had converted to Islam to remain steadfast in the Islamic faith. What these people commanded was correct, namely telling others to do good, but they themselves did not practice it. So in this verse, Allah criticizes their bad behavior and actions that lead to error. Among the errors committed by the Jewish people was that they claimed to believe in their holy book, the Torah, but they did not read it properly.

In this verse, it is mentioned that they "forget" themselves. This means they "allow" themselves to suffer loss, because usually humans never forget themselves in order to gain profit, and they are unwilling for others to precede them in attaining happiness. The expression "forgetting" shows how they neglect and do not care about what they should do, as if Allah is saying, "If you truly believe in Allah that He will give rewards for good deeds, and threatens to punish those who abandon good deeds, why do you forget your own interests?"

It is quite clear that the structure of this sentence contains unparalleled reproach, because whoever commands others to do good but does not do it himself, means he has contradicted his own words. The priests who always read the holy book to other people, of course know the contents of the book better than the people they tell to follow it. There is a great difference between a person who does something even though he does not really know the benefits of that action, and a person who abandons that action even though he knows the benefits of the action he abandons. Therefore, Allah considers them as if they have no sense, because a person of reason, however weak, will certainly practice his knowledge.

This word of Allah, although addressed to the Children of Israel, also serves as a lesson for others. Every nation, both individually and as a whole, should pay attention to their own condition, and strive to distance themselves from the conditions and characteristics found in the Jewish people who are criticized in the verse above, so as not to encounter the same consequences as they experienced.
text.45:
After explaining how terrible the state and characteristics of the Children of Israel were, so that their intellect was of no benefit to themselves and the holy book in their hands brought them no advantage whatsoever, Allah guided them to the best path, which is to seek help from Allah with patience and prayer.

What is meant by "patience" here is the following attitude and behavior:

1. Steadfastly facing the reality that occurs, not panicking, but still able to control emotions.

2. Calmly accepting reality and thinking about why it happened, what caused it, and how to overcome it in the best possible way.

3. Calmly and thoughtfully, and with *tawakal* (reliance on God), making improvements by avoiding the causes of failure and anticipating more accurately based on experience.

Being patient means following Allah's commands and staying away from His prohibitions, by restraining desires and lusts from all forbidden actions. Performing *salat* (prayer) can prevent us from bad deeds, and with *salat* we always remember Allah, so that it will prevent us from evil deeds, whether known to others or not. *Salat* is a very important act of worship in which we can confide in Allah five times every day.

"The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, when faced with a difficult problem, he would pray." (Narrated by Ahmad).

Performing *salat* feels heavy and difficult, except for those who are *khusyuk* (humble and attentive to God), namely those who truly believe and are obedient to Allah, and perform His commands sincerely, hoping for His pleasure alone, and protecting themselves from His punishment. For those who are *khusyuk*, performing *salat* does not feel heavy, because at those times they are diligent and immersed in confiding in Allah so that they no longer feel or remember anything else, whether it is the difficulties or suffering they experienced before. Regarding this, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

"And my heart's tranquility was made in *salat*." (Narrated by Ahmad and an-Nasa'i)

This is because his diligence in performing *salat* is something very pleasing to him, while worldly affairs are considered tiring.

In addition, they are full of hope, waiting for rewards from Allah for this worship, so that various difficulties in carrying it out can be overcome easily. This is not surprising, because a person who knows the essence of what he is looking for will certainly find it easy to sacrifice anything to obtain it. A person who is sure that Allah will give a greater replacement than what he has given will certainly feel light to give to others whatever he has.
text.46: Those who are truly humble are absolutely certain that they will return to Allah and meet Him on the Day of Judgment, where all of humanity's deeds will be examined, and each person will receive recompense for all the actions they have done during their life in this world. Based on such conviction, they will always be obedient to Allah's rules and regulations, and humble in performing worship and good deeds.
text.47:
Allah has favored the Children of Israel over other nations who at that time possessed high civilizations and cultures, such as the Egyptians and the inhabitants of the holy land of Palestine. Allah calls them again at the beginning of this verse by mentioning the name of their ancestor "Israel," who is Prophet Jacob (peace be upon him), because he is the origin of their nationality and the source of their glory. The blessings bestowed upon him can be enjoyed by all of them.

The advantages that Allah had bestowed upon them in the past were because their ancestors adhered firmly to noble qualities and avoided bad traits and deeds, because anyone who is noble and favored over others certainly wants to maintain that honor, so he avoids despicable traits and deeds.

The Children of Israel who existed at the time of the revelation of this verse had deviated far from the noble qualities held firmly by their ancestors. Therefore, Allah reminds them of the blessings and favors that have been given to awaken them to the fact that Allah, who has given them advantages, certainly has the right at some point to give them to others, for example, to Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his ummah. The Children of Israel should pay more attention to the verses revealed to Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Someone who is given an advantage should be the first to do good deeds than others.

If the advantage given to the Children of Israel was due to the large number of prophets chosen from among them, then this does not guarantee that every individual from the Children of Israel is superior to people outside their circle. It is even possible that others are more noble than them if they themselves have abandoned the sunnah and teachings of their prophets, while others make it their guidance and way of life in the best possible way.

If their advantage was due to their closeness to Allah, even to the point that they once considered themselves *sha'bullah al-mukhtar* (the chosen people of Allah), because they used to follow His sharia, then this only applies to the prophets themselves along with those who practice His sharia without deviating from those teachings, and remain on the right path, so they deserve to receive that advantage and favor. But those who have abandoned the teachings of the prophets can no longer be regarded as "those who are close" to Allah.
text.48:
Allah warns the Children of Israel who were present at the time this verse was revealed, to return to the right path, to follow the religion of Allah, which has been perfected with the revelations sent down to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). By this path, they can protect themselves from the torment of the Day of Judgment, which cannot be averted by anyone. No one can save themselves from it except those who believe, are pious, and follow the sharia and guidance of Allah.

Allah SWT explains that on the Day of Judgment, no one can provide assistance to another to be freed from His punishment, and each person is responsible for their own actions. One cannot bear the sins of another, even if they are willing. This is an affirmation from Allah of the falsehood of their assumption that based on their merits, they will receive intercession (shafa'at). In fact, that assumption is incorrect, because only those who believe will receive intercession from Allah.

Shafa'at is the assistance given by a messenger or certain individuals to alleviate the punishment or burden of someone in the afterlife, with the permission of Allah. In this regard, Allah SWT says:

"And no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another." (al-An'am/6:164)

"And if one heavily laden calls (another) to (bear) his load, not the least bit of it will be carried, even though he be a near relative." (Fatir/35:18)

"That Day a man will flee from his brother, and from his mother and his father, and from his wife and his children. For every man, that Day, will be a matter adequate for him." ('Abasa/80:34-37)

Although this warning is addressed to the Children of Israel, it also applies to Muslims, so that during their lives in the world they strive to prepare themselves as well as possible, so that they will be spared from the punishment of Allah on the Day of Judgment. The way to do this is by following the guidance of Allah and implementing His sharia.
text.49:
Another reminder to the Children of Israel about Allah's other blessings, namely that they were saved from the misery they experienced due to the cruelty of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, when the Children of Israel resided there. The first person from the Children of Israel to enter Egypt was Prophet Yusuf. Then his brothers also came there and lived with him. Subsequently, they multiplied there, so that in a period of +400 years (from the time of Prophet Yusuf to the time of Prophet Musa) their number reached hundreds of thousands. The native inhabitants were increasingly marginalized because the Children of Israel worked diligently and had more intelligent minds. In addition, they were very self-centered, because they still considered themselves *sha'bullah al-mukhtar*. Therefore, they did not want to unite with the native inhabitants, and did not want to cooperate and help them in daily life.

Seeing this situation, the native inhabitants of the country became increasingly worried, because if the number of the Children of Israel increased, they would control the situation and the native inhabitants would be increasingly marginalized. Therefore, they tried to weaken the strength of the Children of Israel. Initially by requiring them to do forced labor. Then it increased with the killing of their male children, and only their female children were allowed to live. Regarding this event, compare with Exodus i.16; Pharaoh's orders to the midwives. The torture and suffering of the Children of Israel is depicted in Exodus i.22, and in several other parts of the Old Testament. Pharaoh ordered every tribe of his people to kill every male of the Children of Israel, even their small children.

The suffering experienced by the Children of Israel was a test for them because they had forgotten His blessings and had committed various sins. Then Allah SWT forgave and accepted their repentance, and bestowed upon them a great blessing, namely being saved from the misery they experienced from the cruelty of Pharaoh. But this mercy was also a test for them, whether they would be grateful for that blessing, or not.

Muslims can take very valuable lessons from the story of the Children of Israel. Allah SWT, initially bestowed various blessings upon the Muslims, so that the *ummah* was united under the banners of Islam and lived in strong brotherhood, and succeeded in building a strong Islamic state. But then divisions occurred among the Muslims, so that Allah SWT brought disaster upon them.

The Abbasid Caliphate in Baghdad was overthrown by the Tartars. Then the Crusades took place for a long time, about 200 years. Meanwhile, Western nations infiltrated Islamic countries, controlling their sources of wealth so that Muslims everywhere became weak.
text.50:
In this verse, another blessing bestowed upon the Children of Israel is mentioned: Allah saved them when they left Egypt under the leadership of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) from the pursuit of Pharaoh and his army.

After Allah appointed Musa as a Messenger, He commanded him to call Pharaoh and his people to believe in Him, demanding that Pharaoh release the Children of Israel who were in that land, and stop the cruelty inflicted upon them. In response, Pharaoh intensified the torture and cruelty against the Children of Israel and ordered his people to increase the forced labor imposed upon them.

Then Allah gave various miracles to Musa (peace be upon him) and his brother, Prophet Harun, including the staff of Prophet Musa that could turn into a snake and swallow the snakes conjured by the magicians whom Pharaoh had deployed to oppose the miracle of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him).

Seeing this reality, the magicians acknowledged their defeat and declared their belief in God. Finally, Pharaoh expelled and pursued them. So they departed, leaving the land under the leadership of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him), while Pharaoh and his army pursued them.

When they reached the edge of the Red Sea, which borders the city of Suez with the Sinai Peninsula, Allah commanded Prophet Musa to strike the sea with his staff. Then Musa (peace be upon him) did so. The sea split, and twelve lanes of highway stretched out, which Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) and his followers, consisting of twelve groups, would pass through, so they safely reached the other side.

Meanwhile, Pharaoh and his entourage continued to pursue them. But when they reached the middle of the sea, the seawater closed again, so they all drowned, swallowed by the seawater. This event was witnessed by the Children of Israel who had safely reached the other side.

The splitting of the sea is one of the various miracles of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) to prove to mankind that Allah is All-Powerful. He is the One who created this universe, and He is the One who established the laws of nature that apply for all time, and He also has the power to change or cancel those laws of nature when He wills.

The law of nature that applies to water is that water, as a liquid, cannot be separated without another object separating it. This is the law that He changed and canceled when the sea split. The seawater parted and stood like upright walls without anything holding it back, so a road stretched out between the walls.

Such is the greatness of the blessings that Allah has bestowed upon the Children of Israel. They were freed from the cruelty of Pharaoh and his people. Then they were also saved when crossing the sea. After that, they witnessed with their own eyes the drowning of their enemies in the middle of the sea, which certainly gladdened their hearts. They should be grateful for these blessings.
text.51:
In this verse, Allah SWT reminds them of another favor after the favors mentioned above, which is that Allah promised Musa (peace be upon him) that He would give him the Torah, and Allah set the time for it to be 40 nights. They considered the appointed time to be too long, so they made a calf statue out of gold and worshipped it. Thus, they had wronged themselves because of the shirk (associating partners with Allah) they committed.

Their attitude was very surprising, because Allah's promise to Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) to reveal the Torah was actually a great favor and virtue for the Children of Israel, but they repaid it with a very vile act, namely disbelief and ignorance.
text.52: Allah is the Most Compassionate and Most Forgiving to His servants. Even though the Children of Israel had committed disbelief and polytheism to such an extent, Allah still granted them forgiveness and pardon, so that they would be grateful to Him. Allah did not immediately inflict punishment upon them, but rather postponed it until the coming of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) and informed them of the way to atone for their sins, so that they would subsequently be grateful for His blessings.
text.53: In this verse, Allah swt reminds them again of another of His blessings, which is the Torah that was revealed to them as evidence to strengthen the prophethood of Prophet Musa a.s. The Book was revealed to them through Prophet Musa a.s. for them to use as guidance. By understanding its contents and practicing the sharia and guidance contained within it, it is hoped that they will return to being good people, and no longer fall into other forms of error, such as worshipping idols, and so on.
text.54:
In this verse, Allah swt commands the Messenger of Allah to convey to the Children of Israel who were alive at that time that Musa a.s., upon returning from his communion with his Lord, found his people worshipping a calf idol. He then said to his people, "O my people, indeed by your taking the calf [for worship] you have wronged yourselves. You have eliminated the reward that you would have received from your Lord. How good it would have been if you had kept the promise you made and followed my law." Therefore, repent to your Creator who created you, and do not commit such foolishness, where you have abandoned your true Lord and taken the calf as your object of worship."

Musa a.s. also commanded them, "Kill yourselves." The meaning is that those who did not commit evil among them should kill those who had sinned, or those who had committed evil should kill each other, or they were ordered to kill themselves as a declaration of repentance to Allah. In the Old Testament, Exodus xxxii.27-28, it is mentioned that 3000 people died as a result of the killing.

Then Musa a.s. told them that repenting and killing themselves as a declaration of repentance was better for them in the sight of Allah than continuing to commit wickedness that would cause them to be afflicted with torment. Only when they were cleansed of that sin would they be worthy of receiving reward and recompense.

Abdullah Yusuf Ali is of the opinion that "kill your selves"; anfusakum in this verse means selves, not persons. This is almost in line with the opinions of al-Qasimi, Muhammad Asad, and others.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains that after they did what Musa commanded, Allah accepted their repentance and forgave their mistakes, because He is the One who provides a way for those who sin to repent, and He accepts their repentance. For He is the Most Merciful to those who want to repent to Him. If it were not so, destruction would have immediately befallen them because of the great sins they committed.
text.55:
In this verse, Allah reminds the Children of Israel of the characteristics and denial of their ancestors towards Prophet Musa (Moses), namely, they once said to Prophet Musa, "We will not believe you until we see Allah plainly." Because of their attitude and behavior, Allah sent down punishment upon them, which was a thunderbolt that struck them.

Prophet Musa chose seventy people to go with him to Mount Sinai to seek forgiveness for their mistake of worshiping the calf. They said to Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) that before they could see Allah with their own eyes, they would not believe, would not affirm the words of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) that the Torah was the Book of Allah. They also would not believe that Musa had heard the words of Allah, and they also would not believe that Allah commanded them to accept His words and practice them. Then came a thunderbolt that struck them, while the others witnessed the event clearly (see also al-A'raf/7:156).

Such was the attitude of the Children of Israel towards Prophet Musa, they were always acting up and rebelling. Then came the punishment of Allah upon them. Various diseases afflicted them. Small animals that spread various diseases had destroyed a large number of them. So it is not surprising that when Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came calling them to the religion of Islam, they were defiant and rejected the call.
text.56:
In this verse, Allah reminds the Children of Israel who lived during the time of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) that after many of them had died due to the aforementioned punishment, their remaining descendants multiplied again, even though they had initially thought their numbers would dwindle. Allah had destined them to flourish again so that they could learn from that bitter experience, and thus be grateful for Allah's blessings.

Allah narrates this to us by addressing the Children of Israel who were present at the time of the arrival of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to show that humanity is essentially one. All the trials that He has sent down, whether in the form of good or misfortune, blessings or hardship, are all lessons for future generations by explaining what happened to previous nations, so that people know that all nations in the world have a responsibility towards one another. A person's happiness is closely related to the happiness of others. Similarly, the suffering they endure. Every individual will be afflicted with suffering as a result of widespread sins in their environment, even if they themselves did not participate in those sins.
text.57:
In this verse, Allah reminds the Children of Israel again of another of His favors bestowed upon their ancestors, namely that Allah shaded them with clouds from the scorching heat of the sun that afflicted them. This happened when they left Egypt and crossed the Red Sea. They arrived in the desert and were struck by intense heat. Then they complained to Prophet Musa. As soon as he prayed to Allah, asking for help for them, Allah sent clouds to shade them, so that they could walk to the land they were heading to. In addition, Allah also bestowed food upon them, namely food called *mann* which was sweet like honey, which came down continuously from sunrise to sunset, as well as another food called *salwa*, which was a type of quail. Each of them took enough to eat until the next day.

Facing very hot air temperatures in the middle of the desert, a person's energy and strength can easily be drained. Therefore, to replace lost energy, food and drinks that contain a lot of sugar are needed. *Mann* is a type of sweet food or energy drink like honey that is very much needed in desert areas. If someone eats food that contains a lot of sugar, besides increasing energy and giving a pleasant feeling, it also makes people more enthusiastic.

In addition to foods with high sugar content, meat containing protein and fat is also needed. *Salwa* is a type of quail whose meat has a very high protein and fat content. This food is needed by people who are in very hot desert areas. Allah is All-Knowing and All-Wise in providing *Mann* and *Salwa* to the Children of Israel who made a long and difficult journey from Egypt to Syria.

Allah commanded them to eat good food, from the sustenance that He had bestowed. Good food is food that is halal and beneficial for health and body growth. This shows that whatever Allah commands humans to do, the benefits are for themselves, not for Him. Conversely, whatever He forbids humans to avoid, all of that is to save themselves from the disaster that will befall them because of that action.

A natural product chemist from Belgium, Dr. Errera (1893) suspected that manna was a type of lower plant, belonging to 'lichens' from the group of unattached lichens (lichens that are not attached, easily detached). After making observations, Errera suspected that manna was very likely a lichen species known by the scientific name: Aspicilia esculenta. This aspicilia esculenta lichen is easily carried by wind or storms, so it appears as if it was sent down (*anzalnaa*, sent down) from the sky. This lichen has a high nutritional content and also contains antibiotics (*thayyib*, good food). Meanwhile, *salwa* is most likely quail. It can be understood that the Children of Israel were able to survive for a long time (around 40 years) in the Sinai wilderness, because they received grace from Allah SWT, in the form of *mann* food, which is a source of carbohydrates with high nutrition and also contains antibiotics. Meanwhile, the source of protein was obtained from *salwa*. *Wallahu a'lam bis-sawab*.
text.58: At the beginning of this verse, Allah SWT commands the Children of Israel to enter a region (Baitulmakdis) and enjoy the food that is there and to be grateful for His blessings, because they have been saved from the pursuit of enemies in a very difficult journey. They are commanded to say a prayer to Allah, so that they may be forgiven for all the sins they have committed. Allah affirms that if they obey this command, He will forgive all their mistakes, and will give additional rewards and favors to those who do good.
text.59:
This verse explains that the Children of Israel were unwilling to carry out Allah's commands and guidance. On the contrary, they did things that contradicted those commands, as if they did not acknowledge the existence of any of those commands. They claimed that the opposite was what they were commanded to do. This is how the wicked easily distort reality. Those who are disobedient always violate commands, especially when they are assigned tasks that feel burdensome to them.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that because of their denial and disobedience, Allah sent down punishment upon them. The type of punishment that was sent down is not specified in this verse. Allah tested the Children of Israel with various trials every time they committed wickedness and injustice.
text.60:
At the beginning of this verse, Allah swt. recounts how Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) prayed to Allah to obtain drinking water for his followers, who consisted of twelve tribes. Allah granted this prayer, then commanded Prophet Musa to strike his staff against a large rock in the desert. Suddenly, water gushed forth from the rock in twelve springs, so that each tribe of Prophet Musa's people received sufficient drinking water. This event was a miracle for Musa to prove his prophethood and to demonstrate the power of Allah.

Indeed, Allah is able to make water gush forth from a rock without it being struck with a staff first, but Allah wanted to show His servants the relationship between cause and effect. If they want something, they must strive and work to obtain it according to the process of cause and effect. Allah has provided sustenance for every creature that lives on this earth, but that sustenance does not come on its own; rather, it must be sought and the means to obtain it must be pursued. Whoever is lazy in striving will certainly not obtain the necessary sustenance.

In addition, Allah has created humans with limited thoughts and feelings, so that they can only understand what is within the range of their senses, thoughts, and feelings. When they see something that is beyond their ability, they try to relate the problem back to what they already know. If they cannot understand it at all, they become confused, especially if it happens repeatedly before them. Therefore, Allah shows miracles through the prophets according to the condition of the people at the time of the prophet. Allah commanded them to eat and drink from the sustenance that had been bestowed upon them, and they were forbidden to commit injustice.
text.61:
When the Children of Israel were lost in the Sinai desert, they said to Prophet Musa (Moses) that they could not stand just one type of food, when all they had was manna and quails (al-Baqarah/2:57). They said this because of their denial of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) and their pride in their past life.

The Children of Israel then asked Musa (peace be upon him) to pray to God that He would bring forth vegetables grown from the earth as a replacement for manna and quails. They did not want to pray themselves, but expected Musa to pray to God, because they considered Musa to be close to God and also a Prophet who could communicate with Allah. The vegetables and other things they asked for were abundant in the cities, but not found in the desert. Actually, the request was not difficult to fulfill, because they could obtain them if they went to the city. Prophet Musa rejected the request with disappointment and annoyance, and criticized their attitude because they rejected manna and quails, food that actually contained high nutritional value and was very necessary for the body, to be replaced with vegetables that were lower in nutrition.

Then Prophet Musa ordered them to leave the Sinai desert and go to the city. There they would find what they wanted, because the Sinai desert, where they lived until the time determined by Allah, could not grow vegetables. They lived in the Sinai desert because they were weak and not steadfast enough to defeat the inhabitants of the land promised to them. They would be free from what they disliked if they had the courage to fight the people around them, namely the inhabitants of the land promised by Allah, who guaranteed to give them help. Therefore, they should seek a way to gain victory and benefit.

After Allah narrated Musa's rejection of their request and previously laid out all the blessings bestowed upon them, in this verse Allah presents some of the evils of the descendants of the Children of Israel who came later, namely they denied the verses of Allah, killed the prophets, and violated the law of Allah. Therefore, Allah inflicted upon them humiliation and poverty as a manifestation of His wrath.

It was fitting that they receive divine wrath, endure disasters and punishments in this world, and a painful torment in the Hereafter. Likewise, they received humiliation and poverty because they always rejected the verses of Allah that had been given to Prophet Musa in the form of miracles that they had witnessed themselves. Their disobedience and rejection of Prophet Musa was proof that the verses of Allah had no effect on their souls. They continued to deny them.

They killed the prophets from their own group, without any valid reason. Indeed, a person who makes a mistake sometimes believes that what he is doing is right. Their actions were not due to a misunderstanding or misinterpretation of the law, but deliberately violating the laws of Allah that had been prescribed in their religion.

Their disbelief in the verses of Allah and their audacity to kill the prophets was because they often exceeded the limits of their religion. Religion should have a great influence on the human soul, so that its adherents are afraid to violate the commands of Allah. If a person exceeds the rules or limits of his religion, it means that the influence of religion on his soul is weak. The more often he violates the limits of religious law, the weaker the influence of religion on his soul becomes. Until finally, violating the provisions of religion becomes a habit, as if he forgets the existence of religious boundaries and regulations. Eventually, the influence of religion disappears from his heart.
text.62:
In this verse, Allah explains that every community or nation at that time that truly adhered to the teachings of their prophets and performed righteous deeds would receive a reward from Allah, because His mercy and forgiveness are always open to all His servants.

"The believers" in this verse are those who profess faith in Muhammad, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and accept everything he taught as truth from Allah. The Sabi'in are communities before Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) who knew of the existence of the One God and believed in the influence of the stars. The meaning of faith is as explained by the Messenger (peace be upon him) when Jibril (Gabriel) came to him. The Prophet said:

"That you believe in Allah, His angels, His Books, His messengers, the Last Day, and that you believe in good and bad destiny (qadar)." (Narrated by Muslim from 'Umar, may Allah be pleased with him).

The Jews are all those who embrace the Jewish religion. They are called Jews because most of them are descendants of Judah, one of the descendants of Jacob (Israel). The Christians are those who adhere to the Christian religion. The word Christian (Nasrani) is taken from the name of a region, Nazareth (Nasirah) in Palestine, where Prophet Isa (Jesus) was born. Whoever among these three groups lived in their time, before the arrival of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), and truly practiced their religion, sincerely believing in Allah and the Day of Judgment, and practicing all the requirements of their religious law (sharia), they will receive a reward from Allah. After the arrival of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), all of humanity is obligated to believe in him and all the teachings he brought, namely, by embracing Islam.
text.63:
Allah reminds them again of another mistake of the Jewish ancestors when Allah took a covenant from them, namely that they would believe and practice what was in the Torah. It turned out that they did not practice it, even denying it. Then Allah raised the mountain (Mount Sinai) above their heads to show His power so that they would believe in Him and hold fast to the Torah. The content of the covenant was in the form of Allah's command to them, "Hold fast to the Torah with all your strength and continue to work on its contents, study the Torah, pay attention to its contents and practice the laws contained therein."

This verse gives the understanding that those who abandon the Sharia and underestimate the law of Allah are equated with those who deny and oppose it. Then it is fitting that he will be gathered on the Day of Judgment in a state of blindness. He cannot see the path to victory and the path to happiness.

He said, "My Lord, why have you gathered me blind, while I used to be able to see?" He (Allah) said, "Thus did Our verses come to you, and you neglected them; and thus will you be neglected today." (Taha/20: 125 and 126)

If someone denies the Sharia of Allah and wastes His law, it means that the Sharia has no influence whatsoever on his soul. In connection with the understanding of this verse, it can be said that people who only read the Qur'an without practicing its contents do not benefit from the contents of the Qur'an. The meaning of following the holy books is to practice their contents, not just to read and sing them with various melodious songs. Then Allah commanded the Children of Israel to hold fast to the Torah, always study it, and practice its contents so that they would become people who are pious.
text.64: After the Children of Israel took a covenant from Allah as mentioned in the previous verse, they turned away and did not fulfill that covenant. They violated many of the provisions in the Torah, both by their ancestors in ancient times and by those who lived later. For example, during the time they lived in the barren desert, they opposed the Prophet Musa (Moses), harmed him, and resisted all his commands. In later times, they killed the Prophet Yahya (John), denied the Prophet Isa (Jesus), and even planned to kill him. Their denial of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is also evidence of their deviation from the Torah. Therefore, it was only fitting that they receive punishment from Allah, or that Allah remove blessings from them forever. But Allah did not do so, because of His mercy. They were not destroyed, and Allah always opens the door of repentance for those who want to return to the right path.
text.65:
In the provisions of Jewish religious law, on the seventh day, Sabbath (from the Hebrew, shabbath, meaning "rest") people are forbidden to do anything, because that day is specifically for worship. In Arabic, sabt (Saturday), from the word sabata, yasbitu, sabtan, also means "rest" or "quiet." On that day after "the heavens, the earth, and all that is in them were completed" God rested. "Then God blessed the seventh day and made it holy" (Genesis ii. 1-3), which is also used to celebrate the liberation of the Israelites from slavery in Egypt. According to the Old Testament, those who violate the sanctity of the Sabbath, including catching fish on that day, could be sentenced to death: "Anyone who desecrates the Sabbath is to be put to death; those who do any work on that day must be cut off from their people." (Exodus 31:14).

On that highly respected day, fish usually appeared freely, covering the surface of the sea, because no one dared to disturb them on that day. Outside of Saturday, the fish disappeared again (al-A'raf/7:163). Many mufassir mention that this prohibition was circumvented by them; in the days before the Sabbath they made large ponds and seawater was channeled into them. On Sunday they worked to catch the fish that had been trapped. But in God's law they still violated it, so God imposed punishment by turning them into apes, so that they were far from virtue and were humiliated and debased.

According to Mujahid, as narrated by Ibn Jarir, "Their physical bodies were not exchanged for apes, but their hearts, souls, and natures were made like apes, so that they could not receive instruction and could not understand threats." In this verse they are likened to apes and in another verse they are likened to donkeys, according to Allah's word:

The example of those who were entrusted with the Torah and then did not take it up [i.e., fulfill its obligations] is like that of a donkey who carries volumes [of books]. Wretched is the example of the people who deny the signs of Allah. And Allah does not guide the wrongdoing people. (al-Jumu'ah/62:5)

The majority of scholars (jumhur ulama) are of the opinion that they truly transformed into apes as punishment for their denial. In another narration it is mentioned that those who were turned into apes did not reproduce, did not eat, did not drink, and could not live for more than three days. In the Qur'an there is a verse with a similar meaning:

...And among them are those whom He turned into apes and pigs and those who worshipped Taghut. (al-Ma'idah/5:60)
text.66: In this verse, Allah explains the purpose of the punishment inflicted upon the Children of Israel, to serve as a lesson for humanity to prevent actions that transgress the decrees of Allah, both for those who lived at that time and those who live afterwards until the Day of Judgment. This punishment also serves as a good lesson for those who are pious (muttaqin). They constantly learn from all kinds of events and always distance themselves from actions that transgress the limits.
text.67:
When Prophet Musa (Moses) commanded the Children of Israel (Bani Israil) to slaughter a cow, they said to Prophet Musa, "Are you making a mockery of us? We are asking you about a murder case, and then you command us to slaughter a cow. This is very strange and far from what we intended." The Children of Israel should have carried out Prophet Musa's command and welcomed it with obedience and submission, then waited for what would happen after that, but they did the opposite.

Their words were proof that they were very rude in nature and did not acknowledge the power of Allah. Prophet Musa replied, "I seek refuge in Allah from mocking people, because that is the act of the ignorant, especially for a messenger who will convey Allah's message and laws to mankind."
text.68:
The Children of Israel said again to Prophet Musa, "Ask your Lord to explain to us the characteristics of the cow that is meant." Prophet Musa replied, "The cow that must be slaughtered is neither old nor young, but of middle age. Follow the command and carry it out immediately."

They were ordered to immediately obey the command and forbidden from being stubborn. Actually, they could have carried out the slaughter of the cow with the explanation that had already been given. But they were obstinate and continued and increased their questions.
text.69: After asking about the age of the cow, they said, "Explain to us, what is the color of the cow." They were given a sufficiently clear answer that could distinguish the intended cow. Musa said that the color of the cow was a deep yellow, pleasing to those who see it. But they were not satisfied with that answer. They continued to ask and add questions that complicated things for themselves.
text.70: In this verse, they ask again about what they had asked before, "What is the cow, for the cow is still unclear to us." All of that had actually been explained. However, they felt that the explanation given was not yet complete, and it was even still vague to them because the characteristics of the cow were almost similar, making it impossible to find which one to slaughter. With this last question, they hoped to get guidance about the cow that was needed or guidance to the wisdom and secrets of the command to slaughter the cow.
text.71:
The cow that they were ordered to slaughter was a cow that had never been used for plowing or carrying water, was healthy, and had no defects whatsoever. After receiving this explanation, they declared that it was now clear to them. Finally, they found it and then slaughtered it. They almost couldn't bring themselves to do it, because it was so difficult to find the cow they were looking for.

In a hadith it is mentioned, "If they had simply slaughtered any cow when they received the order, it would have been sufficient. But they asked questions that burdened themselves, so Allah burdened them." (Narrated by Ibn Jarir from Ibn 'Abbas)

The request of Prophet Musa (Moses), upon Allah's command to his people (verse 67), was very simple: "Slaughter a cow." That's it, without having to ask many questions. But they were used to being fussy and asking all sorts of questions about the cow – intending to mock – even though the matter was already clear. Because they were stubborn, the result was that they made it difficult for themselves, as depicted in verse 71 and reinforced in the hadith above. Such ways of asking questions then became an expression in Arabic, directed at those who are fussy with contrived questions: *Ma hiya wa ma lawnuha*, (What is it like and what is its color?).

The verses above (67-71) form a unity. The event is closely related to verse 72 below. According to Jewish tradition in the law of Musa (Moses), peace be upon him, if a murder occurred and the perpetrator was unknown, the elders and judges had to go out and measure the distance to the cities surrounding the slain person; they had to take a young heifer that had never been used for plowing; they had to break the heifer's neck in a valley; all the elders from the nearest city had to wash their hands over the young heifer whose neck had been broken in the valley, and they had to declare that their hands had not shed blood and their eyes had not seen it; then atonement was made and they implored Him not to impute the blood to the innocent (Deuteronomy xxi. 1-9).
text.72:
Allah SWT reveals in this verse the crime concerning the murder of someone, after which they accused each other regarding the perpetrator of the murder, causing the matter to become obscure. But Allah did not allow this matter to remain obscure and hidden. To reveal the secret of the murder, Allah commanded them to slaughter a cow, as mentioned in verse 67 previously.

If the order of the story is observed as stated at the beginning of this group of verses, then verse 72 is located before verse 67, because this murder is what resulted in Allah's command to slaughter a cow. However, in the order of the verses, the event of slaughtering the cow is prioritized, because what was commanded was the investigation of the murder case by first searching for the murderer by slaughtering a cow.
text.73:
In this verse, Allah commands that the murdered person be struck with a part of the cow's body so that the person would come back to life. Thus, Allah brings the dead back to life, and becomes a witness to his death so that the murderer is exposed according to the traditions of Israel.

It is narrated that when the Children of Israel struck the murdered person, by the permission of Allah, he stood up. Blood gushed from the veins of his neck as he said, "I was killed by so-and-so and so-and-so." The two murderers were the cousins of the murdered person. Then he died again. So the two murderers were arrested and killed.

Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) ordered them to strike with a part of the cow's body, and it was not Prophet Musa himself who did it. This was done to avoid accusations that he was practicing magic. Allah shows the signs of His power to the Jewish people so that they understand the secrets of religious law (syariat) so that they submit to that law, so that they prevent themselves from following their desires, and so that they obey Allah in all His commands.
text.74:
In this verse, the character of the Jews is revealed. After they were guided to the right path and had understood the truth, their hearts became hard as stone, even harder. Allah likens the hearts of the Jews to stone, which in geological terms is used to refer to all kinds of objects that are species of coral, or coral-like material that is hard, to show the hardness of their hearts to accept Allah's guidance. It may even be harder. Although the stone is hard, at some point and for some reason it can split or crack. From the cracked stone, water gushes out, and then gathers into streams. Sometimes the stones fall from the mountains because they are obedient to Allah's power. Likewise, the hearts of the Jews are harder than stone, as if they do not know the slightest crack. Their hearts are not affected by religious teachings or advice that can usually penetrate human hearts. However, among those hard hearts, there are hearts that are illuminated by faith, so that the heart changes from hard to soft because of fear of Allah.

Such things are often witnessed in everyday life. Hearts that used to rebel against religion eventually become soft, people who used to commit immoral acts become obedient people thanks to Allah's guidance.

And indeed, among the People of the Scripture are those who believe in Allah and in what has been revealed to you and what has been revealed to them, [being] humbly submissive to Allah. They do not exchange the verses of Allah for a small price. Those will have their reward with their Lord. Indeed, Allah is swift in account. (Ali 'Imran/3:199)

Similarly, in another verse, Allah says:

And among the bedouins are some who believe in Allah and the Last Day and consider what they spend as means of drawing nearer to Allah and of [obtaining] invocations of the Messenger. (at-Taubah/9:99)

According to scientists, the word "heart" does not refer to the liver, but generally refers to the heart. The heart is an internal organ, located in the chest and is the size of a fist. The heart is divided into two sides, namely the right side and the left side. Each side is further divided into two chambers, namely the upper chamber (atrium) and the lower chamber (ventricle). The chambers beat 70 times per minute to maintain blood flow throughout the body. If calculated, the heart will beat more than 30 million times in a year. The journey of blood, if measured and starting from the lungs and heart, will flow through blood vessels throughout the body for 96,000 km. This distance is covered in 23 seconds each time around. It shows how important the role of the heart is in human life.

The word heart in Arabic is 'qalb'. This word is also used for other purposes, namely to mean feelings or the inner heart. The inner heart, like the heart, is also very important in life. The Prophet Muhammad saw, after exemplifying many things about good and bad, said about the inner heart in the sense of the center of feeling or the center of sensitivity, as follows:

"..... Indeed, in a person there is a lump of flesh the size of a chew, if it is good, the whole body is good, and if it is damaged, the whole body is damaged. It is the qalb." (Narrated by al-Bukhari through Nu'man bin Basyir)

The heart or qalb is often juxtaposed with "hati" (liver/feeling). Often united and becomes jantung-hati (heart-liver/heart-feeling). There are several verses related to the heart and sensitivity, two of which are Surah al-Isra'/17: and Qaf/50: 37 which mean as follows:

"And We have placed over their hearts coverings, lest they understand it, and in their ears deafness. And when you mention your Lord alone in the Qur'an, they turn back in aversion." (al-Isra'/17: 46)

"Indeed in that is a reminder for whoever has a heart or who listens while he is present [in mind]." (Qaf/50: 37)

In the language of the Qur'an, it is stated that a closed heart will make its owner unable to accept the truth, let alone follow it. He can only follow things that are not in line with the truth, namely lust. The closing of the heart done by Allah is as a result of their own actions. They are reluctant to use their hearing, sight and heart, so that in the end the heart rusts and closes.

Traditionally, people assume that communication between the head/brain (reason) and the heart (feeling) takes place in one direction, namely how the heart reacts to what the brain orders. However, it is now revealed that communication between the heart and brain is very dynamic, continuous, two-way, and each organ influences each other's functions.

A study reveals that the heart communicates to the brain in four ways, namely (1) transmission through nerves, (2) biochemically through hormones and nerve transmitters, (3) biophysically through pressure waves, and (4) energetically through electromagnetic wave interactions. All forms of communication result in activity in the brain. Research reveals that the message conveyed by the heart to the brain will affect behavior.

So far, experts believe that the electromagnetic field of the heart is the strongest field that humans have. This field not only affects every cell in the body, but also covers all directions of space around it. It is suspected that the electromagnetic field is a carrier of very important information. It can even be proven that a person's electromagnetic field can affect the way another person's brain works.
text.75:
In this verse, Allah redirects His word to the believers, urging them not to have excessive hope that the Jews will believe, because their character is not much different from the character of their ancestors.

This is because there were Jewish priests in the past who studied the Torah and understood it, then changed its meaning, even deliberately replacing its verses, especially those concerning the coming of the Prophet Muhammad. They were actually aware that they had committed deviations by distorting the contents of the Torah. The religious teachings that had been distorted were what they taught to their descendants. The Jews in the time of the Messenger of Allah (saw) held firmly to the erroneous teachings of their ancestors. The great desire of the Prophet (saw) and the Muslims was for the Jews to believe and follow the teachings of Islam, because their religion was closest to Islam.
text.76: This verse informs about several characteristics of the Jews whose faith can no longer be hoped for; namely, their characteristics resemble those of the hypocrites and also explain their behavior. This verse clarifies that when the Jews who act hypocritically meet the companions of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), they say, "We also believe as you do, we acknowledge that you are in the truth, and that Muhammad (peace be upon him) is indeed the Messenger of Allah who has been explained in the Torah." They utter these words with the intention of reassuring the hearts of the Aus and Khazraj who were once their allies. But when they are in the midst of their people, they are reproached by their people, saying, "Why do they tell the Muslims what Allah has explained about the coming of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) specifically in the Torah? That news should be kept secret and no one should know, because if that secret is revealed, it means that the believers have a strong reason to defeat their own arguments before Allah." Such actions are considered by them to be reprehensible, not anticipating the bad consequences that will occur.
text.77: This verse serves as a rebuke and a blow to the Jews, especially to the forgers who conceal the characteristics of the Prophet Muhammad and alter their holy scriptures, as if they intend to hide their disbelief and falsehood. But Allah knows everything they manifest (show), which is displaying faith and putting on a sweet face.
text.78:
This verse informs us about the common people, the followers who simply follow the desires of the priests who distort the contents of the Torah. Both the leaders and the followers are in error. Among the Jews, there was a group of *ummi*, people who were illiterate, unable to read and write. They could only memorize the Torah, but they could not understand the meaning and content, and their actions did not reflect what was intended by the contents of the Torah. They were a people who based things only on conjecture, not reaching the level of certainty based on definite and unquestionable evidence.

Indeed, the Jews often denied the truth, even though the truth was clear and evident. They often denied the verses of Allah, and were most often deceived by themselves and liked to consume the wealth of others in unlawful ways, such as *riba* (interest), deception, and bribery. They considered themselves to be the most superior people among the nations of the world.
text.79:
In this verse, it is explained who the people involved in the falsification of holy scriptures are, namely those who mislead by fabricating lies against Allah and consuming the wealth of others unlawfully. People with such characteristics will be doomed, especially their priests who write the Torah according to their own desires, then tell the common people that this is the true Torah. They do so to gain worldly advantages such as rank, position, and possessions.

It is explained that the profit they take is very little compared to the truth they sell, which is actually very valuable and of high worth. Then Allah repeats His threat against the actions of the Jewish priests, that they will be inflicted with a painful punishment.

The Jewish priests who wrote the Torah committed three crimes, namely:

1. Concealing the characteristics of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) mentioned in the Torah.

2. Lying to Allah.

3. Taking the wealth of others unlawfully.

The priests said, "This book is from Allah." Whereas the book is not from Allah at all. The book actually hinders people from paying attention to the Book of Allah and the guidance contained within it. This act is only done by:

1. A person who has indeed left the religion, who deliberately corrupts the religion and misleads his followers. He wears the clothing of religion and presents himself as someone who is making improvements to deceive people so that they accept what he writes and what he says.

2. A person who deliberately interprets and deliberately creates deception to make it easy for people to violate the religion. This person does so to seek wealth and glory.
text.80: This verse mentions another aspect of the Jews' disobedience, namely their belief that they would only be burned by the fire of hell for a few days. The meaning is that they would not remain eternally in hell because they considered themselves to be the sons and beloved of Allah. Most Jews believed that they would be consumed by fire for seven days. Because the age of the world, according to their opinion, is 7000 years, then whoever among them does not attain salvation, victory, and happiness, they will languish in hell for 7 days. One day for every 1000 years.
text.81:
