In this verse, Allah explicitly states that what they say is completely untrue. In fact, the fire will burn them and others for a long time according to their sins. Sin here refers to the sin of associating partners with Allah (shirk). Therefore, those who associate partners with Allah and the disbelievers will abide in Hell forever.

Some scholars are of the opinion that what is meant by sin here is mistakes in general. They argue that what is meant by "forever" here is remaining in Hell for a long time until the time that Allah has willed. Those who commit disobedience and major sins will remain in Hell for a certain period of time, then exit from Hell, whenever Allah wills it. If a person sincerely repents for all kinds of sins and genuinely abandons those sins, then he will not be enveloped by errors and his soul will not be corroded by those errors.
text.82:
This verse promises those who perform righteous deeds a reward in the form of Paradise. Usually, verses of warning are always followed by verses of good tidings (hope). The benefits include the following:

1. To demonstrate Divine justice. If Allah decrees eternal punishment for those who persist in disbelief, then Allah also decrees eternal reward (Paradise) for those who persist in faith.

2. That good tidings (hope) and bad tidings (warning) from Allah instill a balanced sense of hope and fear in the soul of the believer.

3. That Allah, with His good tidings, demonstrates the perfection of His mercy, and with His warnings, Allah demonstrates the perfection of His justice.

All those who affirm Allah and His Messenger, believe in the Last Day, and perform good deeds, fulfill their obligations, and abstain from disobedience, are those who deserve to enter Paradise as a fitting reward for their submission to Allah and their sincerity to Him, both in secret and in public. In this verse, it is clearly proven that entering Paradise is linked to true faith and righteous deeds, as mentioned in the hadith:

"That the Prophet (saw) said to Sufyan bin Abdillah as-Saqafi, when Sufyan asked the Messenger, "O Messenger of Allah, explain to me about Islam, a guidance that I no longer need to ask about it to others." The Prophet replied, "Say, I believe in Allah, then be steadfast." (Narrated by Muslim from Sufyan bin 'Abdillah as-tsaqafi)
text.83:
Allah reminds Prophet Muhammad saw, when He established upon the Children of Israel a promise that they must fulfill, which is that they would not worship anything other than Allah. Allah forbade them from worshipping anything besides Allah, be it humans, idols, or anything else, because that would mean associating partners with Allah with those things. Worshipping other than Allah sometimes takes the form of other actions that glorify the object of worship.

The religion of Allah brought by His messengers all emphasized worshipping Allah the One and not associating partners with Him in any way, as Allah says:

And worship Allah and associate nothing with Him... (an-Nisa'/4:36)

This promise from the Children of Israel began with a promise to fulfill the rights of Allah, the highest and greatest right, which is that only He alone deserves to be worshipped, and nothing should be associated with Him. All creatures are commanded to worship Him, and it is for this task that they were created.

After mentioning the rights of Allah, it is followed by the command to do good to parents, the highest act of kindness. Because it is through both parents that Allah creates humans. Allah says:

...and be good to parents... (an-Nisa'/4:36)

Being good to parents means loving, caring for, and protecting them perfectly, and obeying their wishes as long as they do not violate the commands of Allah. The wisdom of being devoted to parents is because parents have sacrificed for the sake of their children when they were young with full attention and compassion. They educated them and took care of all their needs when they were weak, unable to benefit themselves, and unable to avoid danger. In addition, parents give unparalleled affection. Is it not obligatory for children to reciprocate their parents as a reward for their kindness?

Is there any reward for good other than good? (ar-Rahman/55:60)

The love of parents for their children is due to:

1.  The love and affection that Allah bestows upon them to perfect His blessings for the preservation of the human race.

2.  Gratitude towards their children.

3.  Hope for their children's future to be able to help them with wealth and energy in life.

4.  To continue the mission of their parents.

After Allah mentions the rights of parents, the rights of relatives (family) are also mentioned, which is to do good to them, because doing good to relatives is a factor that strengthens the bonds of kinship among them.

A community consists of families and households. Therefore, the goodness and badness of a community depends on the goodness and badness of families and households. A person who does not build a household means that he does not participate in building an element of the community. Then, each household should connect the bonds of kinship with other households based on lineage, religion, or nationality. In this way, a strong nation and community will be built.

Maintaining close relationships among family members is in accordance with human nature. The religion of Islam, the religion of fitrah, provides a good path for the growth of these kinship ties. Then Allah also mentions the rights of those who need help, namely the rights of the poor.

Doing good to orphans means educating them well and protecting all their rights. The Qur'an and Sunnah strongly encourage paying attention to orphans even if they are rich, because what is considered is their orphanhood. They have lost the person who is their place to turn to. Allah entrusts orphans to society to consider them as their own children, to provide education. If they are neglected, they can cause damage to other children, and the consequences are greater for the nation and state.

Doing ihsan to the poor means providing assistance to them, especially when they are in difficulty. The Prophet said:

The one who helps a widow and a poor person is like one who strives in the path of Allah. (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah).

Allah mentions orphans before the poor because the poor can try to find food themselves, while orphans, because they are still young, are not able to try on their own.

After receiving the command to do good to parents, relatives, orphans, and the poor, then the command to say good words to fellow human beings. When these virtues have been carried out, it means that the height and progress of society have been achieved.

Allah further commanded the Children of Israel to perform prayer (salat) and give charity (zakat) as outlined by Allah for them. Prayer in every religion aims to improve the soul, cleanse it from baseness, and adorn it with various virtues. The spirit of prayer is sincerity to Allah, submission to His greatness and power. If the prayer is empty of that spirit, it will not provide any benefit. The Children of Israel have always neglected the spirit of prayer from the past until the time the Qur'an was revealed and even until now.

Zakat is also commanded to them, because zakat contains benefits for society. The Jews in the past had several kinds of zakat obligations. But the Children of Israel turned away from these commands, did not carry them out, and even avoided them.

Included in their deviations is considering their priests as Gods who determine the laws of halal and haram, adding religious ceremonies according to their wishes, abandoning support for relatives, neglecting zakat, not doing *amar makruf nahi mungkar* (enjoining good and forbidding evil), and other actions that undermine religion.

Only a small number of them in the time of Musa a.s. or in every age were obedient to the commands of Allah. In every age, in every nation or community, there are always groups of people who sincerely strive to preserve the truth according to their beliefs and abilities. However, when evil has spread in that community, the presence of those sincere people does not prevent the descent of Allah's punishment. At the end of this verse, Allah says, "And you (O Children of Israel) always turn away." This verse shows their habit and fondness for disobeying divine guidance and commands, so that evil spread and punishment descended upon them.
text.84:
In this verse, Allah has taken a covenant from the Children of Israel that they should truly abstain from bloodshed amongst themselves, and not expel one another from their respective lands. They should be a unified nation because of one religion and one lineage. Each should feel that their self and their blood are the self and blood of their people.

This verse also contains a prohibition against committing crimes punishable by death (qisas), or expulsion from one's homeland, which means "killing oneself." If one commits a mistake punishable by death, it means killing oneself. At the end of this verse, Allah states that the Jews in the time of the Messenger (saw) acknowledged receiving that covenant, and they even bore witness to that covenant.
text.85:
This verse mentions the reality of the Jews' violation of Allah's prohibitions. In Medina, before the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), there were three Jewish tribes: Bani Qainuqa, Bani Nadir, and Bani Quraizah. These three tribes were involved in the civil wars that occurred between the Aus and Khazraj tribes; both were native inhabitants of Medina. Bani Qainuqa and Bani Nadir were allies of the Khazraj tribe, while Bani Quraizah were allies of the Aus tribe. Thus, wars and expulsions occurred among the Jews themselves.

This verse explains that after receiving a strong promise, they broke it by killing their own brothers, they killed each other as people had done to them, while they claimed that Allah's promise also applied to them.

Some Jews helped the Arabs who had become their allies by committing sins such as murder and warfare, and helped them in hostility such as expulsion from their homelands. Whenever someone was captured, whether Arab or Jewish enemies, they would ask for ransom to release them.

Each Jewish group ransomed their people who were prisoners, even if the prisoners were their enemies. They argued that their holy book commanded them to ransom the prisoners of the holy nation. If they truly believed in their book as they said, why did they expel their brothers from their villages, while the Torah forbade them from doing so? If so, doesn't that mean mocking religion? Why do they believe in part of the Book and disbelieve in another part?

Allah made a promise with the Children of Israel in the Torah, not to kill each other and not to expel each other. In the Torah it is mentioned, "Whoever you find, male or female slave from the Children of Israel, pay the price and free him." However, they still killed each other and still expelled each other. They violated their promise to Allah. When someone was captured, they ransomed him, as obedience to their promise. This shows that they believe in part of the Book and do not believe in another part.

The retribution for those who violate the above provisions is destruction in this world and a painful torment in the Hereafter. Reality has shown that people who cheat against Allah's commands and throw religion behind them will be scattered and will be afflicted with the torment of humiliation as retribution for their moral corruption and evil.

As for those who remain righteous, purify themselves and are in good condition, they will receive blessings from their Lord. Allah is never unaware of what they do. He will reward all human actions.
text.86:
In this verse, it is emphasized that they are the people who prioritize worldly life over the afterlife and accept this worldly life as a substitute for the afterlife. They provide assistance to their allies who worship idols, because they want to gain worldly advantages.

On the Day of Judgment, they will be punished with a severe torment and will not be given any assistance, because their actions have included them in the group of the wretched. Therefore, the doors of divine mercy are closed to them. They will not find a helper who can assist them, nor will they find an advocate who can help them. They will remain eternally in Hell (Jahanam).
text.87:
Allah SWT revealed the Torah to Prophet Musa (Moses), peace be upon him. Then, Allah sent after him several messengers who came one after another. Thus, there was always a messenger at every time conveying the religion of Allah. Therefore, they had no reason to forget it, replace it, or change the regulations that Allah had established.

After that, Allah mentions Prophet Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, specifically in this verse among the messengers, and explains that he was given miracles that could prove the truth of his prophethood. Then Allah also mentions that Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, was given revelation and strengthened with Ruhulkudus (the Holy Spirit - Gabriel), peace be upon him, and high morals.

Then Allah explains the attitude of the Jews, that when a messenger of Allah came bringing regulations that did not conform to their desires, they behaved arrogantly and haughtily towards the messenger by acting arbitrarily and committing atrocities on earth. Then, some of the messengers they denied, such as Prophet Isa (Jesus) and Prophet Muhammad, and some they killed, such as Prophet Zakaria (Zechariah) and Prophet Yahya (John). So it is not surprising that they did not believe in the call of Muhammad SAW, because disobedience and denial are traits that have penetrated their souls.
text.88:
Allah explains that the Jews who lived during the time of Muhammad saw made the statement that their hearts were closed to the da'wah of Muhammad saw. This statement of theirs demonstrates a mental attitude that prevents them from understanding the book brought by the Prophet Muhammad saw. This verse has the same meaning as Allah's saying:

And they say, "Our hearts are veiled from that to which you invite us, and in our ears is deafness, and between us and you is a partition, ¦." (Fussilat/41:5)

As mentioned above, those who said such things were those who lived at the time the verse was revealed and were contemporaries of Muhammad saw. Allah refutes their statement, because the crux of the matter is not as they said. Their hearts were created according to fitrah, and given the talent to respond to everything that could open their hearts, and convey them to the truth, which should have enabled them to assess the truth of the Qur'an. But because of their attitude, Allah left them far from His mercy, because of the disbelief that nested in their hearts towards the prophets of the past and in the books whose teachings they did not practice, even daring to change them according to the desires of their lusts. Then Allah mentions the curse they deserve to receive and the reason for the infliction of that curse, so that they can understand the cause and effect, accompanied by the explanation that Allah never wrongs them. But solely because of their actions of constantly wallowing in disbelief and disobedience, which caused their hearts to be closed by disbelief to receiving the truth.

Then Allah also mentions that they only believe with a scant belief. What is meant by scant belief is their belief in the book, only in part, while they change the other part according to the desires of their lusts, even refusing to practice it. Or in other words, they do not want to practice it in its entirety, but what they believe in is only a verbal statement, not proven in action. Therefore, the faith that is in their hearts is unable to control their will, and their desires have dragged them into the valley of disbelief.
text.89:
Allah SWT explains that after the Qur'an came from Allah, the Jews and Christians denied it, even though the Qur'an provides guidance and confirms the Torah that they possessed, the coming of which they had greatly hoped for to confirm what was in their book. But after the truth they knew came, they refused to believe. The reason was that they felt they would lose influence, power, and wealth. So it is fitting that Allah curses them, as a recompense for the disbelief that dwells in their hearts.

The Qur'an is called a Book that confirms their book because its contents are in accordance with the contents of their Book in the fields of *tauhid* (monotheism) and the principles and objectives of religion. With the coming of the long-awaited book, they actually hoped for victory over the polytheists of Arabia and the disbelievers of Mecca. This can be known from their saying that the long-awaited book would support the *tauhid* brought by Musa (Moses) a.s., to subdue the *wasaniyah* (paganism) embraced by the Arabs.

It is narrated by Ibn Jarir from Qatadah al-Ansari from the elders of the Ansar, they said, "The story mentioned in this verse is about us and the Jews of Medina. We used to practice their religion during the *Jahiliyah* (Age of Ignorance), while we were still polytheists and they were People of the Book. They said that a prophet who would be sent was near his time, and we would follow him. Together with that prophet, we would destroy you as Allah destroyed the people of 'Ad and Iram. But after the Messenger of Allah SAW was sent, we followed him, while the Jews denied him."

From this story, it can be understood that they were actually envious of the Muslims, and that envy arose after Allah sent the Prophet Muhammad SAW, from among the Arabs, not from among them. That is why they fell into the valley of denial and disbelief. So Allah gave His decree that they would be expelled and far from His mercy, because of their denial of the truth, after the truth they had hoped for appeared before them.
text.90:
Allah explains how vile their actions are and likens it to them selling themselves. Their actions consist of denying the book revealed by Allah, which they actually knew, namely the book that confirms the Torah that they possessed. Thus, they allow themselves to fall into disbelief, as if they are destroying themselves.

As a result of their envy, they denied the prophethood of Muhammad and hated it when he received revelation from Allah. They were not pleased that Muhammad (peace be upon him) was appointed as a prophet, because Muhammad (peace be upon him) was a descendant of Ishmael, whereas they had hoped that the awaited prophet would be appointed from the descendants of Isaac.

Then Allah mentions that they will receive multiplied wrath, exceeding the wrath they should have received previously. This is none other than because, in addition to disobeying Prophet Musa (Moses), they also denied the apostleship of Muhammad (peace be upon him).

Then Allah explains the consequence of their disbelief, which is that they will receive a punishment that drags them into the valley of humiliation and disgrace, both in this world and in the hereafter. Their punishment in this world is that they will be in the valley of humiliation and shackled in the chains of disgrace. While their punishment in the hereafter is that they will experience eternal torment in Hell (Jahannam).
text.91:
Allah explains that when Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) and his companions told the Jews in Medina and its surroundings to believe in the Qur'an revealed by Allah, they replied that they believed in the book (revelation) revealed to the prophets of the descendants of Bani Israil, namely the Torah. They always denied the truth of the Qur'an, which confirms the Torah. If they were honest, they would surely admit that the Qur'an is true, without containing the slightest doubt.

After that, Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) to refute the reasons put forward by the Jews with a refutation that rendered them powerless. If their ancestors were truly people who faithfully followed the Book revealed by Allah, they would certainly not have killed the prophets.

Thus, it is clear that they were not followers of Prophet Musa (Moses) who were obedient and faithful, but only followed their desires. Moreover, they also acknowledged the actions of their ancestors as actions that did not contradict religion. Committing denial or allowing someone to commit denial has the same ruling.

Allah mentions the killings committed by the ancestors of the Jews and connects these actions to the Jews who lived during the time of the Prophet in order to show that they are descendants of one nation, and are considered as one entity, because their character and nature are the same.
text.92: Among the most prominent acts of denial by the Jews was their denial of Allah's blessings, namely that Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) was brought by Allah carrying the teachings of Tawhid and miracles such as the splitting of the sea and the divine gifts of "mann" and "salwa." Then the Children of Israel denied the right path and committed disobedience by worshipping the calf made by Samiri. Their actions were unjust, because they did something reprehensible. They should have conveyed to mankind that shirk is the greatest sin.
text.93:
In this verse, Allah gives a warning once again to the Jews, although there is a difference in the structure of the sentences, the content reinforces its meaning, because this verse contains Allah's threat against them. In another verse, Allah says:

"Hold firmly to what We have given you and remember what is in it..." (al-Baqarah/2:63)

His other saying:

"Hold firmly to what We have given you and listen!" (al-Baqarah/2:93)

Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad saw to tell the Jews to accept the covenant and understand its contents, but they did not like to carry out the covenant, even denying it.

Allah's command "say" contains a meaning of mockery towards the Jews who lived during the time of the Prophet Muhammad saw. The mockery was directed at them because they had followed in the footsteps of their ancestors in associating partners with God.

If they still claimed to truly believe in the Torah, then how bad is the faith they profess, because they do not do what is commanded, but instead carry out actions that deviate from the provisions of the Torah, namely worshiping the calf, killing the prophets, and breaking the covenant. Based on concrete evidence from the actions they took, it is difficult to believe that there is faith in the depths of their hearts because their attitudes and actions are not correct at all.

The previous verse and this verse serve as a refutation of the thoughts of the Jews who do not want to believe in the Prophet Muhammad saw, and the assumption that is contrary to their deeds is sufficient proof of their disbelief.
text.94: Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to say to the Jews that if their words and assumptions were true, that Paradise is only for them, then they should ask for death immediately. The reality is that they do not want death, but on the contrary, they pursue and strive continuously to obtain worldly pleasures. Therefore, their words are not true.
text.95:
Allah explains that they will never desire death, because they know the mistakes and sins they have committed themselves, and they also know that they should receive severe punishment for those sins, such as altering and falsifying the Torah, and denying the prophethood of Prophet Muhammad saw, even though the coming of Prophet Muhammad saw is mentioned in the Torah.

Allah knows that they are zalim. Meaning, Allah is All-Knowing that they do not implement the law as it should be implemented, and do not place things in their proper places, such as their assumption that the Hereafter is reserved specifically for them, and not for others.
text.96:
Allah SWT provides an explanation that Prophet Muhammad SAW will encounter people who desire eternal life on earth and strive in any way possible to achieve it. They are actually not certain about their own assumptions and suspicions. Although what is stated in this verse only concerns people who lived during the time the verse was revealed, the provision continues to apply throughout time. Indeed, the Jews are the most greedy of all people, even more so than the polytheists.

Such an attitude receives great reproach and anger from Allah. Because the polytheists do not believe in the Day of Resurrection, the greed of the polytheists for worldly pleasures is not strange. But the Jews who believe in the Al-Kitab (the Book) and acknowledge the Day of Judgment should not be so greedy for this worldly life. They desire to live in the world for a thousand years or more. Therefore, it is fitting that Allah is angry and punishes them. Their long life in this world will not help them and will not keep them away from the torment that is prepared for them in the Hereafter, and moreover, however long that life may be, it will surely end. In other words, longevity will not be able to release them from God's punishment, because Allah is All-Knowing of their deeds, both hidden and those they do openly. All actions that arise from them will surely be given a fitting reward.
text.97:
In this verse, Allah explains the rejection of the reasons put forward by the Jews by instructing Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to convey to the Jews that whoever is an enemy of Gabriel means he is an enemy of Allah's revelation, because his duties include delivering the Qur'an to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Whoever is an enemy of Allah's revelation means he has denied the Torah and other books of Allah.

The reasons put forward by the Jews are reasons that arise from weakness and corruption of faith. This shows that the hostility of the Jews towards Gabriel is not a proper reason for disbelieving in the book revealed by Allah.
text.98:
In this verse, Allah explains that whoever is an enemy of Allah, His angels, and those who distance themselves from Him, means that person has wronged himself. This is because such a person is hostile to those who convey Allah's call, which also means that person has heard Allah's call to the right path but refuses to listen to it. He has committed injustice by not listening to the call as he should, even though the call is very beneficial for himself.

In this verse, there is a severe threat that Allah states openly, namely the provision that the Jews are classified as disbelievers because they are hostile to the truth and also hostile to everyone who calls to that truth.

The Jews should understand that being hostile to the Qur'an means being hostile to all the heavenly books, because the purpose of those books is only one, namely to give guidance to all mankind and guide them to the straight path. Being hostile to the Prophet Muhammad also means being hostile to all the prophets, because the task of the prophets is essentially one, and their goal is also one.
text.99: Allah swt explains that the verses revealed to the Prophet Muhammad saw contain truth, because there is harmony between its *i'tiqadiyah* (related to belief) theories and its proofs, as well as between its *amali* (practical) laws and its aspects of benefit. No other proof is needed to prove the truth of these verses. It is like a light that illuminates everything, which is bright and clear in itself, requiring nothing to help its brightness. Those who have been illuminated by the truth, but prefer to seek darkness, the reason is none other than envy of those who manifest the truth, also because of the arrogant and haughty nature that arises from them.
text.100:
It is fitting that they deny the verses of Allah, because whenever they made a covenant, a large part of them violated it. The covenant referred to in this verse is their covenant with the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, and the covenants they made were not few. In short, the Jews have a character of disloyalty, and indeed, a large part of them like to break promises.

Allah explains in this verse the dishonesty committed by the Jews in denying the verses found in the Torah and their unwillingness to practice its teachings.
text.101: When the Prophet Muhammad (saw) came bringing a book containing explanations that confirmed the Torah that they possessed, which contained the fundamental teachings of monotheism (tauhid), the foundations of law, wisdoms, and news about past communities, the Jews set aside the teachings of the Torah. Even though the coming of the Prophet Muhammad (saw) had also been alluded to in the Torah, they no longer adhered to the teachings of the Torah. The actions of the Jews in setting aside the Torah and denying it meant that they had thrown the Torah behind them, so that they could no longer know it.
text.102:
The Jews followed the magic that was recited by devils during the time of Solomon, son of David, even though they knew that it was actually wrong. They accused Prophet Solomon of compiling a book of magic and storing it under his throne, which was then taken out and disseminated.

Such an allegation is a fabrication and an act influenced by lust. In reality, they were only associating the magic with Prophet Solomon. Prophet Solomon did not teach or practice magic because he knew that such an act is a form of denying God, especially considering his position as a prophet; it is impossible for him to practice magic.

Stories about magic are often narrated in the Qur'an, especially in the story of Moses and Pharaoh. In that story, the characteristics of magic are explained, that magic is a trick that deceives the eyes, so that the person who sees it thinks that what is seen is the actual reality. This is explained in Allah's word:

"…So it appeared to him that their ropes and staffs were moving quickly because of their magic." (Taha/20:66)

And in accordance with Allah's word:

"…They bewitched the eyes of the people and struck terror into them…" (al-A'raf/7:116)

Magic is something hidden, known only to some people. But what has happened shows that the two angels were not able to provide supernatural influence that exceeded human capabilities; even what they called supernatural power was only skill in mastering the causes that have a connection with the resulting effect. This only happens with Allah's permission alone, in accordance with His established law.

In practice, magicians recite spells by mentioning the names of devils and kings of the jinn to create the impression that their spells are granted by the king of the jinn. Based on their practice, a widespread assumption arises in society that magic is aided by devils.

Then the Jews who were contemporaries of Prophet Muhammad saw spread the magic among the Muslims with the aim of misleading them. They found the magic from their ancestors who said that the magic came from Solomon a.s.. In fact, the two angels did not teach magic to anyone before advising them not to practice magic, because those who practice magic are infidels.

Verse 102 is inseparable from verse 101 before it. Some of the People of the Book abandoned their Book (the Torah) and followed the whispers of the devils (syayatin) who taught magic during the time of Prophet Solomon. This verse refutes the accusation of the Jewish group that he obtained his power and wealth through magic (Zamakhsyari 1/230), and also rejects the statement in the Bible that Solomon had sinned by committing shirk. He was accused of having 700 foreign noble wives and 300 concubines. Because most of them were idolaters, Solomon was also influenced by them in his old age, tending to believe in idols and gods "unlike his father David (1 Kings 11:1-10).

Harut and Marut mentioned in this verse are two people in Babylon, around the Euphrates River in Iraq, "who pretended to be pious and devout. They taught magic to the people, so that they were thought to be two angels who came down from the sky, and what they taught was thought to be a revelation from Allah. They were very good at deceiving and maintaining the good faith of the people towards them, so they said to everyone who wanted to learn from them, that "We are only a trial, do not become disbelievers," meaning that they are the testers "who will test you, whether you will be grateful or ungrateful. So we advise you, do not become disbelievers." They said that to give the impression that the knowledge they brought was from God, and their practice was for spiritual purposes. But the goal was only to disrupt harmony. In this case, the Jews have many superstitions. They believe that the magic that was revealed to them was truly from God. The arrival of the two angels was only to teach humans. So the Qur'an came to refute their assumption that it came from heaven, and strongly condemned those who learn and teach it..." (al-Qasimi 1/210).

Quoting al-hasan al-Basri, al-Zamakhsyari (1/230) says that the word malakaini (two angels) is read malikaini (two kings). Muhammad Asad adds that Ibn Abbas and the following tabi'in, such as al-hasan al-Basri, Abu al-Aswad adh-ahhak also read it malikaini. As for the two angels, they are Gabriel and Michael, who taught magic to Solomon, as accused by the Jews. While the two kings are David and Solomon.

Regarding the phrase Wa ma unzila 'ala al-malakaini, the opinions of the commentators are not the same, some say ma nafiyyah ("not revealed") and some argue ma ismiyyah or isim mausul ("what was revealed"), and so on. But this grammatical difference seems less necessary to discuss here.

Referring to the commentaries of Haqqani, Baidhawi and ar-Razi, we try to summarize what is mentioned in the commentary of Abdullah Yusuf Ali, that "The word 'angels' applied to Harut and Marut is a figurative word, which means 'good people, knowledgeable, learned (or wise) and have strength', like the word angel in modern languages is also used for women who are good and beautiful, and for them apply all the qualities of beauty, which also means goodness, knowledge, wisdom and strength."

"Harut and Marut lived in Babylon, the oldest center of science, especially in astronomy. It is estimated that their time was around the time of the Old Kingdom in the East, very strong and advanced. In fact, it may be even older, considering that Marut or Marduk was a hero who was deified and then worshiped as the god of magic in Babylon. Somewhat different from al-Qasimi's opinion above, he mentions that Harut and Marut as good people did not want to plunge into evil, they were clean from all deception. Science and art, if studied by evil people, can also be used for evil. In addition to their heinous magical practices, devils also learn about the true knowledge little by little and will use it for evil purposes. Harut and Marut did not want to hide knowledge, but they had never taught anyone without giving a warning about the dangers and temptations of such knowledge when it is in the hands of evil people. They saw that it was not impossible for those evil people to fall into disbelief and become arrogant because of their knowledge. This knowledge is indeed a trial and temptation; if we have been warned, we will know the danger. (Abdullah Yusuf Ali: C. 107).

Yusuf Ali adds, "Among the many Israelite stories in the Midrash (Jewish Commentary Book) is a story about two angels who asked Allah for permission to descend to this earth, but then they succumbed to temptation, and as punishment they were hung in Babylon with their feet up. Stories about sinful angels who have received such punishment have also been a belief among Christians in the past. (See 2 Peter 2:4, and Jude, verse 6).

What the devils learned from Harut and Marut they changed for evil purposes. Because it is mixed with falsehood and deception, all kinds of amulets, spells and witchcraft are born. But apart from the harm made by the deceivers who want to inflict it on others, the harm or danger they do will befall their own souls. They sell themselves into slavery to evil (Idem).

This verse does not actually show the essence of magic. Whether magic has a natural effect or is caused by something very mysterious, it is also not explained whether magic can give influence to humans in an unusual way, or does not give any influence at all. In short, Allah does not provide detailed information. If Allah considered it good to explain the essence of magic and beneficial for humans, surely Allah would explain it in detail.

Furthermore, Allah explains that magic does not give any benefit to humans, but even gives harm. Therefore, Allah threatens those who practice it with punishment. The Jews themselves actually knew that magic harms humans, and they should hate it. But, because there is an evil intention contained in their hearts to mislead Muslims, they are willing to do it. Therefore, Allah condemns the act of magic and includes those who do it in the group of people who choose the wrong actions. Furthermore, Allah affirms that in the hereafter they will not get any happiness at all. Because those who have chosen the act of magic, it means they have violated the law contained in the Torah, even though in their own Book there is also a provision that those who follow the whispers of jinn, devils and shamans, the law is the same as those who worship idols and statues.

Furthermore, Allah explains that the magic they do is very bad, Allah describes those who choose the act of magic as their pleasure like people who sell faith for error. This kind of description is useful to uncover their veil, so that their awareness can be opened and know that humans were created by Allah to devote themselves to Him. In other words, if they knew the error of those who study and practice magic, surely they would not do it. But they have been far deceived, so they assume that magic is a branch of knowledge, and they are satisfied with knowledge that is not proven to be true and does not give any influence to a person's soul except with Allah's permission.
text.103: Allah SWT explains that if the Jews believed in their Book and were pious, they would surely receive a great reward. Furthermore, Allah explains that in all their actions and beliefs, they are not based on correct knowledge, because if they based their beliefs and actions on knowledge, they would surely believe in the Prophet Muhammad SAW, and follow him, and they would surely be among the fortunate ones. But in reality, they only follow conjecture and blind imitation (taqlid). In fact, among their excessive actions is that they contradict the contents of the Torah, and they move under the power of their desires and will, so that they fall into error.
text.104:
The Prophet's companions were forbidden from using the word "ra'ina," which they usually said to the Prophet, and which was then imitated by the Jews, who changed its pronunciation to create a bad meaning, in order to mock the Prophet.

Ra'ina, as explained above, means "pay attention to us." But the Jews changed the pronunciation, so that what they meant was "ra'unah," which means "very foolish," as a mockery of the Messenger of Allah. That is why Allah commanded the companions to replace "ra'ina" with "undhurna," which has the same meaning as "ra'ina." Allah taught the believers to say "undhurna," which contains the intention of hoping that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) would pay attention to the condition of the companions.

Allah also directs the believers to listen as well as possible to the religious lessons conveyed by the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), which also contain commands to submit and carry out whatever the Prophet commands, and to avoid his prohibitions. Then, in this verse, Allah reminds that the disbelievers, who do not want to pay attention to the teachings conveyed by the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), will receive a painful punishment.
text.105:
The People of the Book, consisting of Jews and Christians, as well as the polytheists, refused to believe in the Prophet Muhammad because they were envious that he was given a better revelation by Allah. They were unwilling to acknowledge that the Qur'an is the book that contains the most goodness and is full of guidance. Through the Qur'an, Allah gathers and unites the ummah, eliminates the disease of shirk that nests in their hearts, and provides principles for their lives and livelihoods.

Similarly, the polytheists, after seeing the reality that the truth of the Qur'an became increasingly apparent and became a strong motivator for the struggle of the Muslims, tried with all their might to control the situation and destroy the struggle of the Islamic ummah until it disappeared completely.

Nevertheless, they will not be able to realize their dreams because Allah has determined His will, choosing whom He wills solely because of His mercy. He is the One who bestows virtue upon those chosen to be given prophethood. He is also the One who bestows goodness and virtue, so that all His servants rejoice in happiness. Therefore, it is not appropriate for a servant of Allah to feel envious of someone who has been given goodness and virtue, because the channel of goodness and virtue comes from Allah alone.
text.106:
It is explained that any verse whose law is *naskh* (abrogated), or replaced with another verse, or a verse that is abandoned, will be replaced by Him with a verse that is better and more suitable for the benefit of His servants, or replaced by Him with a verse of equal value to the previous law.

As for the wisdom behind the occurrence of verse replacement or change, it is because the value of its benefits varies according to time and place, then it is abolished, or replaced with a better law, or with a verse of equal value, because the verse that is changed or replaced is no longer in accordance with the interests of society, so if a change or replacement is made, it is a wise action.

For those who believe that this verse is a sign of prophethood (a miracle) used to strengthen prophethood, then this verse is interpreted to mean that Allah will not abolish the sign of prophethood used to strengthen His prophethood, or will not change the previous sign of prophethood with a later sign of prophethood, or abandon those signs of prophethood, because several centuries have passed. Except that Allah, who has unlimited power, gives a better sign of prophethood, in terms of its stability and the permanence of that prophethood. Because of His unlimited power, the right to give signs of prophethood to His prophets cannot be hindered.

The replacement of a verse sometimes occurs with a verse that is lighter in its ruling, such as the abolition of the *iddah* of a woman whose husband has died from one year to 4 months and 10 days, or with a verse that has the same ruling, such as the command to face Baitulmakdis when performing prayer being changed to facing the Ka'bah. Or with a heavier law, such as war, which was previously not obligatory for Muslims, becoming obligatory.

This verse is not only addressed to the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him (saw), but also to the Muslims, who felt hurt hearing the mockery of the Jews towards the Prophet Muhammad (saw). People with weak faith are easily influenced, so their hearts easily become doubtful. That is why Allah affirms that He is All-Powerful over all things, and if He wills to *naskh* a law, it cannot be prevented, because the matter of law is within His power.
text.107: Allah SWT explains that He possesses the kingdom of the heavens and the earth. In other words, the heavens and the earth and all that is within them are subject to His power, under His commands and prohibitions. Therefore, Allah also has the power to abrogate a law (nasakh) and establish another law according to His will, if in His consideration there is benefit for all mankind, because the old law is deemed no longer suitable. Therefore, Allah gives affirmation to the Muslims that Allah is the One who gives help and assistance to them. Therefore, the believers are forbidden to pay attention to the Jews who deny the change in the law, even to the point of insulting it. The attitude of the Jews in this way will not cause any harm to the believers.
text.108:
Allah reproaches the attitude of the Jews who insult Muslims because of the abrogation (nasakh) of laws due to Allah's command. In this regard, Allah alludes to them, asking if they want to repeat the actions of their ancestors, namely, posing questions to the Messenger, just as their ancestors asked something of the Prophet Musa, or whether they want to ask the Prophet Muhammad saw to bring a law other than the law that has been established, just as their ancestors improperly proposed things to the Prophet Musa. Allah SWT says:

"The People of the Book ask you (O Muhammad) to bring down to them a book from the heaven. Indeed, they asked Musa (Moses) for even greater than that, for they said, "Show us Allah plainly." (an-Nisa'/4:153)

Then Allah reminds the Jews that those who do not adhere to Allah's commands on the grounds of wanting to seek another law, which according to their consideration is better, means that they have exchanged their faith for disbelief, love misguidance more than guidance, and they have strayed far from the truth. Whoever transgresses the laws of Allah has fallen into the valley of misguidance.

In this verse, there is guidance for Muslims, namely, that they should do what the Messenger saw commands and avoid all his prohibitions. There is also a prohibition against asking for something outside the provisions of existing law.
text.109:
Allah swt explains that the majority of the People of the Book always wished that they could turn the Muslims away from the religion of Tawhid and make them infidels like themselves, after they clearly knew that what Prophet Muhammad saw brought was true and in accordance with the principles contained in the Torah.

This verse contains a warning to Muslims to be wary of the deceitful tricks carried out by the People of the Book. Sometimes by muddying the teachings of Islam, and sometimes by fostering doubt among Muslims themselves.

They commit these deceptions purely out of envy, not arising from a clear perspective. Their envy is not because of doubts about the content of the Qur'an or because it is driven by the truth contained in the Torah, but because of the prompting of their desires, mental decline, and resentment in their hearts. That is why they fall into the valley of error and falsehood.

After that, Allah provides guidance to the Muslim community on how to deal with their actions. Allah commands Muslims to face them with politeness and to forgive all their mistakes, also forbidding them from reproaching them until the time comes when Allah gives the command. Because Allah is the One who will provide assistance to the Muslim community, until the Muslim community can determine its stance in facing their challenges, whether they should be fought or expelled. This event has occurred, the Muslims fought the Bani Quraizah and Bani Nadir from Medina after they tore up the agreements. They gave assistance to the polytheists, after they had been repeatedly forgiven.

Then Allah gives certainty or a promise that He will provide assistance to the Muslims, by stating that He has the power to give other strengths. He also has the power to give steadfastness of heart so that Muslims remain steadfast to the truth. So that they can defeat those who openly oppose the Muslims and boast of their strength.
text.110:
Allah commands the Muslims to continuously pursue the best path, perform prayer (salat) and give alms (zakat). This command is linked to Allah's promise of assistance in achieving victory. Because in prayer there are many wisdoms, such as strengthening the bonds of faith, elevating aspirations, and increasing mental resilience. Because within prayer there is supplication (doa) to Allah uttered by a servant as a declaration of serious intent, and it strengthens the bonds of the heart between believers, through performing congregational prayer and their interaction in the mosque. Through this way, faith can develop and become firm, it can also maintain the purity of the soul, prevent oneself from committing vile deeds, and increase the fighting spirit to carry out the truth. If the Muslims take such measures, surely they will receive help from Allah.

The wisdom contained in giving zakat is to strengthen the relationship between wealthy and poor Muslims, so that with the strength of that relationship, a solid and unified unity of the ummah will be created.

After that, Allah affirms that prayer (salat) and alms (zakat) are the path that must be taken to obtain victory and happiness in this world and the hereafter. This can be known from Allah's statement that whatever good deeds are done by the Muslims, surely they will receive a reward from Allah on the Day of Judgment with the utmost justice. Allah commands Muslims to do good because Allah is truly All-Knowing of all deeds, both many and few. No deed is wasted, whether it is a righteous deed or a bad deed, all will receive a fitting reward.
text.111:
The People of the Book, both Jews and Christians, each believed that none would enter Paradise except their own group. The Jews believed that only Jews would enter Paradise, and similarly, the Christians believed that only Christians would enter Paradise.

To reject and invalidate their assumptions, Allah provides confirmation that their assumptions are merely wishful thinking arising from their imaginations. Their wishful thinking, although stated globally, encompasses a broad meaning, namely their wishful thinking to avoid punishment and the assumption that those not of their group will fall into punishment and receive no blessings whatsoever. That is why in the verse, their wishful thinking is stated in the plural form. This verse contains an indication that an opinion not based on true evidence should not be accepted.
text.112:
The assumptions of each group from the People of the Book are incorrect, because entry into Paradise is not monopolized by a particular nation or group, but will be attained by anyone who strives to obtain it with the condition that they must believe and do righteous deeds.

As an affirmation, Allah gives the statement that whoever believes in Allah and proves that faith with sincere deeds, then he will receive a reward. Allah will not waste the good deeds of a servant. This verse also shows that faith that is not realized in righteous deeds does not guarantee a person's happiness. In the Qur'an, many words of faith are always accompanied by righteous deeds:

"And whoever does righteous deeds, whether male or female, while being a believer - then those will enter Paradise, and they will not be wronged [even as much as] the speck on a date seed." (an-Nisa'/4:124)

"So whoever does righteous deeds while being a believer - his effort will not be denied. Indeed, We will be recording of it for him." (al-Anbiya'/21:94)

If they have surrendered to Allah and done righteous deeds, then they need not worry and grieve. Among the characteristics of believers is that when they are afflicted with something unpleasant, they will investigate the causes of its occurrence and strive hard to overcome it. If it is still not resolved, they surrender the matter to the power of Allah: their intention is not weakened in the slightest and their hearts realize that to overcome all difficulties, they surrender to the true power, namely Allah.
text.113:
The Jews believe that the Christians have no basis whatsoever. The Jews deny Al-Masih (the Messiah), even though they have read the Torah, which contains news about the coming of Prophet Isa (Jesus). The Jews give Al-Masih an inappropriate title.

The Christians also believe that the Jews have no correct religious basis, because the Jews have denied the prophethood of Al-Masih, who acted as the perfecter of their religion. Even though they have read the Book, this mutual accusation should not have happened. If that is the case, they are saying something that is not contained in their Book, because the Torah contains good news about the coming of Al-Masih who perfects the religious regulations brought by Musa (Moses) a.s. (peace be upon him), not to invalidate them. But why did the Christians completely invalidate the religion of the Jews?

In short, it can be said that their religion is actually one. It is only because some parts were removed from the contents of the Book that this mutual accusation occurred. Thus, the Book they read becomes proof of their falsehood.

The words they utter are not a new issue; even nations before them said things without being based on strong evidence. Like followers of wasaniyyah, paganism (idol worshippers) also say to other religions that the religion followed by those people has no basis whatsoever. If humans could know the truth, there would certainly be no fundamental conflicts.

Then Allah gives confirmation that Allah is the All-Knowing of all truth and falsehood that they dispute. Allah also justifies what is true and places those who love the truth in Paradise, and also invalidates what is false, and perpetuates the lovers and supporters of falsehood in Hell.
text.114:
Among the most unjust actions are:

1.  Preventing people from mentioning the name of Allah in His mosques. This includes preventing all actions related to religious affairs, such as studying and practicing religion, *itikaf*, prayer, *dhikr*, and so on.

2.  Demolishing the mosques of Allah (places of worship). This includes actions, efforts, or measures aimed at damaging, demolishing, and preventing the establishment of mosques, and so on.

Both types of actions are unjust because they result in the disappearance of the symbols of Allah's religion. The *mufassirun* (Quran commentators) agree that the verse above alludes to "general actions" and "specific actions."

"General actions" are all kinds of actions related to preventing people from worshiping in mosques and actions of demolishing the mosques of Allah (places of worship). "Specific actions" mean that the verse above was revealed to explain or allude to an event in history that has the same characteristics as the actions or deeds mentioned in the verse. The *mufassirun* differ in opinion about the event referred to by this verse.

The first opinion: The verse above alludes to the actions of the polytheists of Mecca who prevented the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his companions from performing *umrah* in the month of Dhul-Hijjah in the 6th year of Hijri (March 628 AD). The attitude of the polytheists eventually led to the Treaty of Hudaybiyah. This desire arose again because in the Treaty of Hudaybiyah, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his companions were allowed to enter the city of Mecca in the year after the treaty was signed. It is their actions that Allah refers to as preventing people from mentioning the name of Allah in the Masjid al-Haram and efforts to demolish the mosque.

This first group further asserts that in the continuation of the verse there is the statement:

"They should not enter them except in fear (of Allah)." (al-Baqarah/2:114)

This verse describes that the time will come when Muslims will enter the city of Mecca safely and peacefully, and the polytheists of Mecca will enter the Masjid al-Haram with fear. This was proven later with the liberation of the city of Mecca by the Muslims and the polytheists of Mecca abandoning their religion and entering Islam.

The second opinion: The verse above alludes to the actions of King Titus (70 AD) of the Roman nation, the son of Emperor Vespasian, who destroyed the Temple of Solomon and the places of worship of the Jews and Christians in Jerusalem.

The actions of the polytheists of Mecca in preventing the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and the Muslims from entering the city of Mecca to perform *umrah* and the actions of King Titus in destroying Baitulmaqdis are included in "general actions." While the "specific action" referred to in this verse is the second opinion because of the statement "demolishing the mosques" of Allah in the verse. The polytheists of Mecca never demolished the Mosque of Allah in the true sense; they only defiled the Baitullah and prevented Muslims from worshiping. While Titus and his army truly demolished the Baitullah in Jerusalem and killed those who worshiped Allah.

The continuation of the verse explains the qualities that humans must possess when entering the mosque of Allah, with humility, obedience, and purifying their obedience only to Allah alone. From this verse, it can be understood that humans are prohibited from entering the mosque of Allah with arrogance and *riya* (showing off). It is forbidden for those who intend to prevent people from worshiping inside it, and those who intend to damage or demolish it, to enter the mosque.

At the end of the verse, Allah threatens those who commit the above actions with humiliation in this world and a painful punishment in the hereafter. Humiliation in this world may be in the form of disaster, destruction, and all kinds of humiliation, whether directly or indirectly felt by humans. The form of punishment in the hereafter is known only to Allah.

Allah forbids humans from carrying out all kinds of actions related to preventing people from praying, *salat*, *itikaf*, studying religion, worshiping, and other actions in upholding the symbols of Allah's religion in His mosques, as well as efforts to damage and demolish them.

That action is unjust in Allah's view because it directly or indirectly results in the disappearance of Allah's religion on earth. That action is so unjust that Allah threatens the perpetrators with humiliation in this world and a painful punishment in the hereafter. What Allah commands is for humans to prosper the mosques of Allah, establish and maintain them well, and enter them with a sense of submission and surrender to Allah.
text.115:
The reason for the revelation of this verse is as narrated by Jabir as follows: "We were sent by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) on a military expedition, and I was among the troops. When we were in the middle of the journey, darkness gripped us, so we did not know the direction of the Qibla." A group among us said, "We know the direction of the Qibla, which is over there, to the north." So they prayed and drew a line on the ground. Some of us said, "The direction of the Qibla is over there, to the south." And they drew a line on the ground. When the morning came and the sun rose, the line pointed in a direction that was not the direction of the Qibla. When we returned from the journey and we asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) about the incident, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) remained silent and this verse was revealed."

Allah SWT affirms His ownership of the entire universe. He Himself regulates it, knowing everything that happens within it, both small and large. Allah says:

¦And He is with you wherever you are. And Allah is Seeing of what you do. (al-Hadid/57:4)

Another verse of Allah:

¦There is no private conversation between three, but He is the fourth of them; nor between five, but He is the sixth of them; and no less than that or more, but He is with them wherever they are¦ (al-Mujadilah/58:7)

... (They say), "Our Lord, You have encompassed all things in mercy and knowledge, so forgive those who have repented and followed Your way..." (al-Mu'min/40:7)

Therefore, basically, wherever a person turns his face in prayer or worship, to the east, west, north, south, down, up, and so on, his prayer and worship will surely be heard by Allah and reach Him.

This verse refutes the belief that Allah has a place, that prayer or worship will be heard and reach Allah if the worshiper faces a certain direction only or a place that is considered more noble than another place, and so on. The word *wajh* has many meanings. In this verse, it means "presence."

Based on the verse above and the reason for its revelation, the following rulings can be established:

1.  The Qibla is basically all directions. Wherever a servant faces, he will surely meet the face of Allah. To maintain the unity and solidarity of the Muslims, the Ka'bah has been designated as the direction of the Qibla.

2.  If the day is very dark and the direction of the Qibla is unknown, then it is permissible to pray facing the direction that is believed to be the Qibla. If it later turns out that the direction is not the direction of the Qibla, then the prayer is still valid.

3.  For a person who is on a moving vehicle, he may face the direction he likes. Some scholars recommend facing the front of the vehicle.
text.116:
The verbal and heartfelt confession of the Jews and Christians that Allah has a son. The Jews say Uzair is the son of Allah, while the Christians say that Al-Masih (the Messiah) is the son of Allah.

And the Jews say, "Uzair is the son of Allah," and the Christians say, "The Messiah is the son of Allah." That is their statement from their mouths. (at-Taubah/9: 30)

Both beliefs are fundamentally the same, namely stating that Allah has a son, which means they associate partners with Allah (shirk), stating that Allah needs helpers in managing this universe, stating that Allah has an ambition and that ambition will be continued by His son if He no longer exists.

The beliefs and statements of these disbelievers are untrue, astonishing, and overly audacious. Exalted is Allah above such statements. Allah does not need anything, does not need helpers or assistants in carrying out all His affairs, does not need anything to continue His will, because He is eternal and without end.

From the phrase "Exalted is Allah" it is understood that the confession of the Jews and Christians about Allah having a son is a confession that is considered a major sin. Therefore, servants who have unfortunately made this confession should repent to Allah. Only through repentance can a servant's major sin be forgiven by Allah.

The end of this verse gives the understanding that Allah intends to purify Himself from the words of the disbelievers. Allah states this solely to protect the rights of His servants, to purify the beliefs of His servants that could harm them in this world and in the hereafter.

Allah even affirms that the entire universe belongs to Him, is under His power. Nothing can diminish His will or harm Him. All are obedient and submissive to Him.
text.117:
Allah is the All-Creator. He creates something without imitating what already exists, without using existing materials or tools. Allah creates from nothing. Thus, Allah created the heavens and the earth, from initially non-existent to existent.

According to the verse, Allah creates something with the word "kun" (be!), this expression is a simplification of the Greatness of Allah's power, whatever He wills to establish, all happens easily. While the meaning of creating is merely an example, to be easily understood by His servants. About how Allah brings something into being and how the process occurs, only Allah knows best.

Allah's word in the previous verse explains that "whatever is in the heavens and on the earth belongs to Allah, and all are devoutly obedient to Him" is a statement of His power and might. He is the Creator, He is the One who regulates and has power over everything.

The word "fa yakun," which means "then it is," here does not necessarily mean that something happens instantly, but rather through stages of a process that takes time. Every stage of the process that takes place in this universe will certainly be subject to the laws of nature, namely Allah's provisions or *sunnatullah*.

The constructive engineering process from the availability of raw materials to finished goods will require a process that is sometimes long and takes time. The process of the formation of petroleum or valuable minerals takes a very long time according to human calculations.

In the process of creating the universe, pay attention to Allah's word in Surah al-Anbiya'/21: 30, which means:

And do not the disbelievers see that the heavens and the earth were joined together, then We clove them asunder? And We made from water every living thing. Will they not then believe? (al-Anbiya'/21: 30)

The verse above explains that the heavens and the earth were once joined together, then Allah separated them into one heaven and one earth. But this separation process did not happen instantly. This process took millions of years. The formation of the unified whole may also require a process and time, not instantly.

Likewise, in the creation of the first human, Adam *as*, Siti Hawa, Isa *as* and us, as well as other creatures in this universe, everything will take place in stages according to His decree, even though Allah is able to change His existing provisions into other provisions according to His will.
text.118:
What is meant by the expression "Those who do not know" in this verse are the polytheists of Mecca. They are said to not know because their beliefs are not based on the revelation that Allah sent down to His prophets and do not follow the prophets He sent. This is affirmed by the following verse, which directly addresses Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, regarding the attitude of those polytheists and the similarity of their words to the words of those before Prophet Muhammad was sent.

The polytheists said, "Why does Allah not speak directly to them, explaining that Muhammad is the messenger of Allah and the Qur'an was revealed from Allah, or an angel come to them to explain it, or signs come that explain and prove the prophethood of Muhammad?"

This verse explains that their words are the same as the words of those before them, which they spoke to the prophets who were sent to them. Allah also explains that the reason for what they say is the same, namely, because of their denial and envy of Muhammad, not because of the absence of signs or evidence that Allah has brought. Allah has brought many signs, but their hearts are closed to receiving those signs because of their arrogance and pride. Whatever signs and evidence are brought, they will still not believe.

The words of those before, which are the same as the words of the polytheists, are mentioned in the Qur'an, such as the words of the Jews, as reported in the Qur'an:

And (remember) when you said, "O Moses, we will never believe in you until we see Allah outright."... (al-Baqarah/2:55. See also an-Nisa'/4:153)

Allah's word:

And (recall) when you said, "O Moses, we can never endure one kind of food. So invoke your Lord for us that He bring forth for us from the earth its herbs and its cucumbers and its garlic and its lentils and its onions."... (al-Baqarah/2:61)

The Christians said to Prophet Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, as mentioned in the word of Allah Almighty:

[And remember] when the disciples said, "O Jesus, Son of Mary, can your Lord send down to us a table [spread with food] from the heaven?"... (al-Ma'idah/5:112)

Furthermore, it is affirmed that the disbelievers will not believe, no matter what explanation or evidence is revealed to them. Allah says:

And even if We had sent down to you, [O Muhammad], a written scripture on a page and they touched it with their hands, the disbelievers would say, "This is not but obvious magic." (al-An'am/6:7)

At the end of the verse, it is explained that Allah always sends down evidence and signs for everything, and He explains it as clearly as possible. People who are pure in soul and heart will immediately accept the signs and evidence, and they will immediately believe in them. Those who do not accept it are those who have envy and disease in their hearts, their hearts are hard and closed. Allah says:

Have they instructed one another in it? Rather, they are a transgressing people. (adz-dzariyat/51:53)

The above verse is a solace for Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, who is facing the denial of the Meccan polytheists to his call. It is as if the verse above explains that the attitude of the polytheists is the same attitude as the people of the past towards the prophets who were sent to them. Therefore, do not pay attention to their attitude and do not be sad.
text.119:
Allah sent Muhammad with the truth. That truth is something firm and certain, not misleading those who adhere to it, but rather making them happy, and it does not contain even the slightest element of doubt, let alone falsehood. From this verse, it can be understood that within the truth brought by the Prophet Muhammad, there are beliefs, laws, procedures, good customs, and everything that can make human life happy in this world and the hereafter.

This verse explains that among the duties of the Prophet Muhammad are:

1.  To give glad tidings from Allah, who promises happiness in this world and the hereafter for those who follow the religion brought by Muhammad. The word *basyiran* also gives the meaning: a sign, a signal that gives glad tidings, such as the presence of clouds as a sign that it will rain.

2.  To give a warning that there is misery for those who do not follow Allah's commands and stop His prohibitions, and for those who hinder the call of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).

Those who do not heed the warning will be thrown into a blazing fire. Such an expression shows the severity of the punishment that will be suffered by those who disobey the Prophet. The verse explains the duty of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), which is to convey the religion to mankind. While the one who assesses the attitude of humans towards the call of Muhammad is Allah Himself. Only Allah gives rewards and gives punishments. Allah says:

"Not upon you, [O Muhammad], is [responsibility for] their guidance, but Allah guides whom He wills." (al-Baqarah/2:272)
text.120:
This verse states the true desire of the People of the Book, which is why they take actions against those who worship in the mosques of Allah, demolish mosques, associate partners with Allah, and deny the call of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), the final Prophet. They will not stop taking these actions until Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his followers embrace their religion, which is a religion originating from the religions brought by previous prophets, but whose teachings have been greatly altered by them. Therefore, Muslims should be wary of the attitude of the People of the Book, and should not hesitate to follow the guidance of Allah revealed to His prophets, not guidance originating from human desires and whims, especially the desires and whims of the Jews and Christians.

The Jews and Christians take these actions after knowledge has come to them about the religion approved by Allah and the teachings of Islam. Outwardly, this verse is directly addressed to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), as a stern warning should the Prophet (peace be upon him) follow their wishes, even though the Prophet has been guaranteed protection from actions forbidden by Allah. There are many such verses in the Al-Qur'an that outwardly are addressed to the Prophet, but whose intended meaning is for the Ummah of Muhammad (peace be upon him). Allah warns with this verse so that Muslims are careful about the attitude of the People of the Book towards Islam and the Muslims.
text.121:
Among the People of the Book are Jews who follow the Torah, and Christians who follow the Gospel. They truly read the book revealed to them with a true reading, not followed by their desires and lusts.

They read it with a true reading by understanding it wholeheartedly, not interpreting or explaining it according to their own desires, not adding, subtracting, or changing it.

According to Ibn Mas'ud and Ibn 'Abbas, reading with a true reading means legalizing what it legalizes, forbidding what it forbids, reading it as Allah revealed it, not changing or diverting words from their proper places, and not interpreting anything from the book with an improper interpretation.

In His other words, the intended reading is explained, namely:

"...Indeed, those who were given knowledge before it - when it is recited to them, they fall upon their faces in prostration." (al-Isra'/17:107)

Certainly, in their stories is a lesson for those of understanding. (Al-Qur'an) (Yusuf/12:111)

From the verses above, it is understood that all the books (revelations) of Allah revealed to His servants are lessons for them, the purpose of which is to direct and guide them to the straight path. Therefore, the servants of Allah are obligated to read them truly, repeatedly, and strive to understand Allah's guidance contained therein. Allah says:

Then do they not reflect upon the Qur'an? If it had been from [someone] other than Allah, they would have found within it much contradiction. (an-Nisa'/4:82)

The word of Allah:

Then do they not reflect upon the Qur'an, or are there locks upon [their] hearts? (Muhammad/47:24)

From the verses above, it is understood that reading the Qur'an without paying attention to its meaning and intention, interpreting it according to one's own desires, is the same as the reading of the Book by the Jews and Christians. From the verse above, it is understood that reading the books of Allah with a true reading is obligatory for humans. Reading the Book not with a true reading, not practicing what is read, means mocking the books of Allah and challenging Allah.
text.122:
This verse reminds the Children of Israel again of the blessings that Allah bestowed upon their ancestors. Allah had favored them above other nations of their time.

The blessings that Allah gave were because, in addition to adhering to Allah's teachings, justice, and truth, they possessed noble characteristics and aspirations, avoided bad traits, and restrained their desires and lusts (hawa nafsu).
text.123:
The Children of Israel are warned to always follow the religion of Allah. They should remember the coming of a Day, on which nothing can help except Allah.

On that Day, no one can help another avoid the punishment of Allah; each person is responsible for all the deeds they have ever done. No one can redeem their sins with any wealth, and no one can replace another in bearing the punishment.

This verse warns believers to always protect themselves from the torment of the Day of Judgment by carrying out all the commands and stopping the prohibitions of Allah.
text.124:
Ibrahim (peace be upon him) was tested by God with several commands and prohibitions, such as building the Ka'bah, cleansing it from all forms of polytheism, sacrificing his son Ismail (peace be upon him), confronting King Namrud, and so on.

According to Mahmud Zahram, Ibrahim (peace be upon him) was given various experiences of trials and tribulations by Allah. He was commanded by Allah to slaughter his son, to travel back and forth between Syria and the Hijaz to see his wife and children who were in both places, and so on.

Allah does not explain the various commands that were assigned to Prophet Ibrahim. This indicates that the tasks that Allah had given were great, heavy, and numerous. Nevertheless, Ibrahim (peace be upon him) carried out these tasks and burdens in the best possible way, which led him to a position of perfection.

"And [that of] Abraham, who fulfilled [his obligations]?" (an-Najm/53:37)

The statement, "Indeed, I will make you a leader for the people," is not related to the previous statement, because there is no conjunction ('atf) at the beginning of the sentence.

According to Muhammad Abduh, this statement is a standalone statement, unrelated to the previous statement. The meaning is that the position of imam (prophet and messenger) is solely a position bestowed by Allah, and He alone determines to whom that position will be given. Not all people can achieve it, even if they have carried out all the commands and stopped all the prohibitions of Allah.

In other words, the position of imam that Allah bestowed upon Prophet Ibrahim was determined by His will, not because Prophet Ibrahim had completed and perfected the tasks given to him, so that he would realize that the position given by Allah was appropriate for him, and so that he would feel capable of carrying out the tasks and bearing the burdens that had been given.

After being bestowed with the position of "imam," Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) prayed to Allah that the position of "imam" would also be bestowed upon his descendants in the future. This prayer of Prophet Ibrahim is a prayer that is in accordance with *sunnatullah* (the way of Allah). According to *sunnatullah*, children and descendants are a continuation of life for a person. An ideal that cannot be achieved during one's lifetime in the world is hoped to be achieved by one's children and descendants.

The task of an imam is a sacred and noble task because the giving of that task aims to achieve sacred and noble ideals as well. Ibrahim (peace be upon him) felt that he was unable to achieve all his ideals contained in his task during his lifetime in the world. Therefore, he prayed to Allah that his children and grandchildren would also be bestowed with the position of imam, so that the ideals that could not be achieved during his lifetime could be continued and achieved by his children, grandchildren, and descendants.

From the verse above, it can also be understood that the way Prophet Ibrahim prayed was in accordance with *sunnatullah*, so it was a correct way of praying and included a prayer that was granted by Allah. It is proven that in the future, all the messengers that Allah sent after him came from his descendants.

From Allah's statement, "My covenant does not include the wrongdoers," it can be understood that among the descendants of Prophet Ibrahim there are wrongdoers. In another verse, Allah explains that the descendants of Ibrahim are those who do good and those who do evil. Allah says:

"And We blessed him and Isaac. But among their descendants are those who do good and those who are clearly unjust to themselves." (as-Saffat/37:113)

Allah says:

"And he left it as a lasting word among his descendants, so that they might return [to it]." (az-Zukhruf/43:28)

From this verse, it can be understood that Prophet Ibrahim made the *kalimat tauhid* (the word of monotheism) a guideline for his descendants. If any of them associate partners with Allah, they are asked to return to the *kalimat tauhid*.

"Zalim" (oppression) is of various kinds. Oppression against oneself is not carrying out the commands and not abandoning the prohibitions of Allah, so that one incurs the wrath and punishment of Allah, which brings disaster to oneself. Oppression against Allah's creatures, such as causing damage on earth, severing ties of kinship, oppression against humans, and so on.

From the word "zalim," it can be understood that an imam must not have the characteristic of being zalim. It is impossible for that position to be given to someone whose soul is impure, people who do not carry out Allah's commands and do not stop His prohibitions.
text.125:
The Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, and the Muslims were commanded to remember when Allah made the Ka'bah a gathering place for mankind, a safe haven, and made Maqam Ibrahim a place of prayer. Maqam Ibrahim is the place where Ibrahim stood when building the Ka'bah.
