Allah's command to Ibrahim and Ismail was to reassure the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, and the Muslims in the face of the disbelievers' denial and to explain to the polytheists, Jews, and Christians that the religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, is based on the same foundation as the religion brought by the Prophet Ibrahim, their ancestor's religion.

There are two benefits that can be drawn from the verse above in connection with the establishment of the Ka'bah: First, a gathering place for mankind for worship. Since ancient times, before the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, was sent until now, the Ka'bah or Mecca has been a gathering place for people from all directions, from all kinds of nations in order to honor and perform the Hajj pilgrimage. Their hearts feel at peace living around the Ka'bah. After they return to their homeland, their hearts and souls are always drawn to it and they always aspire to return again if there is an opportunity.

Second, Allah Almighty made it a safe place. That is, Allah made the land around the Masjidilharam a safe land and place for those who are there. Since ancient times until now, the Arabs have glorified and sanctified it.

The Arabs are known for their tendency to seek revenge on people or tribes who kill, hurt, or insult their families. Wherever they find that person or tribe, they will carry out the revenge. Except if they find them in the Haram Land, they will not disturb them in the slightest. In the meantime, since ancient times, there have been many attempts by the Arabs themselves or by other nations to control the Haram Land or to damage the Ka'bah, but they have always been thwarted by Allah, such as the attempt by Abrahah, the King of Najashi, with his army to control the Haram Land and the Ka'bah. They were destroyed.

Allah says:

Have you not considered, [O Muhammad], how your Lord dealt with the companions of the elephant? Did He not make their plan into misguidance? And He sent against them birds in flocks, striking them with stones of hard clay, and He made them like eaten straw. (al-Fil/105:1-5)

Have they not seen that We made [Makkah] a safe sanctuary, while people are being snatched away all around them? Then do they believe in falsehood and disbelieve in the favor of Allah? (al-'Ankabut/29:67)

Allah commanded that Maqam Ibrahim be made a place of prayer. The benefit of that command is to bring that command to mind or for people to follow what is commanded, as if the command is directed to them so that the command is embedded in their hearts and they feel that they are among those who are commanded.

Thus, the meaning of the verse is: The people of the past who believed in Ibrahim, peace be upon him, were commanded to make part of Maqam Ibrahim a place of prayer. The command was also addressed to those who came later, who acknowledged Ibrahim, peace be upon him, as a prophet and messenger of Allah and acknowledged the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, one of the descendants of Ibrahim, peace be upon him, as the last prophet.

Allah commanded the Prophet Ibrahim to cleanse it in the true and figurative sense. Cleansing in the true sense is cleansing from all kinds of things that are judged to be impure, such as all kinds of dirt and so on. Cleansing in the figurative sense is cleansing it from all kinds of actions that contain elements of shirk, the act of worshiping idols, prohibited acts, quarreling, and so on.

This command to cleanse the Ka'bah, even though it was addressed to the Prophet Ibrahim and Ismail, also includes those who came after them. Allah named the Ka'bah that was built as "House of Allah" (Baitullah). This naming does not mean that Allah lives in or around the Ka'bah. But the meaning is that Allah made that house a place to worship Him and in worship to face the Ka'bah.

The wisdom of making the Ka'bah as the "house of Allah" and making it as the direction to face in worshiping Allah, the Creator and Ruler of all creatures, is so that humans feel that they can directly convey praise, expressions of gratitude, requests for help, and requests for prayer to Allah.

Humans are less able to express their thoughts in worshiping Allah if it is not done in a specific place and facing a specific direction. With a specific place and a specific direction, humans can increase their faith at any time, deepen their knowledge, and increase the spiritual values ​​within themselves. Because in this way he feels as if Allah is in front of him so close, so that there is nothing that limits him from Allah.

In another verse it is emphasized that wherever humans face in worship, praying will meet the face of Allah, and reach Him, because Allah is All-Encompassing and All-Knowing. ) From the verse above it can be understood that the naming of the Ka'bah as the house of Allah is only to make it easier for humans to focus their minds in worship. In principle, Allah is the Greatest, the All-Knowing, and the All-Encompassing.
text.126:
The prayers of Prophet Ibrahim have been answered by Allah. It is also affirmed regarding the nature of Ibrahim a.s.'s prayer, which is security for the Haram land and the characteristics of those who are entitled to inherit it, namely those who are good and noble.

What is meant by "this land" is the holy land of Mecca, in accordance with Allah's word:

Ya Tuhan, sesungguhnya aku telah menempatkan sebagian keturunanku di lembah yang tidak mempunyai tanam-tanaman di dekat rumah Engkau (Baitullah) yang dihormati, ¦ (Ibrahim/14:37)

O our Lord! I have settled some of my offspring in a valley barren of any fruit near Your Sacred House, ¦ (Ibrahim/14:37)

The holy land of Mecca was prayed for to be guaranteed security from all kinds of disasters, such as enemy attacks, bloodshed, and destruction as experienced by previous peoples due to their denial of Allah. It was also prayed for to be given sustenance in the form of fruits to its inhabitants.

The prayer of Prophet Ibrahim was granted by Allah with His word:

¦Bukankah Kami telah meneguhkan kedudukan mereka dalam tanah haram (tanah suci) yang aman, yang didatangkan ke tempat itu buah-buahan dari segala macam (tumbuh-tumbuhan) sebagai rezeki (bagimu) dari sisi Kami? Tetapi kebanyakan mereka tidak mengetahui. (al-Qasas/28:57)

Have We not established for them a secure sanctuary to which are brought fruits of all kinds as a provision from Ourselves? But most of them do not know. (al-Qasas/28:57)

The acceptance of Ibrahim a.s.'s prayer is proven by the arrival in the land of Arabia of all kinds of fruits brought by people from all corners of the world. Ibrahim a.s. specifically directed his prayer to those who believe, but Allah's mercy is immense and infinite, given to those who believe and those who disbelieve. Allah says:

Kepada masing-masing (golongan), baik (golongan) ini (yang menginginkan dunia) maupun (golongan) itu (yang menginginkan akhirat), Kami berikan bantuan dari kemurahan Tuhanmu. Dan kemurahan Tuhanmu tidak dapat dihalangi. (a1-Isra'/17:20)

To each We extend Our bounty—to these and to those—from the bounty of your Lord. And the bounty of your Lord can never be withheld. (a1-Isra'/17:20)

What is meant by "these" are the disbelievers who prioritize worldly matters, and "those" are the believers who prioritize the life of the hereafter over worldly life, as mentioned in the previous verses.

Furthermore, the difference in pleasure given to believers and the pleasure given to disbelievers is explained. The pleasure given to disbelievers is temporary pleasure, a small amount of sustenance that they receive and experience during their life in the world, then in the hereafter they will enter hell.

Humans are given rewards and punishments because of their own actions. The meaning is that humans become disbelievers and transgressors by their own will and desire. Because the punishment inflicted upon them is based on the actions they do according to their own will and desire. Their disbelief in Allah causes them to be punished according to *sunatullah*.

Based on this *sunatullah*, all kinds of human knowledge and actions, whether actions driven by lust or driven by their physical and spiritual desires, will directly give an impression of happiness or misery, much or little, whether humans are willing to accept it or not. This is what is meant by the expression: Allah has made the dirty soul and despicable deeds the target of His wrath and the target of His punishment in the hereafter, just as Allah has made the dirty and unprotected body the target of the place of disease that He has created.
text.127:
The Arabs are reminded that the one who built the Baitullah was their ancestor named Ibrahim and his son Ismail. Ibrahim is the ancestor of the Arabs through his son Ismail, while the Israelites are through his son Isaac. All Arabs followed the religion of Ibrahim.

From the verse, it can be understood that the one who built the Baitullah was Prophet Ibrahim and his son Ismail. The purpose was to worship Allah and not for anything else, as a reminder for themselves, which would be remembered by their descendants in the future. The materials for building the Ka'bah were ordinary objects, the same as other objects, and not objects that Allah deliberately sent down from the sky. All narrations that excessively describe the Ka'bah are untrue narrations, suspected to originate from Isra'iliyat. Regarding al-hajar al-Aswad (the Black Stone), 'Umar bin al-Khatthab r.a. said when he kissed it:

"From Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, that he kissed the Hajarul Aswad and said: "Indeed, I know that you are a stone that can neither harm nor benefit. If I had not seen the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) kiss you, I would not have kissed you." (Muttafaq 'Alaih)

According to the narration of ad-Daraqutni, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) once stated before kissing the Hajar Aswad that it was just an ordinary stone. Similarly, Abu Bakar r.a., and other companions. From the above narrations, it can be concluded that the Hajar Aswad is just an ordinary stone. The command to kiss it is related to worship, such as the command to pray facing the Ka'bah, the command to throw jamrah during the Hajj pilgrimage, and so on. All of them are carried out solely to carry out the commands of Allah.

After Ibrahim and Ismail finished laying the foundation of the Ka'bah, they both prayed: "Accept from us," (meaning: accept our deeds as righteous deeds, be pleased with them and reward us...) "Allah is All-Hearing" (meaning: Allah is All-Hearing of our prayers), and "Allah is All-Knowing" (meaning: Allah is All-Knowing of our intentions and purposes in building and establishing this Ka'bah).

From the verse above, it can be inferred that it is sunnah (recommended) to pray and surrender all our deeds to Allah after completing them. With this surrender, it means that the duty of a servant is to perform righteous deeds for Allah, and Allah is the One who has the right to evaluate those deeds and reward them according to His evaluation.

From the verse above, it can also be understood that Ibrahim a.s. and his son, Ismail a.s., prayed to Allah after completing righteous deeds with the intention and purpose that the deed was solely done and performed for Allah. Because the nature and form of the deed they performed was believed to be in accordance with the commands of Allah, the father and son were also certain that their deeds would be accepted by Allah. This means that all kinds of prayers offered to Allah that have the same nature, form, and purpose as those performed by Ibrahim a.s. with his son, will surely be accepted by Allah and will surely be given a good reward from His side.

In the following verse (128), Ibrahim a.s. continues his prayer, that his descendants become a people who are submissive and obedient to Allah. In the word "Muslim" (submissive and obedient) is contained the understanding that the people intended by Ibrahim a.s. have the following characteristics:

1.  Purifying belief only to Allah. The heart of a Muslim only believes that the One who has the right to be worshiped and asked for help is only Allah, the One and Only. This belief stems from the Muslim's awareness that he is under the supervision and power of Allah. Only Allah can make decisions about him.

2.  All actions, obedience, and submission are done only for and to Allah alone, not because of following desires, not because of wanting to be praised and seen as good by people, not because of rank and position, and not because of worldly gains.

If the belief and submission are not purely to Allah, then Allah is no longer a protector for them. Allah says:

Have you seen he who has taken as his god his [own] desire, and Allah has left him astray due to knowledge and has set a seal upon his hearing and his heart and put over his vision a veil? Then who will guide him after Allah? Will you not then be reminded? (al-Furqan/25:43)

Allah allows to go astray those who make their desires as their god and seals their hearts, because Allah knows that they do not accept the guidance given to them. Allah says:

Then have you seen he who has taken as his god his [own] desire, and Allah has sent him astray due to knowledge and has set a seal upon his hearing and his heart and put over his vision a veil? So who will guide him after Allah? Will you not then be reminded? (al-Jasiyah/45:23)

In verse 124, Ibrahim a.s. prayed that his descendants be made imams, Allah answered, "The descendants of Ibrahim who are unjust are not included in that prayer." Therefore, in verse 128, Ibrahim a.s. prays that some of his family be made people who are submissive and obedient to Allah.

In relation to the above verse, there is an indication that what is meant by his descendants is Ismail a.s. and his descendants who will be left in Mecca, while he himself returns to Syria. It is the descendants of Ismail a.s. who inhabit Mecca and its surroundings, including the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him). This is what is meant by the word of Allah.

...Follow the religion of your father, Abraham. Allah named you "Muslims" before [in former scriptures] and in this [revelation]... (al-Hajj/22:78)

Ibrahim and Ismail asked Allah to show them the ways to perform all kinds of worship in the context of performing worship, the place of wuquf, tawaf, sa'i, and so on, so that he and his descendants could perform worship in accordance with what Allah commanded.

In this verse, Ibrahim a.s. asks Allah to accept his repentance, even though Ibrahim is a prophet and messenger, as is his son. All prophets and messengers are protected by Allah from all kinds of sins (ma'sum). Therefore, the meaning of the prayer of Ibrahim and his son is:

1.  Ibrahim a.s. and his son Ismail a.s. ask Allah to forgive all unintentional mistakes, those that are unknown, and those that he did without his own will.

2.  As a guide for his descendants and followers in the future, to always purify themselves from all kinds of sins by repenting to Allah, and to maintain the sanctity of the place of performing the Hajj pilgrimage.

"Allah is the Accepter of Repentance" means that Allah Himself accepts the repentance of His servants, there is no other. He always accepts the repentance of His servants who truly repent and gives taufik (divine guidance) to always perform righteous deeds. "Allah is the Most Merciful" means that Allah is Most Merciful to His servants who repent by erasing sins and punishment from them.

Furthermore, Ibrahim a.s. prayed that Allah would raise a messenger from his descendants who would purify obedience to Him, to give good news, give guidance, and give warnings. Allah swt granted the prayer of Prophet Ibrahim by raising from his descendants prophets and messengers including Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), the last prophet. Rasulullah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

I am the prayer of Ibrahim and the good news that was given by Isa. (Narrated by Ahmad).

The characteristics of the messengers prayed for by Ibrahim a.s. are:

1.  Reciting the verses of Allah that have been revealed to them, so that the verses become lessons and guidance for their people. The verses contain teachings about the oneness of Allah, the existence of the Day of Resurrection and the Day of Judgment, the existence of rewards for those who do good deeds and punishment for those who disbelieve, guidance to the right path, and so on.

2.  Teaching them the Al-Kitab and Al-Hikmah. Al-Kitab is the Al-Qur'an. Al-Hikmah is knowing the secrets, benefits, laws of sharia, as well as the purpose and objective of the sending of the messengers, which is to be a good example for them so that they can take the straight path.

3.  "Purifying them" means purifying themselves and their souls from all kinds of shirk (associating partners with Allah), disbelief, evil, bad character, the nature of liking to damage society, and so on.

Ibrahim a.s. concludes his prayer by praising his Lord, namely by mentioning His attributes, the All-Mighty, and the All-Wise. "All-Mighty" means that no one can refute His words, and no one can prevent His actions. "All-Wise" means the One who creates everything and its use is in accordance with its nature, function, and benefit.

From the prayer of Prophet Ibrahim, it can be understood that he asked that his descendants be given taufik and hidayah (divine guidance), so that they can implement and develop the religion of Allah, build the civilization of mankind, and develop knowledge according to what is pleasing to Allah.

2.  As a guide for his descendants and followers in the future, to always purify themselves from all kinds of sins by repenting to Allah, and to maintain the sanctity of the place of performing the Hajj pilgrimage.

He always accepts the repentance of His servants who truly repent and gives taufik (divine guidance) to always perform righteous deeds. "Allah is the Most Merciful" means that Allah is the Most Merciful to His servants who repent by erasing sins and punishment from them.

Furthermore, Ibrahim a.s. prayed that Allah would raise a messenger from his descendants who would purify obedience to Him, to give good news, give guidance, and give warnings. Allah swt granted the prayer of Prophet Ibrahim by raising from his descendants prophets and messengers, including Prophet Muhammad saw, the last prophet. Rasulullah saw said:

I am the prayer of Ibrahim and the one who was proclaimed as good news by Isa. (Narrated by Ahmad).

The characteristics of the messengers prayed for by Ibrahim a.s. are:

1.  Reciting the verses of Allah that have been revealed to them, so that those verses become lessons and guidance for their people. The verses contain teachings about the oneness of Allah, the existence of the Day of Resurrection and the Day of Judgment, the existence of rewards for those who do good deeds and punishment for those who disbelieve, guidance to the right path, and so on.

2.  Teaching them the Al-Kitab and Al-Hikmah. Al-Kitab is the Al-Qur'an. Al-Hikmah is knowing the secrets, benefits, laws of sharia, as well as the purpose and objective of the sending of the messengers, which is to be a good example for them so that they can take the straight path.

3.  "Purifying them" means purifying themselves and their souls from all kinds of shirk (associating partners with Allah), disbelief, evil, bad character, the nature of liking to damage society, and so on.

Ibrahim a.s. concludes his prayer by praising his Lord, namely by mentioning His attributes, the All-Mighty, and the All-Wise. "All-Mighty" means that no one can refute His words, and no one can prevent His actions. "All-Wise" means the One who creates everything and its use is in accordance with its nature, function, and benefit.

From the prayer of Prophet Ibrahim, it can be understood that he asked that his descendants be given taufik and hidayah (divine guidance), so that they can implement and develop the religion of Allah, build the civilization of mankind, and develop knowledge according to what is pleasing to Allah.
text.129:
The Arabs are reminded that the one who built the Baitullah was their ancestor named Ibrahim and his son Ismail. Ibrahim is the ancestor of the Arabs through his son Ismail, while the Israelites are through his son Isaac. All Arabs follow the religion of Ibrahim.

From the verse, it can be understood that the one who built the Baitullah was Prophet Ibrahim and his son Ismail. The purpose was to worship Allah, not for anything else, as a reminder for themselves, which would be remembered by their descendants in the future. The materials for building the Kaaba were ordinary things, the same as other things, and not things that Allah deliberately sent down from the sky. All narrations that excessively describe the Kaaba are incorrect narrations, suspected to originate from Isra'iliyat. Regarding al-hajar al-Aswad (the Black Stone), 'Umar bin al-Khatthab r.a. said when he kissed it:

"From Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, that he kissed the Hajarul Aswad and said: "Indeed, I know that you are a stone that can neither harm nor benefit. If I had not seen the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, kissing you, I would not have kissed you." (Muttafaq 'Alaih)

According to a narration by ad-Daraqutni, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, once stated before kissing the Hajar Aswad that it was just an ordinary stone. Similarly, Abu Bakar r.a., and other companions. From the narrations above, it can be concluded that the Hajar Aswad is just an ordinary stone. The command to kiss it is related to worship, such as the command to pray facing the Kaaba, the command to throw pebbles at the jamrah during the Hajj pilgrimage, and so on. All of this is done solely to carry out the commands of Allah.

After Ibrahim and Ismail finished laying the foundation of the Kaaba, they both prayed: "Accept from us," (meaning: accept our deeds as righteous deeds, be pleased with them and reward us...) "Allah is All-Hearing" (meaning: Allah is All-Hearing of our prayers), and "Allah is All-Knowing" (meaning: Allah is All-Knowing of our intentions and purposes in building and establishing this Kaaba).

From the verse above, it can be inferred that it is sunnah (recommended) to pray and submit all our deeds to Allah after completing them. With this submission, it means that the duty of a servant is to perform righteous deeds for Allah, and Allah is the One who has the right to evaluate those deeds and reward them according to His evaluation.

From the verse above, it can also be understood that Ibrahim a.s. and his son, Ismail a.s., prayed to Allah after completing righteous deeds with the intention and purpose that the deed was solely done and performed for Allah. Because the nature and form of the deed they performed was believed to be in accordance with the commands of Allah, the father and son were also certain that their deeds would be accepted by Allah. This means that all kinds of prayers offered to Allah that have the same nature, form, and purpose as those performed by Ibrahim a.s. with his son, will surely be accepted by Allah and will surely be given a good reward from His side.

In the following verse (128), Ibrahim a.s. continues his prayer, that his descendants become a community that is submissive and obedient to Allah. In the word "Muslim" (submissive and obedient) is contained the understanding that the community that Ibrahim a.s. meant has the following characteristics:

1.  Purifying belief only to Allah. The heart of a Muslim only believes that the One who has the right to be worshiped and asked for help is only Allah, the One and Only. This belief stems from the Muslim's awareness that he is under the supervision and power of Allah. Only Allah can make decisions about him.

2.  All actions, obedience, and submission are done only for and to Allah, not because of following desires, not because of wanting to be praised and seen as good by people, not because of rank and position, and not because of worldly gains.

If belief and submission are not purely to Allah, then Allah is no longer a protector for them. Allah says:

Have you seen he who has taken as his god his [own] desire, then would you be responsible for him? (al-Furqan/25:43)

Allah allows to go astray those who make their desires as their god and seals their hearts, because Allah knows that they do not accept the guidance given to them. Allah says:

Then have you seen he who has taken as his god his [own] desire, and Allah has sent him astray due to knowledge and has set a seal upon his hearing and his heart and put over his vision a veil? ¦. (al-Jasiyah/45:23)

In verse 124 previously, Ibrahim a.s. prayed that his descendants be made imams, Allah answered, "The descendants of Ibrahim who are unjust are not included in that prayer." Therefore, in verse 128, Ibrahim a.s. prays that some of his family be made people who are submissive and obedient to Allah.

In relation to the verse above, there is an indication that what is meant by his descendants is Ismail a.s. and his descendants who will be left in Mecca, while he himself returns to Syria. It is the descendants of Ismail a.s. who inhabit Mecca and its surroundings, including the Prophet Muhammad saw. This is what is meant by the word of Allah.

¦. (Follow) the religion of your father, Ibrahim. It is He (Allah) who named you Muslims before, and in this (Quran)¦ (al-hajj/22:78)

Ibrahim and Ismail asked Allah to show them how to perform all kinds of worship in order to perform worship, places of wuquf, tawaf, sa'i, and so on, so that he and his descendants could perform worship in accordance with what Allah commanded.

In this verse, Ibrahim a.s. asks Allah to accept his repentance, even though Ibrahim is a prophet and messenger, as is his son. All prophets and messengers are protected by Allah from all kinds of sins (ma'sum). Therefore, the meaning of the prayer of Ibrahim and his son is:

1.  Ibrahim a.s. and his son Ismail a.s. ask Allah to forgive all unintentional mistakes, those that are unknown, and those that he did without his own will.

2.  As a guide for his descendants and followers in the future, to always purify themselves from all kinds of sins by repenting to Allah, and to maintain the sanctity of the place of performing the Hajj pilgrimage.

"Allah is the Accepter of Repentance" means that Allah Himself accepts the repentance of His servants, there is no other. He always accepts the repentance of His servants who truly repent and gives taufik (divine guidance) to always perform righteous deeds. "Allah is the Most Merciful" means that Allah is the Most Merciful to His servants who repent by erasing sins and punishment from them.

Furthermore, Ibrahim a.s. prayed that Allah would raise a messenger from his descendants who would purify obedience to Him, to give good news, give guidance, and give warnings. Allah swt granted the prayer of Prophet Ibrahim by raising from his descendants prophets and messengers including Prophet Muhammad saw, the last prophet. Rasulullah saw said:

I am the prayer of Ibrahim and the one who was proclaimed as good news by Isa. (Narrated by Ahmad).

The characteristics of the messengers that Ibrahim a.s. prayed for are:

1.  Reciting the verses of Allah that have been revealed to them, so that the verses become lessons and guidance for their people. The verses contain teachings about the oneness of Allah, the existence of the Day of Resurrection and the Day of Judgment, the existence of rewards for those who do good deeds and punishment for those who disbelieve, guidance to the right path, and so on.

2.  Teaching them Al-Kitab and Al-Hikmah. Al-Kitab is Al-Qur'an. Al-Hikmah is knowing the secrets, benefits, laws of sharia, as well as the purpose and objective of the sending of the messengers, which is to be a good example for them so that they can take the straight path.

3.  "Purifying them" means purifying themselves and their souls from all kinds of shirk, disbelief, evil, bad character, the nature of liking to damage society, and so on.

Ibrahim a.s. closes his prayer by praising his Lord, namely by mentioning His attributes, the All-Mighty, and the All-Wise. "All-Mighty" means that no one can refute His words, and no one can prevent His actions. "All-Wise" means the One who creates everything and its use is in accordance with its nature, use, and benefit.

From the prayer of Prophet Ibrahim, it can be understood that he asked that his descendants be given taufik and hidayah (divine guidance), so that they can implement and develop the religion of Allah, build the civilization of mankind, and develop knowledge according to what is pleasing to Allah.
text.130:
This verse does not explain the religion of Ibrahim. Other verses explain the foundations of Ibrahim's religious beliefs. Allah says:

"Say, "Allah has told the truth." So follow the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth; and he was not of those who associate others with Allah." (Ali 'Imran/3: 95).

In another verse, it is explained that the religion of Ibrahim, or the religion of Islam, is the religion brought by Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Allah says:

"Then We inspired to you, [O Muhammad], to follow the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth; and he was not of those who associate others with Allah." (an-Nahl/16: 123)

"So direct your face toward the religion, inclining to truth. [Adhere to] the fitrah of Allah upon which He has created [all] people. No change should there be in the creation of Allah. That is the correct religion, but most of the people do not know. [Return] in repentance to Him, and fear Him, and establish prayer and do not be of those who associate others with Allah" (ar-Rum/30: 30-31)

The Jews, Christians, and polytheists of Mecca, including the descendants of Ibrahim (peace be upon him), boast about him, but they do not follow the religion of Ibrahim, the religion conveyed by Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), the Prophet whom Ibrahim prayed would be sent by Allah in the future. They know this, but they act as if they do not know it. In fact, most of them follow a religion created by their own desires, which is to worship idols, associate partners with Allah, say that Allah has a son, and so on. This verse is good news for Ibrahim (peace be upon him), that he has been chosen by Allah in this world from among His servants and in the Hereafter will be among the righteous.
text.131:
Ibrahim was commanded to submit, acknowledging the oneness of Allah and purifying obedience solely to Him. What is meant by "submit" here is to be submissive and obedient to the religion of Allah, a religion that is in accordance with reason accompanied by clear arguments or evidence. This religion will be continued in its conveyance by the messengers who come later, including the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).

Therefore, Ibrahim (peace be upon him) immediately answered Allah's command without asking anything, "I submit to the Lord of all the worlds." The meaning is, "I purify my obedience and submission only to Allah. I turn my face to Him. My worship, my life, and my death are for the Lord of all the worlds."

"Indeed, I have turned my face toward He who created the heavens and the earth, inclining toward truth, and I am not of those who associate others with Allah." (al-An'am/6: 79)
text.132:
Ibrahim and Jacob bequeathed to their sons, as did Jacob's grandson to his sons, that Allah had chosen the best religion for them and reminded them to adhere to that religion forever, and not to die except in a state of Muslim. The religion referred to is the religion of Islam. Allah affirms that the true religion in His sight is the religion of Islam. Allah says:

Indeed, the religion in the sight of Allah is Islam. And those who were given the Scripture did not differ except after knowledge had come to them - out of jealous animosity between themselves. And whoever disbelieves in the verses of Allah, then indeed, Allah is swift in account. (Ali 'Imran/3: 19)

And whoever desires other than Islam as religion - never will it be accepted from him, and he, in the Hereafter, will be among the losers. (Ali 'Imran/3: 85)

The religion brought by Ibrahim is also found in the book of Musa (Torah). Allah SWT says:

Indeed, this is in the former scriptures, The scriptures of Abraham and Moses. (al-A'la/87: 18,19)

Say, "We have believed in Allah and in what has been revealed to us and what has been revealed to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, and the Descendants, and in what was given to Moses and Jesus and to the prophets from their Lord. ¦" (al-Baqarah/2: 136)

Allah does not differentiate between the prophets and messengers He sent. Allah says:

"¦We make no distinction between any of them, and to Him we submit." (al-Baqarah/2: 136)

Therefore, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims to believe in His prophets and messengers. Belief in the prophets and messengers and what they brought is one of the pillars of faith.

From the statement "Ibrahim bequeathed..." it can be understood:

1. That what is bequeathed is something very important. It is dangerous for life if the will is not carried out. Therefore, the following words are used in the verse:

a. "Wasiat" (bequeathed) not "memerintahkan" (commanded). The word "wasiat" indicates that something is very important.

b. "Anak-anaknya" (his children), not "orang lain" (other people). According to custom, bequeathing to "one's own children" is expected to be more likely to be carried out than bequeathing to other people.

2. In this verse, it is mentioned that those who bequeathed were Ibrahim a.s. and Yakub a.s. as if the words were separated. This gives the understanding that those who are told to carry out the will are not only the descendants of Ibrahim a.s. and his grandson Yakub a.s. (Bani Israil) alone, but the will includes all the descendants of Ibrahim and all Muslims, including the descendants of Ismail a.s.
text.133:
This verse is directed towards the Jews, when they asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), "Do you not know that Jacob, in his final days, bequeathed to his sons to embrace the Jewish religion?" Then this verse was revealed, refuting their statement.

This verse challenges the truth of the Jews' statement, questioning why they dared to say such a thing. Were they present when Jacob made his will, so that they could say Jacob was Jewish or Christian? No, they were not present, therefore do not fabricate, saying something that is not true, such as saying that Abraham was Jewish or Christian, and so on. What Jacob bequeathed to his sons was that they should worship Allah, the One God, that they should adhere to Islam, the religion followed by Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, Jesus, and the prophets.
text.134: This verse alludes to past communities and their deeds, namely the community of Prophet Ibrahim and the prophets he prayed for, which have been explained in the previous verse. This verse affirms that people are judged and rewarded based on their deeds; no one can help them besides Allah.
text.135:
*hanif* means "straight," not inclined towards falsehood. "The *hanif* religion is the true religion, the religion that can reach the right path, the path to happiness in this world and the hereafter. Indeed, it is a religion that has not been mixed with anything and has not deviated even slightly from its origin.

This verse seems to instruct the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to say, "O Jews, Christians, and polytheists of Mecca, we do not follow your religion." In it, there is no guidance to the right path, and because that religion has been greatly interfered with by human hands, but we will follow the religion of Abraham that you boast about, because in that religion, obedience is purified only to Allah, and because that religion has not been interfered with by human hands at all.

The phrase "Muslims follow the *hanif* religion of Abraham" is to make the Jews and Christians aware of their actions. They claim to be descendants of Abraham (peace be upon him), but they do not behave, have character, and think like Abraham (peace be upon him). They claim to be followers of the religion of Abraham, but they have changed it and do not maintain it as Abraham (peace be upon him) did.

From this verse, it can be understood that Allah reminds the Ummah of Muhammad to always be vigilant about their religion and always be guided by the Al-Qur'an and the Sunnah of the Prophet, never following their desires to the point of daring to change, add to, or subtract from the religion of Allah.

From the statement "and he (Abraham) was not of the polytheists," it can be understood that the religion of Abraham is the religion of Tawhid, the religion that acknowledges the oneness and power of Allah. Allah says:

And [mention, O Muhammad], when We designated for Abraham the site of the House, [saying], "Do not associate anything with Me and purify My House for those who perform Tawaf and those who stand [in prayer] and those who bow and prostrate." (al-hajj/22:26)
text.136:
This verse provides guidance on how to present rebuttals and arguments in exchanging ideas, namely by comparing the foundations of one religion with another, and so on.

Al-Asbat are the descendants of the Prophet Jacob (peace be upon him). What is meant by "believing in the prophets" mentioned above is believing in the prophets of Allah, who were commanded to invite people in their time to believe in Allah. The fundamental principles of religion brought by the prophets are the same, namely monotheism (tauhid).

The statement "we submit to Him" is a sharp insinuation directed at the Jews, Christians, and polytheists of Mecca. Because they claimed and acknowledged themselves as followers of Abraham (peace be upon him), while Abraham (peace be upon him) did not associate partners with Allah, as they had done.
text.137:
The confession of faith of the People of the Book differs from the confession of faith of the Muslims. The People of the Book only believe in the previous prophets who were sent to them from the descendants of Israel, not believing in the other prophets of Allah. Their faith is influenced by their own desires. Therefore, they dare to add to and subtract from the religion of Allah. Those who believe and follow their desires are those who are in enmity with the Muslims.

From the statement "indeed are in enmity with you" it can be understood that among the People of the Book there is a feeling of dislike for the Messenger of Allah (saw). This feeling is not because they dislike the religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad, but because the last messenger was not appointed from their group. The statement "Allah will protect you from them" is a promise from Allah to Muhammad (saw) and the Muslims that Allah will surely protect and grant them victory in the struggle to uphold the religion of Allah.
text.138:
True faith is faith that is not mixed with elements of shirk (polytheism). Ibn Jarir said, "Indeed, when the children of Christians are born, they come to the priest on the seventh day and bathe them with water called 'al-Ma'mudi' to baptize them. They say, "This is a purification to replace circumcision." So when they have done this, the child becomes a true Christian." Then Allah revealed this verse."

Sibghah Allah means "the dye of Allah." The meaning is faith in Allah that is not accompanied by even a little shirk. This is emphasized by the statement "and to Him alone do we worship," not to others. This is emphasized by the word of Allah:

So direct your face toward the religion, inclining to truth. (Adhere to) the fitrah (nature) of Allah upon which He has created (all) people. No change should there be in the creation of Allah. That is the correct religion, but most of the people do not know. (ar-Rum/30:30)

This verse explains that in resolving matters related to religion, religious rules or arguments must be used, and it should not be based on desires and human wishes. From the verse above, it can be understood that humans cannot erase or cleanse the sins of other humans, or accept their repentance as the Christians do by baptizing their children. What cleanses and erases a person's sins is that person's own efforts in accordance with Allah's guidance, and only Allah can accept a person's repentance.
text.139:
It is narrated that the Jews and Christians said, "It is obligatory for people to follow our religion, because the prophets came from us and the religion was revealed to us, it was never promised to the Arabs." So Allah rejected their opinion with this verse.

With this verse, the claims of the Jews and Christians have been answered by affirming that there is no reason for them to say such a thing. Allah is the Lord of all the worlds, the Creator and Owner of all creatures. The degree of a person is not measured by nation, lineage, or rank, but is measured by their deeds and actions. The influence of these actions is evident in each person and their behavior. Good deeds have a good influence, while bad deeds have a bad influence. Only Allah can judge those deeds.

The influence of bad deeds on the Jews and Christians is reflected in their words. Allah says:

"And they (the Jews and Christians) say, "None will enter Paradise except one who is a Jew or a Christian." That is (merely) their wishful thinking. Say, "Produce your proof, if you should be truthful." (al-Baqarah/2:111).

And they say, "Be Jews or Christians that you may be guided." Say, "Rather, [we follow] the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth, and he was not of those who associate others with Allah." (al-Baqarah/2:135).

The end of this verse affirms that the true religion is the religion based on Tawhid, the religion that purifies obedience to Allah alone. That is the religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad saw, for all mankind until the end of time.
text.140:
This verse explains another admission from the Jews and Christians, namely that all prophets and messengers acknowledged their religion. They exerted all sorts of efforts to strengthen and justify their statements, even though such efforts were forbidden by Allah.

Allah reveals the error of the Jews and Christians who presented arguments in an attempt to justify their statements. The error was that they claimed Ibrahim, Ismail, Isaac, Jacob, and his descendants adhered to Judaism and Christianity, even though those prophets existed before Judaism and Christianity even existed. The term "Jew" only became known after the death of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him), and the term Christian only arose and became known after the death of Prophet Isa (peace be upon him). Why did they say such a thing, when it did not correspond to historical reality and correct logic? Was it because they knew more, or did Allah know more? Did they intentionally utter those words simply to refute the prophethood of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)?

The intention of the Jews and Christians in uttering such words is explained by the following sentence, which is to conceal the *syahadah* of Allah. The "*syahadah* of Allah" is the testimony of Allah mentioned in the Torah and the Gospel that Ibrahim (peace be upon him) and his descendants were not followers of Judaism nor were they followers of Christianity, and that Allah would send Muhammad as the last prophet and messenger who would come from the descendants of Ismail (peace be upon him).

The act of "concealing the *syahadah* of Allah" is among the most unjust deeds in the sight of Allah, because that act results in misleading people from the path of Allah, the path of truth, and the path of happiness. Therefore, Allah warns them that Allah is not unaware in the slightest of all kinds of deeds of His servants, whether visible or invisible, whether great or small.
text.141:
Allah states that Ibrahim, Ismail, Ishaq, Yaqub, and their descendants, as well as past communities, will be given rewards according to their deeds, and you are not burdened with responsibility for their actions. You who are present now should do good deeds and will receive rewards according to the deeds you perform.

This verse is a warning to the Ummah of Muhammad to always preserve the religion of Allah. Do not be influenced by desires to the point of daring to alter the religion of Allah, as the Jews and Christians have done. This verse explains the form of responsibility of each person. Each person is responsible to Allah for what they do. Allah does not burden one person's sins upon another.
text.142:
This verse was revealed in Medina concerning the change of the Qibla for Muslims from Baitulmaqdis (Masjidilaqsa) to Baitullah (Masjidilharam). Prophet Muhammad saw and the Muslims, while still in Mecca, performed prayers facing Baitulmaqdis, as had been done by previous prophets; but he had a desire and hope that the Qibla would be moved to the Ka'bah, which is located in the Masjidilharam in Mecca. Therefore, he tried to combine the two Qiblas by facing the Ka'bah and Baitulmaqdis simultaneously, by praying on the south side of the Ka'bah facing north, because Baitulmaqdis is also located to the north.

After he migrated to Medina, it was certainly no longer possible to do so, because the Ka'bah is not located north of the city of Medina, no longer in the same direction as Baitulmaqdis. Thus, after being in Medina, he only faced Baitulmaqdis when praying. This lasted for 16 months, and he prayed that Allah would establish the Ka'bah as the Qibla, as a replacement for Baitulmaqdis. He raised his face to the sky, awaiting revelation from Allah swt with full hope, without uttering a word, as one of Allah's noble and submissive servants. Not long after, this verse was revealed, ordering the change of the Qibla from Baitulmaqdis to the Ka'bah. This verse was revealed in the month of Rajab in the second year of Hijri. This verse also serves as an answer to the mockery of the polytheists and the denial of the Jews and the hypocrites regarding the change of the Qibla.

Those who deny and mock the change of the Qibla are called in this verse "those who are foolish" (sufaha'/pandir). They criticize without knowing the fundamental issues in the matter of changing the Qibla. They do not realize that the four directions, namely east, west, north and south, all belong to Allah swt, and none has superiority over the other. Thus, if Allah commands His servants to face one direction in prayer, it is not because that direction is more noble than the others, but solely to test their obedience to His commands and regulations.

The Jews, polytheists, and hypocrites who denied the change of the Qibla are called by God "those who are foolish" (pandir). They asked the reason for the change. Prophet Muhammad saw was commanded by Allah to give us an answer by saying that all directions belong to Allah. If He determines the Qibla for the Muslims, then it is to unite them in worship. It is only that those who are foolish have made stones and buildings the basis of religion. In fact, the advantage and virtue of a direction is not because of its essence, but because it has been chosen and determined by Allah swt.

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that Allah guides whom He wills to the straight path. So whoever obeys and obeys the commands of Allah will surely receive His guidance to obtain happiness in this world and the hereafter. Conversely, those who deny and disbelieve in His religion will certainly not receive His guidance or hidayah.
text.143:
The Muslim community is *ummatan wasathan*, a community that receives guidance from Allah SWT, so that they become a just and chosen community and will be witnesses against the denial of those who disbelieve. Muslims must always uphold justice and truth, defend what is right, and eliminate what is false. In all matters of life, they are in the middle ground between those who prioritize material things in their lives and those who only prioritize the afterlife. Thus, Muslims become just and chosen witnesses against those who rely on material things, who forget the rights of divinity and tend to satisfy their desires. They also become witnesses against those who are excessive in religious matters, so that they detach themselves from all physical pleasures by restraining themselves from a normal life. Muslims become witnesses over all of them, because of their just and chosen nature, and in carrying out their daily lives they always take the middle path. Likewise, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) is a witness for his community, that his community is the best community created to give guidance to mankind with *amar makruf nahi mungkar* (enjoining good and forbidding evil).

Then it is explained that the change of the *qibla* from Baitulmaqdis to the Ka'bah was to test people, who among them truly believe and follow the Messenger and who are weak in faith, deviating from the straight path. Indeed, the transfer of the *qibla* was felt very heavy by those who were fanatical about the first *qibla*, because people in general find it difficult to change and abandon their habits. But those who receive guidance from Allah by knowing the laws of their religion and the secrets of its *sharia*, they realize that performing worship facing the *qibla* is solely because of Allah's command, not because of a hidden secret in that place, and that the placement of the *qibla* is to gather people in one direction and for the unity of the *ummah*.

To eliminate the doubts of some Muslims about the reward of their prayers while they faced Baitulmaqdis before, Allah explains that He will never waste the faith and deeds of those who obey the Messenger because Allah is Most Gracious and Most Merciful.
text.144:
As has been explained in the narration regarding the reason for the revelation of the verse above, the Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, greatly desired that the qibla be established by Allah towards the Ka'bah. Therefore, he often turned his face towards the sky, awaiting the revelation that would command the transfer of the qibla. Then, this verse was revealed, establishing the transfer of the qibla from Baitulmakdis to the Masjidilharam. Here, the direction of the Masjidilharam, not the Ka'bah, is mentioned, as an indication that it is permissible for us to face "towards the Ka'bah" during prayer if the Ka'bah is far from us and cannot be seen. Conversely, if we are close to the Ka'bah, then we face the Ka'bah during prayer.

So it is not obligatory to face the building of the Ka'bah itself, except for those who can see it. Thus, all Muslims in various parts of the earth are obligated to face "towards the Ka'bah" in prayer. To carry out this task, they are obligated (wajib kifayah) to know geography to determine the direction of the qibla in prayer, just as they should know astronomy to determine the schedule of prayer times.

The transfer of the qibla to the Ka'bah is a true decree from Allah, but those who lack intellect dispute this truth, even creating slander and spreading doubts among Muslims who are weak in faith.
text.145: People of such character cannot be expected to return to the truth. They will remain in error even if given reasons, explanations, and clear evidence. Therefore, they will not be willing to follow the qibla of the Muslim community. Even among themselves, the Jews and Christians maintain their respective qiblas. If the Muslims were to follow their desires, they would certainly be among the wrongdoers.
text.146:
The Jews knew that what Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) brought was true, because they already knew Prophet Muhammad from their own scriptures. This is explained in Allah Almighty's saying:

"(Those) who follow the Messenger, the unlettered prophet, whom they find written in what they have of the Torah and the Gospel, who enjoins upon them what is right and forbids them what is wrong and makes lawful for them the good things and prohibits for them the evil and relieves them of their burden and the shackles which were upon them. So they who have believed in him, honored him, supported him and followed the light which was sent down with him - it is those who will be the successful." (al-A'raf/ 7: 157)

The Jews knew Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) because he had been mentioned in the Torah (see al-A'raf/7:157 and its tafsir) with his characteristics and personality even more than they knew their own children.

It is narrated from Umar that he met a Jewish priest who had converted to Islam named Abdullah bin Salam, who said, "I know Prophet Muhammad better than I know my own son." Umar asked him, "Why?" He replied, "Because I have no doubt whatsoever that Muhammad is a prophet, whereas regarding my son, there is always the possibility that his mother has been unfaithful." Then Umar kissed Abdullah bin Salam's head.

Some Jews denied and concealed the truth that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was a prophet and that the Ka'bah was the qibla, but some of them acknowledged the truth and believed in and accepted his guidance.
text.147:
The truth is what Allah has revealed to His Messenger, not what the Jews and Christians say.

In this matter, Muslims should not doubt. The issue of the qibla is not actually a fundamental issue as a basis of religion like tawhid, belief in the Day of Judgment, and others, but the qibla is only a direction that each ummah is commanded to face in their prayers.
text.148: Every people has their own Qibla. Prophet Ibrahim and Prophet Ismail, peace be upon them, faced the Ka'bah. The Children of Israel faced Baitulmakdis, and the Christians faced the east. The principle is to believe in Allah and obey all His commands. Because Allah has commanded the Muslims to face the Ka'bah in prayer, the slander and mockery of the disbelievers should not be heeded. Instead, the Muslims should work diligently, perform good deeds, repent, and compete in doing good. Allah will gather mankind to reckon and recompense all their deeds, and Allah is All-Powerful over all things; nothing can weaken Him from gathering all mankind on the Day of Reckoning.
text.149:
The command to face the Masjidilharam is repeated in these two verses to clarify that the command is general for all people, times, and places, because it is very important and there is wisdom contained within it, namely so that there is no longer any reason for the People of the Book, the polytheists, and the hypocrites to oppose the Prophet in the matter of changing the qibla.

The same applies to the polytheists who believed that the Prophet, from the descendants of Ibrahim, would come to revive his religion, so it was not fitting for him to face anything other than the Ka'bah, which was built by the Prophet Ibrahim.

Thus, the arguments of the People of the Book and the polytheists are invalidated. The unjust among them who hurl mockery and refutations without reasons based on common sense and revelation need not be considered or heeded. As for their mockery, it is as follows:

The Jews said, "Muhammad only changed the qibla to the Ka'bah because of his inclination towards the religion of his people and his love for his country; if he were upon the truth, he would have remained facing the qibla of the previous prophets."

The polytheists said, "He has returned to our qibla and will return to our religion." And the hypocrites said, "The changing of the qibla indicates that Muhammad is in doubt and has no firm stance." Such were the fabricated reasons made by the opponents of Islam at that time.
text.150:
The command to face the Masjidilharam is repeated in these two verses to clarify that the command is general for all people, times, and places, because it is very important and contains wisdom within it, namely so that there is no longer any reason for the People of the Book, the polytheists, and the hypocrites to oppose the Prophet in the matter of changing the Qibla.

The same applies to the polytheists who believed that the Prophet from the lineage of Ibrahim would come to revive his religion, so it is not fitting if he faces other than the Ka'bah which was built by the Prophet Ibrahim.

Thus, the arguments of the People of the Book and the polytheists are invalidated. The unjust among them who hurl ridicule and refutations without reasons based on common sense and information from revelation need not be considered or heeded. As for their ridicule, it is as follows:

The Jews said, "Muhammad only changed the Qibla to the Ka'bah because of his inclination towards the religion of his people and his love for his country; if he were upon the truth, he would have remained facing the Qibla of the prophets before him."

The polytheists said, "He has returned to our Qibla and will return to our religion." And the hypocrites said, "The shifting of the Qibla indicates that Muhammad is in doubt and has no conviction." Such were the fabricated reasons made by the opponents of Islam at that time.
text.151: Among the perfections of blessings is by sending a messenger, namely Muhammad saw, who recites the verses of Allah, frees the people from the disease of shirk and the evils of jahiliyyah, teaches the Al-Qur'an and wisdom (hikmah), and teaches what they did not know, so that the Muslim community becomes a community that leads humanity towards progress and happiness.
text.152:
Therefore, with the blessings that Allah has bestowed upon the Muslims, let them always remember Him, both in their hearts and with their tongues, by way of tahmid (saying al-hamdulillah), tasbih (saying Subhanallah), and reciting the Qur'an, while contemplating His creation in order to know, realize, and absorb the signs of His greatness, power, and oneness.

If they always remember Allah, He will also always remember them. Let them be grateful to Him for all the blessings He has bestowed, by carrying out the provisions He has established, and by praising and glorifying Him, and acknowledging His goodness. In addition, let them not be ungrateful for His blessings by wasting them and using them outside the lines He has determined.
text.153: The struggle to uphold the truth must be accompanied by patience and increasing prayer, so that all difficulties and trials become light, because Allah is always with those who are patient. He will help, strengthen, and grant victory to those who strive to uphold the truth of His religion.
text.154:
Maintaining the Islamic religion is a struggle. Every struggle will demand sacrifice. Some will lose possessions or family, and some will fall on the battlefield, and so on.

Those who fall on the battlefield are *syuhada* (martyrs) in the path of Allah. They occupy a very noble place. So do not think that they are dead, but rather they are alive in another realm. It's just that humans are unaware of their life and do not know its reality. They live in an unseen realm (*alam gaib*) where the souls of the *syuhada* are privileged from the souls of other humans. Their spirit and ideals of struggle will be continued by subsequent generations, so they will remain alive forever.
text.155: Allah will test the Muslims with various fears, hunger, lack of wealth, lives, and fruits (foodstuffs). Through this test, the Muslims will become a people who are mentally strong, firm in their faith, steadfast in their souls, and resilient in facing trials and tribulations. They will receive the predicate of being patient, and they are the ones who will receive good tidings from Allah.
text.156: Allah commands Prophet Muhammad (saw) to inform about the characteristics of those who receive good news, namely those who are patient. When they are afflicted with a calamity, they say: Inna lillahi wa inna ilaihi raji'un (Indeed, we belong to Allah, and indeed to Him we will return).
text.157: The glad tidings are the news that those who are patient receive blessings, forgiveness, mercy, and praise from Allah, and they are the ones who are guided to the right path.
text.158:
In this verse, the good news is reaffirmed by explaining that Safa and Marwah are among the places of worship, and whoever wants to perform the Hajj pilgrimage must perform Sa'i between Safa and Marwah. Thus, it is clear that the Muslims will surely succeed in conquering the city of Mecca, because Mecca is the place to perform the Hajj pilgrimage, which is the fifth pillar of Islam that must be performed by every Muslim who is able to do so. Therefore, the Masjidilharam and its surroundings must be cleansed of idols and polytheism (shirk).

Although there are differences of opinion among the imams of the schools of thought (mazhab) regarding the ruling on Sa'i; some consider it a pillar (rukun) of Hajj, such as Imam Malik and Imam Shafi'i, and some consider it an obligation (wajib) of Hajj, such as Imam Abu Hanifah, it is clear that Sa'i must be performed in carrying out the Hajj pilgrimage.

Generally, there is no difference between a pillar (rukun) and an obligation (wajib), but specifically in the matter of Hajj, a distinction is made between the two. A pillar (rukun) is something that must be done and cannot be replaced or redeemed. An obligation (wajib) is something that must be done, but if it is missed, it must be replaced by paying a penalty (dam). The question here is why this verse mentions "there is no blame on him for performing Sa'i between them" when it is a pillar (rukun) that is obligatory (wajib), and it is impossible for someone who performs a pillar (rukun) or obligation (wajib) to be blamed.

This is to eliminate the doubts of the Muslims about performing Sa'i, because the polytheists also performed Sa'i in their worship, as if what the polytheists did should not be done by the Muslims and they would be blamed if they did it. So it must be understood that the purpose of the polytheists performing Sa'i is different from that of the Muslims. Performing Sa'i is proof or manifestation of faith in Allah and obedience to His commands.

Then Allah explains that whoever does good deeds or acts of worship more than what is obligated upon him (performing the sunnah acts), Allah will be appreciative of those good deeds, and Allah is All-Knowing of all the deeds of His servants. So do not hesitate to do good, because all those deeds will be rewarded manifold by Allah.
text.159:
This verse was revealed concerning the Jewish priests. They concealed from their people the characteristics of the Prophet Muhammad mentioned in their holy scriptures, so that the Jews would not convert to Islam. The People of the Book always concealed the truth of Islam and the truth of the Prophet Muhammad, even though it was written clearly and explicitly in their books. These people deserve to be cursed by Allah and distanced from His mercy and compassion, and it is fitting that curses be invoked upon them by the angels and all of mankind. The ruling regarding the curse for those who conceal true knowledge must be disseminated and developed, not only limited to the People of the Book, but also encompassing all those who behave in that manner.

This is strengthened by a hadith of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) narrated by Abu Hurairah, who said:

"Whoever is asked about some knowledge that he knows but refuses to explain it to the questioner, Allah will bridle him with a bridle of fire on the Day of Resurrection." (Narrated by Ibn Majah from Abu Hurairah).

Abu Hurairah said, "If it were not for fear of Allah's threat in this verse (verse 159), I would not have narrated any hadith from the Messenger of Allah." Therefore, a Muslim is obligated to convey the knowledge he possesses, whether it is religious knowledge or general knowledge, that is beneficial to society. If it is known that there will be a violation of religious law, or a deviation from the correct creed, such as the spread of *bid'ah* from schools of belief that contradict *tauhid*, the scholars must rise up simultaneously to prevent it, both with speech and writing. In this way, the sanctity and purity of religion will be preserved.

The Jews are cursed because they always conceal the truth. When they see something *mungkar* or untrue, they remain silent and do not try to prevent or correct it.
text.160: Those who repent from their mistakes and negligence, improve themselves by drawing closer to Allah, explain and spread the knowledge they possess, and dare to uphold truth and fight against evil are excluded and freed from the curse of Allah. For those who are like that, even though they have already made mistakes, Allah still provides forgiveness, because Allah is Most Forgiving and Most Merciful. So, let no one despair of Allah's mercy and guidance, no matter how great and numerous their mistakes and sins, because the door of repentance and Allah's mercy is open as wide as possible for those who are aware and want to improve themselves.
text.161:
Those who disbelieve, including the People of the Book who do not repent, then die in disbelief, they will remain under the curse of Allah, the angels, and all of mankind. They will abide in Hell forever, their punishment will not be lightened, nor will it be postponed. Such is their fate on the Day of Judgment; there will be no more opportunity to repent and perform righteous deeds, and even if they were able to give gold as great as the earth to redeem their sins, it would certainly not be accepted by Allah, as mentioned in His word:

Indeed, those who disbelieve and die while they are disbelievers - never will there be accepted from any of them the [whole] earth full of gold, even if they should seek to ransom themselves with it. For those there will be a painful punishment, and they will have no helpers. (Ali 'Imran/3: 91)
text.162:
Those who disbelieve, including the People of the Book who do not repent, then die in disbelief, they will remain under the curse of Allah, the angels, and all of mankind. They will abide in Hell forever, their punishment will not be lightened, nor will it be postponed. Such is their fate on the Day of Judgment, there will be no more opportunity to repent and do good deeds, and even if they were able to give gold the size of the earth to redeem their sins, it would certainly not be accepted by Allah, as mentioned in His word:

Indeed, those who disbelieve and die while they are disbelievers - never will there be accepted from any of them the [whole] capacity of the earth in gold, even if he should offer it as ransom. For those there will be a painful punishment, and they will have no helpers. (Ali 'Imran/3: 91)
text.163:
Allah, the One and Only God, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. He alone is worthy of worship, and it is forbidden to associate partners with Him by worshipping idols and the like, as some of the People of the Book do, as mentioned in His word:

"They have taken their scholars and monks as lords besides Allah, and [also] the Messiah, the son of Mary. And they were not commanded except to worship one God; there is no deity except Him. Exalted is He above whatever they associate with Him." (at-Taubah/9: 31).

He is the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful, whose mercy is vast and abundant, and it is not permissible to seek help (in matters beyond the capacity of human nature) except from Him, because seeking mercy and help from other than Him is shirk and means acknowledging power other than His power.
text.164:
He is the One who created the heavens and the earth for the needs of mankind. Therefore, humans should pay attention to and contemplate the blessings of Allah, the Most Holy. By observing the contents of the universe, their conviction in His Oneness and Power will increase, and their knowledge of His creation will expand. This knowledge can be utilized as desired by Allah, the All-Knowing.

In this verse, Allah swt "guides" humans to see, observe, and contemplate everything that exists and occurs around them by mentioning His creations. The creation of the heavens and the earth is truly laden with secrets and signs of Allah swt's greatness. Some of Allah's creations are directly visible and their benefits are obvious, making them easy to understand. However, understanding others requires a long and deep process of thought and contemplation.

Human efforts to understand the secrets and signs of Allah's greatness have also driven them closer to Him. Understanding the magnificence, sophistication, and harmony of the universe has made many scientists increasingly aware and convinced that everything in the universe is deliberately planned, created, arranged, and maintained by Him.

The development of science and technology has led humans to the conclusion that the Solar System, consisting of millions of stars or perhaps even more (including our Earth), is only a small part of the Milky Way Galaxy, which contains more than 100 billion stars. And the Milky Way is just one of over 500 billion galaxies in the known universe.

Indeed, all the stars in the universe are in their respective predetermined orbits (adz-dzariyat/51:7). Galaxies also have orbits in the universe, moving at high speeds in established orbits. As they move, none of these celestial bodies intersect or collide with other celestial bodies.

Similarly, regarding the earth, His creation, everything demonstrates the perfection of its Creator. Allah says, which means:

"And on the earth are signs for those of assured faith." (adz-dzariyat/51:20)

A modern science encyclopedia describes the chemical elements on our earth as having amazing variations. Some are rare because they are difficult to find, while others are abundant. Some can be seen with the naked eye because they are in the form of liquids and solids, but others are invisible because they are gases. This reality should guide us to be increasingly impressed with the majesty and oneness of its Creator, Allah swt.

The alternating occurrence of day and night invites us to think about the existence of perfect regulation. The question that arises is, "Who regulates all of that?" The alternation of night and day, and the rotation between the two, the length and shortness of time, and the existence of various seasons, are perfect climate regulations that are comfortably conditioned for human habitation. The word *al-fulk* in this verse means ark or boat. Making a boat requires knowledge of the properties of water, the movement of wind, air, clouds related to seasons, basic principles of fluid physics, and other basic laws, such as Archimedes' law for floating objects, or concepts of design and construction. Finally, humans can make ships or boats to sail the oceans so they can explore the corners of the earth. In the alternation of night and day, there are clues about time and direction because both are needed in navigation. From this natural phenomenon, humans also created astronomy and knowledge of weather, which are very useful for fulfilling human needs. Allah says, which means:

"And it is He who has placed for you the stars that you may be guided by them through the darknesses of the land and sea..." (al-An'am/6:97). Then, "He sends down water from the sky."

In the Al-Qur'an, there are a number of verses that explain how Allah swt sends down rain. The verses referred to are ar-Rum/30:48; Qaf/50:9-11; Gafir/23:18 and 48-50; al-hijr/15:22; Fathir/35:91; al-A'raf/7:57; al-Jasiyah/45:5; ar-Ra'd/13:17; al-Mulk/67:30; az-Zumar/39:21; an-Nur/24:43 and al-Waqi'ah/56:68.

The occurrence of rain can be simply explained as follows. It begins with the evaporation of water caused by the heat of the air that heats the surface of the sea. Heating causes a shift in the molecules of water, which then become vapor. When the vapor rises, clouds form and thicken. Because of the cold and weight, the thick clouds turn into raindrops, which then fall to the earth. That is what is called rain.

"...and gives life thereby to the earth after its lifelessness. And He disperses therein every kind of animal..." (al-Baqarah/2:164)

With this water, life arises with various plants on the surface of the earth, which are then used by animals and humans as their source of life. Finally, life on earth develops as we can witness. This is also indicated in Allah's word, which means:

"...and you see the earth barren, but when We send down upon it rain, it stirs [to life] and swells and puts forth every kind of beautiful growth." (al-hajj/22:5).

The descent of rain, which supports life for plants, animals, and humans, is proof that Allah is One and the Creator. And if viewed from the point of view of its benefits, then this reality is a divine mercy.

The following should always be noted and investigated in this verse:

1.  The creation of the earth inhabited by humans and what is stored within it is a treasure and wealth that will never run out, both on land and at sea. All of this is a blessing and love from Allah to humans. Therefore, humans must utilize, maintain, and preserve it for a good life from generation to generation.

2.  The creation of the heavens with stars and planets all runs and moves according to divine order and rules. Nothing deviates from these rules. If there is a deviation, there will be a collision between one and the other, and this universe will be destroyed entirely. This will not happen unless the Creator Himself, Allah the Almighty, has willed it to happen.

3.  The exchange of night and day and the difference in the length and shortness of night and day in some countries due to differences in their location, all bring great benefits and advantages to humans. Although the causes have been known through astronomy, human research in this matter must be intensified and deepened further so that with this knowledge, humans can be more advanced in utilizing God's mercy.

4.  The ark that sails the seas to carry people from one country to another and to carry merchandise to advance the economy. For people who have never sailed in the middle of the vast ocean, this may not be interesting, but for sailors who always sail the seas, experiencing the severity of the waves and storms, especially when in complete darkness at night, this will surely lead to the realization that indeed everything is controlled and under the *inayah* of Allah, the Almighty and Most Powerful.

5.  Allah swt sends down rain from the sky so that with the rainwater, the earth that has died or dried up can become alive and fertile, and all kinds of animals can also continue their lives with the presence of water. It can be imagined, what if rain did not fall from the sky, all the land would become a desert, all living creatures would die and be destroyed by drought.

6.  The change in the direction of the wind from one place to another is a sign and proof of Allah's power and the greatness of His mercy for humans. In the past, before the existence of steamships, sailing ships were used to sail the vast oceans; and if there was no wind, the ship could not move to its destination. Among these winds, some drive clouds to places desired by Allah, and some even pollinate plant pollen, and there are many more hidden secrets that have not been investigated and known by humans.

7.  Likewise, the greatness of Allah's blessings to humans with the accumulation of clouds between the sky and the earth must be thought about and considered. In short, all the blessings created by Allah, including what is mentioned in verse 164, deserve to be thought about and contemplated, even discussed and researched, to instill deep faith in the heart, and to advance knowledge that also leads to the recognition of the oneness and greatness of Allah.
text.165:
Among mankind, both in the past and present, there are those who consider that besides Allah there are other deities that are glorified and loved equally to the glorification and love of Allah, such as: idols, leaders, ancestral spirits, and so on.

When they receive blessings and goodness, they offer gratitude and praise to these deities, and when they are afflicted with hardship or disaster, they ask and pray to Allah with the hope that they will be helped and released from the clutches of the danger they face. Such actions are the actions of polytheists (mushrik), not the actions of believers (mukmin).

A believer (mukmin) will not commit such acts because he believes and is fully convinced in his heart that the One who must be worshipped is Allah and the One to whom prayers must be offered is only Allah. In the Hereafter, those who associate partners with Allah by worshipping idols, leaders, and spirits will abide in Hell forever and will witness with their own eyes that Allah alone is the Almighty and He alone has the right to punish, and His punishment is very severe.
text.166: At the time of receiving torment in the afterlife, they see the deities they worshipped while in the world disavowing them and declaring that they are not responsible for their misguidance and errors in worshipping other than Allah. Because of this, they hope that they will be given the opportunity to live again in the world, so that they can worship Allah alone and disavow the idols and leaders they used to worship. Thus, they would not experience the bitterness and harshness they are experiencing. But that hope is in vain because what's done is done. They will remain in hell and cannot escape from there, neither to return to the world to correct their *akidah* and deeds, nor to enter paradise, because the gates of paradise are closed to the polytheists.
text.167: At the time of receiving torment in the afterlife, they see the deities they worshipped while in the world disavowing them and declaring no responsibility for their misguidance and errors in worshipping other than Allah. Because of this, they hope that they would be given the opportunity to live again in the world, so that they could worship Allah alone and disavow the idols and leaders they worshipped before. Thus, they would not experience the bitterness and acrimony they are experiencing. But that hope is in vain because what's done is done. They will remain in hell and cannot escape from there, neither to return to the world to correct their creed and deeds, nor to enter paradise, because the doors of paradise are closed to the polytheists.
text.168:
Ibn 'Abbas said that this verse was revealed concerning a group of people consisting of Bani Saqif, Bani Amir bin Sa'sa'ah, Khuza'ah, and Bani Mudli. They prohibited, according to their own desires, the eating of certain types of animals, such as *bahirah*, which was a female camel that had given birth five times, and the fifth offspring was male, then its ear was slit; and *wasilah*, which was a sheep that gave birth to two offspring, one male and one female, then the male offspring was not allowed to be eaten and had to be dedicated to idols. Whereas Allah did not prohibit eating these types of animals, and even explained what He prohibited from eating in His saying:

"Forbidden to you are dead animals, blood, the flesh of swine, and that which has been dedicated to other than Allah, and [those animals] killed by strangling or by a violent blow or by a fall or by being gored to death or by being eaten by a wild animal - unless you [are able to] slaughter it [before its death] - and those which are sacrificed on stone altars, and [prohibited is] that you seek decision through divining arrows. That is grave disobedience." (al-Ma'idah/5: 3).
