Everything other than what is mentioned in this verse is permissible to eat, while *bahirah* and *wasilah* are not mentioned in that verse. Indeed, some scholars are of the opinion that in addition to what is mentioned in that verse, there are other things that are forbidden to eat based on the hadith of the Messenger of Allah (saw), such as eating animals with sharp fangs or strong claws.

Allah commands mankind to eat good food that is found on earth, namely the planet known as the dwelling place of living beings such as humans, animals, plants, and others. While the food that is prohibited by some tribes, determined according to their own desires and regulations that they made themselves, is halal to eat, because Allah did not prohibit that food. Allah only prohibited certain types of food as mentioned in verse 3 of Surah al-Ma'idah and in verse 173 of Surah al-Baqarah.

Apart from what Allah has forbidden and apart from what is mentioned in the hadith, according to the opinion of some scholars, is halal, permissible to eat. The tribes only prohibited certain types of plants and animals based on laws that they established by following traditions that they inherited from their ancestors, and because they indulged in their desires and the will of Satan alone. Let not the Muslims follow the footsteps of Satan, for Satan is a clear enemy to mankind.
text.169: Satan always commands people to commit evil and do what is vile and reprehensible. Satan is not willing and not happy when he sees someone believing in Allah and obeying all His commands and regulations. Satan does not hesitate to command people to lie against Allah by commanding them to make regulations and laws that contradict Allah's law, so that religious regulations will be chaotic and it will no longer be possible to know which regulations are religious and which are not.
text.170:
Truly strange are the will and the way of thinking of the followers of Satan. When it is said to them, "Follow the rules that Allah has revealed," they answer, "We will not follow it; we will only follow the rules that we inherited from our ancestors." Yet it is clear that those rules were only made according to mere desires.

Can they not think and examine so that they can know that those rules have no benefit or advantage?" Will they still obey those rules even if their ancestors who made those rules were ignorant, not knowing anything and not guided by Allah? In this verse, a conclusion can be drawn, namely that a Muslim should not blindly *taqlid* to anyone because blind *taqlid* is the characteristic of the followers of Satan.
text.171: Allah gives an example for the disbelievers who simply accept everything their leaders command and what their ancestors did, so that they reject the true teachings of Islam that are in accordance with reason. They are like livestock, which, when called by their owner, comes; when driven away, it goes; and when forbidden from entering a pasture, it avoids it, while it itself does not understand, let alone think about, why it is called, why it is driven away, and why it is not allowed to enter a place. Thus, the disbelievers are as if they have no ears to hear, no tongue to speak, and no eyes to see and pay attention.
text.172: In this verse, it is emphasized that a believer should eat good food that Allah has provided, and the sustenance He has given must be thanked for. In verse 168, the command to eat good food is addressed to humanity in general. Therefore, that command is accompanied by a prohibition against following the teachings of Satan. Whereas in this verse, the command is addressed only to believers, that they should eat of Allah's good sustenance. For that reason, this command is accompanied by the command to be grateful for it.
text.173:
Establishing a law by declaring something halal or haram is entirely the right of Allah SWT, because He is the All-Powerful. He is the One who is worshipped, whose commands are obeyed, and whose prohibitions are avoided. If someone declares something haram or halal, then that person has essentially equated himself with Allah, and should not be followed. To validate that person is the same as associating partners with Allah and acknowledging that besides Allah, there is someone who has the right to be validated and obeyed in their laws. Such is the case with polytheists; they worship and obey commands other than Allah in the form of idols, leaders who control those idols. They are not acknowledged by Allah and His Messenger as believers as long as they hold such beliefs.

Here, it is emphasized that the foods that are forbidden are only those four types. There are also several types of animals that are forbidden to be eaten based on the verses mentioned above. It is further explained that there is no sin for a person who, in a state of emergency, eats forbidden food, if they are truly in a state of emergency, such as when there is no other food to eat, and if they do not eat, it will lead to great danger or death. In reality, they do not want to, and even feel disgusted to eat it, but only to save their lives. As for eating more than that, it remains haram. This is the will of Allah, and Allah does not burden a servant beyond his capacity.

According to the majority of scholars (jumhur ulama), food that is haram to eat is also haram to trade, because it is impure (najis), except for the Hanafi and Zahiri scholars who say that everything that can be utilized can be traded, such as the sale of animal waste and impure garbage, because its use is needed in gardens and elsewhere.

The verse clearly explains that Muslims are forbidden from eating carrion, blood, and pork. Blood and carrion are clear, because they contain many toxins. As for pork, perhaps further explanation is needed.

According to scientists, pigs are animals shaped like barrels, with short legs. Wild boars that exist today are thought to be the ancestors of domestic pigs. Wild boars can run very fast and are good swimmers. They are omnivores, eating all kinds of food, from grass to carrion. Even domestic pigs like their own feces. Thus, it is not a matter of the cleanliness of pig farms that needs to be discussed here, but rather that pigs are naturally not clean animals. No matter how sophisticated the cleanliness system that is applied, the nature of the pig does not change.

In accordance with their naturally very filthy lifestyle, they have a high content of antibodies (a substance produced by the body for self-defense against disease). The high content of antibodies stored in pork is not beneficial to the health of humans who eat it. This includes the high cholesterol and fat content in pork.

The sexual maturity of pigs is very rapid. Male pigs are mature and can fertilize at the age of eight months. While female pigs can give birth after the age of six months. They only stop giving birth at the age of 15 years. Female pigs can give birth to up to 20 piglets in one fertilization. The sexual drive of pigs is very high.

The growth of piglets is very rapid. When born, they weigh about 2 kg. After six months, they can weigh up to 100 kg. The weight of pigs can reach, the largest found, 363 kg. All of this can happen because pigs have very high growth hormones and sex hormones. This is what causes pigs to have a lot of fat. Both of these hormones (present in high amounts) also add to the long list of reasons why pork is not good for consumption.

Some medical studies mention that the body of pigs contains several viruses that can cause someone who eats it to contract a disease. In addition, one study mentions that one in six people in America are infected with germs in their muscles because of consuming pork. This can happen because the body of pigs contains several types of tapeworms that are dangerous. As is already widely known, the tapeworm disease Trichinellosis is transmitted through pork. Tenasolium is one name of a worm that multiplies in the digestive system and can reach eight meters in length.

Some diseases that are spreading widely due to diseases with pigs as their hosts can be seen below. In 1968, a type of germ was found from pork which was the cause of the death of so many patients in the Netherlands and Denmark. In 1918, Swine Flu attacked many parts of our world and claimed millions of lives. This flu reappeared in 1977, and in the United States at that time, immunization was carried out at a cost of 135 million dollars.

The outbreaks of bird flu and SARS viruses in 2005-2007 were also inseparable from the role of pigs as intermediate hosts for several viruses from other animals that can also be transmitted to humans, such as the SARS virus and bird flu.

Some other diseases that can be caused by pigs are transmitting influenza, encephalitis (Japanese B. Encephalitis), inflammation of the mouth and liver (Stomatitis and Myocarditis) and others. One new finding that was revealed after the rise of genetic engineering is the discovery of viruses found in pigs that are not killed by burning or ordinary cooking. There is also a worm called Trichine that can enter and reside in the human body for years.

Pork fat contains complicated fats including triglycerides, and its meat contains very high cholesterol, reaching fifteen times more than beef. The Encyclopedia Americana explains the comparison between the fat content found in pigs, sheep, and buffalo. In the same weight, pigs contain 50% fat, sheep 17%, and buffalo no more than 5%.

Some parts of pigs are known to be used to replace human organs. For example, pig heart valves are the best replacement for human heart valves. But it needs to be considered, because pigs are also a habitat for many bacteria, viruses and parasites that are dangerous to humans, then the possibility of infecting humans who receive pig organs is very high.
text.174:
Those who conceal what Allah has revealed in His Book do so because they follow their desires and whims, fearing the loss of influence and position, and worrying that they will no longer obtain wealth and possessions. These are the people who have sold their religion for a very cheap price. What is the meaning of the pleasures of this temporary worldly life compared to the eternal pleasures of the Hereafter?

The things they obtain in this world through misguided means will become blazing fire in the Hereafter, which they will constantly swallow and enter their stomachs, causing them immense torment.

Furthermore, Allah is very angry with them, so no matter what they complain about and in whatever way they seek forgiveness to be shown mercy, Allah will not listen to their complaints and requests. Allah will not speak to those who constantly conceal what He has revealed and are always disobedient to Him. Allah will not erase their sins nor cleanse them from errors and misguidance in this world. Indeed, a painful punishment has been prepared for them.
text.175: Those are the people who have purchased error with guidance that Allah revealed to His messengers. Indeed, they have actually purchased punishment with forgiveness. Surely, what they have done is a very detrimental transaction that would not be done by a person of sound mind who can consider what is good and what is bad. But even though they have been given intellect, they do not use it because they have been influenced by their desires and blinded by rank and position. They are diligent and persistent in doing deeds that will bring and put them into Hell in the Hereafter.
text.176: Allah has revealed the Qur'an and the books before it, bringing the truth. However, they conceal and interpret them according to their desires, causing sharp disagreements among themselves. Those who dispute the truth brought by the book have strayed far and fallen into the abyss of error. They will receive a painful punishment from Allah.
text.177:
This verse is not only addressed to the Jews and Christians, but also encompasses all people who adhere to religions descended from the heavens, including Muslims.

In verse 177, Allah explains to all mankind that virtue is not merely turning one's face towards a particular direction, whether east or west, but true virtue is believing in Allah sincerely, a faith that resides in the depths of the heart, which can bring peace to the soul, which can show the truth and prevent oneself from all kinds of lustful desires and evil. Believing in the Hereafter as the ultimate goal of the deficient and perishable worldly life. Believing in the angels, whose duties include being intermediaries and bringing revelations from Allah to the prophets and messengers. Believing in all the books revealed by Allah, whether the Torah, the Gospel, or the Qur'an and others, not like the People of the Book who believe in some of the books revealed by Allah, but do not believe in others, or believe in some verses that they like, but do not believe in verses that do not suit their desires. Believing in all the prophets without distinguishing between one prophet and another.

This faith must be accompanied and marked by real deeds, as described in this verse, namely:

1. a. Giving wealth that is loved to needy relatives. Family members who are able should prioritize providing for closer family members.

b. Giving financial assistance to orphans and the helpless. They need help and assistance to make a living and continue their education, so that they can live peacefully as useful human beings in their community.

c. Giving wealth to travelers in need, so that they are not stranded on their journey and avoid various difficulties.

d. Giving wealth to those who are forced to beg because there is no other way for them to cover their needs.

e. Giving wealth to abolish slavery, so that they can regain their lost freedom and liberty.

2. Establishing prayer, meaning performing it on time with humility, complete with its pillars and conditions.

3. Paying zakat to those who are entitled to receive it as mentioned in Surah at-Taubah verse 60. In the Qur'an, whenever the command to "establish prayer" is mentioned, it is always followed by the command to "pay zakat", because there is a very close relationship between prayer and zakat in carrying out worship and virtue. Because prayer purifies the soul while zakat purifies wealth. Giving zakat is indeed difficult for humans, because zakat is an expenditure of one's own wealth which is very dear. Therefore, whenever there is a command to pray, it is always followed by a command to give zakat, because virtue is not enough with the soul alone but must also be accompanied by wealth. That is why, after the Prophet Muhammad saw died, the companions agreed on the obligation to fight those who refused to pay zakat on their wealth.

4. Keeping promises for those who have made agreements. All kinds of promises that have been made must be kept, whether promises to Allah such as oaths and vows and some of them, or promises to humans, except for promises that contradict the law of Allah (Sharia Islam) such as promises to commit immorality, then it is not permissible (haram) to do, this is reinforced by the words of the Messenger of Allah saw:

The signs of a hypocrite are three: when he speaks, he always lies, when he makes a promise, he always breaks his promise, when he is trusted, he always betrays. (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah r.a.).

5. Patience in the sense of steadfastness, self-restraint and struggling in overcoming hardship, namely difficulties in life such as economic crises; suffering, such as illness or trials; and in warfare, namely when war is raging.

They are the ones who are truthful in the sense that their attitudes, words and deeds are consistent and they are the ones who are pious.
text.178:
This verse establishes a *qisas* punishment that must be carried out with the following provisions:

1. If a free person kills a free person, then *qisas* applies to the free killer.

2. If a slave kills a slave, then *qisas* applies to the slave killer.

3. If someone kills a woman, then that woman is subject to the death penalty.

This is according to the wording of this verse, but what is the ruling if the following occurs:

a. If a free person kills a slave.

b. If a Muslim kills a *kafir zimmi* (a non-Muslim citizen of an Islamic state).

c. If many people together kill one person.

d. If a man kills a woman.

e. If a father kills his child.

The scholars have given their respective *ijtihad* results as follows: According to the Hanafi school of thought, in matters no. 1 and no. 2, the ruling is that the killer must be sentenced to death, even if the status of the person killed is considered lower than the killer, for reasons including:

1) From the beginning of verse 178 to the words *al-qatl* (the killing) is already considered a complete sentence. Thus, there is no distinction between the status of the person who kills and the person who is killed. While the following words, namely a free person with a free person, a slave with a slave, and a woman with a woman, are only to strengthen the law, so as not to act as in the days of *jahiliyah* (ignorance).

2) This verse is *naskh* (abrogated - its ruling no longer applies) by verse 45 of Surah al-Ma'idah/5, which does not distinguish between the status and religion of people.

According to the Maliki and Shafi'i schools of thought, in matters No. 1 and No. 2, the killer is not killed, because equality is a condition for them, on the grounds that:

1) The sentence in the verse is not considered complete until it reaches the words:

(woman with woman). So free with free, slave with slave, and woman with woman. Equality is a condition, while verse 45 of Al-Ma'idah is general in nature and is *takhsis* (specified) by this verse.

2) The words of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him):

"A believer is not killed for killing a disbeliever." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Ali bin Abi thalib)

Matter no. 3: according to the *jumhur* (majority) of scholars, all are sentenced to death because each has taken part in the killing. Matter no. 4, the ruling is in accordance with the *ijmak* (consensus) of the companions, namely that the killer must be sentenced to death, because it is considered that there is no fundamental difference between men and women. Matter no. 5, the ruling is not to be sentenced to death for killing his child, according to the words of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him):

"A father is not killed for killing his child." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Umar)

In this last matter and the previous matters, it is established that the killer is free from the *qisas* punishment, but another punishment is imposed on him, such as *diat* (blood money), fines, and so on, as explained in detail in the books of *fiqh* (Islamic jurisprudence).

Furthermore, Allah SWT explains another possibility that is lighter than *qisas*, namely "But if anyone is forgiven by his brother, then there should be a suitable follow-up and payment to him with good will." This means that the mandatory *qisas* punishment is dropped and replaced with a *diat* punishment that must be paid properly by the killer.

Then, in the closing of this verse, Allah warns the heirs who have given forgiveness, not to act improperly towards the party that has been forgiven, because if they do things that are not appropriate, then that means the act exceeds the limits and will receive a painful punishment on the Day of Judgment.
text.179:
In that verse, an explanation is given regarding the wisdom of the *qisas* punishment, which is to achieve security and tranquility. Because with the implementation of the *qisas* law, humanity will not arbitrarily commit murder by simply indulging their desires, and basing the murder on the feeling that they are stronger, richer, more powerful, and so on.

Tafsir al-Manar has provided a lengthy explanation of the benefits of the *qisas* punishment and the *diyat* punishment brought by the Qur'an; by providing various comparisons of legislation, as well as the behavior of mankind, both in the east and in the west, and providing an analysis of several opinions of legal scholars. Tafsir al-Manar says: if we pay attention to the *sharia* of previous and current communities regarding the punishment stipulated for murder, then we see that the Qur'an is truly in a very reasonable middle ground. Because the punishment given to murderers in the *jahiliyyah* period was always based on the strength and weakness of the tribe. A person killed from a strong tribe, as retaliation, usually killed 10 people from the side of the weak tribe of the murderer.

Tafsir al-Manar adds, "... Some people (criminals), if the punishment for murder is only set as imprisonment for a few years, they will not be deterred, some even want to go to prison to get protection and a free living. For people like this, the best punishment is certainly *qisas*, to be killed if they kill someone else. But if the heirs of the murdered person grant forgiveness, then the *qisas* punishment is dropped and replaced with another punishment, namely paying *diyat* (compensation)." Thus, some summary descriptions from Tafsir al-Manar.
text.180:
Generally, according to the wording of verse 180, Allah obligates those who believe to make a will when they feel their death is near, with the arrival of signs that they will die. The obligation to make a will applies to those who have wealth, so that after death, a portion of the wealth can be set aside to be given to parents and close relatives in a good way (justly and fairly).

In establishing a positive legal ruling on wills from verse 180, the mujtahid scholars require discussion and research on other verses in the Qur'an and the hadiths of the Prophet that are related to this issue, so that they produce opinions including:

1. The majority of scholars give the opinion that verse 180 on wills has been *naskh* (abrogated) by the verses on inheritance that were revealed in detail in Surah an-Nisa' verses 11 and 12, with reasons including the following:

a. The saying of Rasulullah saw:

Indeed, Allah swt has given to each person his due right, so there is no will for an heir (Narrated by Ahmad and al-Baihaqi from Abu Umamah al-Bahili).

This hadith, although not *mutawatir*, has been well-received by Islamic scholars since ancient times.

b. The scholars agree that the verses on inheritance were revealed after this verse on wills.

2. The scholars who hold the opinion that this verse on wills is *naskh* by the verses on inheritance are also divided into 2 groups: the first group says that there is no obligatory will, either to relatives who are heirs or relatives who are not heirs. The second group is of the opinion that what is *naskh* is only the will to relatives who are heirs, in accordance with the verses on *mawaris* (inheritance), but for close relatives who are not included as heirs, the will remains obligatory according to this verse on wills.

3. According to Abu Muslim al-Isfahani (a scholar who does not recognize the existence of *naskh* in the verses of the Qur'an) and Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari, verse 180 on wills is not *naskh* by the verses on *mawaris*, with reasons including:

a. There is no contradiction between this verse on wills and the verses on *mawaris*, because the will is a gift from God. Therefore, an heir can receive a portion from the will according to verse 180, and from the inheritance according to the provisions of the verses on inheritance.

b. If there is a contradiction between this verse on wills and the verses on inheritance, then it can be reconciled, namely that the verses on wills are general in nature, meaning that it is obligatory to make a will to every relative, whether an heir or not, while the verses on *mawaris* are specific in nature. So the obligation to make a will as in verse 180 remains in effect, so that it does not conflict with the verses on inheritance.

In verse 180, it is further explained that the will is implemented if the wealth to be left by the testator is abundant. The scholars give opinions about how much wealth requires a will. Details of the opinions of these scholars can be found in books of *fiqh*. But no matter how many arguments are put forward, a healthy mind can conclude that the wealth left behind is certainly not small, because a will may not exceed one-third of the total amount of wealth left behind, after first deducting what must be deducted, such as debts and necessary expenses for the funeral arrangements. If the will is more than one-third, then it must have the approval of the heirs.

If there is disagreement, then the will only applies to one-third of the amount of wealth left behind, according to the saying of the Prophet Muhammad saw:

Indeed, Allah has permitted you to give one-third of your wealth when near death (ajal) to increase your good deeds. (Narrated by ad-Daraquthni from Mu'adz bin Jabal)

So if the wealth is small, a will is not appropriate and not reasonable to issue.

After that, this verse emphasizes that what is bequeathed is given and distributed in a *makruf* manner, meaning in a good, fair and reasonable way. No one should receive little, while others receive a lot, except in matters that are quite reasonable, namely that the person who receives more, because his needs are very great compared to others.
text.181: This verse (181) sternly warns that a will that has been made should not be changed by anyone. Whoever alters or replaces it, and he has knowledge of the true content of the will, then he is the one who will bear all the unavoidable sins, because indeed Allah is All-Knowing, All-Hearing.
text.182:
This verse provides an explanation: if someone is concerned that the testator is not being fair in making their will (wasiat), then there is no sin for them to instruct the testator to be fair in making their will.

If someone knows that a will (wasiat) that has been made is unfair and then tries to reconcile those who receive the will, so that changes occur, then this is not considered a change that results in sin. Rather, it is a change from unfairness to fairness, which is agreed upon by the parties receiving a portion of the will (wasiat).
text.183:
Scholars have provided many explanations regarding the wisdom of fasting, for example: to elevate morals, to create awareness and compassion towards the poor, the weak who are unable to meet their needs, to train the soul and body, to improve health, and so on.

The explanations above certainly have some truth, although not easily felt by everyone. Because, hunger, thirst, and other consequences of fasting do not always remind one of the suffering of others; instead, it can encourage them to seek and prepare various kinds of food during the day to relieve their hunger and thirst when breaking the fast at night. Likewise, it will not be easily felt by everyone who fasts that fasting helps health, even though doctors have provided scientific explanations that fasting can indeed cure some diseases, but there are also diseases that do not allow fasting. If we pay attention to the command to fast during the month of Ramadan, then at the beginning of verse 183, Allah directly shows that obligatory command to those who believe.

A believer will obediently carry out the command to fast with all their heart, because they feel that physical and spiritual needs are two fundamental elements for human life that must be developed with various kinds of training, so that they can be utilized for a peaceful and happy life in this world and the hereafter.

In verse 183, Allah obligates fasting to all people who believe, as it was obligated to the communities before them so that they may become those who are pious ( *muttaqin*). So, fasting is indeed important for the life of a believer. If we investigate the various religions and beliefs in the present day, we find that fasting is one of the common teachings for restraining desires and so on.

The command to fast was revealed in the month of Sha'ban in the second year of Hijri, when the Prophet Muhammad (saw) began to build an authoritative government and organize a new society, so it can be felt that fasting is very important in forming people who can accept and carry out great and sacred tasks.
text.184:
Verse 184 and the beginning of verse 185 explain that the obligatory fast is for a few days, namely during the month of Ramadan according to the number of days in the month of Ramadan (29 or 30 days). The Great Prophet Muhammad saw, since the revelation of the fasting command until his death, always fasted in the month of Ramadan for 29 days, except for one time when the month of Ramadan was a full 30 days.

Even though Allah has obligated fasting in the month of Ramadan to all believers, Allah, the All-Wise, gives leniency to those who are sick and travelers, not to fast during the month of Ramadan and to replace it on other days outside of that month. In that verse, the type/nature of the limitations and the extent of sickness and travel are not detailed, so the scholars provide their respective ijtihad results, including the following:

1.  It is permissible not to fast for those who are sick or traveling without distinguishing whether the illness is severe or mild, and likewise whether the journey is far or near, in accordance with the wording of this verse. This opinion was pioneered by Ibn Sirin and Dawud az-Zahiri.

2.  It is permissible not to fast for anyone who is sick who truly feels difficulty in fasting because of their illness. The measure of this difficulty is left to each person's sense of responsibility and faith. This opinion was pioneered by some of the scholars of tafsir.

3.  It is permissible not to fast for those who are sick or traveling with certain conditions, if the illness is severe and will affect the safety of life or the safety of some parts of the body or worsen the illness if they fast. Also for those who are traveling, if the journey is a long distance, which measures at least 16 farsakhs (approximately 80 km).

4.  There is no difference of opinion regarding the journey of a traveler, whether by walking, or by any means, as long as it is not for committing immoral acts. After that, Allah explains in the middle of verse 184, which translates to, "And upon those who are able [to fast, but with hardship] - a ransom [as substitute] of feeding a poor person [each day]."

According to that verse (184), whoever truly feels it is difficult to fast, he may replace it with fidyah, even if he is not sick and not traveling.

Included among those who find it difficult to fast are:

a. The elderly who are unable to fast, if they do not fast, it is replaced with fidyah.

b. Pregnant and breastfeeding women. According to Imam Syafi'i and Ahmad, if pregnant women and breastfeeding women are worried about the health of their fetus/baby being disturbed, and then they do not fast, then it is obligatory for both of them to qada the fast that they left, and pay fidyah. If they are only worried about their own health being disturbed and not worried about the health of their fetus/baby, or they are worried about the health of themselves and their fetus/baby, and then they do not fast, then it is obligatory for them to only qada the fast. Meanwhile, according to Abu Hanifah, pregnant and breastfeeding mothers in all the matters mentioned above, it is sufficient to only qada the fast.

c. People who are sick who are unable to fast and their illness has no hope of recovery, are only obligated to pay fidyah.

d. Regarding laborers and farmers whose livelihood only comes from hard work and toiling every day, in this case, the scholars of fiqh put forward the following opinions:

1) Ibn Hajar and Imam al-Azra'i have given a fatwa, "Indeed, it is obligatory for those who harvest rice and so on and those who are similar to them, to intend to fast every night of Ramadan. If during the day it turns out that they experience difficulty or severe suffering, then they may break their fast. If not, they may not break their fast."

2) "If someone whose livelihood depends on a heavy job to cover his living needs or the living needs of those who must be supported by him where he cannot endure fasting, then he may break his fast at that time," (meaning he must fast from the morning).

The end of verse 184 explains that whoever willingly does good by paying fidyah more than its measure or feeding more than one poor person, then that action is good for him. After that, Allah closes this verse by emphasizing that fasting is better than not fasting.
text.185:
This verse explains that the Qur'an was revealed in the month of Ramadan. Regarding this important event, there is some information in the Qur'an that can be used as a reference for determining the time of this revelation. These verses include Surah al-Qadar/97: 1, this verse indicates that the Qur'an was revealed on a night full of glory or the night of Qadar. Surah ad-Dukhan/44: 3, this verse indicates that the Qur'an was revealed on a blessed night. Surah al-Anfal/8: 41, this verse indicates that the Qur'an was revealed coinciding with the meeting between two armies, namely the Islamic army led by the Prophet Muhammad and the Quraysh army commanded by Abu Jahal, in the Battle of Badr which took place on the 17th of Ramadan.

From this Qur'anic information, the scholars determined that the Qur'an was first revealed on the night of Qadar, which is a night full of glory, which is also a blessed night, and this occurred on the 17th of Ramadan, coinciding with the meeting and outbreak of war between the Islamic army and the infidel Quraysh army in Badr, at which time Muhammad was 40 years old when the revelation came down. Furthermore, this important event was designated as the first revelation and is always commemorated by Muslims every year throughout the world.

Regarding the night of Qadar, there are differences in its determination, as the first time the Qur'an was revealed, and the night of Qadar that the Prophet Muhammad encouraged Muslims to seek. The first is determined to have occurred on the 17th of Ramadan, which only happened once and will not be repeated. While the second, according to the hadith of the Prophet, occurs in the last ten days of Ramadan, even more emphasized on odd nights. This night of Qadar can occur every year, so we are always encouraged to seek it with total preparation, namely by performing many sunnah prayers in the last ten days of Ramadan.

This verse also explains that the obligatory fast is in the month of Ramadan. To determine the beginning and end of the month of Ramadan, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

"Fast because you see the moon (Ramadan) and break your fast because you see the moon (Shawwal), if it is hidden from you, (in one) narration says: If it is hidden from you due to cloudy weather), then complete the month of Sha'ban thirty days (and in one narration of Muslim "determine" or calculate the month of Sha'ban thirty days)." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Regarding the situation of the moon being hidden either due to weather conditions, or indeed because according to astronomical calculations it cannot be seen on the 29th night of the 30th of Sha'ban, or on the 29th night of the 30th of Ramadan, the following provisions apply: Whoever sees the moon of Ramadan on the 29th entering the 30th night of Sha'ban, or someone sees the moon, who can be trusted, then he is obliged to fast the next day. If the moon is not visible, then he must complete the month of Sha'ban 30 days. Likewise, whoever sees the moon of Shawwal on the 29th night of the 30th of Ramadan, or someone sees it, who can be trusted, then he is obliged to break his fast the next day. If he does not see the moon on that night, then he must complete the fast for 30 days.

In the matter of determining the beginning of the day of fasting Ramadan and the day of Eid al-Fitr, it should be entrusted to the government, so that if there are differences of opinion, they can be eliminated with one government decision, in accordance with the prevailing rule:

"The government's decision eliminates differences of opinion."

People who cannot see the moon in the month of Ramadan, such as residents in the north or south polar regions where there are six months of night in the north pole and six months of day in the south pole, then the law is adjusted to the area where the revelation was revealed, namely Mecca, where the area is considered a mu'tadilah area (moderate or intermediate area) or calculated to the place closest to the north and south polar regions.

In verse 185, Allah strengthens verse 184, that although fasting is obligatory, leeway is given to those who are sick and travelers not to fast in the month of Ramadan and replace it on other days. At the end of this verse, Allah emphasizes that the number of fasts should be completed and commands us to say takbir and be grateful to Allah for all the guidance given.
text.186:
In this verse, Allah commands His servants to pray to Him, and He promises to answer them, but at the end of this verse, Allah emphasizes that His servants must fulfill His commands and believe in Him so that they are always guided.

In the hadith, many things are explained regarding prayer, including:

1. The words of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him):

"Three types of people whose prayers are not rejected are: a just Imam, a person who is fasting until he breaks his fast, and the prayer of one who has been wronged." (Narrated by Muslim)

2. The words of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him):

"The supplication of every servant will be answered as long as he does not supplicate for something involving sin or severing ties of kinship, and as long as he does not seek haste." He was asked, "What is seeking haste, O Messenger of Allah?" He replied, "It is when a servant says, 'I have supplicated, but I see that it has not been answered for me,' so he becomes frustrated and stops supplicating." (Narrated by Ahmad, at-Tirmidzi, an-Nasa'i and Ibn Majah)

Although there are opinions that Allah SWT is All-Powerful, All-Knowing, and arranges everything, whether asked or not, He does as He wills, so humans do not need to pray, but that opinion contradicts this verse and the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad.

If some of the prayers offered to Allah are not answered, there are several reasons:

a. Not fulfilling the necessary conditions.

b. Allah does not necessarily grant according to what His servant asks for, but replaces or adjusts it with something better for the petitioner, both in this world and in the hereafter. In this verse, Allah connects the prayer that He promises to answer with the condition that His servants must obey all His commands and believe in Him.

In addition, prayer should be done with khusyuk (humility), sincerity, and with all one's heart, and not prayer to oppress people, sever ties of kinship, and other acts of disobedience. Indeed, everything must be according to the conditions or procedures that are good and can convey to what is intended. If someone says, "O my Lord, give me a thousand rupiah," without making an effort, then he is not praying but is actually ignorant. Meaning, such a request is meaningless because it is not accompanied by reasonable effort.
text.187:
In this verse, Allah explains the excuses or obstacles that permit one to abstain from fasting, as well as the laws related to fasting.

Many narrations recount the reason for the revelation of this verse, among others: at the beginning when fasting was made obligatory, the Prophet's companions were permitted to eat, drink, and have intercourse until the Isha prayer or sleep.

Once they had prayed Isha or slept, then all of that became forbidden for them. On one occasion, 'Umar bin al-Khaththab had intercourse with his wife after the Isha prayer, and he greatly regretted this action and conveyed it to the Messenger of Allah (saw). Then this verse was revealed, explaining Allah's law which is lighter than what they had known and practiced. That from sunset (Maghrib) until before the rising of dawn (Subuh), everything that is not permitted during the day in the month of Ramadan is permitted, with the following explanation: "Permitted to you, on the night of the fasts, is the approach to your wives. They are your garments and ye are their garments. Allah knoweth what ye used to do secretly among yourselves; but He turned to you and forgave you; so now associate with them, and seek what Allah hath ordained for you." (al-Baqarah/2:186). Meaning, now you are permitted to have intercourse with your wives and do things that are permissible for you. "And eat and drink until the white thread of dawn appear to you distinct from its black thread; then complete your fast till the night appears; but do not associate with your wives while ye are in retreat in the mosques." Then Allah concludes this verse by affirming that these prohibitions that Allah has determined must not be approached, and you must not exceed or violate them. Thus does Allah make clear His signs to mankind, that they may become righteous.
text.188:
In the first part of this verse, Allah prohibits consuming the wealth of others through unlawful means (bathil). "Consuming" means "using or utilizing," as is commonly used in Arabic and other languages. Bathil refers to methods that are not in accordance with the laws determined by Allah.

The scholars of tafsir mention many things that are prohibited and fall within the scope of the first part of this verse, including:

1.  Consuming riba (interest) money.

2.  Receiving wealth without having the right to it.

3.  Brokers who commit fraud against buyers or sellers.

Then, in the second part or the last part of the verse, it prohibits bribing judges with the intention of obtaining a portion of someone else's wealth through unlawful means (bathil), by bribing, giving false oaths, or false testimony. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

"Indeed, I am a human being, and you come to me with disputes for me to resolve. Perhaps some of you are more eloquent in speech, so I rule in their favor based on the arguments I hear. So whoever receives a legal decision from me to obtain a portion of their brother's wealth (which is not their right) and then takes that wealth, then it means I have given them a piece of the fire of Hell." (Upon hearing this), both of them wept and each said, "I am willing to relinquish my share of the wealth to my friend." Then the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) commanded, "Go, both of you, with a sense of brotherhood, and draw lots and mutually make lawful each other's share according to the result of the draw." (Narrated by Malik, Ahmad, al-Bukhari, Muslim, and others)
text.189:
In this verse, Allah teaches Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to answer the companions' questions about the use and wisdom of the "moon" for mankind, namely for the purpose of calculating time in carrying out their acts of worship such as prayer (salat), fasting (puasa), pilgrimage (hajj), and so on, as well as necessary worldly affairs. Allah explains the calculation of time using the lunar (qamariah) calculation, because it is easier than calculation according to the sun's orbit (syamsiah) and more in line with the level of knowledge of the Arab people at that time.

The scholars of tafsir explain that many of the Ansar, when they had performed ihram or hajj, would no longer enter the house from the usual door, but would enter from the back door, and this was considered a virtue.

This verse explains that virtue is not according to feelings and traditions that smack of superstition, such as entering the house from the back or from above, but virtue is to be mindful of Allah (taqwa), and it is prescribed for them to enter the house from its door.

According to scientists, the moon is a satellite of the earth, about a quarter of the size of the earth. It orbits the earth at an average distance of 384,400 kilometers under the pull of the earth's gravity. As a result of its orbit, the moon experiences phases, including the crescent moon phenomenon, full moon, new moon and dark moon. All of this happens because the positions of the moon and earth shift regularly relative to the position of the sun. When the moon is between the earth and the sun, its dark side faces the earth so the moon is not visible to us on earth. This phase is called the new moon phase. Then it shifts from the new moon phase to the full moon phase and from the full moon phase to the dark moon phase. In the dark moon phase, the moon is completely invisible again.

Meanwhile, the crescent moon occurs between the new moon phase to the first half moon phase (first week, before the full moon) and between the second half moon phase (fourth week, after the full moon) towards the dark moon phase.

From the new moon phase to the full moon phase, what happens is the crescent moon phase, which looks like a thread that we can see in the western sky after sunset. Gradually, the crescent moon becomes wider until it becomes half. We call this moon phase the half moon phase. Then, seven days after the half moon phase, we can see a full picture of the moon. We call this moon phase the full moon. Seven days later, the appearance of the moon shrinks again, returning to the half moon phase. And so on until the moon experiences the crescent moon phase again, which then eventually disappears. We call this phase the dark moon phase. So the crescent moon phase occurs twice a month, namely in the first week and the fourth week.

The distance between the new moon phase to the next new moon or from the full moon to the next full moon is 29.5306 days, which we call the synodic period. This is the basis for the calendar made using the lunar calendar system, which we know as the qamariah calendar. How Wise is Allah who has created the moon with extraordinary wisdom contained within it.
text.190:
This verse is a Madaniyah verse, among the first verses commanding Muslims to fight the polytheists if the Muslims are subjected to a sudden attack, even if the attack occurs during the sacred months, namely Rajab, Zulkaidah, Zulhijah, and Muharram, as explained in the previous verse.

In the Jahiliyah era, these months were considered months of prohibition from warfare. Islam recognized this prohibition, but because the polytheists violated it first, Allah SWT permitted the Muslims to retaliate against their attacks.

Before the Hijrah, there were no verses permitting Muslims to engage in warfare. There is no disagreement among the mufassir that warfare was prohibited in Islam at that time.

This verse, up to verse 194, was revealed at the time of the Hudaibiyah peace treaty, a peace agreement between the polytheists of Mecca and the Muslims of Medina. The agreement was made at a place on the road between Jeddah and Mecca. Hudaibiyah was the name of a well/spring located in that place. This event occurred in the month of Zulkaidah in the sixth year of the Hijri. The Prophet Muhammad SAW and his companions left Medina for Mecca to perform Umrah. When the group arrived at Hudaibiyah, they were prevented by the polytheists from entering Mecca, so the Prophet Muhammad SAW's group was forced to stay in Hudaibiyah for a month. Finally, a peace agreement was made, the contents of which included:

a. The Prophet Muhammad SAW's group had to return to Medina that year.

b. The following year, the seventh year of the Hijri, the Prophet Muhammad SAW and his companions were allowed to enter the city of Mecca to perform Umrah.

c. There would be no war between the polytheists and the Muslims for ten years.

The following year, the Prophet Muhammad SAW returned to Mecca with his group to perform Umrah, which is commonly called Umrah Qadha, because they were unable to do so the previous year. At that time, the Muslims were worried that the polytheists would violate the peace treaty, and the Muslims were not happy to fight in the Haram land (Mecca), especially in the months of Syawal, Zulkaidah, Zulhijah, and Muharram, which are commonly called "sacred months." Because of these circumstances and events, these verses were revealed.

In verse 190, Allah commands the Muslims to fight the polytheists who fight them. The war should be aimed *fi sabilillah* (to exalt the word of Allah and uphold His religion).

The war called "*fi sabilillah*" is as explained in a hadith narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim:

"From Abu Musa al-Asy'ary, that the Messenger of Allah SAW was once asked about a man who fought because of his courage, and who fought because of resentment, or who fought only to get praise, which of them fought in the way of Allah? The Messenger of Allah replied, "The one who fights to exalt the word of Allah, then his fighting is *fi sabilillah*." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

In this holy war, believers are prohibited from violating various provisions, such as killing children, weak people who are helpless, very old people, women who do not participate in the war, people who have surrendered, and priests, because Allah does not like those who transgress.
text.191:
The believers are commanded to fight the polytheists who fight them wherever they are found, whether in the lawful land or the sacred land (Mecca and its surroundings). The basis for Mecca and its surroundings being a sacred land is as stated in a sahih hadith:

From Ibn 'Abbas, it is mentioned that on the day of the conquest of Mecca, the Messenger of Allah said that this land has been a sacred land since Allah created the heavens and the earth until the Day of Judgment. It was never made lawful except at this time of day, and that time is my time. The sacred land of Mecca will remain a sacred land until the Day of Judgment; its plants must not be uprooted, and its open fields must not be damaged. If someone is permitted to fight in Mecca on the grounds that the Messenger of Allah did the same, tell him that Allah permitted it to His Messenger and did not permit it to you. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

The believers are also commanded to expel the polytheists from Mecca, because the polytheists once expelled them from there, and the presence of the polytheists in Mecca (the sacred land) is dangerous to the purity of religion and will cause a fitnah that is more dangerous than fighting in the sacred land. The meaning of fitnah here is the persecution of the Muslims by the polytheists through expulsion, torture, confiscation of property, and obstructing the performance of worship, and so on. If this is the case, then the believers are commanded to retaliate with war as well. Such is the recompense that must be given to the polytheists, but if the polytheists stop fighting and eventually become believers, then they must not be disturbed, because the things that caused them to be fought no longer exist. Allah is Most Forgiving, Most Kind, and Most Merciful.
text.192:
The believers are commanded to fight the polytheists who fight them wherever they are found, whether in the permissible land or the sacred land (Mecca and its surroundings). The basis for Mecca and its surroundings being a sacred land is as stated in a sahih hadith:

From Ibn 'Abbas, it is mentioned that the Messenger of Allah, on the day of the liberation of Mecca, said that this land has been a sacred land since Allah created the heavens and the earth until the Day of Judgment. It was never made permissible except at this time of day, and that time is my time. The sacred land of Mecca will remain a sacred land until the Day of Judgment; its plants must not be uprooted, and its open fields must not be damaged. If someone is permitted to fight in Mecca on the grounds that the Messenger of Allah once did the same, tell him that Allah permitted it to His Messenger and did not permit it to you. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

The believers are also commanded to expel the polytheists from Mecca, because the polytheists once expelled them from there, and the presence of the polytheists in Mecca (the sacred land) is dangerous for the purity of religion and will cause a fitnah that is more dangerous than fighting in the sacred land. The meaning of fitnah here is the persecution by the polytheists against the Muslims through expulsion, torture, confiscation of property, and obstructing the performance of worship, and so on. If this is the case, then the believers are commanded to retaliate with war as well. Such is the recompense that must be given to the polytheists, but if the polytheists stop fighting and eventually become believers, then they must not be disturbed, because the things that caused them to be fought no longer exist. Allah is Most Forgiving, Most Kind, and Most Merciful.
text.193:
The believers are commanded to continue fighting the polytheists who fight them until they no longer have the power to persecute the Muslims and hinder them from carrying out the commands of their religion, so that the religion of Islam can be fully practiced by every Muslim with sincerity, free from fear, disturbance, and pressure.

If the polytheists have stopped all evil actions and have embraced Islam, then the Muslims are not allowed to take revenge or actions that exceed the limits, except against those who are unjust, namely those who start again or return to disbelief and slander the Muslims.
text.194: This verse explains that if the polytheists attack the Muslims during the sacred months (bulan haram), then the Muslims are permitted to retaliate during the sacred months, including if the Muslims are attacked by the polytheists during 'umratul qadha', because this verse explicitly permits the Muslims to retaliate, even during the sacred months. This is further emphasized by the permissibility of retaliating with an equivalent response for every violation of the provisions that must be respected. If the Muslims retaliate, they are never allowed to be excessive and they must be careful not to overstep the boundaries, and they must be mindful of Allah, because Allah is always with those who are mindful of Him.
text.195:
Believers are commanded to spend their wealth in *jihad fi sabilillah* and are forbidden from throwing themselves into the abyss of destruction because of their miserliness. If a people face war and they are stingy, unwilling to finance the war, then their actions mean destroying themselves.

Facing *jihad* without complete preparation and supplies, and engaging in *jihad* together with those who are weak in faith and will, will certainly lead to destruction. In the matter of *infaq fi sabilillah*, one must have good intentions, so that in this way they will always obtain Allah's help.
text.196:
The Hajj pilgrimage is the fifth pillar of Islam. Hajj became obligatory for Muslims in the sixth year of Hijri. Prior to that, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) performed Hajj as a voluntary act of worship. Besides Hajj, there is also Umrah. Both are obligatory for Muslims to perform once in a lifetime. Performing Hajj and Umrah more than once is considered sunnah (recommended). However, Imam Malik bin Anas held the opinion that performing Umrah twice a year is makruh (disliked). Hajj and Umrah do not have to be performed immediately; they can be performed when circumstances permit. Whoever is capable of performing Hajj and Umrah should hasten to fulfill them.

The place for performing Hajj and Umrah is only in the holy land of Mecca and its surroundings. Those who are obligated to go and perform Hajj and Umrah are those who are in a state of being able and capable, meaning sufficient funds are available, physical condition permits, and security is not compromised. The difference between Hajj and Umrah is that Hajj has five pillars: intention (niyyah), standing at Arafah (wukuf), circumambulation of the Kaaba (thawaf), walking between Safa and Marwa (sa'i), and shaving or cutting the hair (tahallul), while Umrah has only four pillars: intention (niyyah), circumambulation of the Kaaba (thawaf), walking between Safa and Marwa (sa'i), and shaving or cutting the hair (tahallul).

The acts of worship in Hajj include those that are pillars (rukun), those that are obligatory (wajib), and those that are sunnah (recommended). The acts that are pillars, if any are omitted, render the Hajj and Umrah invalid. The acts that are obligatory, if any are omitted, require a penalty (dam) to be paid, but the Hajj and Umrah remain valid. The acts that are sunnah, if any are omitted, do not invalidate the Hajj and Umrah, and no dam is required. In addition, there are prohibitions for those who are performing Hajj and Umrah. These prohibitions are commonly called *muharramat*. Whoever violates the *muharramat* is required to pay a *dam*. The size of the *dam* corresponds to the severity of the *muharramat* that was violated. Engaging in sexual intercourse before completing the *tawaf ifadhah* invalidates the Hajj and Umrah.

Hajj and Umrah have several legal aspects. Therefore, whoever intends to perform these acts of worship should first study them. These practices are commonly called *manasik*. Verse 196 was revealed at the time of the Hudaibiyah peace treaty in the 6th year of Hijri, the same time as the revelation of verse 190 regarding permission to fight for the Muslims.

This verse was revealed in connection with Hajj and Umrah, in which Muslims are obligated to perform Hajj and Umrah. What is meant by Allah's command to "complete" Hajj and Umrah is to perform them perfectly and sincerely for the sake of Allah (SWT). It is possible that someone who has already made the intention (niyyah) for Hajj and Umrah is prevented by various obstacles from completing them. In this case, Allah (SWT) provides the following provision: a person who has entered *ihram* for Hajj and Umrah and is then prevented by an enemy from completing his Hajj and Umrah must provide a camel, cow, or goat to be slaughtered.

These animals may be slaughtered after reaching Mecca, and he ends his *ihram* by (shaving or cutting his hair). Regarding the place of slaughter, there are differences of opinion; some require it to be in the Holy Land of Mecca, while others allow it to be outside the Holy Land of Mecca. If he cannot find an animal to slaughter, then the animal can be replaced with food of the same value as the animal and given as charity to the poor.

If he is unable to give food as charity, then it is replaced with fasting, each *mudd* of food being equivalent to one day of fasting. People who have entered *ihram* for Hajj or Umrah, and then become ill or have a disease on their head such as boils, and they consider it easier to shave their heads, are allowed to shave, but must pay *fidyah* by fasting for 3 days or giving food as charity of 3 *sa'* (10.5 liters) to the poor, or by paying *fidyah* with a goat.
text.197:
The time for performing the Hajj has been fixed, namely in the months that have been determined, and it is not permissible in other months. It is narrated from Ibn 'Abbas and is valid in the madhhab of Abu Hanifah, Shafi'i, and Imam Ahmad, that the time for performing the Hajj is in the months of Shawwal, Zulkaidah, up to the dawn of the night of the 10th of Zulhijah. These provisions regarding the timing of Hajj have been in effect since the time of Prophet Ibrahim and Prophet Ismail. After the religion of Islam came, these provisions were not changed, but rather continued as they were. Those who are performing Hajj are forbidden from engaging in sexual relations, uttering obscene words, violating religious prohibitions, mocking, boasting, quarreling, and being hostile.

All attention should be directed towards doing good deeds alone. The heart and mind should only be focused on worship, seeking the pleasure of Allah, and always remembering Him. Whatever good deeds a Muslim who has performed Hajj does, Allah will surely know and record them and will reward him with manifold rewards. In order for the Hajj pilgrimage to be carried out well and perfectly, everyone should bring sufficient provisions, especially food, drink, clothing, and so on, namely provisions for the journey and performing Hajj in the holy land and provisions for returning to their respective places. It is narrated by al-Bukhari, Abu Daud, an-Nasa'i, and others from Ibn 'Abbas that he said, "There were some people from Yemen who, when they went on Hajj, did not bring sufficient provisions; they simply put their trust in Allah. After they arrived in the holy land, they ended up begging because they ran out of provisions." Therefore, the best provision is taqwa, and one should bring sufficient provisions so that one does not have to beg and live in misery.

Allah reminds us that the Hajj pilgrimage should be performed with full taqwa to Allah by doing all that He has commanded and leaving all that He has forbidden. By doing so, one will be able to achieve happiness and good fortune filled with divine pleasure and mercy.
text.198:
During the Hajj season, a person is not prohibited from engaging in business, such as trading and other activities, as long as it does not interfere with the primary goal, which is to perform Hajj perfectly. This verse was revealed in connection with the doubts of Muslims at the beginning of Islam about seeking sustenance, so many of them closed their shops during the Hajj season for fear of sinning. It was narrated by al-Bukhari from Ibn 'Abbas, who said, "In the time of Jahiliyyah, there were 3 markets, namely Ukaz, Majannah, and Zulmajaz."

During the Hajj season, the Muslims felt guilty about trading in those markets, then they asked the Messenger of Allah (saw), and this verse was revealed. Seeking lawful sustenance while performing Hajj is permissible as long as the effort is done incidentally, not as the main goal. The main goal is to perform the Hajj pilgrimage with full piety to Allah and with a sincere heart.

Then in this verse, Allah commands everyone performing Hajj to remember Allah when departing from Arafah towards Muzdalifah, that is, when arriving at Masy'aril Haram. Masy'aril Haram is a hill in Muzdalifah called Quzah. When arriving at that place, one should increase the recitation of prayers, takbir, and talbiyah. Remember Allah with a humble and submissive heart, as a sign of gratitude to Him for His grace and guidance that has released a person from the disease of shirk in the past, becoming a person who has purely professed the oneness of Allah (swt).
text.199: During the Jahiliyyah period, the Quraysh, when performing Hajj, would perform wuquf in Muzdalifah, while other Arabs would perform wuquf in Arafah. The reason was that the Quraysh felt themselves to be higher and more noble than others, and that it was not fitting for them to perform wuquf together with ordinary people in Arafah. Therefore, this verse was revealed. This verse commands that they perform wuquf together in Arafah and then depart together from Arafah to Muzdalifah. In essence, during the performance of Hajj, there is no difference; everyone is equally a creation of Allah, and must perform wuquf in Arafah together. Everyone should seek forgiveness from Allah, abandoning boasting and arrogance. Whoever seeks forgiveness from Allah, Allah will surely forgive their sins, because Allah is Most Forgiving and Most Merciful to His servants. It is narrated from Ibn Jarir from Ibn 'Abbas.
text.200:
Allah commands that, if the Hajj pilgrimage has been completed, to remember Allah by mentioning His name. It is narrated by al-Baihaqi from Ibn 'Abbas that, usually, the Arabs in the pre-Islamic era, when they had finished performing Hajj, would gather in Mina, between the mosque and the hill, while standing they would boast and act arrogantly, mentioning and glorifying the greatness of their respective ancestors. Then this verse was revealed to remind them that what they were doing after completing the Hajj pilgrimage was not good, but rather a bad habit. What is good is, after completing the Hajj pilgrimage, to increase the remembrance of Allah's name as they used to mention the names of their ancestors, or to strive even more to mention the name of Allah.

In a sermon, the Prophet Muhammad saw during the Farewell Pilgrimage on the second day of the days of Tasyrik, gave a stern warning to abandon those old ways, namely boasting about the superiority of their respective ancestors. Among other things, the Messenger of Allah said, "O people, know that your Lord is one and your ancestor is one (Adam)."

"Know that there is no superiority for an Arab over a non-Arab, nor is there any superiority for a non-Arab over an Arab. There is no superiority for a red-skinned person over a black-skinned person, and no superiority for a black-skinned person over a red-skinned person. Their superiority in the sight of Allah is only measured by their piety (taqwa) towards Allah." Then the Messenger of Allah asked them, "Have I conveyed this warning?" Then the audience replied, "Indeed, the Messenger of Allah has conveyed it." Then Allah divides the levels of people who perform the Hajj pilgrimage, namely there are people who only get worldly benefits, and do not get benefits in the Hereafter; namely those whose attention is only focused on seeking worldly gains, both in their prayers and in their remembrance (zikir). In his prayer, he only asks for glory, honor, victory, and wealth. His calculations are only about worldly profit and loss. People like this are because their knowledge has not reached the secret and essence of the true Hajj, their hearts have not received a ray of guidance from Allah. For him, worldly gain is more important than gain in the Hereafter.
text.201: In this verse, Allah mentions the people who attain benefit in this world and the hereafter, namely those who in their prayers always ask to obtain happiness in this world and happiness in the hereafter, and to be kept far from the torment of the fire of hell. To achieve a happy life in this world, several conditions must be met, including being patient in striving, obedient to regulations and disciplined, good at socializing and trustworthy, and having good intentions in one's endeavors. To achieve a happy life in the hereafter, one must have pure and strong faith, perform righteous deeds (amal saleh), and possess noble character (akhlak yang mulia). Therefore, to be free from the torment of hell, one should always abandon acts of disobedience (maksiat), distance oneself from what is vile, and protect oneself from doing things that Allah has forbidden due to the influence of desires (syahwat) and whims (hawa nafsu).
text.202:
Those who ask for happiness in this life and happiness in the Hereafter are the ones who will receive a good and fortunate destiny because of their earnestness in striving and doing good deeds. This means they have been able to align the desires of their hearts, spoken by their tongues, with the earnestness of their physical efforts in striving and doing good deeds. The fruit of this is fortune and happiness. This verse is concluded with a reminder that Allah is swift in reckoning.

The intention is that every human being should not hesitate in striving and doing good deeds, because everything will be reckoned by Allah and no one will be wronged. Allah's reckoning is very swift and precise, so that in an instant, every human being can see the results of their efforts and deeds and will immediately receive the reward for those efforts and deeds from Allah.
text.203:
After the pilgrims are in Mina, returning from Arafah, Allah once again reminds them to remember Allah through *dhikr*, namely saying *takbir* on specific days, which are the days of *tasyrik* (11th, 12th, and 13th of Dhul Hijjah), abandoning the customs of the Jahiliyyah era, where they held large gatherings on those days to boast, highlight the merits of their ancestors, and other things that were a source of pride for each. For this reason, when the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, finished performing the Farewell Pilgrimage, he gave a guidance sermon in Mina, as mentioned above.

Allah commands the pilgrims to remember Allah through *dhikr* on specific days. The majority of scholars are of the opinion that the specific days referred to are the three days after Eid al-Adha, the 11th, 12th, and 13th of Dhul Hijjah. The meaning of *dhikr* in this verse is *takbir*, and it is performed after completing each obligatory prayer (*salat fardu*) and each time after throwing pebbles at the *jumrah*. And the wording of the *takbir* is as follows:

Allah is the Greatest; Allah is the Greatest, Allah is the Greatest; There is no god but Allah. Allah is the Greatest; Allah is the Greatest; And all praise is only for Allah.

The *takbir* after the Asr prayer on the third day of *tasyrik* is the last *takbir* in the implementation of the command to say *takbir* mentioned in this verse.

Pilgrims who are in Mina for two days after Eid al-Adha are allowed to return to Mecca immediately. They are in Mina to throw pebbles at the *jumrah*. Therefore, pilgrims are required to spend the night in Mina only on the first and second nights of the days of *tasyrik*. They may also return to Mecca later, thus staying in Mina for three days, namely on the 11th, 12th, and 13th of Dhul Hijjah. Whichever of the two options they choose and do, there is no sin for them, even though returning later (3 days in Mina) is more virtuous (*afdal*).

This provision is a reaffirmation from Allah SWT to eliminate the views of the people of Jahiliyyah, some of whom believed that those who returned to Mecca immediately were sinful, and some of whom believed that those who were late in returning to Mecca were sinful. Those who hasten to return to Mecca (two days after Eid) are called *nafar awal* (the first group), while delaying until the third day is called *nafar sani* (the second group). For the *nafar awal*, they must leave Mina on the second day of *tasyrik*, after throwing pebbles at the *jumrah* and after noon before sunset.

If they have not left Mina by sunset for some reason, then the *nafar awal* is canceled and they must spend the night again and can only leave Mina after throwing pebbles at the *jumrah* on the third day of *tasyrik* after noon.

This leniency and opportunity to choose is given by Allah to the pilgrims because both can be carried out with full piety (*takwa*) to Allah SWT. For those who hasten because they fear committing violations such as killing forbidden animals, sleeping with their wives (intercourse), and things that are still prohibited after the first *tahallul* before the second *tahallul*, and for those who delay, it is because they want to do what is more virtuous (*afdal*) and believe that they are able to avoid all these prohibitions.

Because of the importance of *takwa* and to establish *takwa* in the heart, Allah SWT emphasizes once again with His words:

...And fear Allah,... (al-Baqarah/2: 203)

Then followed by words that can strengthen the heart to be pious, namely:

...And know that you will be gathered to Him... (al-Baqarah/2: 203)

A person who knows and believes that he will be gathered on the Day of Judgment and held accountable for all his deeds in the world, will certainly do more good and increase his *takwa* to Allah SWT.
text.204:
With this verse, Allah informs us that a person like Al-Akhnas is a liar, untrustworthy, and that he is an enemy of Islam and a staunch opponent of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).

Al-Akhnas and other hypocrites want to deceive and plot against mankind with three things:

1.  With attractive words and speech, so that those who hear it are fascinated and influenced, without the slightest doubt about the truth of his words.

2.  Swearing by the name of Allah to show his truthfulness as if he intends good.

3.  Persistent in debating and arguing against his opponents.
text.205:
This type of person, once they have passed and left the person they deceived, carries out their true purpose. They commit acts of corruption on the earth; crops and fruits are destroyed, and livestock are annihilated, especially when they are in power. Everywhere they do as they please and violate women. There is no place safe from their evil deeds. Fitnah threatens everywhere, society feels fear, and households and children are shattered because of their arbitrary actions.

Such characteristics are not liked by Allah at all. He is angry with those who act in this way, as well as with everyone whose deeds are dirty and disgusting. Things that appear good on the surface but do not bring benefit, Allah will not be pleased with them because He does not look at the beauty of appearance and the attractiveness of words, but Allah looks at the sincerity of the heart and the benefit of an action.

The Prophet Muhammad saw said:

Indeed, Allah does not look at your bodies, nor at your forms, but Allah (only) looks at your hearts. (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah ra)
text.206:
Those whose morals are already corrupted, when warned and advised to fear Allah and abandon their bad traits, they become angry and continue to rise up, displaying their arrogance and pride, highlighting their traits of ignorance (jahiliyyah) and satanic nature. With the advice and warnings, they feel humiliated and consider that the advice and warnings are inappropriate and unworthy for them, because of their high rank and position. They do not hesitate to commit disobedience and sin.

A person with a damaged nature and character will certainly not be pleased with someone who advises them, because they feel that their bad deeds, which are always wrapped in grand words and veiled with attractive gestures, have been discovered by others. So, if they could, they would not hesitate to arrest, beat, and if necessary, kill the person they dislike.

In this regard, 'Umar bin al-Khaththab is a sufficient example to follow. When he was told, "Fear Allah," he would then place his cheek on the ground, showing his awareness of his weaknesses and shortcomings, even though we know that he was a famous just companion, especially when he became caliph.

Ibn Mas'ud r.a., one of the Prophet's companions, once said, "Great enough is the sin of a person, when he is told, "Fear Allah," and then he replies, "Enough for you to advise yourself, and do not try to interfere in the personal affairs of others."
text.207:
After explaining the characteristics of the hypocrites, who are filthy and disgusting, Allah explains the characteristics of the sincere believers (mukhlis).

Ibn 'Abbas, Anas, Sa'id bin Musayyab, and several other companions stated that this verse was revealed in connection with the event of Suhaib bin Sinan ar-Rumi, who was about to follow the Prophet (saw) in his hijrah to Medina. The Quraysh forbade him from migrating with his wealth.

Suhaib ignored the prohibition of the Quraysh and even willingly and sincerely surrendered all his wealth so that he would be allowed to migrate to Medina, and then this verse was revealed.

Then Sayyidina 'Umar bin al-Khaththab, along with several companions, went to see Suhaib and said, "Your trade is truly profitable." Suhaib said, "May the trade of my brothers not be in loss. What brings you here?" Sayyidina Umar (r.a.) then informed him that Allah (swt) had revealed this verse in connection with the event experienced by Suhaib.

A sincere person (mukhlis) like Suhaib, whose words and actions are always the same, whose words are in accordance with what is in his heart, not saying one thing and meaning another, not two-faced, they are sincerely willing to sell and sacrifice themselves and everything they have in order to obtain the pleasure of Allah (swt).

Everyone who strives in the path of Allah should be like that, that is, they must dare to sacrifice what they have, their energy, wealth, or both, according to their ability, in order for the struggle to succeed, as a reflection of the faith and piety that is in each of their hearts. Thus, they will achieve a great victory. Allah says:

Indeed, Allah has purchased from the believers their lives and their properties [in exchange] for that they will have Paradise. They fight in the cause of Allah, so they kill and are killed. [It is] a true promise [binding] upon Him in the Torah and the Gospel and the Qur'an. And who is truer to his covenant than Allah? So rejoice in your transaction which you have contracted. And it is that which is the great attainment. (at-Taubah/9: 111).
text.208:
This verse emphasizes that believers, whether they are newly converted to Islam like the Jew named Abdullah bin Salam, or hypocrites who still engage in actions that contradict Islamic teachings, should obediently implement Islamic teachings completely, not partially. They should not be like those who fast during Ramadan but abandon the five daily prayers, and they should not behave as Allah describes the characteristics of the Jews in the Qur'an:

¦ Do you believe in a part of the Scripture (Torah) and disbelieve in a part? ¦. (al-Baqarah/2: 85).

And do not follow the footsteps and teachings of Satan, because Satan always invites to evil, causing many people to abandon the commands of Allah and violate His prohibitions.
text.209:
Even though Allah emphasizes to the Muslims that Islamic teachings should be implemented in their entirety, Allah's commands obeyed, and His prohibitions avoided, there are still those who slip, then act according to their own desires, even though the proofs of the truth of the Islamic religion are clear enough for them. Let them remember that Allah is All-Powerful to carry out retribution, and if Allah wills, there is no power or strength whatsoever that can prevent Him, and Allah is All-Wise.

He will not let lawbreakers go unpunished, but He will repay them in proportion to the errors and evils they have committed.
text.210:
Then Allah affirms to those who are of such a nature, that there is nothing to wait for except the coming of punishment on the Day of Judgment as He has promised.

Allah will bring His punishment and torment in the form of the shadow of clouds which they initially thought would bring mercy, but in fact, the cloud is full of torment, brought by the angels. In another verse it is mentioned:

And (remember) the Day when the heaven will split open with [white] clouds and the angels will be sent down in successive descent. (al-Furqan/25:25).

This will certainly happen, because it has become Allah's decree and there is no way to avoid it, because indeed everything will be returned to Allah.

Hopefully, there is not much time left for those who have not yet realized and for the violators of Allah's laws to quickly repent, leaving their evil deeds before leaving this mortal world and moving to the eternal realm.
text.211:
The Children of Israel had become corrupted by worldly influences, leading them to commit numerous sins and deny countless blessings from Allah. Therefore, the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) was commanded by Allah to ask them how many verses and signs of Allah's power had been shown to them.

This question was not meant to be answered, but rather as a warning for them to realize and become aware, so that they would obey Allah and abandon their evil deeds.

Allah had shown them miracles that occurred through their prophets, demonstrating the truth of the teachings they brought, such as the staff of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) which, when struck against a rock, caused twelve springs to gush forth, the cloud that shaded them from the heat when they walked in the desert, the food in the form of *mann* and *salwa*, and so on.
