But they remained stubborn, with no sign whatsoever that they would become conscious and aware. Therefore, Allah gave them a stern warning: whoever exchanges the blessings of Allah for disbelief after the blessing has come to them and replaces His verses, Allah will repay them with a severe and painful punishment, especially in the Hereafter, by throwing them into Hell.

Allah says:

"Have you not seen those who have exchanged the favor of Allah for disbelief and settled their people [in] the home of ruin? [It is] Hell, which they will [enter to] burn, and wretched is the settlement." (Ibrahim/14: 28-29).
text.212:
According to Abdullah bin Abbas, this verse was revealed in connection with Abu Jahal and his companions. Meanwhile, according to Muqatil, this verse was revealed in connection with the hypocrites, such as Abdullah bin Ubay and his followers.

Another narration says that this verse was revealed in connection with the Jews, their figures and leaders, from Bani Quraizah, Bani Nadir, and Bani Qainuqa, all of whom always insulted the Muslims.

Imam Fakhrur Razi said, "There is nothing wrong with saying that this verse was revealed for these three groups." It has become an inherent trait, especially in the hearts of the disbelievers, to love the world more than anything else. Satan depicts to them the pleasures of life in this beautiful world as grandly as possible until all their attention is focused on the world. They seize it fiercely, defend it with their lives, disregarding religious prohibitions, decency, or the laws of Allah and His Messenger. They direct many insults at the believers, such as Abdullah bin Mas'ud, Ammar bin Yasir, Suhaib, and so on, deliberately to insult and demean their position. They say, "Muslims like to torture themselves and abandon worldly pleasures, they struggle to perform worship, restrain their desires by fasting, giving zakat, and spending large sums to go on Hajj, and so on."

The mockery and insults of the disbelievers towards the Muslims are answered by stating that those who are pious to Allah will have a much higher status and position in the hereafter than them. The pious will be admitted to Paradise, as mentioned in Allah SWT's words:

"That is Paradise which We will give as inheritance to those of Our servants who were pious." (Maryam/19: 63).

The disbelievers boast of the worldly pleasures they possess, the accumulated wealth they have acquired, and they insult the believers who are generally poor, not many of whom are rich compared to them. To answer this insult, Allah concludes this verse with an affirmation that their assumptions are not true. Allah gives sustenance in this world to whomever He wills, whether they are disbelievers or believers, the only difference being that if they are disbelievers, their sustenance is an "istidraj," which is to gradually plunge them into the painful torment they will encounter. The torment and punishment they receive in the hereafter is because they do not want to be aware and do not want to return to the path of Allah, even in a state of happiness and abundance. Meanwhile, for the believers, their sustenance is a "fitnah," which is a test, whether they are able and willing to use and utilize it for things that are pleasing to Allah SWT or not?

In the hereafter, the disbelievers will cower in hell, feeling endless, excruciating torment and punishment, and the believers will be admitted to Paradise, given multiplied rewards without limit. Allah SWT says:

"And whoever does righteous deeds, whether male or female, while being a believer - those will enter Paradise, being given provision therein without account." (al-Mu'min/40: 40)
text.213:
Mankind was originally a single community. One creed and one purpose in their actions, which was to improve and not to destroy, to do good and not to do evil, to be just and not to be oppressive. Then they turned away and did the opposite, and there was no longer unity of creed and opinion among them, which would lead them to happiness, so they disagreed and became scattered.

To return them to their original state, united in truth, Allah sent prophets, chosen people, to guide them to the right path, to give guidance on the mistakes they made, and to deliver good news to those who believe and obey.

The prophets who were sent were equipped with divine books (kitab-kitab samawi) that were revealed to them, all of which contained truth, guidance, and complete explanations, which would be used as a basis for giving consideration and making the fairest decisions on everything that was disputed.

Actually, humans no longer need to disagree because the divine books that were given contain clear explanations, all of which have been known and understood. So what is it that causes them to blame each other and assume that only they are right and others are wrong? This is due to envy and a tendency to commit transgressions.

If this envious nature has been ingrained in the heart, whether individually or collectively, it is difficult to obtain peace and prosperity among them.

Blessed are those who believe, because by the will of Allah SWT they have been given guidance to the right path.

Aisyah RA said, "Indeed, when the Messenger of Allah SAW woke up in the middle of the night, he performed "shalah al-Lail" (night prayer), and he prayed:

"O Allah, Lord of Jibril, Mikail, and Israfil, Creator of the heavens and the earth, who knows the unseen and the seen. You are the one who decides between Your servants about what they dispute. Guide me to the truth about what is disputed with Your permission. Indeed, You are the one who guides whom You will to the straight path." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

In one of the *ma'sur* (practiced) prayers of the companions, there is the following statement:

"O Allah, show us the truth as truth, then guide us to follow it, and show us the falsehood as falsehood, and guide us to avoid it. Do not make the truth and falsehood obscure to us, which will cause us to go astray. And make us leaders for the pious." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim).
text.214:
There are several opinions regarding the reason for the revelation of this verse. First, the opinion of Qatadah, as-Suddi, and most commentators of the Quran (ahli tafsir) who say that this verse was revealed during the Battle of Khandaq when the Muslims experienced various difficulties and emotional pressures, causing them to feel apprehensive and fearful.

Second, another opinion states that this verse was revealed during the Battle of Uhud, when the Muslim forces were pushed back by the enemy troops. In that battle, Sayyidina Hamzah was brutally killed, and the Prophet (peace be upon him) was injured.

Third, the opinion of another group is that this verse was revealed to comfort the hearts of the Muhajirin when they left their hometowns, and their wealth was seized by the polytheists, and the Jews openly showed hostility towards the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and other difficulties he experienced in Medina. This verse indirectly reinforces the previous verses, namely that Muslims should always be steadfast and patient in their struggle.

Allah (SWT) says:

"And We will surely test you with something of fear and hunger and a loss of wealth and lives and fruits, but give good tidings to the patient," (al-Baqarah/2: 155)

and His saying:

"Do the people think that they will be left to say, "We believe" and they will not be tried?" (al-'Ankabut/29: 2)

The heavier and higher the ideals to be achieved, the greater the obstacles and trials that will be experienced. To achieve the pleasure of Allah and obtain Paradise is not easy, but must go through a tenacious struggle full of obstacles and trials, as was the case with the people of the past. They were afflicted with disasters and misery, their prophets were killed, their followers were tortured until some of them had their heads sawn off while alive or burned alive. Because the trials and suffering they experienced were felt for a long time, even though they were sure that Allah's help would come no matter what, their messenger and his followers felt restless and said, "When will the help of Allah come?" That question was answered by Allah, "Indeed, the help of Allah is near." In due time, they will win and defeat the enemy, the persecutors, and the oppressors.
text.215:
Ibn 'Abbas narrated that Amir bin al-Jamuh al-Ansari, an elderly man with considerable wealth, asked the Messenger of Allah (saw), "What wealth is best for me to spend and to whom should I give it?" In response, this verse was revealed. The spending referred to in this verse is voluntary spending, namely charity (sadaqah), not obligatory spending such as zakat and others.

This verse teaches that whatever is spent, whether much or little, the reward is for the one who spends it and is recorded with Allah (swt) as a righteous deed, as explained in a hadith that reads:

"Verily, the reward for your actions belongs to you. I am the One who records it for you." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Dharr al-Giffari).

Whatever is spent should first be given to parents, namely mother and father, because they are the ones who have done the most for their child. They are the ones who raised him/her from the womb, and in childhood struggled to care for his/her growth. After that, spending should be given to relatives, such as children, siblings who need help. They are the ones who should be helped, because if left alone, they will eventually ask others, which will embarrass the family, then to orphans who are not yet able to strive to meet their needs. Finally, to the poor and those who are traveling to cover their needs, alleviating their burden because even though they have no family ties, they are members of the large family of Muslims, who should be helped when they are in trouble.

Whatever is spent by humans, Allah knows it. Therefore, it should not be publicized, because Allah is the One who will repay it and give manifold rewards according to one's sincerity.
text.216:
With the revelation of this verse, the law of war became *wajib kifayah* (a communal obligation) for the purpose of self-defense and liberating from oppression. If the enemy has entered the land of the Muslims, it becomes *wajib 'ain* (an individual obligation). This obligatory law of war was revealed in the second year of the Hijri. When still in Mecca (before the Hijrah), the Prophet Muhammad saw. was forbidden to wage war; only at the beginning of the Hijri year was the Prophet permitted to wage war when necessary.

War was felt as a heavy command for the Muslims because it would expend wealth and lives. Especially at the beginning of the Hijrah to Medina. The Muslims were still few in number, while the polytheists had a large number. War at that time felt very heavy, but because the command to wage war had come to defend the sanctity of the Islamic religion and to exalt the word of Allah ( *kalimatullah*), Allah explained that not everything that is felt heavy and difficult necessarily brings suffering, but hopefully it will bring goodness. How worried is a patient whose treatment requires surgery, while surgery is the most hated and feared, but for the sake of his health he must obey the doctor's advice, only then will the disease disappear and the body become healthy after the operation.

Allah commands something not to trouble humans, because behind the command many secrets that make humans happy will be found. Allah knows more about the matter of secrets, while humans do not know.
text.217:
Fighting in the sacred months is indeed forbidden, it is haram, unless the enemy attacks. When people asked the Messenger of Allah (saw), what is the ruling on fighting in the Haram months, as Abdullah bin Jahsy had done against a caravan of the Quraysh, then revelation came down stating that fighting in that month is haram and a great sin. But preventing people from the path of Allah is an act of disbelief in Allah. And preventing Muslims from entering the Masjidil Haram, expelling Muslims from Mecca, is an even greater sin in the sight of Allah. All of that is *fitnah* which is more dangerous than killing in the Haram month.

*Fitnah* in this verse includes all serious violations such as the things mentioned above and persecuting and torturing Muslims. Such actions are a greater sin than fighting. Like what the disbelieving Quraysh did to Ammar bin Yasir, Bilal, Habbab bin Arat and others. Ammar bin Yasir was tortured with hot iron pressed against his body, so that he would leave the religion of Islam. But he remained in Islam. He was not the only one tortured, but also his father, mother and siblings. Bilal was also tortured by his master, Umayyah bin Khalaf. Bilal was not allowed to eat or drink day and night with his hands and feet tied, thrown into the middle of the scorching desert, a large stone was placed on his back, then Umayyah tortured him while saying, "This torment will continue until you die, if you do not want to leave Islam and return to worship the gods "Lata and Uzza". But Bilal preferred to suffer torment and torture rather than deny Allah and Muhammad. Many followers of the Prophet Muhammad (saw) shared the same fate as Ammar bin Yasir and Bilal.

This cruel method will continue to be launched by the disbelievers against Muslims in all times and places, wherever they have the opportunity, so that Muslims become apostates from their religion. *Murtad* means leaving the religion of Islam. If those *murtad* die in a state of apostasy, all their deeds will be erased and they will abide in hell forever.
text.218:
This verse explains the reward for those who are strong in faith in facing all trials and tribulations. Likewise, the reward for those who migrate, leaving their country which they feel is unsafe, to a safe country to uphold the religion of Allah, such as the migration of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) with his followers from Mecca to Medina, and the reward for those who perform jihad fi sabilillah, both with their wealth and with their lives.

All of them hope for Allah's mercy and forgiveness, and they deserve to attain victory and happiness as a reward for their struggle. Indeed, Allah is Oft-Forgiving, Most Merciful.
text.219:
This verse answers the questions the companions posed to the Prophet Muhammad saw. The answers not only concern the laws of *khamar* (intoxicants) and gambling, but also answer the question of what to spend in charity; and also regarding the issue of orphans.

The prohibition of drinking *khamar* was revealed gradually. This is because drinking *khamar* had become a deeply ingrained custom for the Arabs since the time of *jahiliyah* (ignorance). If it were forbidden all at once, it was feared it would be very burdensome for them. First, it was said that its sin was great, then it was said that intoxicated people should not perform *salat* (prayer); and finally it was said that drinking *khamar* is vile and is a deed of Satan. Then they were reproached by saying, "Will you not then abstain?" In short: drinking *khamar* and gambling are forbidden, and it is *haram* (prohibited) according to Islamic law.

According to the majority of scholars, *khamar* refers to all intoxicating drinks, regardless of what they are made from. So drinking anything that intoxicates is *haram*, whether it is a small or large amount. All health experts agree, both in the past and present, that drinking *khamar* has many dangers. Allah will not forbid something unless it is harmful to humans.

There is no doubt that drinking *khamar* is dangerous to health, mind, and nerves, as well as property and family. Drinking *khamar* is the same as using opium, narcotics, and illegal drugs (narcotics) that cause addiction. A person who is addicted to drinking *khamar* has no value for property; no matter how much the *khamar* costs, they will buy it.

Thus, *khamar* is harmful in social interaction, causing animosity, fights, and so on. Households will be chaotic, neighbors will be unsafe, and society will be damaged because of drinking *khamar*.

The disease of *khamar* addiction is closely related to all acts of immorality and crime. A person who is drunk will not be ashamed to commit adultery in places of immorality such as nightclubs, bars, and so on. These two immoral acts are usually combined in one place. The danger of drinking *khamar* will be even greater if it is mixed with adultery. Not only squandering wealth and indulging in lust, but all kinds of sexually transmitted diseases will spread, children will be born without legitimate fathers, and innocent babies will be murdered. This kind of work is a cursed act that is inhumane, a vile act that is more vile than the actions of animals.

As with drinking *khamar*, Allah also forbids gambling because its dangers are greater than its benefits. Gambling is any game that uses bets where the loser must pay the winner. The bet can be anything: money, goods, and so on.

The danger of gambling is no less than the danger of drinking *khamar*. Gambling quickly causes animosity and anger, and often leads to murder. This danger has been proven from the past to the present. Whenever gambling breaks out in a place, there will always be disputes, animosity, and murder in that place. Reckless acts often occur among gamblers, such as suicide, robbery, and so on, especially if they experience defeat.

Gambling is a dangerous act; as a result of gambling, a good person can become evil, lazy to perform worship, and bored of remembering Allah. He becomes lazy, angry, his eyes are red, and his body is weak. Naturally, his morals become damaged, he does not want to work to earn a living in a good way, and always hopes for victory. In the history of gambling, no one has become rich from gambling. On the contrary, many rich people suddenly fall into poverty and misery because of gambling. Many happy households suddenly fall apart because of gambling.

As for the benefits of drinking *khamar*, they are very few, it can be said that they are meaningless compared to its dangers. For example, *khamar* may be a medicine, can be used as a trade commodity that brings profit, and can inspire soldiers who are going to war, and so on. But all of that is not a significant benefit.

Regarding the dangers of drinking *khamar* and gambling, and what will be suffered by drinkers of *khamar* and gamblers later, in addition to being explained by Allah in the Al-Qur'an, it is also explained in many *hadith*-*hadith* (sayings) of the Prophet Muhammad saw.

After the companions asked about these two very dangerous issues, namely drinking *khamar* and gambling, they asked about what to spend in charity.

In one narration, from Ibn Abi Hatim from Ibn 'Abbas, some of the companions of the Messenger of Allah saw came and asked him, "We do not yet know what *nafkah fi sabilillah* (spending in the way of Allah) is that we are commanded to take out of our wealth?" This verse is the answer. Allah swt deliberately combined the issue of *nafkah* with the issue of *khamar* and gambling in one verse, to be a mirror of comparison for humans, that besides there are people who squander their wealth to commit immorality such as drinking *khamar* and gambling, there are also people who use their wealth to spend in the way of Allah.

People who squander their wealth in the way of immorality will suffer destruction and disaster, while people who use their wealth in the way of Allah will gain happiness and good fortune. What is meant by *nafkah* in this verse is giving *sedekah* (voluntary charity), *amal jariah* (ongoing charity), donations, contributions, and so on, which are *sunah* (recommended), while *zakat* (obligatory charity) is *wajib* (obligatory). This has been explained in other verses. The meaning of *al-'afwa* here is "what is more than needed". So what will be spent in charity is wealth that is more than the basic daily needs.

Allah encourages a person to seek sustenance for the needs of his children and wife and those under his responsibility. But if the sustenance given by Allah is more than those needs, Allah encourages him to give *infak* (charity), which is to give some of the excess wealth for the needs of *fi sabilillah*. For example, to build houses of worship, such as mosques, *musala* (small mosque) or *surau* (prayer room), or to build orphanages or educational institutions such as *madrasah* (Islamic school), student dormitories, the poor, also to students and university students in the form of scholarships, and so on.

Social activities such as those mentioned above can be financed with the *nafkah* given by Muslims. Giving *nafkah* in this case is very important, because it is the lifeblood of development in Islam and becomes a bridge connecting the rich and the poor.

That is how Allah gives guidance with His verses for the happiness of mankind. He shows which path can bring benefits and goodness and which path will plunge into danger and destruction. In this case, humans must think about it. Think not only about the world but also think about the afterlife in every effort and work.

Muslims become victorious and noble when they are willing to use their minds to think about the safety of their lives and their society in this world and in the hereafter. In this world, they become respected and revered people, because they are capable, authoritative, and hold the reins of power. In the afterlife, he becomes a fortunate person because of his many good deeds.
text.220:
Then in this verse, Allah swt simultaneously answers the question about the issue of orphans. Orphans are children who no longer have a father, because he has passed away.

The question regarding orphans arose during the time of the Prophet Muhammad saw from people who had been living with orphans, mixing their wealth with theirs, and eating and drinking together in one house. In this way, the orphans were cared for, both in terms of food and well-being, but then this verse was revealed:

"Indeed, those who devour the property of orphans unjustly are only swallowing fire into their bellies, and they will burn in a blazing Fire." (an-Nisa'/4: 10)

With the revelation of that verse, they became hesitant, fearing that their actions towards orphans had been unjust, including consuming the orphans' wealth. Verse 220 explains that the main point in this matter is the good care of orphans, so that their lives are not wasted. They should not be neglected and their peace and well-being should be guaranteed. All kinds of care and protection of orphans are good deeds. Even if they are brought to live in the same house, that is also good, because living together is like living as siblings. It is as if the orphan is a younger sibling, whose health is cared for like caring for a sibling, or one's own child. So it is permissible to mix the wealth of orphans with the wealth of the person who cares for them, as long as there is an intention for their safety and not to harm them. The matter of a person's intention and what is stored in their heart, only Allah knows, because Allah is All-Knowing of who is good and who is evil. It often happens that people say they intend to take good care of orphans, but in reality, they abuse and torture them.

In caring for orphans, it depends on the ability of the caregiver, but the main thing is to ensure the safety of the orphans, and that they are not wasted, whether regarding their food and drink needs, clothing and shelter, as well as education and health, especially regarding their property, if any. That must be maintained as well as possible. If the orphans are wasted, it will certainly arouse the wrath of Allah swt. Indeed, He is All-Powerful and All-Wise in regulating the welfare of His servants.
text.221:
In this verse, it is emphasized that it is forbidden for a Muslim to marry a polytheistic woman and forbidden to marry a believing woman to a polytheistic man, unless they have believed. Even if they are beautiful and handsome, dashing, rich, and so on, a believing female slave or male slave is better to marry than them. From the believing women, there are also quite a few who are beautiful, attractive, and have good character.

In a hadith, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Do not marry women for their beauty, perhaps that beauty will destroy them. Do not marry them for their wealth, perhaps that wealth will cause them to be disobedient and stubborn. But marry them for their religion (faith and character). A black female slave who is religious is better than those mentioned above." (Narrated by Ibn Majah from Abdullah bin 'Umar).

In another hadith, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"A woman is married for four reasons: for her wealth, for her lineage, for her beauty, and for her religion. Choose the one who is religious, and you will be successful." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

Marriage is closely related to religion. Polytheists are not religious people; they worship other than Allah. In the matter of marriage with polytheists, there is a strong prohibition, but in the matter of association and community, it is normal. Because marriage is closely related to offspring, and offspring are closely related to inheritance, food and drink, and it is related to education and the development of Islam.

Marriage with polytheists is considered dangerous as explained above, so Allah forbids establishing marital relations with them. The polytheistic group will always plunge Muslims into danger in this world and plunge them into hell in the hereafter, while Allah's teachings to the believers always lead to happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.222:
This verse explains menstruation and how to deal with women who are menstruating. Menstrual blood consists of weak egg cells that are not fertilized, which are discharged from a woman's uterus every month, lasting at least a day and a night, usually 6 or 7 days, and at most 15 days. People in the past had various attitudes towards menstruating women. The Jews were very strict, refusing to associate with their menstruating wives, refusing to eat and drink together, refusing to live in the same house with them, and refusing to touch menstruating women because their skin was considered impure.

The Christians had a different attitude; they associated normally with menstruating women, with no difference between those who were menstruating and those who were not. They associated with them freely and did as they pleased. The Arabs in the Jahiliyyah era had the same attitude as the Jews. Islam forbids husbands from having intercourse with their wives while they are menstruating. Health experts have explained a lot about the dangers of having intercourse with menstruating women. The end of the verse explains that Allah is very loving to those who repent from their mistakes and to those who always maintain cleanliness.

The menstrual period in adult women occurs when an unfertilized egg is expelled from the body. Because fertilization does not occur, the uterine wall, which was initially ready to receive fertilization, will contract. With this contraction, the unfertilized egg will be expelled along with blood discharged from ruptured capillaries. After the egg and blood are expelled, the process of egg maturation will begin again.

This entire process is repeated continuously at specific time intervals. Every month, a new egg is formed, the same hormones are also released, all at the same time. Thus, women have a specific time when they are truly ready to be fertilized. If fertilization occurs, the continuously rotating menstrual pattern will change.

The occurrence of "emptiness" in the uterus can only be detected through anatomical examination of the womb using sophisticated equipment. However, it turns out that this change, which can only be revealed by modern science, has been revealed in the Al-Qur'an, which means:

"Allah knows what every female bears and what the wombs lose [of their time] or exceed. And everything with Him is by due measure." (ar-Ra'd/13: 8)

The verse above speaks about the occurrence of menstruation. The translation of the verse does not adequately show the process of menstruation. However, the English translation seems to express this process better, as follows:

"Allah knows what every female bears and every shrinking of the womb and every swelling. Everything has its measure with Him". (ar-Ra'd/13: 8)

At the beginning of the menstrual period, the mucus layer lining the uterine wall (the endometrium layer) is 0.5 mm thick. Under the influence of hormones secreted by the ovaries, this layer will thicken to 5-6 mm. This layer is then shed when the egg is not fertilized. As can be seen from the verse above, the thickening and shedding of the layer on the uterine wall is expressed by the translations "shrinking" and "swelling."
text.223:
In this verse, wives are likened to fields for cultivation and for spreading seeds. It is permissible to approach the garden from any direction as long as it is for spreading seeds and for the plants to grow well and fertile. Wives are the place to spread the seeds of offspring so that they develop well, so a husband may mix with his wife in any way he likes, as long as it does not cause harm.

It is clear that the purpose of marriage is for the happiness of family life, including having offspring, not just for pleasure and releasing desires. For this reason, Allah commands us to do good deeds, as preparation for the future so that we may have righteous offspring, useful to religion and nation, and devoted to their parents.

Then Allah commands husbands to be careful in protecting their wives and children, protecting their households, lest they be destroyed and fall apart. Therefore, be mindful of Allah. Because in the end, mankind will return to Allah alone, and will meet Him in the afterlife to receive recompense for every deed they did in the world. Allah swt commands that every believing person who is mindful of Him be given the good news that they will obtain happiness in this world and in the hereafter.

The soil used for cultivation is fertile soil, full of nutrients and other fertilizer substances, including minerals. When seeds are put into such fertile soil, the seeds will immediately germinate and grow luxuriantly. This sprout grows with the energy it gets from the soil's nutrients. It is clear that the soil used for cultivation is a fertile medium for the growth of seeds into new plants. In the verse above, it is explained that "your wives are (like) a field for you to cultivate." Indeed, this is the case, because the womb in every woman is a fertile medium for conception between sperm (male seed) and the egg cell, which is found in the woman's womb. This conception event will soon be followed by growth into a fetus, aided by 'food' in the form of nutrients or vitamins found in the mother's womb. Even the mother's mitochondria will supply energy to the process of fetal growth into a baby. So the analogy above is accurate, that wives are fields or land for cultivation.
text.224:
This verse warns people to be careful in using Allah's name when swearing oaths. Do not dare to swear by mentioning Allah's name for things that are not good and are forbidden by religion, because Allah's name is very noble and must be glorified.

Narrated by Ibn Jarir that the reason for the revelation of verse 224 was when Abu Bakr swore by mentioning Allah's name that he would no longer help a relative (an-Nur/24:22) named Mistah who participated in spreading false news that defamed the name of Aisyah, the wife of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The slanderous story about Aisyah by the hypocrites is called *hadisul-ifki* (false news).

This verse prohibits swearing not to do good, not to be pious, or not to make *islah* (reconciliation) between people. If such an oath has been uttered, it must be broken (canceled), because the oath is out of place, but after the oath is broken, it must be atoned for by paying *kaffarat*, which is freeing a slave, or feeding ten poor people, or giving them clothes, or if unable to do so, fasting for 3 days.

Allah always hears and knows what is said and done by everyone. Swearing that is only a verbal utterance without sincerity will not be punished by Allah. But an oath that comes from the heart and is spoken by the tongue will be considered an oath.
text.225:
This verse warns people to be careful in using Allah's name when swearing oaths. Do not dare to swear by mentioning Allah's name for things that are not good and are forbidden by religion, because Allah's name is very noble and must be glorified.

It is narrated by Ibn Jarir that the reason for the revelation of verse 224 was when Abu Bakr swore by mentioning Allah's name that he would no longer help a relative of his (an-Nur/24:22) named Mistah, who participated in spreading false news that defamed the name of Aisyah, the wife of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). The slanderous story about Aisyah by the hypocrites is called *hadisul-ifki* (false news).

This verse prohibits swearing not to do good, not to be pious, or not to make reconciliation among people. If such an oath has been uttered, it is obligatory to break (cancel) it, because the oath is not in its place, but after the oath is broken, it must be atoned for by paying *kaffarat*, which is freeing a slave, or feeding ten poor people, or giving them clothes, or if one is unable to do so, fasting for 3 days.

Allah always hears and knows what is said and done by everyone. Swearing that is only a verbal utterance without sincerity will not be punished by Allah. But an oath that comes from the heart and is spoken by the tongue will be considered an oath.
text.226: This verse relates to someone who swears not to have relations with his wife, such as, "By Allah, I will not have intercourse with you again." Such an oath is called *ila'*. In this case, the wife will certainly be tormented and suffer, because she is neither being had relations with nor divorced (*ditalak*). Such a situation should not be allowed to drag on, because such an act is an act of injustice (*zalim*). When it is close to four months after taking the oath, the husband must make a decision whether he will return to living as husband and wife or divorce. If the husband decides to reconcile with his wife, then that is better, but he must pay the expiation (*kafarat*) for the oath. He must reorganize his household, educate his children, and not repeat such an oath again. But if he intends to divorce, then divorce her in a good manner, so that the wife is not oppressed, because Allah is All-Hearing, All-Knowing.
text.227: This verse relates to someone who swears not to have marital relations with his wife, such as, "By Allah, I will not have intercourse with you again." Such an oath is called *ila'*. In this case, the wife will certainly be tormented and suffer, because she is neither having relations nor being divorced (*talaq*). Such a situation should not be allowed to drag on, because such an act is an act of injustice (*zalim*). When it is close to four months after taking the oath, the husband must make a decision whether he will return to living as husband and wife or divorce. If the husband decides to reconcile with his wife, then that is better, but he must pay the expiation (*kaffarat*) for the oath. He must reorganize his household, educate his children, and not repeat such an oath again. But if he intends to divorce, then divorce her in a good manner, so that the wife is not oppressed, because Allah is All-Hearing, All-Knowing.
text.228:
In this verse, the law of divorce (talak) is explained as a complement to the laws mentioned in the previous verses. If a wife who has menstrual periods is divorced by her husband, then she must patiently wait for three *quru'* before being allowed to marry another man.

Three *quru'* is three periods of purity according to the majority of scholars (jumhur ulama). This is called the waiting period (*iddah*), which is a period of waiting. As long as she is still in the *iddah* period, she is not allowed to hide what has happened in her womb, whether she is pregnant or menstruating again. Every wife who believes in Allah and the Last Day must be honest, frankly admitting what has happened in her womb.

During the Jahiliyyah period, among dishonest wives, they often did not say that they were pregnant. After her *iddah* ended, she married another man, and not long after the marriage, her child was born, causing disputes and quarrels between the two husbands. If the former husband did not acknowledge that it was his child, then the innocent baby would be oppressed, because the mother was not honest when she was still in the *iddah* period. There were also cases in that era where a wife did not want to be frank that her *iddah* had ended, she said she was still menstruating, her intention in lying was so that her husband would continue to provide for her during her *iddah*, so this verse was revealed prohibiting divorced wives from hiding what happened in their womb. As long as the divorced woman is still in *iddah*, the husband may take her back (*rujuk*), which is better if his intention in taking her back is to rebuild his good household. The *iddah* period is enough time for the husband to think about whether he will take her back (especially if there are children) or divorce.

But if the *rujuk* is not motivated by good intentions, namely only to take revenge, or to trouble and hurt the wife, then such actions are forbidden by Allah and are an act of injustice towards women. The divorce given to the wife in this way is called *talak raj'i*, which is a divorce that can still be revoked before the *iddah* period ends.

Then Allah's saying that women have rights equivalent to men and that men have one degree of advantage over their wives, is evidence that in good deeds to achieve progress in all aspects of life, especially in the field of knowledge, women and men have equal rights and obligations. Nevertheless, these rights and obligations are adjusted to their nature, both physically and mentally. For example, a wife has the obligation to manage the household, educate children and maintain their health, maintain cleanliness and household secrets, and so on. While the husband, as the head of the family, works and strives to earn a halal living to provide for his wife and children. In the family/household, husband and wife are equal partners, helping each other in realizing a sakinah household that is pleasing to Allah SWT. The differences that exist are to complement and cooperate, not as something contradictory in building a happy household.

Although family sustenance is the husband's obligation, it does not mean that the wife is not allowed to help with family sustenance, but if the wife spends money/sustenance for the household, it is only as *tabarru'* not as an obligation. If the husband falls into poverty, due to termination of employment (PHK) or illness that makes him unable to provide sustenance, then the wife is obliged to help with household expenses, but if the husband is already able to provide sustenance, then he is obliged to replace the expenses that have been incurred by the wife, unless the wife is willing not to be replaced, then the sustenance she has spent becomes voluntary assistance to the household.

In society, women are allowed to compete with men to seek progress and do good deeds. If someone accuses that Islam does not give fundamental freedom to women, that is an untrue accusation. It was Islam that first raised the status of women as high as possible, before the advanced world today was able to do so. It has been 14 centuries since Islam gave rights and obligations to women and men, while the rest of the world at that time was still in darkness. A husband, as the head of the household, is responsible for the welfare and safety of the household by providing household expenses obtained in a halal way. Thus Allah regulates the relationship between husband and wife in harmonious ways to achieve happiness in married life.
text.229:
This verse explains that *talak raj'i* (revocable divorce) is only valid twice. If *talak* has been pronounced three times, reconciliation is no longer permitted, and it is called *talak ba'in* (irrevocable divorce). Scholars hold the opinion that if someone pronounces *talak* three times at once, it is counted as three pronouncements, but some scholars hold the opinion that it counts as one.

During the Jahiliyyah (pre-Islamic era), Arabs pronounced *talak* according to their desires and without limit, then they would reconcile as they pleased. Such actions made a mockery of women and humiliated them, even though they are servants of Allah who must be respected and honored, just like men. Therefore, the revelation of this verse was to change and improve that bad situation, to regulate matters of marriage, divorce, and reconciliation in the best possible way.

As long as it is still *talak* one or *talak* two, the husband may reconcile in a good manner, or continue with the divorce in a good manner as well. What is meant by "good manner" is that during the *iddah* (waiting period), the woman still receives living expenses, is still allowed to stay in her husband's house, and then the division of marital property is carried out in a good manner as well, so that the woman has been given her rights as they should be. If they are truly divorced, the husband is not allowed to take back what he has given to his wife, such as the *mahar* (dowry) and other things; on the contrary, the *mahar* should be increased with gifts, to ensure her livelihood after the divorce.

If it is feared that the husband and wife will not be able to carry out the provisions of Allah, if this is caused by the husband, then he is not allowed to take back what he has given to his wife. But if it is caused by the wife because of hatred for her husband or fear that she will not be fair to him, then the wife may give back the property that her husband has given her to release herself from the bonds of marriage, so that her husband will divorce her, and her husband is not sinful in taking back his gift. The action of a wife like this, namely, willingly giving some of her property to her husband in order to be divorced, is called *khulu'*.

It is narrated by al-Bukhari, Ibn Majah, and an-Nasa'i' from Ibn 'Abbas that a woman named Jamilah, the sister of 'Abdullah bin Ubay bin Salul, the wife of Sabit bin Qais, came to the Prophet Muhammad (saw) and said, "O Messenger of Allah, I will no longer obey my husband Sabit bin Qais because I am angry at seeing his bad behavior, I fear that I will become a disbeliever again because of betraying and disobeying my husband." The Messenger of Allah (saw) asked, "Are you willing to give back the garden that your husband gave you as a *maskawin* (dowry) before, and with that, you will be divorced?" Jamilah replied, "I am willing to return it as long as I am divorced, O Messenger of Allah." Then the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "O Sabit, take back your garden and divorce her."

Willingly giving back the garden that has become her property, as long as she is divorced, is called redeeming oneself, and the word "garden" is a *kuniyah* (euphemism) for *mahar*. The divorce is called *khulu'*, reconciliation is not allowed except with a new contract and *mahar*, and the redemption is called *'iwadh*.

These provisions are the decrees of Allah that regulate household life that must not be violated, so that a happy household is realized. So whoever does not obey them, they are the wrongdoers.
text.230:
This verse explains that if a triple talaq (divorce) has been pronounced, reconciliation is no longer permissible. If both parties wish to return to living together as husband and wife, then the woman must first marry another man, and have consummated the marriage with her new husband, and then be divorced at her own volition, and her waiting period ('iddah) must have ended, only then are the two allowed to reconcile.

This verse instructs us to be careful in pronouncing talaq, not to be rash or impulsive. Think carefully, because being impulsive in pronouncing talaq will ultimately lead to regret. Pronouncing talaq is permitted in Islam, but it is an act that is disliked by Allah. The consequences of divorce are significant, both for the husband, and especially for the wife and children. Therefore, if it is still within the second talaq, it is better to reconcile, if there is still hope for a happy household and to carry out the commands of Allah in the best possible way.
text.231:
This verse explains the proper way for a husband who has divorced his wife to act, as a clarification of the previous verses. As for the reason for the revelation of this verse, there are two narrations. First, Ibn Jarir narrates from Ibn 'Abbas that during the time of the Prophet Muhammad (saw), there was a man who divorced his wife, then before her 'iddah period ended, he took her back. After that, he divorced her again and then took her back again. This was done to hurt and mistreat his wife, so the verse above was revealed.

The second narration is told by as-Suddi that this verse was revealed concerning the actions of a companion from the Ansar, namely Thabit bin Yasar, who had divorced his wife. When only two or three days remained of his wife's 'iddah period, he took her back, then divorced her again with the intention of troubling his wife, so this verse was revealed, prohibiting such actions.

If a husband has divorced his wife, then when the 'iddah period of his wife is nearing its end, he should choose one of two options, namely to reconcile (rujuk) or to remain divorced in a good manner. With the end of the 'iddah, the marriage between husband and wife is terminated, and his ex-wife is free to choose another partner.

Furthermore, this verse forbids a husband from reconciling with his wife with the intention of hurting and mistreating her. This prohibition of Allah illustrates the behavior of society during the Jahiliyyah period, where a husband divorced his wife without a specific limit, and every time the end of the 'iddah period approached, the husband would reconcile and so on. It also serves as an explanation of the actions of the companion Thabit bin Yasar, which have been described in the reason for the revelation of this verse. A husband who acts in this way is mistreating himself, an act that can cause hostility with the relatives of his wife's family and is also hated by society, and ultimately he will not escape the wrath of Allah.

In this verse, Allah forbids people from making a mockery of His laws, including the laws that regulate the relationship between husband and wife, to lead people to a happy life in this world and the hereafter. These provisions are a blessing from Allah that must be remembered and practiced as a sign of gratitude to Him.

There is no disagreement among the scholars within the four madhhabs regarding the validity of a divorce pronounced by a husband in a playful manner (not seriously). This is in line with the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (saw):

There are three matters which, if done seriously, will be taken seriously, and if done playfully, will be taken seriously: marriage, divorce, and reconciliation (rujuk). (Narrated by al-Arba'ah except an-Nasa'i from Abu Hurairah)

Having sexual intercourse with a wife who is still in 'iddah raj'i is haram according to the Shafi'i madhhab, because the validity of reconciliation (rujuk) is by utterance (lafal). Meanwhile, according to the Hanafi and Hanbali madhhabs, sexual intercourse is considered reconciliation even without lafal (utterance).
text.232:
This verse explains about a woman who is divorced by her husband and the possibility of her remarrying, whether she will marry her ex-husband or another man. In responding to this verse, the scholars of jurisprudence (fiqh) disagree about who is meant by the verse, especially in the phrase "do not prevent them."

Imam Shafi'i is of the opinion that the prohibition is addressed to the guardian (wali), based on a hadith narrated by Imam al-Bukhari about Qasim Ma'qil bin Yasir. Ma'qil had a sister who was married to Abibaddah. Then she was divorced by her husband. After her waiting period ('iddah) ended, Abibaddah felt regret and wanted to return to his ex-wife. But Ma'qil, as the guardian, did not agree, so this event was known to the Messenger of Allah (saw) and then the verse above was revealed, and Ma'qil allowed Abibaddah to return to his sister.

From the narration that is the reason for the revelation of this verse, it is clear that the prohibition is addressed to the guardian. If the prohibition in the verse was not addressed to the guardian, the woman would have been able to marry herself and would not have been delayed by Ma'qil's attitude as her guardian.

So it is clear that the marriage contract is still carried out by the guardian. Imam Hanafi holds the opposite opinion; the prohibition is addressed not to the guardian but to the husband. This can happen if the ex-husband prevents his ex-wife from marrying someone else. Thus, according to Abu Hanifah, the verse does not indicate that a guardian is a condition for the validity of a marriage contract. As is known, Imam Abu Hanifah is of the opinion that a woman who is a widow can carry out a marriage contract without going through a guardian.

Neither the guardian nor the ex-husband should prevent a woman who is going to marry. The custom that prevailed in the days of ignorance (jahiliyyah) was that the guardians interfered too much in an arbitrary manner in matters of marriage, so that women did not have the freedom to choose their future husbands, and they were even forced to marry men they did not like. Such is the teaching of the Qur'an regarding marriage law, a teaching that can only be accepted by those who believe in Allah and the Last Day, because only those who believe can accept the teachings of Allah by setting aside the desires of their lust in suppressing women.

Returning to the teachings of Allah is a good and commendable deed. Allah is All-Knowing and you do not know.
text.233:
Every mother (even if she is a widow) is obligated to breastfeed her child until the child reaches the age of two years. There is no harm if the breastfeeding period is less than that period if both parents see a benefit in it. Likewise, every father is obligated to fulfill the needs of the mothers, both clothing and food, according to their needs. The mother is like a vessel for the child, while the father is the owner of that vessel. Therefore, it is only natural that the father is obligated to provide for those under his responsibility and to maintain and care for his property.

Allah obligates the mother to breastfeed her baby because breast milk has a great influence on the child. Research by medical experts shows that breast milk consists of truly pure essence. Breast milk is also the best food for babies, and this is undoubtedly agreed upon by nutritionists. In addition, the mother, by her very nature, has a deep affection, so breastfeeding directly from the mother is closely related to the child's psychological and mental development. Thus, it is inappropriate for some mothers to refuse to breastfeed their children solely for personal interests, for example, to maintain their beauty. In fact, this contradicts their own nature, and indirectly they lose the opportunity to build a foundation of maternal relationship with their own child in the emotional realm.

Such is the division of obligations of both parents towards their baby, as regulated by Allah SWT. Meanwhile, relief is also given to the obligation, for example, if the mother's health is disturbed or a doctor says it is not good if the child is breastfed by the mother for some reason, then it is okay if the child receives breast milk or food from someone else.

Likewise, if the father is unable to fulfill his obligations due to poverty, then he may fulfill his obligations according to his ability. This relief proves that the child should not be made a cause of harm, either to the father or to the mother. In other words, the obligation does not necessarily apply absolutely, resulting in harm to both of them. One party should not harm the other by making the child a scapegoat. For example, because the mother knows that the father is obligated to provide, she resorts to extortion by not breastfeeding or caring for the baby without a certain amount of money. Or the father is very stingy in providing, so the mother suffers because of it.

Furthermore, if one of the parents is unable to fulfill the obligation or dies, then these obligations are transferred to the heirs. The duration of breastfeeding is two years, however, if based on deliberation between the father and mother for the benefit of the child, they agree to stop it before the age of two years or continue it beyond two years, then this is permissible.

Likewise, if they take another woman to breastfeed their child, then this is okay, provided that the woman who breastfeeds is given appropriate compensation, so that the benefit is guaranteed for both the child and the woman who breastfeeds.

Fiqh scholars differ on who has the right to breastfeed and care for the child if a divorce occurs between husband and wife. Is the care the obligation of the mother or the obligation of the father? Imam Malik is of the opinion that the mother is obligated to breastfeed the child, even if she does not have breast milk; if she still has wealth, then the child is breastfed by someone else using the mother's wealth. Imam Shafi'i in this case is of the opinion that the obligation is the father's obligation.
text.234:
The waiting period ('Iddah) for women whose husbands have died is four months and ten days. Although this verse appears general (encompassing all women whose husbands have died), there is an exception for those who are not pregnant. Because for pregnant women, there is another ruling in another verse. This will be explained further in the commentary on verse 240. During the 'Iddah period, she is not allowed to adorn herself, prepare to receive proposals, or make promises to accept proposals. Likewise, she is not allowed to leave the house except for matters permitted by religion. Because in addition to that period being for determining the cleanliness of her womb (pregnant or not pregnant), it is also used as a period of mourning. If she is not pregnant, then she is obligated to mourn, respecting the bond of husband and wife, both towards the deceased husband and towards his family. She must mourn as long as she is in 'Iddah. After the four months and ten days have passed, she is allowed to do everything concerning herself in a reasonable manner, for example, accepting proposals, leaving the house, and other actions that do not contradict the religion.

Allah knows everything that humans do. This verse affirms that regarding this period of mourning, Islam provides the best possible path that suits human needs. Women in the pre-Islamic era (Jahiliyyah) observed a period of mourning for a full year and were not allowed to wear jewelry, eat delicious food, or show themselves in public. Even in some community groups, women undergoing this period of mourning had to do things that were far more burdensome than what people did in the Jahiliyyah era, such as: continuously crying and wailing. They were not allowed to adorn themselves and so on. They observed this period of mourning not only because of the death of their husbands, but also because of the death of children, they mourned in such a way. So, what is regulated by Islam is precise: that the period of mourning for a woman whose husband has died should not be more than four months and ten days, and for the death of other relatives, it should not be more than three days.

Deviations from this provision must be avoided because Allah is All-Knowing of everything that humans do.
text.235:
This verse explains that a man is permitted to use suggestive words to propose to a woman who is still in her *iddah* period, whether the *iddah* is due to the death of her husband or due to a *talaq ba'in* (irrevocable divorce). However, this is absolutely not permitted if the woman is in the *iddah* period of a *talaq raj'i* (revocable divorce).

The expression that describes the man's intention to marry her, once her *iddah* is complete, is, for example, if the man says, "I would be very happy to have a wife who has qualities like you," or other expressions that do not directly express his intention. Allah forbids a man from making a promise to marry, or persuading her to marry secretly, or holding secret meetings. This is not permitted because it is feared that *fitnah* (temptation, discord) will occur.

A man is not prohibited from proposing to a woman who is still in the *iddah* period of a *talaq ba'in* if the proposal is done indirectly, or is still in the planning stage, because Allah knows that humans cannot always hide the contents of their hearts. The proposal should not be made openly but should be with figurative words that are a prelude, which will be followed up in the form of a formal proposal, when the woman's *iddah* has ended. A proposal with indirect allusions is not permitted to a woman who is still in the *iddah* of a *talaq raj'i*, because there is still a possibility that the woman will return to her former husband.

This method is intended so that the feelings of the woman who is mourning are not offended, and also to avoid a bad reaction from the former husband's family and the general public. Therefore, a marriage contract (*akad nikah*) with a woman who is still in *iddah* is prohibited. A prohibition that is considered *haram qath'i* (absolutely forbidden), and the marriage contract must be annulled.
text.236: A husband who divorces his wife before *dukhul* (consummation), and before determining the amount of the *mahar* (dowry), is not obligated to pay the *mahar*. However, he is encouraged to give *mut'ah*, which is a gift to please his former wife. The size of the gift depends on the husband; the wealthy according to his wealth, and the less capable according to what he can afford. Giving *mut'ah* is a recommendation for men who want to do good.
text.237:
If a husband pronounces divorce (talak) before consummation (of the marriage) while he has already determined the amount of the dowry (mahar), then the right of his ex-wife is half of that dowry amount, which she can claim unless she willingly accepts the divorce. The woman can receive the full dowry without returning half of it if her former husband willingly relinquishes it.

The act of willingly relinquishing the full dowry is closer to piety (taqwa). It is reasonable for a husband to relinquish it if the divorce occurred due to his desire. Likewise, it is reasonable for a wife to relinquish her right to the dowry she should receive if the reasons for the divorce originate from her side.

According to the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, if *dukhul* (consummation) has occurred and the amount of the dowry was not mentioned at the time of the marriage contract (akad nikah), then the amount of the dowry is according to *mahar misil*, which is the dowry equivalent to the woman's position among her family and community.
text.238:
This verse explains the virtue of performing prayer (salat) and always maintaining it. The family is a part of society, and in fulfilling all its needs and life's problems, it often encounters difficulties that can sometimes lead it to things forbidden by religion. Therefore, a good way has been given for humans to do so that their worldly relationship with piety to Allah is always guaranteed by always maintaining prayer. Starting from waking up before making contact with other humans, he remembers and pleads first with Allah (at dawn). Then, after he interacts with society, and it is very possible that actions not pleasing to Allah occur, to remind and save him, he is called to connect again with Allah at midday (Zuhr prayer). So it continues for 24 hours. Thus, there is always a connection between human busyness (to fulfill their life's needs) with remembering Allah and carrying out His commands. This has an influence and leaves a mark on the soul and life of humans, as it is affirmed that through prayer, humans can avoid evil and reprehensible deeds. In addition, maintaining prayer is proof of faith in Allah and is an absolute requirement for the life of a Muslim, strengthening the bonds of brotherhood, and guaranteeing human rights. According to a narration from Ahmad, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"The agreement between us and the disbelievers is prayer; whoever abandons it (intentionally) has become a disbeliever." (Narrated by Ahmad)

In another hadith narrated by Ahmad and ath-Thabrani, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Whoever always maintains prayer will have light and guidance and will have salvation on the Day of Judgment. Conversely, whoever does not maintain prayer will have no light, guidance, or salvation. In the afterlife, he will be with Pharaoh, Haman, and Ubai bin Khalaf in hell." (Narrated by Ahmad and ath-Thabrani)

The verses above explain how important it is to guard and maintain prayer. A person who carries out this command truly becomes a pious creature of Allah, and his life will always be safe, within Allah's forgiveness and pleasure (magfirah and rida).

As for the reason for the revelation of this verse, according to a narration from Zaid bin Thabit, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) always performed the Zuhr prayer, even on hot days, which the companions found difficult, so this verse was revealed. Allah commanded the Muslims to always maintain the five daily prayers. If the prayer is performed, it can protect oneself from doing evil and reprehensible things. Prayer can be a comforter of the soul from all the anxieties that befall oneself. Therefore, prayer is the pillar of religion.

Allah emphasizes the middle prayer (salat wustha). According to the majority of scholars (jumhur Ulama), the middle prayer is the Asr prayer. Allah also teaches that in performing prayer, we should be humble and submissive (khusyuk and tawaduk). Because focusing the mind solely on Allah is the best level of prayer, and this prayer is what can leave a mark on the human soul.

Because of the importance of performing and maintaining this prayer, a Muslim should not abandon it in any situation. Prayer should still not be abandoned, even in an atmosphere of anxiety about life, property, or position. In a state of excuse ('uzur), prayer can be performed in a way that is possible, whether on foot, riding, or sick. Then, after the excuse disappears, especially in the form of anxiety, one should be grateful to Allah, because Allah teaches humans things they did not know, including the manner (kaifiat) of performing prayer in unsafe times/in a state of war.
text.239:
This verse explains the virtue of performing prayer (salat) and always maintaining it. The family is a part of society, and in fulfilling all its needs and life's problems, it often encounters difficulties that can sometimes lead it to things forbidden by religion. Therefore, a good way has been given for humans to do so that their worldly relationship with piety to Allah is always guaranteed by always maintaining prayer. Starting from waking up before making contact with other humans, he remembers and pleads first with Allah (at dawn). Then, after he interacts with society, and it is very possible that actions not pleasing to Allah occur, to remind and save him, he is called to connect again with Allah at midday (Zuhr prayer). So it goes on for 24 hours. Thus, there is always a connection between human activities (to fulfill their life's needs) with remembering Allah and carrying out His commands. This has an influence and leaves a mark on the soul and life of humans, as it is affirmed that through prayer, humans can avoid evil and immoral deeds. In addition, maintaining prayer is proof of faith in Allah and is an absolute requirement for the life of a Muslim, strengthening the bonds of brotherhood, and guaranteeing human rights. According to a narration from Ahmad, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"The agreement between us and the disbelievers is prayer; whoever abandons it (intentionally) has become a disbeliever." (Narrated by Ahmad)

In another hadith narrated by Ahmad and ath-Thabrani, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Whoever always maintains prayer will have light and guidance and will have salvation on the Day of Judgment. Conversely, whoever does not maintain prayer will have no light, guidance, or salvation. In the hereafter, he will be with Pharaoh, Haman, and Ubai bin Khalaf in hell." (Narrated by Ahmad and ath-Thabrani)

The verses above explain how important it is to guard and maintain prayer. A person who carries out this command truly becomes a pious servant of Allah, and his life will always be safe, within Allah's forgiveness and pleasure (magfirah and rida).

As for the reason for the revelation of this verse, according to a narration from Zaid bin Thabit, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) always performed the Zuhr prayer, even on hot days, which the companions felt were difficult, so this verse was revealed. Allah commanded the Muslims to always maintain the five daily prayers. If the prayer is performed, it can protect oneself from doing evil and immoral things. Prayer can be a comforter of the soul from all the anxieties that befall oneself. Therefore, prayer is the pillar of religion.

Allah emphasizes the middle prayer (salat wustha). According to the majority of scholars (jumhur Ulama), the middle prayer is the Asr prayer. Allah also teaches that in performing prayer, we should be humble and submissive (khusyuk and tawaduk). Because focusing the mind solely on Allah is the best level of prayer, and this prayer is what can leave a mark on the human soul.

Because of the importance of performing and maintaining this prayer, a Muslim should not abandon it in any situation. Prayer must not be abandoned, even in a state of anxiety about life, property, or position. In a state of hardship ('uzur), prayer can be performed in a way that is possible, whether on foot, riding, or sick. Then, after the hardship is gone, especially in the form of anxiety, one should be grateful to Allah, because Allah has taught humans things they did not know, including the manner (kaifiat) of performing prayer in unsafe times/in a state of war.
text.240:
Allah encourages husbands, when they feel their death is near, to make a will for their wives, namely by providing a portion of their wealth for their expenses for one year, while remaining in their home. If the wife leaves the house after a year, then the husband's family should not prevent the wife's actions because it does not violate religious teachings. For example, to be active in the community and show her willingness to remarry. Because her status is free, unlike the customs of *jahiliyyah*, where women were inherited property. Allah is All-Wise in establishing laws for the benefit of His servants.

It is necessary to explain here the views of the *tafsir* scholars regarding verse 240, namely, just as *ushul* scholars differ on the issue of *nasikh* and *mansukh* in the Qur'an, there are also differences among the *tafsir* scholars.

There are *mufassir* who acknowledge the existence of *nasikh* and *mansukh* in the Qur'an and some who do not. The *tafsir* scholars who acknowledge *nasikh* in the Qur'an interpret that this verse commands the husband to make a will, namely setting aside a portion of his wealth for his widowed wife for a period of one year and that she remains in her husband's residence. This indicates that the *idah* period for death is one year long. Thus, between these two verses (240 and 234) there is a conflicting ruling. This group views that:

(a) The verse indicating the *idah* period for death is one year is later in placement than the verse that establishes the *idah* period for death as 4 months and ten days, but in the history of its revelation it came earlier. On this basis, verse 234 which establishes the *idah* period for death as 4 months and 10 days *nasakh* the ruling of verse 240.

(b) If the existence of *nasakh* in the Qur'an is not acknowledged, then the apparent meaning of this verse obligates the husband to make a will for his wife. Thus, the wife receives two types of shares, first a share as a wife (heir) which is established by the inheritance verses, and second, a share as a bequest according to this verse. But this verse is *takhsis* with a *sahih* hadith which reads: ("There is no bequest for an heir," [Narrated by Ahmad and the Four Imams except an-Nasa'i]), so the wife does not receive two types of shares.
text.241: Every divorced woman has the right to receive *mut'ah* as a consolation from her former husband in a good manner. The husband who provides this consolation is one who is pious towards Allah, and therefore is generous in providing assistance to his former wife with sincerity of heart, in accordance with the guidance of religion, which is to take a wife in a good manner or divorce her in a good manner.
text.242: Thus, Allah explains His laws, which are often accompanied by causes and consequences, to be a guide for mankind in achieving benefit (maslahah), so that they may be heeded by mankind.
text.243:
In this verse, Allah provides a *tamsil* or parable for a group of people who are discouraged, unwilling to strive for the progress of their society and religion. With this verse, Allah gives encouragement so that these traits are not emulated, and that people should persistently strive for the glory of their nation and religion. It also explains the story of people who fled their homeland, numbering in the thousands. They should have been brave, capable of defending their homeland, but they were weak and lost their spirit out of fear of death.

What was pictured in the minds of those who fled was a path to safety. However, the opposite happened: their flight strengthened the enemy's position to easily colonize them. To those who were cowardly like this, Allah says, "Woe to you, for you are cowards."

Then, after they became aware and united again, Allah gave His mercy by reviving their spirit so that they rose up, gathering strength to free themselves from the slavery of the colonizers because Allah has bounty, is Most Forbearing towards mankind, yet mankind is ungrateful to Him.

Even though Allah revived their spirit as His bounty, many are still ungrateful to Him. From this verse, we can learn that if a people always oppose the teachings of Allah, then this people will always be in danger with various trials from Him.

This has become *sunatullah* for past peoples until now. According to some *mufassirun* (Quranic commentators), this verse provides a lesson in the form of a comparative example for a people whose souls are dead, who flee their country because they have no responsibility to defend it, so that their country becomes a colony. The people within it suffer misery, humiliation, and poverty because they are treated as slaves by the ruling group that comes from outside. But after that period passed, with the awareness that Allah gave them, their souls came back to life. They rose up simultaneously to expel the tyrannical rulers. This is a bounty from Allah, the Almighty and Most Merciful.
text.244:
Believers should rise to the battlefield to uphold the word of Allah, secure the da'wah, and spread the religion. The upholders of truth will surely attain victory. Allah is All-Hearing, All-Knowing of those who go to the battlefield with the intention of defending the religion. Likewise, He knows those who betray the struggle.

In this verse, Allah commands us to fight to uphold the truth. This warfare has two kinds of strategies: defense and offense. The defensive strategy is to organize and strengthen the Muslim community in all fields so that it is respected by the enemy and a safe and peaceful atmosphere is created. The offensive strategy is to fight against enemies who disrupt the order of the ummah and to protect the honor of the nation in the best possible way. Allah is All-Knowing, All-Hearing of everything.
text.245:
Narrated by Ibn Hibban, Ibn Abi Hatim, and Ibn Mardawaih from Ibn Umar, when verse 261 of Surah al-Baqarah was revealed, explaining that those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah, their spending is like a grain that produces 7 stalks; in each stalk are a hundred grains, then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) pleaded, "O my Lord, increase the reward for my ummah (more than 700 times)."

After the story of a people who were destroyed because of fear and weakness of faith, in this verse, Allah encourages the ummah to willingly sacrifice and spend their wealth in the way of Allah, and this spending is called a loan. Allah calls it a loan, even though Allah Himself is the Most Rich, because Allah knows that the motivation to spend wealth for the benefit of the ummah is very weak in most people; only a small group is willing to do so. This can be felt where a wealthy person sometimes easily spends his excess wealth to help his friends, perhaps with the intention of protecting himself from evil or to maintain a high position, especially if the person being helped is his own relative. But if the expenditure of wealth is to defend religion and maintain its glory and exalt the word of Allah, in which there are no things that directly benefit himself in this world, then it is not easy for him to release the wealth he loves, unless it is openly or through official channels. Therefore, the expression used to spend wealth in the way of Allah is very appealing, namely: "Who is it that will lend to Allah a good loan."

A good loan is one that is appropriate to the field and its benefits and is given sincerely solely to achieve the pleasure of Allah SWT. Allah promises to give a multiple reward. Allah gives an analogy about the multiple reward like a grain of rice that is planted can produce seven stalks of rice, each stalk containing 100 grains, thus producing 700 grains. In fact, Allah rewards it without limit according to what the Messenger of Allah asked for his ummah and according to the sincerity of the person who gives the spending.

Allah SWT limits sustenance to those who do not know the sunnatullah in matters of seeking wealth because they are not active in building in various fields that Allah has shown. Allah expands sustenance to other people who are good at adapting to the sunnatullah and cultivating various fields of business so that they feel the benefits. If Allah makes a poor person rich or vice versa, then that is entirely within the power of Allah. Allah's encouragement to spend some of the wealth in the way of Allah is solely for the benefit of mankind itself and gives guidance to him to be grateful for the gift because by being grateful, the blessings will increase. Then Allah explains that all creatures will be returned to Him on the Day of Judgment to receive the reward for their respective deeds.
text.246:
The first story about the Children of Israel in the previous verse was outlined generally, and in this verse, it is elaborated in detail. In that era, it was customary for the Children of Israel that matters of state were governed by a king, and religious matters were led by a person who was also obeyed by the king himself. Samuel (their prophet at that time), knowing the nature of the Children of Israel, when he heard their proposal to appoint a king, doubt arose in his heart about the loyalty of the Children of Israel, so he said, "Perhaps if war is later made obligatory upon you, you will not want to fight." He often witnessed cowardice among them. They answered, "Why should we not want to fight in the way of Allah, when there are sufficient reasons that encourage us to carry out that war? We have been driven out of our homes, and many of our children have been taken captive by the enemy."

They stated that their suffering was severe enough that there was no other way except to use force. It turned out that what Samuel doubted was true, namely when war had been made obligatory upon the Children of Israel and Samuel had chosen a king to lead them, many of them turned away and abandoned jihad in the way of Allah, and only a few remained steadfast in keeping their promise.

Allah knows those who did not participate in jihad, and they are included in the group of people who are zalim (wrongdoers), who oppress themselves because they do not want to engage in jihad to defend rights and uphold the truth. In this world, they become humiliated people, and in the Hereafter, they become unfortunate people and receive punishment.
text.247:
Samuel told the Children of Israel that Allah SWT had appointed Talut (Saul in the Bible) as king. The Children of Israel refused to accept Talut as king, arguing that according to tradition, only those from the tribe of Judah could be made king, while Talut was from the tribe of Benjamin. Furthermore, it was stipulated that a king should be a wealthy person, while Talut was not wealthy. Therefore, they spontaneously rejected him, "How can Talut rule over us when we are more entitled to control the government than he is, and he has not been given sufficient wealth to be king?"

Samuel replied that Talut was appointed king by Allah's choice, and therefore Allah bestowed upon him vast knowledge and a strong body so that he could lead the Children of Israel. From this verse, it can be understood that a person who is to be made king should:

1.  Have physical strength so that he is able to carry out his duties as head of state.

2.  Possess extensive knowledge, knowing the strengths and weaknesses of the people, so that he can lead them with wisdom.

3.  Have physical health and mental intelligence.

4.  Be devoted to Allah so that he may receive His *taufik* and *hidayah*, to overcome all difficulties that he cannot overcome on his own, except with His *taufik* and *hidayah*.

As for wealth, it is not included as a condition for becoming king, because if the four conditions mentioned above have been fulfilled, it will be easy for him to obtain the necessary wealth, because Allah is Vast in His provision and All-Knowing.
text.248:
Samuel declared to the Children of Israel that Allah had chosen Saul (Thalut) as the king who would lead them in war against the Amalekites (Amalik or Amaliqah). As a sign that Saul was truly chosen by Allah was the return of the Ark (Tabut) to the Children of Israel after being lost from their hands for several years because it was seized by the enemy. Inside the Ark were kept some remnants of the family of Moses and Aaron, such as the staff of Prophet Moses, sandals, the turban of Prophet Aaron, and some fragments of the stone tablets that Moses brought from Mount Sinai. If the Children of Israel waged war, the Ark was always brought with them alongside the army because they felt that the Ark could generate enthusiasm and courage in battle.
