In a battle between the Children of Israel and the Amalekites, the Children of Israel suffered a defeat which resulted in the Ark being seized and carried away by the enemy. After the Ark had been in the hands of the Amalekites for some time, suddenly at one time the Amalekites were struck by various calamities and disasters such as a plague of rats that damaged crops, and the outbreak of disease, so they felt unlucky with the presence of the Ark in their midst. They assumed that the calamity came from the God of the Children of Israel who was taking revenge on them, so they returned the Ark to the Children of Israel by placing it in a cart pulled by two cows. It turned out that the cart was steered by angels so that it returned to the Children of Israel. The arrival of the Ark was perfectly timed with the election of Saul as king. With the return of the Ark, the Children of Israel finally submitted and accepted Saul as king, because that was evidence from Allah for those who believe.
text.249:
When King Talut went out leading his army to fight against the Amalekites, he first gave instructions about the events they would experience, namely that they would later be tested by Allah with a river flowing in the desert. He warned that the river was not an ordinary river but a river to test them, to see who was steadfast in their faith and who would be tempted. He said, "Whoever drinks from the water of that river is not of my followers, and whoever does not drink, then he is of my followers, except if he drinks only a handful." It is narrated that when the Children of Israel saw the Ark had returned, they no longer doubted that they would be victorious, so they immediately prepared an army to fight. At the direction of King Talut, only young men in good health were allowed to participate in the war; a man who was building a house but had not finished, or a merchant who was busy managing his business, or a man who had debts, or a groom who had not yet been with his wife, were not allowed. With such selection, King Talut was able to gather 80,000 reliable soldiers to fight. Because when they departed it was summer and the journey was very long through the desert, they requested that they be given the opportunity to drink from the river along the way. Most of the soldiers ignored King Talut's warning. They drank their fill from the water of the river, and some drank only a handful, and very few did not drink at all.

When King Talut and the believers had crossed the river to carry out *jihad fi sabilillah*, those who had drunk said, "We have no strength today to fight Goliath and his army." Goliath was a large man and the king of the Amalekites.

Such words did not frighten Talut's believing soldiers who were convinced that they would meet Allah on the Day of Judgment with steadfastness. They said, "How often has a small group overcome a large group, by the permission of Allah. For Allah is with the patient with His help."
text.250: When King Saul (Thalut) and his army faced King Goliath (Jalut) and his army, and witnessed the vast number of enemies and their complete equipment, they prayed to Allah to pour faith into their hearts, patience and reliance (tawakal) on Allah, and that Allah would help them defeat their idolatrous enemies.
text.251:
Then, Talut's army defeated Jalut's army with Allah's permission. In that battle, Prophet Dawud, who also participated, managed to kill King Jalut. Before the fierce battle occurred, King Jalut, whose body was very large and tall and wearing armor, arrogantly challenged someone to a one-on-one duel. From the side of the Children of Israel, no one dared to step forward to accept the challenge, then came a young shepherd named Dawud (who later became a prophet) and he declared his willingness to face King Jalut. It turned out that he only used a slingshot that he always used to protect his goats from wolf attacks. Because King Jalut was wearing armor, it was very difficult to penetrate his body with stones. Therefore, Dawud skillfully aimed for the gap between his eyes as his target, and it turned out that his throw hit the target precisely, so King Jalut immediately collapsed because his forehead was pierced by the stone bullet.

After that, Dawud took his sword and beheaded Jalut, severing it from his body. With the fall of King Jalut, the entire Amalekite people scattered because their king had been killed. All the soldiers of the Children of Israel greeted Dawud with a thunderous and boisterous voice, and he was later made the son-in-law of King Talut as a reward for his services.

In addition to that victory, Allah also bestowed wisdom and kingship upon Dawud, so that he became the first person to hold two positions at once, namely as a prophet and a king.

And were it not that Allah repels some people by means of others, the earth would have been corrupted. And were it not that Allah repels the wicked and unjust with those who do good, then evil would become even more rampant and destroy the good people. But Allah deliberately arranges these defenses because Allah has bounty that is bestowed upon the entire universe.
text.252:
Thus are the verses of Allah revealed to mankind with truth. Indeed, these verses stand as witness to the prophethood of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), which cannot be doubted by any of the People of the Book, be they Jews or Christians. It turns out that the stories described correspond exactly with what is in their books, even though Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) did not witness these events himself. Yet, he was able to know all of it solely through the revelation that was sent down to him. Allah states emphatically:

"...and you (Muhammad) are truly a messenger." (al-Baqarah/2: 252)
text.253:
In this verse, it is explained that among the messengers, some were given the opportunity to speak directly with Allah without the mediation of the angel Jibril. The messenger referred to here is the Prophet Musa a.s. He spoke directly with Allah swt. This experience was never experienced by other messengers. Therefore, Prophet Musa a.s. is called "Kalimullah," which means, "The Prophet who was spoken to directly by Allah swt." 36)

The next verse explains that Prophet Isa was given various miracles that were not given to others, for example: Prophet Isa could speak when he was still in the cradle; could bring the dead back to life, and heal the blind and those afflicted with leprosy, with the permission of Allah. Allah also supported him with Ruhulkudus, namely the angel Jibril, in addition to having a pure soul himself.

Finally, Prophet Muhammad saw was given a higher degree than the previous messengers, namely: he was declared as the last prophet and messenger of Allah, for all mankind, while other messengers were only sent to their people. The Islamic religion brought by Prophet Muhammad applies to all people until the end of time. The Al-Qur'an he received, besides being a guide for mankind, is also the greatest miracle for Prophet Muhammad, which is unmatched throughout time.

Furthermore, this verse explains the condition of mankind after the passing of the messengers who were sent to them. In general, when the messengers were still alive, their people could unite, but after their passing, they disagreed and quarreled, even killing each other. Differences in understanding religious matters encouraged them to insult each other, even accusing each other of disbelief (kafir). Their fanaticism towards a particular mazhab or an imam caused them to refuse to accept the truth presented by other groups.

These various disputes occurred, even though they had received clear explanations, and they continued to disagree, so that some believed and others disbelieved. If Allah had willed that humans not disagree and not be hostile or kill each other, Allah would have been able to do so. If Allah had done such a thing, then all humans would have become good, and this world would be peaceful from disputes between humans.

But Allah acts according to His will, based on wisdom and supreme knowledge. Allah gives humans nature, thoughts, feelings and will, so that humans can think and act better than other creatures on this earth, so that they think about the power of Allah. If humans use their thoughts and feelings in the best possible way, they will surely see signs of Allah's power and greatness everywhere, because this vast universe is a sign of His power and greatness and all of it is His creation.

Allah bestows religion upon humans through His messengers, to guide human reason to the right path. Because the ability of human reason is limited, especially regarding matters that are unseen or abstract, such as the attributes of Allah, the affairs of the afterlife, and so on. So that if there is a difference of opinion between them, they can resolve it with guidance from that religion.

Differences of opinion that occur among humans are natural. But these differences of opinion should not cause hostility that causes them to kill each other.

History has shown that the Jews after the death of Prophet Musa disagreed and split apart. The same thing happened to the Christians after the death of Prophet Isa until the present day. Between various Christian groups themselves, there were protracted quarrels, attacking and killing each other. One group did not want to worship in the places of worship of another group, even though they were of the same religion.

The Muslim community was not spared from division, even though when Prophet Muhammad was still alive, they had become a united community, and had great potential in forming a society that lived in harmony and helped each other. But then they became fragmented, due to differences in understanding, coupled with fanaticism of mazhab and groups, so that their strength became weak; they became a backward people, with a weak economy; and became the target of other people. Even though Allah has given guidance in the Al-Qur'an:

O you who have believed, obey Allah and obey the Messenger (Muhammad) and those in authority among you. And if you disagree over anything, refer it to Allah (Al-Qur'an) and the Messenger (his sunnah), if you should believe in Allah and the Last Day. That is the best [way] and best in result. (an-Nisa'/4:59).
text.254:
In this verse, believers are commanded to spend a portion of the wealth that has been bestowed upon them for the benefit of themselves and their families, or for the benefit of the general public. They must remember that a day will come when there will be no more opportunity for them to spend that wealth, because on that day the Day of Judgment will occur, followed by the Day of Reckoning. There will be no close friends who will provide assistance, and no one who can save and provide help. Wealth and descendants will also be of no help, except for those who come before God with a pure heart and abundant good deeds.

Those who are unwilling to spend their wealth in the world for the common good (fi sabilillah) are those who deny Allah's blessings. Thus, they will become people who are unjust to themselves and to others. Unjust to themselves because, through that denial, they will receive punishment from Allah. Unjust to others because they are reluctant to give the rights of others that are in their wealth, whether in the form of zakat that has been obligated upon them, or in the form of charity and various donations that are encouraged by religion.

There are various opinions among scholars regarding infaq or "spending wealth" that is meant in this verse. Some say that what is meant by "infaq" in this verse is obligatory infaq, namely zakat, because at the end of this verse Allah mentions those who are unwilling to give infaq as disbelievers (kafir). If what is meant by infaq here is only sunnah, namely "charity," then those who do not give charity would certainly not be called disbelievers.

Some scholars are of the opinion that what is meant by infaq in this verse is infaq for the sake of jihad fi sabilillah, namely for the sake of struggling to uphold the religion of Allah and defending oneself and the country against the threat of enemies. While other scholars are of the opinion that what is meant by infaq in this verse is obligatory infaq and sunnah infaq, namely zakat and charity. As for the word "kafir" in this verse, it has the meaning of "reluctant to pay zakat," not kafir in the sense of not believing.

Wealth, according to Islam, has a social function, in addition to personal interests. If a person has succeeded in obtaining wealth in a halal way, then he has an obligation to spend a portion of his wealth for the benefit of himself and his family, and another portion for the benefit of the general public, whether in the form of zakat, charity, or voluntary donations for the common good.

Fulfilling zakat contains two kinds of benefits. First, the benefit for the person who pays zakat is that it frees him from the obligation that Allah has placed upon him. Thus, he will obtain His pleasure and reward, and will also eliminate the trait of stinginess from himself. The second benefit is that the fulfillment of zakat also means purifying his excess wealth (the remainder) after the zakat is taken out, because as long as the zakat has not been taken out, his wealth always contains the rights of others, namely the rights of relatives, the poor, travelers, and other people who need help (at-Taubah/9: 103; ar-Rum/30: 38; al-An'am/6: 141; adz-dzariyat/51: 19).

Indeed, the wisdom contained in Islamic Sharia regarding zakat is very high. Because humans in general are stingy. If he succeeds in obtaining wealth, his heart is heavy to spend his wealth for the benefit of others. There are even people who are reluctant to spend their wealth for their own benefit, even though they have worked hard to accumulate it. If he remembers that at some point he will leave this mortal world and leave that wealth behind, then he will certainly not be stingy.

The religion of Islam has shown a very effective cure for eradicating the disease of miserliness from the human heart. Islam provides education and training to humans to be generous, open-handed, and willing to sacrifice for the benefit of themselves and the benefit of others, namely with the rules of zakat and charity (al-Baqarah/2: 245, 261, 265, 274; an-Nur/24: 22).

Charity and various donations that we give for the common good are valued by religion as "amal jariah," an act whose reward will continue to flow to the person who does it, even though he has died, as long as the results of his donation can be enjoyed and utilized by the general public. In fulfilling zakat and charity, a sincere intention is needed, namely seeking the pleasure of Allah and avoiding the trait of riya, wanting to be praised and flattered by people.

Fulfilling zakat and charity is a manifestation of faith and gratitude to Allah who has promised to increase His blessings to anyone who is willing to be grateful. Conversely, those who are unwilling to be grateful, so that they are reluctant to pay zakat and give charity, have been threatened with punishment in the Hereafter.

"If you are grateful, I will surely increase you [in favor]; but if you deny, indeed, My punishment is severe." (Ibrahim/14:7)
text.255:
Allah is the One and Only God, there is no god besides Him, and only He is worthy of being worshipped. As for the other gods worshipped by some people for untrue reasons, they are indeed numerous. However, the true God is only Allah. He alone is eternally living, self-subsisting, and He is the One who always manages His creation without the slightest negligence.

Then it is further emphasized that Allah never slumbers. A person who is drowsy certainly loses consciousness, so he will not be able to do his job well, whereas Allah SWT always manages and maintains His creation well, never losing consciousness or being negligent.

Because Allah never slumbers, of course He never sleeps, because drowsiness is the beginning of the process of sleep. A person who sleeps loses more consciousness than a person who is drowsy.

Another attribute of Allah mentioned in this verse is that He has power and owns what is in the heavens and on earth. He has unlimited strength and power, so He can do whatever He wills. Everything is in His power, so that none of His creatures, including the prophets and angels, can provide help except with His permission, let alone the idols that the disbelievers consider as their helpers.

What is meant by "help" or "syafaat" (intercession) in this verse is the help given by the angels, prophets and righteous people to mankind on the Day of Judgment to obtain relief or freedom from Allah's punishment. That syafaat will occur with Allah's permission. In a hadith it is mentioned:

The Prophet SAW said, "…Then Allah will say, "The Angels have interceded, the Prophets have interceded, and the believers have also interceded." (Narrated by Ahmad and Muslim from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri)

Another attribute of Allah mentioned in this verse is: that Allah always knows what happens before and behind His creatures, while they do not know anything of Allah's knowledge, except only what He wills for them to know. Allah's Kursi (Footstool) encompasses the heavens and the earth. Allah does not feel the slightest burden in maintaining His creatures who are in the heavens and on earth, and in all His creation. Allah is the Most High, the Most Great.

They do not know Allah's knowledge, except what He has willed for them to know. Thus, what can be known by humans is only what can be reached by the knowledge that Allah has bestowed upon them, and the amount is very little compared to His vast knowledge. This is affirmed by Allah in His word:

"…And you have not been given of knowledge except a little." (al-Isra'/17:85)
text.256:
There is no compulsion in [acceptance of] the religion. Our obligation is only to convey the religion of Allah to mankind in a good and wise manner, and with reasonable advice, so that they enter Islam with their own awareness and willingness (an-Nahl/16:125).

If we have conveyed it to them in such a way, but they still do not want to believe, that is not our business, but Allah's business. We are not allowed to force them. In another verse (Yunus/10:99) Allah says, which means: "Would you then compel the people until they become believers?"

With the coming of Islam, the right path has become clear and can be distinguished from the wrong path. Therefore, there should be no compulsion to believe, because faith is a conviction in the heart, and no one can force someone's heart to believe something if they themselves are not willing.

The verses of the Qur'an that explain the prophethood of Muhammad (saw) are clear enough. So it is up to each person whether to believe or disbelieve, after the verses have reached them. This is the ethics of Islamic da'wah. As for the voices that say that Islam was developed with the sword, these are merely accusations and slander. Muslims in Mecca before migrating to Medina only performed prayers in secret, and they did not want to do so demonstratively in front of the disbelievers.

This verse was revealed approximately in the third year after the Hijrah, that is, after the Muslims had real strength and their numbers had increased, but they were not allowed to use coercion against non-Muslims, either subtly or with violence.

As for the wars that Muslims have waged, both in the Arabian Peninsula and in other countries, such as Egypt, Persia, and so on, they were solely acts of self-defense against attacks by disbelievers against them. In addition, wars were waged to secure the path of Islamic da'wah, so that various acts of injustice by disbelievers who slandered and disturbed Muslims for adhering to and practicing their religion could be prevented, and so that those disbelievers could respect personal freedom and human rights in adhering to beliefs.

In various areas that have been controlled by Muslims, people who have not embraced Islam are given the right and freedom to choose: whether they will embrace Islam or remain in their religion. If they choose to remain in their original religion, then they are required to pay "jizyah," which is a kind of tax as compensation for the protection provided by the Islamic government to them. Their safety is fully guaranteed, as long as they do not take actions that are hostile to Islam and its people.37)

This is clear evidence that Muslims do not use coercion, but rather respect religious freedom, even towards minorities in their areas of control. Conversely, we can see from historical evidence, both in the past and in modern times, how unfortunate the fate of Muslims is when they become a minority in a country.

This verse further explains that whoever no longer believes in *thagut*, or no longer worships idols or other objects, but believes in and worships Allah alone, then he has obtained a firm hold, like a strong rope that will not break. True faith is faith that is believed in the heart, spoken with the tongue, and accompanied by deeds. That is why at the end of the verse, Allah says, which means: "Allah is All-Hearing and All-Knowing." Meaning, Allah always hears what is spoken, and He always knows what is believed in the heart, and what is done by the limbs. Allah will reward a person's deeds according to their faith, words, and deeds.
text.257:
Allah is the Protector of those who believe. He brings them out of disbelief into the light of faith and guidance. As for those who disbelieve, their protectors are devils who bring them out of the light of faith into the darkness of disbelief. They are the inhabitants of the Fire on the Day of Judgment, and they will abide therein forever.

If the disbeliever at some point obtains a little light of guidance and faith, then the devils immediately strive to eliminate it, so that the faith that has begun to sprout vanishes, and they return to darkness.

Therefore, the faith that has been planted in the heart must always be maintained, cared for, and nurtured well so that it continues to grow and become stronger, and the devils will no longer be able to damage it. The fertilizer of faith is: ibadah (worship), amal saleh (righteous deeds), and deepening knowledge and teachings of the Islamic religion.
text.258:
This verse exemplifies the state and nature of the arrogance of King Nimrod of Babylon when confronted by Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) as a messenger of Allah. King Nimrod had been granted great power and a vast kingdom by Allah, but he was ungrateful for these blessings, even becoming a disbeliever and an oppressor. The mercy of Allah, which he should have used to obey Allah, he used to disobey Him, by committing deeds that were not pleasing to Him.

Nimrod, who had taken Satan as his leader and protector, arrogantly said in defiance of Prophet Ibrahim, "Who is your Lord whom you call us to believe in?" Ibrahim replied, "My Lord is Allah, who has the power to create beings that did not exist before, or to bring back to life those who were dead." Then Nimrod replied, "If that is so, then I too can give life and cause death." He meant, to allow someone to live or not to kill someone he should have killed; and he was able to cause someone to die, namely by killing him. While what Ibrahim meant was that Allah SWT creates living beings that did not exist before, namely by creating bones, flesh and blood, then breathing the spirit into them, or from creatures that have died, then Allah returns them to life; on the Day of Resurrection. Allah is also able to cause living beings to die, not by killing them as humans do, but by removing the spirit of the creature with the coming of death or with the occurrence of the Day of Judgment. So Nimrod's answer mentioned in this verse is merely mockery, not in accordance with what Ibrahim a.s. meant.

Because Nimrod's answer was worthless, Prophet Ibrahim ignored it. Then he said, "My Lord (Allah) has the power to bring the sun from the east, so bring the sun from the west." Nimrod could not answer. Therefore, he was silenced, unable to move.

Here we can see the difference between Prophet Ibrahim and Nimrod. Prophet Ibrahim, as a messenger of Allah who believed in and obeyed Him, always received His guidance, so he did not lose his reason and arguments in the debate, even his last argument about the proof of Allah's power silenced King Nimrod. Conversely, King Nimrod, who disbelieved and disobeyed Allah, truly did not receive His guidance, so he was defeated and could no longer move to answer Prophet Ibrahim's challenge. That is the consequence of people who take Satan as their leader and protector.
text.259:
In this verse, Allah provides another parable, also aimed at proving His power. However, the figure presented in this parable is not someone who denies and disbelieves in His power, but rather someone who was initially doubtful about Allah's power, but after seeing various concrete proofs, he believed with all his heart and acknowledged that Allah is All-Powerful over all things.

It is mentioned that the person once walked through a village that was already in ruins. The buildings had collapsed, so the roofs that had fallen to the ground were buried by the rubble of the walls. Because he still doubted Allah's power, when he witnessed the ruins, he said, "How can Allah bring this ruined village back to life and restore it to its original state?"

His doubt about Allah's power to restore the village to its original state can be applied to something greater than that, namely: "Is Allah able to bring His creatures back to life on the Day of Resurrection, after they have all perished on the Day of Judgment?"

Because the person was not an infidel, but rather someone who was still at a level of doubt about Allah's power, and he needed proof and explanation, Allah did something that would provide that explanation and proof to him. The incident was as follows: After he found the village deserted and the buildings in ruins, he still found fruit-bearing trees there. Then he stopped at a place, and after tethering his donkey, he took some fruit and ate it. After eating, he fell asleep. At that moment, Allah swt. caused him to die, that is, by removing his soul from his body. A hundred years later, Allah swt. brought him back to life, restoring him to his original state, and returning his soul to his body. This "revival" process took place quickly and easily, without going through childhood and so on. The leftover food he left behind before he died was still intact and undamaged, while his donkey was dead, leaving only bones. After he was revived, Allah asked him a question, "How long have you been in this place?" Allah swt. asked that question to show him that he could not know everything, including things about himself. This turned out to be true. The person thought that he had only been in that place for a short time, namely a day or half a day. Therefore, he answered, "I have only been in this place for a day or half a day."

Then Allah explained to him that he had been in that place for a hundred years. Then Allah told him to pay attention to the remnants of food and drink that he had left behind a hundred years ago, which were still intact and undamaged. This proves Allah's power, because food usually spoils after only two or three days. Allah also told him to pay attention to his donkey, which had become bones in that place. Then Allah showed him how He arranged the bones in their original place and arrangement. After that, He gave it flesh and skin and other body parts, and breathed the soul into the donkey's body so that it came back to life.

After seeing all these realities, the person declared his faith with the words, "Now I am truly certain that Allah is All-Powerful over all things, including bringing the dead back to life." Based on that belief, his doubts about the Day of Resurrection disappeared.

In this verse, Allah swt. does not explain the name of the person or the name of the country he passed through. What is important in this verse is the lesson that can be learned from the event.

The proofs of Allah's power shown in this verse are as follows:

1.  The person was brought back to life after he had been dead for a hundred years. The bones of his donkey are proof to ensure that his donkey had indeed been dead for a long time. Allah is able to bring it back to life.

2.  The remnants of his food and drink from a hundred years ago were still intact, of course by the will and power of Allah. This proves His power because, under normal circumstances, food and drink will spoil after a few days. Or the food was indeed spoiled, but Allah was able to restore it to its original state. This also shows His power.

3.  His donkey, which had been dead for a long time and only bones remained, was brought back to life by God as before. This was done in front of the person's eyes so that it could be witnessed clearly.

All of these are concrete proofs of Allah's power, and that Allah is able to create something, and is also able to repeat the creation of His creatures. Then all kinds of *syubhat* and doubts disappear, and a strong conviction arises about the oneness and power of Allah. He is All-Powerful over all things, including resurrecting and bringing His creatures back to life in the afterlife after the Day of Judgment.
text.260:
This verse adds another parable about Allah's power to resurrect creatures that have died. If verse 258 presented the event of a dialogue between Prophet Ibrahim and King Namrud, then this verse narrates the dialogue between Prophet Ibrahim and his Lord. With full humility and devotion to Allah, Ibrahim a.s. submitted a request to Him to be gracious enough to show him how Allah resurrects creatures that have died.

At first glance, Prophet Ibrahim's request gives the impression that he himself still had doubts about Allah's power to resurrect the dead. Therefore, Allah said to him, "Do you still not believe that I can resurrect creatures that have died?" However, that is not what is meant in this verse, because Prophet Ibrahim had no doubts whatsoever about Allah's power. He submitted the request to Allah not because of doubt, but because he wanted to see with his own eyes how Allah resurrects creatures that have died. So Ibrahim answered, "I do not doubt Allah's power at all, but I submit this request to reach the degree of 'ainul yaqin, which is certainty obtained after witnessing it with my own eyes, so that my heart becomes more tranquil, and my conviction becomes stronger and more solid."

Allah granted the request, and Prophet Ibrahim was ordered to cut up four birds, then place the parts of the birds' bodies on hills that were far apart from each other. Ibrahim was ordered to call the birds that had been cut up, and it turned out that the birds came to him in their original, complete state. Of course, Allah first restored the birds to their original state, so that they could come to answer the call of Ibrahim a.s. With this, Ibrahim a.s.'s request to Allah to show him how Allah resurrects creatures that have died was fulfilled, so that his heart felt tranquil and his conviction became stronger.

Another opinion says that Prophet Ibrahim was ordered to take the birds to tame them. Then Allah swt ordered Ibrahim a.s. to place each bird on a specific hill that was far apart from each other.

After that, Ibrahim a.s. was ordered by Him to call the birds. With just one call, the birds came to him obediently and submissively. Likewise, it will be with mankind on the Day of Judgment. When Allah swt calls them with just one call, the creatures will rise and come to Him simultaneously, obediently and submissively.

At the end of this verse, Allah swt warns Ibrahim a.s. and all humans, to truly believe that Allah is All-Powerful and All-Wise. Meaning: Powerful in all things, including resurrecting creatures that have died, and He is All-Wise, especially in providing guidance and direction to His servants, towards the straight and true path.
text.261:
The relationship between *infak* (charitable spending) and the afterlife is very close. A person will not receive any help from anyone on the Day of Judgment, except from the results of their own deeds during their life in the world, including deeds in the form of *infak* in the path of Allah. How fortunate is the person who likes to spend their wealth in the path of Allah; that person is like someone who sows a grain of seed in fertile soil. The seed grows into a tree, and the tree branches into seven stalks, each stalk producing fruit, and each stalk containing a hundred seeds, so that the single seed yields as many as 700 grains. This means seven hundred times more. Imagine how much the yield would be if the seeds planted were more than one.

The depiction found in this verse is better than saying directly that "a single seed will produce 700 grains." Because the depiction in the verse gives the impression that the good deeds done by a person are always developed and grown by God in such a way that they become multiple benefits for the person who does them, like the growth of plants planted by someone in fertile soil for the benefit of the planter.

The revelation about the development that occurs in plants as described in this verse has aroused the interest of plant experts to conduct research on the matter. The results of their research show that a seed planted in good soil and growing into a tree generally produces more than one stalk of fruit, some even having more than fifty stalks. So, it's not just one stalk. Each stalk contains more than one seed, sometimes even more than sixty seeds. Thus, it is clear that the depiction given in the verse that a seed is multiplied until it becomes seven hundred grains is not an exaggeration, but is reasonable and in accordance with reality.

On this basis, we can say that the more scientific investigations people conduct, and the higher the knowledge and technology of mankind, the more the truth contained in the Holy Qur'an is revealed, whether concerning objects, plants, animals, outer space, and so on.

Many narrations originate from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) that describe the good fortune of those who spend their wealth in the path of Allah, to obtain His pleasure and to uphold His religion. Among them is the hadith narrated by Imam Muslim:

From Ibn Mas'ud, that he said, "A man came bringing a camel with a rope in its nose ( *maqbūdah* ) and the man said, "I am spending this camel in the path of Allah." Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "With this spending, you will obtain in the Hereafter seven hundred camels, also with ropes in their noses." (Narrated by Muslim)

At the end of this verse, two of His attributes are mentioned, namely, All-Encompassing and All-Knowing. Meaning, Allah is All-Encompassing in His mercy to His servants; His gifts are countless. He is All-Knowing as to which of His servants deserves to be given a multiplied reward, namely those who like to spend their wealth for the public good, to uphold the truth, and for the benefit of the nation's and religion's education, as well as the virtues that will lead the nation to happiness in this world and in the Hereafter. If such spending has shown its results for the strength of religion and the happiness of the nation, then the person who gives the *infak* will also be able to enjoy it, both in this world and in the Hereafter.

The teachings of Islam regarding *infak* are of very high value. In addition to eroding bad traits such as stinginess and selfishness, *infak* also creates a deep social awareness that humans are always in need of each other, and that a person cannot live alone. Therefore, there must be a spirit of mutual cooperation and giving so that the gap between the rich and the poor can be eliminated, and brotherhood can be fostered with closer relationships.

Spending wealth in the path of Allah, both obligatory such as *zakat*, and voluntary such as *sedekah* that is used for the welfare of the people, to eradicate the diseases of poverty and ignorance, for the propagation of Islam and for the development of knowledge, is highly demanded by religion, and highly recommended by *shara'*. Therefore, there are many verses of the Qur'an that discuss this issue, and provide strong encouragement and give parables that describe how fortunate those who like to give *infak* are and how unfortunate those who do not want to spend their wealth are.
text.262:
The reward and fortune to be gained by those who spend their wealth in the path of Allah are conditional: that they give their wealth sincerely, and afterwards they do not like to mention their spending with words that can hurt the feelings of the recipient. Only such people are entitled to receive rewards from Allah, and there is no fear upon them, nor will they grieve. This means that if someone gives charity to another, then mentions the charity and the giving with words that offend the feelings and honor of the recipient, then such a person is not entitled to receive rewards from Allah.

This is a teaching of very high value, because there are people who donate their wealth not because they expect the pleasure of Allah, but only want popularity and fame and praise from society, broadcasting the infaq in a conspicuous way, so that they are admired as a generous person. Or when giving charity, they utter words that are unpleasant for the recipient. Such giving is contrary to the purpose of religion, because it will not create relationships of affection and brotherhood, but rather creates hatred and hostility. Therefore, it is natural that such people will not get a reward from Allah.

In short, spending wealth in the path of Allah must be with a sincere intention and a pure purpose. It is upon this sincere intention that Allah will give rewards, and society will appreciate it. Rasulullah saw said:

"All deeds are based on intentions. And every person will get the reward for his deeds based on his intention." (Narrated by Imam al-Bukhari from 'Umar bin al-Khaththab).

Those who spend with a sincere intention, besides obtaining rewards from Allah, also have no fear for their fate, because they will surely receive rewards and the pleasure of Allah. They will also not be sad, but they will rejoice later in the Hereafter because they have been able to do good, and that goodness brings rewards for them. Conversely, those who are reluctant to spend, will be sad and regretful in the Hereafter, because there will be no more opportunity for them to do good. They will receive punishment from Allah.
text.263:
A person who is unable to give charity but can utter pleasant or non-offensive words, and forgive others, is better than a person who gives charity but their charity is accompanied by hurtful and offensive words. If a person who gives charity cannot avoid uttering hurtful words or mentioning the gift, whether when giving it or afterwards, it is better for them not to give charity, but to continue to utter good and pleasant words to anyone they interact with. That is better than giving something accompanied by insults, and so on.

At the end of this verse, Allah mentions two of His perfect attributes: "All-Sufficient and Most Forbearing." The meaning is that Allah is All-Sufficient, so He does not command His servants to donate their wealth for Allah's benefit, but for the benefit of the servants themselves, which is to purify themselves and grow their wealth, so that they become a strong and compact nation, and help one another.

Allah SWT does not accept charity accompanied by hurtful words, because Allah only accepts good deeds done in good ways. Allah is Most Forbearing towards His servants who do not accompany their charity with hurtful words, or who like to mention their charity after it has been given or when giving it. Because Allah is All-Sufficient and Most Forbearing, Allah is also able to give rewards and help to His servants who like to spend their wealth sincerely.
text.264:
Believers should not nullify the reward of their infaq or charity by accompanying it with hurtful words or by mentioning the infaq that has been given.

The purpose of infaq or charity is to comfort and alleviate the suffering of the poor and needy, and to improve the welfare of the community. That is why charity should not be mentioned, or accompanied by words that hurt the recipient.

If the charity is accompanied by such words, then the main purpose of the charity, which is to comfort and alleviate suffering, will not be achieved. Therefore, Allah forbids it, and affirms that such charity will not receive a reward.

A person who gives charity out of *riya* (show-off), is the same as a person who performs the prayer out of *riya*. His prayer will not be rewarded, and will not achieve the intended purpose. Because the purpose of prayer is to direct all hearts and souls to Allah swt and to glorify His greatness and power, and to offer gratitude for all His blessings. While a person who prays out of *riya*, his attention is not directed to Allah, but to people who are expected to praise and flatter him.

The trait of *riya* is a bad habit. Some people want to be praised and flattered for a good deed they do. A person who gives charity expecting praise and thanks from the recipient of the charity or from others, if at some point he feels less praised and less thanked by the recipient or less appreciation from the recipient for his charity, he will feel very disappointed. In such a situation, it is very likely that he will utter words that offend the recipient, so that his charity will not bring reward in the sight of Allah. A person with such a nature does not truly believe in Allah and the Hereafter. Such charity is like dust on a smooth rock; when heavy rain comes, the dust disappears without a trace.

Likewise, charity given out of *riya* will not bring any reward in the Hereafter, because the deed is not done to achieve the pleasure of Allah, but only to expect praise from people. Thus, he does not get any results, either in this world or in the Hereafter. In this world, he does not get anything from his charity, because charity accompanied by *riya* or hurtful words will only cause hatred from the community towards him, while in the Hereafter, he does not get a reward from Allah, because *riya* and unpleasant words have erased the reward of his deeds. Allah swt gives rewards only to those who act sincerely, want to purify themselves and improve their condition, and solely seek His pleasure.

Allah gives an analogy for charity accompanied by *riya* and insults as soil erosion on a rock. Erosion is the process of losing soil from the earth's surface in general because it is carried away by water flow. The greater the rainfall, the more and faster the soil particles will be eroded. The process of soil formation on rocks takes a long time, but by heavy rain the soil layer can be easily and quickly transported and lost from the rock surface. If the soil on the rock has disappeared, then the rock is a particle that cannot grow plants. Such an analogy illustrates that a person who painstakingly collects wealth, then gives charity but the charity is accompanied by *riya* and insults, then he will not get anything, neither benefit, reward nor the pleasure of Allah from what he gives in charity.

The habit of distributing money to beggars who usually gather in front of the mosque after Friday prayers or Eid prayers, or in other places, besides appearing as charity and social action towards the poor, also has a bad effect and may even be categorized as an act of *riya*. This habit will actually invite people we don't know to come to places of worship only to beg, not to participate in worship, so that the Islamic holiday is only a day of poverty exhibition everywhere. There is a mosque whose leader forbids his congregation from giving charity to the beggars who usually come to gather at the doors of the city mosque. It turned out that this method was successful, because then no one came to the mosque to beg. The poor and the weak should be the shared responsibility of those who are able. We are grateful that there are now institutions that have been formed specifically to deal with this problem.

Allah does not give guidance to those who disbelieve, because guidance is based on faith. It is faith that guides a person to sincerity in doing good deeds, and protects oneself from actions and words that can damage his deeds, and eliminate his rewards. So in this verse there is a hint, that the nature of *riya* and unpleasant words are part of the nature and deeds of the disbelievers that must be avoided by the believers.

Many hadith of the Prophet Muhammad saw condemn charity accompanied by hurtful words. Imam Muslim narrated the following hadith from Abu Dharr, the Prophet Muhammad saw said:

There are three kinds of people whom Allah will not speak to on the Day of Judgment and will not look at them, and will not purify them from sin, and they will have a painful punishment, namely those who like to mention their gifts when they give something, and those who like to wear their sarongs too low until they sweep the ground because of their arrogance, and those who try to sell their merchandise with a false oath. (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Dharr)

Imam an-Nasa'i also narrated a hadith from Ibn Umar, from the Prophet saw, that he said:

Those who always drink *khamr* (intoxicants) will not enter Paradise, nor will those who are disobedient to their parents, nor will those who like to mention their gifts. (Narrated by an-Nasa'i from Ibn 'Abbas)
text.265:
Infak (charity) is likened to a garden that receives sufficient rainwater, so that the garden yields twice the usual harvest. If the rain is not heavy, then even a drizzle is sufficient, because the garden is located in a highland area that receives sufficient sunlight and good air, and the soil is fertile.

This verse is related and is a continuation of the previous verse. Viewed from the perspective of erosion mechanisms, the presence of land cover in the form of trees or plants can prevent or reduce the risk of erosion. Rain in a mountain garden is not a cause of erosion but provides benefits in the form of increased yields for the land cultivated as a garden. In this case, spending wealth to seek the pleasure of Allah is likened to a garden in the mountains that is watered by rain and produces fruits twice as much. If there is no heavy rain, in a mountain garden, even a drizzle or dew is sufficient to produce good fruits.

In the view of ecology, the situation described in verse 265 of Surah al-Baqarah above does indeed occur. This natural phenomenon clearly shows the greatness of Allah who regulates this nature in great detail, so that all creatures have the opportunity to glorify Him.

Dew, or more precisely called fog, is a cloud that is in direct contact with the ground or trees. In English, two words are used for this natural phenomenon, namely fog and mist. The only difference between the two is the density of the cloud material. The word fog is used when fog causes visibility to be less than one kilometer. While mist is a state of fog that results in visibility of less than two kilometers.

Fog differs from other clouds only because the cloud is in contact with the earth's surface. This condition can occur both in lowlands and mountains. Fog appears when there is a difference in air temperature and the freezing point of water of 3oC or less. Fog begins when water vapor condenses into very fine water droplets in the air. It is the condensation of water vapor that then appears and becomes what is called a cloud. Fog generally occurs in very humid areas. Humid conditions can occur due to the addition of water vapor in the air, or a decrease in air temperature. However, sometimes fog can occur without these conditions. Generally, fog occurs when air humidity reaches 100%. In this condition, the air can no longer bind the water vapor in the air.

The classification of fog can be done because of differences in cause, nature, and others. For example, there is fog that can occur and disappear in a short time. This fog is commonly called flash fog. There is also fog known as sea fog, which occurs above the surface of sea water. Here, the occurrence of fog is greatly influenced by the presence of salt. Tiny salt particles will fill the air above the surface of sea water for various reasons. Among other things, caused by wind or splashes of breaking waves and other causes. These tiny salt particles will then act as collectors of water vapor. There is also a type of fog caused by temperature changes at dusk or dawn or a situation when cold wind passes through a warm water area, or rain water passes through a layer of hot air so that evaporation occurs.

Fog often produces rain in the form of drizzle. This condition generally occurs because air humidity has exceeded 100%. Soon the cloud will turn into raindrops. Especially if the fog layer rises up and comes into contact with cold temperatures at the top.

In relation to fog, ecologists have found a unique type of forest because it is very closely associated with fog. This forest is commonly called cloud forest or fog forest. Such a forest refers to a wet rainforest in a highland area, either in tropical or subtropical mountains. Generally, this fog layer will thicken on the tops of forest trees (canopy). Generally, fog forests are not very large and are limited only to areas where the atmospheric environment is suitable for forming fog.

This forest is also characterized by fog that is almost always present, thus reducing the possibility of plants obtaining direct sunlight. Trees in this area are characterized by growing shorter and smaller. This size is very different from the same type and grows in the lowlands or other parts of the mountains that receive full sunlight. High humidity encourages the growth of epiphytic plants that stick to the trunks and branches of trees, which are mostly dominated by moss and fern groups. The presence of vines and moss is also a characteristic that this is a fog forest.

In the fog forest, the main source of water is tiny grains of water that come from the fog. Condensation of water vapor from the fog will occur especially on the leaves of trees, and fall in the form of water droplets to the forest floor.

A natural phenomenon that is in an area very far from where the Al-Qur'an was revealed, but is explained in detail in the Al-Qur'an, is proof that this holy book is not a human creation. Only God the All-Knowing can reveal verses like this.

It is said that what is likened to a garden is a person who spends his wealth, because he realizes that he has received much grace from Allah, so he is willing to give a lot of infak; even if one day he receives a little grace, he still gives infak.

Spending wealth in the way of Allah or giving infak, can truly strengthen the soul. Because love for wealth has become human nature, because of his great love for wealth it feels heavy for him to spend it, especially for the benefit of others. So if we give charity for example, it is an act that can strengthen the heart to do good, and eliminate the influence of wealth that is attached to the soul.

This verse closes with His word: *Wallahu bima ta'maluna bashir* (And Allah is Seeing of what you do). This means that Allah always knows the good deeds done by His servants, including giving infak with sincere intentions, then He will give the reward. Conversely, Allah also knows all the bad deeds, then He will repay them with torment.

(266) In this verse, Allah swt also gives an analogy for people who spend their wealth not to get the pleasure of Allah, but because of *riya* (showing off), or their charity is accompanied by words that hurt feelings or like to mention the charity they have given. This person is likened to a person who has a garden containing various kinds of plants, and the garden gets enough water from a flowing river, so that it produces a lot of fruit. The person is old, and has small children and grandchildren who cannot yet earn a living on their own. Thus, he and his children and grandchildren really need the results of the garden. But suddenly a hot *samum* wind comes. So that the trees and plants are damaged, not producing any results, even though he really hopes for it.

Such is the state of people who spend their wealth not for Allah. He thinks he will get a reward from his charity and infak. But the truth is not so, the reward will disappear because his intention is not sincere. He gives infak only because of *riya*, following the whispers of Satan. Not because he hopes for the pleasure of Allah swt.

With these clear explanations and parables, Allah swt explains His verses to His servants so that they can think and can take lessons and lessons from the parables.
text.266:
Infak is likened to a garden that receives sufficient rainwater, so that the garden yields twice the usual harvest. Even if the rain is not heavy, a drizzle is sufficient, because the garden is located in a highland that receives sufficient sunlight and good air, and the soil is fertile.

This verse is related and is a continuation of the previous verse. From the perspective of erosion mechanisms, the presence of land cover in the form of trees or plants can prevent or reduce the risk of erosion. Rain in a mountain garden does not cause erosion but provides benefits in the form of increased yields for land cultivated as a garden. In this case, spending wealth to seek the pleasure of Allah is likened to a garden in the mountains that is watered by rain and produces fruits twice as much. If there is no heavy rain, in a mountain garden, even a drizzle or dew is sufficient to produce good fruits.

In the view of ecology, the situation described in verse 265 of Surah al-Baqarah above is indeed true. This natural phenomenon clearly shows the greatness of Allah who regulates this nature in great detail, so that all creatures have the opportunity to glorify Him.

Dew, or more precisely called fog, is a cloud that is in direct contact with the ground or trees. In English, two words are used for this one natural phenomenon, namely fog and mist. The only difference between the two is the density of the cloud material. The word fog is used when fog causes visibility to be less than one kilometer. Meanwhile, mist is a state of fog that results in visibility of less than two kilometers.

Fog is different from other clouds only because the cloud is in contact with the earth's surface. This condition can occur both in lowlands and mountains. Fog appears when there is a difference in air temperature and the freezing point of water of 3oC or less. Fog begins when water vapor condenses into very fine water droplets in the air. It is the condensation of water vapor that then appears and becomes what is called a cloud. Fog generally occurs in very humid areas. A humid condition can occur because there is an increase in water vapor in the air, or the air temperature decreases. However, sometimes fog can occur without these conditions. Generally, fog occurs when the air humidity reaches 100%. In this condition, the air can no longer bind the water vapor in the air.

The classification of fog can be done because of differences in cause, nature, and others. For example, there is fog that can occur and disappear in a short time. This fog is commonly called flash fog. There is also fog known as sea fog, which occurs above the surface of sea water. Here, the occurrence of fog is greatly influenced by the presence of salt. Tiny salt particles will fill the air above the surface of sea water for various reasons. Among other things, it is caused by wind or splashes of broken waves and other causes. These tiny salt particles will then act as water vapor collectors. There is also a type of fog that is caused by temperature changes at dusk or dawn or a situation when cold wind passes through a warm water area, or rainwater passes through a layer of hot air so that evaporation occurs.

Fog often produces rain in the form of drizzle. This condition generally occurs because the air humidity has exceeded 100%. Soon the cloud will turn into raindrops. Especially if the fog layer rises up and comes into contact with cold temperatures at the top.

In relation to fog, ecologists have found a unique type of forest because it is very closely associated with fog. This forest is commonly called cloud forest or fog forest. Such a forest refers to a wet rainforest in a highland area, both in tropical or subtropical mountains. Generally, this fog layer will thicken on the tops of the forest trees (canopy). Generally, fog forests are not too large and are limited only to areas where the atmospheric environment is suitable for forming fog.

This forest is also characterized by fog that is almost always present, thus reducing the possibility of plants obtaining direct sunlight. Trees in this area are characterized by growing shorter and smaller. This size is very different from the same type and grows in the lowlands or other parts of the mountains that receive full sunlight. High humidity encourages the growth of epiphytic plants that attach to the trunks and branches of trees, which are mostly dominated by mosses and ferns. The presence of vines and moss is also a characteristic that this is a fog forest.

In the fog forest, the main source of water is tiny grains of water that come from the fog. Condensation of water vapor from the fog will occur especially on the leaves of trees, and fall in the form of water droplets to the forest floor.

A natural phenomenon that is located in an area very far from where the Al-Qur'an was revealed, but is explained in detail in the Al-Qur'an, is proof that this holy book is not a human creation. Only God the All-Knowing can reveal a verse like this.

It is said that what is likened to a garden is a person who spends his wealth, because he realizes that he has received much grace from Allah, so he is willing to give a lot of infak; even if one day he receives a little grace, he still gives infak.

Spending wealth in the way of Allah or giving infak, can truly strengthen the soul. Because love for wealth has become human nature, because of his great love for wealth, it feels heavy for him to spend it, especially for the benefit of others. So if we give charity for example, it is an act that can strengthen the heart to do good, and eliminate the influence of wealth that is attached to the soul.

This verse closes with His word: *Wallahu bima ta'maluna bashir* (Allah always sees what you do). This means that Allah always knows the good deeds done by His servants, including giving infak with sincere intentions, then He will give the reward. Conversely, Allah also knows all the bad deeds, then He will repay them with torment.
text.267:
A truly believing person will certainly spend something good if their intention with the spending is to purify themselves and strengthen their soul. What is spent is likened to a grain that produces seven hundred grains, or likened to a garden located on high ground, which gives good results. It is certainly something good, not something bad that the one spending dislikes, or that they themselves would not want to receive if they were given such a thing.

However, the person giving charity should not be forced to give only the best of what they own, as mentioned above. The Prophet Muhammad (saw) once said to Mu'adh bin Jabal when he sent him to Yemen:

From Ibn Abbas (r.a.) that the Prophet (saw) sent Mu'adh to Yemen "then he mentioned the hadith" and in it: that Allah obligated them to pay zakat on their wealth, which is taken from the rich and given to the poor among them. (Narrated by Muttafaq 'alaih)

From the above explanation, it can be understood that Allah strongly condemns if what is given in charity consists of bad things. This does not mean that the item given in charity must be the best, but rather something reasonable, and that the person spending would like it themselves if they were the one receiving it.

In another verse, Allah says:

"Never will you attain the good [reward] until you spend [in the way of Allah] from that which you love." (Â'li 'Imran/3:92)

At the end of this verse, Allah says, which means the following: "Know that Allah is Free of need and Praiseworthy." This is a warning, especially to those who like to spend bad things, that Allah does not need such charity. He will not accept it as a good deed. If someone truly wants to do good and seek Allah's pleasure, why would they give something bad, which they themselves do not like? Allah is Free of need, Praiseworthy, and the praise worthy of Allah is that we are willing to spend something good from our wealth, which Allah has bestowed upon us.
text.268:
Satan always frightens those who give charity and persuades them to be stingy and miserly. Satan makes them imagine that giving charity will deplete their wealth and cause them to become poor and miserable. Therefore, their wealth must be saved for future preparation.

Spending on bad things, and reluctance to spend on good things, is called an evil by Allah, not a virtue, because those who are like that mean they trust Satan and do not give thanks for Allah's blessings and do not believe in Allah's wealth and His power to give additional grace to them.

Allah promises His servants through His Messenger to grant forgiveness for many mistakes, especially in matters of wealth. Because it is human nature to love wealth, so it is difficult for him to spend it.

In addition to promising forgiveness, Allah also promises those who give charity that they will get a replacement for the wealth they spend. In this world, he will gain glory and a good name among his community because of his sincerity in giving charity or by increasing the wealth that remains. In the Hereafter, he will receive manifold rewards.

In this regard, Allah says:

... And whatever you spend of anything [in His cause], He will compensate it; and He is the best of providers. (Saba'/34:39)

Giving charity is one way to be grateful. So, those who give charity sincerely are those who are grateful to Allah who has bestowed wealth upon them, and He will increase His grace to that person. His word:

If you are grateful, I will surely increase you [in favor]; but if you deny, indeed, My punishment is severe. (Ibrahim/14:7)

Imam al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated a hadith, which says that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

"There is no day in which the servants of Allah are in the morning, except that there are two angels who descend. One of the angels prays, "O Allah, give to those who spend (their wealth) a replacement." And the other angel prays, "Give to those who refuse (to spend their wealth) destruction." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

What is meant by "replacement" for the wealth that is spent is: Allah will make it easy for him to obtain sustenance, and he will gain honor in society. While what is meant by "destruction" is that his wealth is exhausted without giving him any benefit.

At the end of this verse, Allah swt reminds that He is Vast in His mercy and grace in giving forgiveness and replacement for the wealth that is spent. Allah is All-Knowing of what His servants spend, so He will not waste it, but will even give him a good reward.
text.269:
Allah bestows wisdom upon whomever He wills. Meaning, Allah grants wisdom and knowledge to whomever He wills among His servants, so that with that knowledge and wisdom, he can distinguish between right and wrong, between the whispers of Satan and the inspiration from Allah SWT.

The tool for acquiring wisdom is a healthy and intelligent mind, which can recognize something based on evidence and proofs, and can know something according to its true essence. Whoever has attained such wisdom and knowledge means that he has been able to distinguish between the promise of Allah and the whispers of Satan, then the promise of Allah is believed and the whispers of Satan are avoided and abandoned.

Allah affirms that whoever has obtained such wisdom and knowledge means that he has obtained much good, both in this world and in the Hereafter. He does not want to accept evil whispers from Satan, but rather he uses all his senses, reason, and knowledge to know what is good and what is false, what is the guidance of Allah and what is the seduction of Satan, then he surrenders himself completely to Allah.

At the end of this verse, Allah praises those who are intelligent and willing to think. They are always mindful and vigilant and can know what is beneficial and can lead them to happiness in this world and the Hereafter.
text.270:
A vow (Nazar) is an intention made to oneself to do a good deed, if a good purpose is achieved, or when one is freed from something unpleasant. For example, someone says: "If I pass the exam, I will donate so much rupiah," or "I will fast for so many days," or "If I recover from this illness, then I will donate my wealth to the renovation of the mosque."

This kind of vow is certainly good and permissible in religion, because passing an exam, or recovering from an illness is a blessing from Allah that should be gratefully acknowledged. Fasting, giving charity, and donating wealth for religious purposes and public welfare are good and beneficial deeds.

However, there are also vows that are not good, even causing harm, so such vows are certainly not pleasing to Allah swt. For example, someone says, "If I talk to my brother later, then I must fast for so many days (meaning, he will not reconcile with his brother)." This kind of vow is not justified in religion, because even though fasting is good, being hostile to one's own brother is a reprehensible act.

Whatever charity (Infak) and vows we make, Allah always knows it, so He will give a reward or punishment. If the item donated or vowed is good, and fulfilled in good ways, namely with sincerity and solely seeking the pleasure of Allah, then Allah will reward it with manifold rewards. Conversely, if the item donated or vowed is bad, or fulfilled in bad ways, for example by mentioning it repeatedly, or accompanied by hurtful words, or done with riya (showing off), then Allah will not accept it as a righteous deed, and will not reward it with any reward.

Likewise, those who are reluctant to spend their wealth in the way of Allah, or they spend it to commit immorality, or they do not want to fulfill the vow they have made, then Allah swt will repay them with punishment.

At the end of this verse, Allah swt affirms that the wrongdoers will have no helpers. This is a warning that reluctance to spend wealth in the way of Allah, reluctance to fulfill a vow that has been made, or carrying out charity (Infak) and vows in bad ways, are all acts of injustice (zalim). Allah swt will repay it with punishment, and no one can escape from that punishment, even if he redeems it with the reward of his own deeds. In this regard, Allah says in another verse:

... There is not for the wrongdoers any devoted friend or any intercessor who is obeyed. (al-Mu'min/40: 18).

Spending wealth in the way of Allah, whether it is charity to alleviate the suffering of the poor, or charity (Infak) for the public interest, the state, and religion, is an obligation for those who have wealth, as members of society. If he refuses to fulfill it, or fulfills it in inappropriate ways, then he himself will bear the consequences. Therefore, it is only natural that Allah threatens them with punishment as mentioned in the verse above.
text.271:
In this verse, Allah mentions those who give charity to the poor and needy openly, visibly, and known or heard by others. Such a way is good, as long as it is not accompanied by feelings of *riya* (showing off). Because, revealing charity will eliminate accusations of stinginess against oneself, and those who hear it will be grateful and pray for them, and they will respect and imitate their actions.

Furthermore, Allah explains that if charity is given secretly and unknown to others, then such a way is even better, if it is done to avoid feelings of *riya* in the heart, so that the poor and needy who receive it do not feel inferior to others, and are not looked down upon in their society. Because giving charity secretly will foster sincerity in good deeds for the giver. Sincerity is the soul of every act of worship and good deed.

Many hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) praise those who give charity in secret. Among them is the hadith narrated by Imam al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him), who said that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

"There are seven types of people whom Allah will shade on the Day of Resurrection, when there will be no shade but His shade; they are: A just Imam (leader), and a youth who has been brought up and loves to worship Allah since his childhood, a person whose heart is always attached to the mosque, and two people who love each other in carrying out the religion of Allah, they gather and separate for that purpose, and a man who is invited by a woman of good standing and beauty to commit adultery but he refuses, saying, "I fear Allah, the Lord of the Worlds", and a person who gives charity and conceals it, so that his left hand does not know what his right hand spends, and a person who remembers Allah when he is alone, and then he weeps." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah).

Imam Ahmad and Ibn Abi Hatim narrated a hadith from Abu Umamah that Abu Dharr said:

I once asked the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), "O Messenger of Allah, which charity is the most virtuous?" Then the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) replied, "Charity given secretly to the poor and needy, or hard work from someone who is in need." (Narrated by Ahmad and Ibn Abi Hatim)

Allah will cover and erase some of the mistakes that have been made by those who spend their wealth in a good way, in accordance with the charity they give, in addition to the reward they will receive later.

Then Allah warns that He always knows what His servants do, as well as the intentions that drive them to do it. All of that will be rewarded according to their deeds and intentions.
text.272:
Guidance (hidayah, taufik) is solely Allah's affair, not the Messenger's, nor the affair of his ummah. We should not withhold charity from non-Muslims solely on the basis of religious differences. However, giving charity to fellow Muslims is certainly more preferable, as long as there are still poor and needy people among Muslims who need help.

Charity has and contains reciprocal benefits. The person who receives charity can be helped out of difficulty, while the person who gives it receives reward in the sight of Allah, and is appreciated by those around him, as long as he gives the charity in a good way and sincerely for the sake of Allah alone.

Furthermore, it is mentioned that whatever good wealth a person spends sincerely, Allah will surely reward him with sufficient reward and he will not be harmed in the slightest, because people who like to spend (infaq) sincerely are certainly loved and respected by society, especially by the poor and needy; and their reward will not be diminished in the sight of Allah.
text.273:
The characteristics and circumstances of those who are most entitled to receive charity are:

1. Those who have sincerely dedicated themselves to tasks in the path of jihad fi sabilillah, so that they do not have the opportunity to do other work as a source of livelihood. For example, the Muhajirin, some of whom were poor at the beginning of Islam because they had left their possessions in Mecca in order to migrate to Medina to defend and develop the Islamic religion. They often fought on the battlefield, warding off the tyranny of the infidels, so they did not have free time to earn a living.

2. The poor who are unable to work, either by trading or other work, because they are weak, elderly, or for other reasons.

3. The poor who are thought by others to be self-sufficient, because they are patient and refrain from begging.

4. Those who are tasked with memorizing the Qur'an, studying religious teachings, and preserving the Sunnah of the Prophet by living a simple life.

The poor can be known from the signs that appear on them. They absolutely do not want to beg, or if they ask, not in a pressing or coercive way. In this regard, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

The one who goes around to people and is turned away with one or two morsels or one or two dates is not the truly needy person. The truly needy person is the one who does not have enough to live on and is not known to be in need so that he may be given charity, nor does he get up and beg from people. (Muttafaq 'Alaih)

In Islam, begging is haram, except in emergencies. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

From Qabishah bin al-Mukhariq r.a. he said, "I had a responsibility to the community. Then I went to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) to ask for funds from him to pay that responsibility. He replied, "Wait until the zakat funds come, I will order that you be given from those funds." The Prophet then said, "O Qabishah, begging is not halal except for one of three people. First, a person who has a responsibility to the community, it is halal for him to beg until he can pay off his responsibility, then he stops begging. Second, a person who is struck by a disaster that destroys his wealth. He may beg until he can re-establish his life. And third, a person who is afflicted with poverty until three rational people say that the person is truly afflicted with poverty. It is halal for him to beg until he can re-establish his life. Begging outside of that, O Qabishah, is a haram act that is eaten by the perpetrator in a haram way." (Riwayat Muslim)

In relation to infaq, namely zakat and charity, it is necessary to emphasize the following:

1. Islam has encouraged wealthy people to give charity to the poor. When giving charity, good items should be given, in the form of food, clothing, and so on, and should not be accompanied by hurtful words. That is, the poor must be treated as well as possible.

2. The encouragement to give infaq does not mean that Islam increases the number of poor people and encourages them to beg and always expect charity from others as their source of livelihood. Because, although on the one hand Islam obligates zakat and encourages charity from the rich to the poor, on the other hand, Islam encourages the poor to try to free themselves from poverty, so that their lives do not depend on charity and gifts from others. In this regard, there are verses of the Qur'an and hadith of the Prophet Muhammad that encourage diligent work, eliminating laziness and negligence, and praising those who can earn a living through their own efforts and hard work. Allah says:

¦ Indeed, Allah will not change the condition of a people until they change what is in themselves. ¦ (ar-Ra'd/13: 11).

What is meant by "what is in themselves" includes bad traits that are the cause of poverty. For example, laziness, negligence, dishonesty, unwillingness to seek knowledge to have the skills to work, and so on. If they change these traits with good traits, namely working diligently, then Allah will give them a way to improve their lives. In another verse, Allah says:

"And when the prayer has been concluded, disperse within the land and seek from the bounty of Allah." (al-Jumu'ah/62:10).

The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) praised those who earn a living from their own hard work and sweat. He said:

"The best food for a person to eat is from his own labor." (Riwayat al-Bukhari)

To raise self-esteem and avoid begging or expecting gifts from others, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

"The upper hand (the hand that gives) is better than the lower hand (the hand that receives charity or gifts from others)." (Riwayat al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Thus, Islam wants people who have wealth to like to help the poor. Conversely, Islam guides the poor to strive hard to free themselves from that poverty.
text.274:
This verse is the last in a series of verses discussing the issue of *infak* (spending in charity) in Surah al-Baqarah. In this verse, Allah affirms the benefits that will be obtained by those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah, whether during the day or at night, given secretly or openly. They will surely receive their reward from their Lord, both in this world and in the hereafter. Because in this world they are loved by society, especially by the poor and needy and anyone who has ever received charity from them, while in the hereafter they will receive a multiplied reward from Allah.

They also do not feel sad about the wealth they have spent, because they are confident that they will receive a greater replacement from Allah, whether in the form of additional sustenance and ease of life in this world, or in the form of Allah's pleasure and His grace.
text.275:
There are two types of riba known:

1. Riba nasi'ah

2. Riba fadhal

Riba nasi'ah is an additional payment on a debt given by the debtor because of a request to postpone payment. This additional payment is requested by the creditor each time the debtor asks for a postponement of payment. Example: A owes B Rp 1,000 and will repay it after one month. After one month, A is unable to pay his debt, so A asks B to agree to postpone the payment. B agrees to postpone the payment on the condition that A increases the payment, making it Rp 1,300. This additional payment with a postponement of time is called riba nasi'ah.

This additional payment may be made repeatedly because the debtor always requests a postponement of payment, so that eventually A is no longer able to pay it, and sometimes even has to sell himself to pay his debt. This is what is meant by the word of Allah:

"O you who have believed, do not consume riba, doubled and multiplied, but fear Allah that you may be successful." (Ali 'Imran/3:130).

Riba nasi'ah as mentioned above was widely practiced among the Arabs of the Jahiliyyah (pre-Islamic era). This is the riba meant by the Qur'an. When studying and following the riba system in this verse and that practiced in the Jahiliyyah era, there are several things to note:

1. The interest system is a system that benefits the lender and is very detrimental to the borrower. In some cases, the borrower is even forced to sell himself into slavery in order to repay his loan.

2. In the Jahiliyyah era, this act was considered an effort to seek wealth and accumulate property for the lender.

According to Umar Ibn Khaththab, the Qur'anic verse about riba was among the last verses revealed. Until the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed away, he did not explain what was meant by riba. Thus, riba remained in its general meaning, such as the interest system applied by the Arabs in the Jahiliyyah era.

Umar's statement means that the Messenger of Allah deliberately did not explain what was meant by riba because the Arabs already knew very well what was meant by riba. When riba was mentioned to them, they already had a clear understanding in their minds, and they had agreed on its meaning. Their understanding of riba was riba nasi'ah. In other words, the Qur'an has actually explained and clarified what is meant by riba.
