This is in accordance with the saying of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) regarding his two legacies that must be obeyed:

"I have left with you two things, that if you hold fast to them, you will never go astray after me: the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Messenger." (Narrated by Ibn Majah)

The religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is a religion that has been perfected and completely received by him from Allah, nothing has not been revealed to him.

"This day I have perfected for you your religion and completed My favor upon you and have approved for you Islam as religion." (al-Ma'idah/5:3)

Riba fadhal is selling a type of goods with the same type of goods with the condition of giving an addition as compensation for the type that is of good quality, such as selling 20-karat gold with 24-karat gold with an additional 1 gram of gold as compensation for 24-karat gold. This riba fadhal is also forbidden. The legal basis for the prohibition of riba fadhal is the saying of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him):

"Do not sell gold for gold, silver for silver, wheat for wheat, barley for barley, dates for dates, salt for salt, except like for like, equal for equal, and hand to hand. Whoever gives more or asks for more, then he has engaged in riba." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Ahmad)

"Like for like, equal for equal, and hand to hand" means do not harm one of the two parties who are bartering. The verse above explains the consequences that will be experienced by those who consume riba, namely their souls and hearts are not at peace, their minds are uncertain. Their condition is like people possessed by demons or like crazy people.

The Arabs of the Jahiliyyah believed that demons could influence the human soul, as well as jinn. When a demon or jinn has influenced someone's soul, then he is like someone possessed.

The Qur'an likens the influence of riba on someone who does it, to the influence of a demon that has entered someone's soul according to the beliefs of the Arabs of the Jahiliyyah. The purpose of the analogy in this verse is to facilitate understanding, not to explain that the Qur'an adheres to beliefs like the beliefs of the Arabs of the Jahiliyyah.

According to the majority of commentators (mufasir), this verse explains the condition of the riba eaters when they are resurrected on the Day of Judgment, which is like people possessed by demons. This opinion follows the opinion of Ibn 'Abbas and Ibn Mas'ud.

Also based on the saying of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him):

"Avoid sins that are not forgiven, namely: gulul (which is concealing spoils of war and others), so whoever commits gulul, later the things he hides will be carried by him on the Day of Judgment. And the riba eater, whoever eats riba, he will be resurrected on the Day of Judgment in a state of madness, again possessed (by demons)." (Narrated by ath-Thabrani from 'Auf bin Malik)

In reality in human life in this world, many riba eaters' lives are truly not peaceful, always restless, no different from people possessed by demons. The commentators (mufasir) are of the opinion that this verse describes the condition of the riba eaters in the world. This opinion can be reconciled with the first opinion, namely their condition later in the hereafter is the same as their condition in the world, there is no peace for them.

From the continuation of the verse it can be understood that the condition of the riba eaters is such that they can no longer distinguish between what is halal and what is haram, between what is beneficial and what is harmful, between what is permitted by Allah and what is forbidden, so that they say that buying and selling is the same as riba.

Furthermore, Allah affirms that He has permitted buying and selling and forbidden riba. Allah does not explain the reason. Allah does not explain this in order to make it easy for the riba eaters to understand, because they themselves have known, experienced and felt the consequences of riba.

From this affirmation, it is understood that it is as if Allah is giving a comparison between buying and selling and riba. Let people know, think about and understand the comparison.

In buying and selling there is a balanced exchange and replacement carried out by the seller and the buyer, there are benefits and advantages obtained from both parties, and there is also the possibility of obtaining reasonable profits in accordance with the efforts that have been made by them. In riba there is no balanced exchange and replacement. There is only a kind of indirect extortion, carried out by the party who has the goods against the party who is in need, who borrows in a state of compulsion.

After Allah explains the consequences experienced by the riba eaters, the words spoken by the riba eaters, the thoughts that are influencing the condition of the riba eaters, and Allah's affirmation about the law of buying and selling and riba, then Allah invites the riba eaters with a gentle invitation, which directly penetrates into their conscience, as the continuation of the verse above.

Allah (SWT) mentions the prohibition about riba in the manner of mau'idhah (teaching), meaning that the prohibition of consuming riba is a prohibition that aims for the good of mankind itself, in order to live happily in this world and the hereafter, to live in an environment of love and affection among fellow human beings and to live full of peace and tranquility.

Whoever understands Allah's prohibition and obeys the prohibition, let him stop the act of riba immediately. They are not punished by Allah for the actions they took before this verse was revealed. They are not required to return the riba at the time this verse was revealed. They may take only their principal loan, without the interest they agreed to previously.

This verse contains a lesson that can be used as a basis for establishing laws, regulations or rules, namely: a law, regulation or rule that will be established must not apply retroactively if it results in harm to the parties who are subject to or burdened by the law, regulation or rule, conversely, it may apply retroactively if it benefits the parties who are subject to or burdened by it.

The end of this verse affirms that those who have committed riba, and those who have stopped committing riba, then do it again after the revelation of this prohibition, they are among the inhabitants of hell, they will abide therein forever.

According to some commentators (mufasir), the great sin imposed on the riba eaters is because in the hearts of the eaters there has been planted a love of wealth, prioritizing their own interests, doing something for their own interests not for Allah. Such people are people who cannot possibly grow in their souls true faith, namely faith that is based on feelings, recognition and submission to Allah. If such riba eaters still claim to believe in Allah, then their faith is only lip service, a very thin faith that does not reach into the depths of their hearts.

Hasan al-Basri said, "Faith is not an adornment of the mouth and empty dreams, but faith is a strong declaration in the heart and proven by deeds. Whoever says good with his tongue, while his actions are not appropriate, Allah rejects his confession. Whoever says good while his actions are also good, his deeds will raise his degree."

The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said:

"Allah does not look at your physical form and your wealth, but Allah looks at your heart and your deeds." (Narrated by Muslim and Ahmad)
text.276:
Riba (usury/interest) has no benefit whatsoever, neither in this world nor in the hereafter. What is beneficial is charity (sadaqah).

Allah destroys riba and increases sadaqah. This means destroying wealth obtained from riba and wealth mixed with riba, or eliminating its blessing (barakah). "Increasing sadaqah" means developing wealth that has been given as charity in accordance with religious provisions, or multiplying the blessing of that wealth. Allah says:

And whatever riba (interest) you give so that it may increase in the wealth of people, it does not increase with Allah. But what you give in zakat, desiring the countenance of Allah - those are the multipliers [in reward]. (ar-Rum/30:39).

The scholars are of the opinion that what is meant by the statement "Allah destroys riba" is that Allah destroys the blessing (barakah) of riba wealth, because as a result of engaging in riba, enmity arises between those who consume riba, and the hatred of society towards them, especially those who have paid debts to them with multiplied riba, and it also causes an increase in the distance between the rich and the poor. This hatred and enmity, when it reaches its peak, will cause wars and chaos in society.

Allah does not like those who deny His blessings in the form of wealth that He has bestowed upon them. They do not use that wealth according to the provisions that Allah has established, nor do they give it to those who are entitled to receive it. Likewise, Allah does not like those who use and spend their wealth solely for their own interests, and seek wealth by oppressing or violating the rights of others.
text.277:
This verse affirms good deeds that can prevent oneself from actions that anger Allah.

Allah mentions that those who possess four qualities, as mentioned in this verse, will have no fear for themselves, nor will they grieve over any trials that Allah inflicts upon them. These four qualities are:

1. Believing in Allah

2. Performing righteous deeds (amal saleh)

3. Performing prayer (salat)

4. Paying zakat

These four qualities can be a remedy to cure the disease resulting from the practice of usury (riba). If a person has believed in Allah, with true faith, even if he was previously a consumer of usury, that faith will drive him towards good deeds. His faith will encourage him to perform prayer (salat) and pay zakat, which is the right of others in his wealth.

This verse provides a lesson to those who consume usury (riba) and cannot control themselves from stopping that practice. It is as if Allah says, "O consumers of usury, stop consuming usury. If you have intended to stop it, but you cannot control yourself to stop it, then do these four things. If you do them correctly, you will surely be able to stop usury."

People who possess these four qualities have peace of mind and are content with the trials that Allah inflicts upon them. Such a thing will not be obtained by those who consume usury (riba); what they obtain is only anxiety, worry, and doubt, like someone possessed by Satan.
text.278:
Verse 275 explains the condition of those who consume usury (riba) in this world and the Hereafter, and verse 276 explains the good education that must be undertaken by the usurer to eliminate the consequences and influence of usury on himself. All of this is conveyed with subtle expressions. This is Islam's true stance towards usury. Allah commands those who believe and are pious to stop the practice of usury.

The command to abandon usury is linked to the command to be pious (taqwa). With this connection, it is as if Allah is saying, "If you truly believe, then abandon usury. If you do not stop it, then you have lied to Allah swt in your declaration of faith. It is impossible for someone who claims to believe and be pious to engage in the practice of usury, because that action cannot exist in a person at the same time. What may happen is that someone becomes a usurer, or someone believes and is pious without consuming usury." This verse is in line with the words of the Prophet Muhammad saw:

"The adulterer does not commit adultery while he is a believer." (Narrated by al-Bukhari).

Meaning, a person who truly believes will not commit adultery, and likewise, a person who truly believes will not engage in usury. From this verse, it is understood that faith that does not produce good deeds is weak faith. Such faith does not penetrate the depths of a person's heart, therefore it does not produce happiness in this world and the Hereafter.
text.279:
This verse is the final affirmation to those who consume usury (riba). The tone is one of severe threat and is directed at those who know the law of usury but continue to practice it. This means that those who disregard Allah's commands are equated with those who wage war against Allah's religion. They will be warred against by Allah and His Messenger.

"Warred against by Allah" means that Allah will inflict a painful torment upon them in this world and the Hereafter. "Warred against by His Messenger" means that the Messengers warred against the usurers in their time. Usurers are judged as apostates and opponents of Allah's law, therefore they are permissible to be fought against. If the usurers stop their actions, by following Allah's commands and ceasing His prohibitions, they are allowed to receive back their principal capital, without any reduction.

According to the narration of Ibn Jarir, verses 278 and 279 were revealed in connection with an agreement between Abbas bin Abdul Muttalib and someone from Bani Mugirah. They agreed in the era of Arab ignorance (jahiliyah) to lend money with interest to people from the Saqif group from Bani 'Amar, namely 'Amar bin Umair. After Islam came, they still had a large amount of outstanding usury and they wanted to collect it. Then this verse was revealed.

According to the narration of Ibn Juraij: Bani Saqif had made a peace treaty with the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ, on the basis that the usury they gave to others and the usury they received were abolished. After the conquest of Mecca, the Messenger of Allah ﷺ appointed 'Attab bin Asid as governor. Bani 'Amr bin Umair bin 'Auf lent money to Mugirah with usury, and vice versa. So when Islam came, Bani 'Amr, who had a lot of usurious wealth, met Mugirah and asked for the wealth back along with the interest. Mugirah refused to pay the usury. After Islam came, this matter was submitted to the governor 'Attab bin Asid. 'Attab sent a letter to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. Then this verse was revealed. The Messenger of Allah conveyed the letter to 'Attab, which, among other things, justified Mugirah's attitude. If Bani 'Amr wanted to accept, that was good, if they refused, it meant they were opposing Allah and His Messenger.
text.280:
This verse is a continuation of the previous verse. The previous verse commanded believers to cease the practice of riba after the aforementioned verse was revealed. Lenders were to receive back the principal they had lent. This verse then explains: If the debtor is in difficulty, grant him time until he is able to repay his debt. Conversely, if the debtor is in a comfortable situation, he is obligated to repay his debt immediately. The Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

"Delaying payment of debt by a wealthy person is an act of injustice." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim).

Allah (swt) states that giving charity to a debtor who is unable to repay his debt is better. If believers have understood this command, they should implement it.

From this verse, it is also understood that:

1.  There is a command to give charity to a debtor who is unable to repay his debt.

2.  The creditor is obligated to grant a respite to the debtor if they are experiencing difficulty in repaying the debt.

3.  If someone has a receivable from someone who is unable to repay the debt, efforts should be made to free that person from the debt by releasing them from payment of the debt, either partially or entirely, or through other good means.
text.281:
After the explanation regarding the verses on usury concluded, people are given a warning to fear Allah. In the afterlife, they will return to Him, when all the deeds of servants are held accountable, including the wealth that was once acquired and used. If they are negligent or being influenced by material possessions and so on, then they should be aware and remember the coming of the Day of Reckoning/Judgment. On that day, Allah will judge with justice, not diminishing the reward for good deeds in the slightest, nor increasing the punishment for the evil deeds committed.

According to a narration by al-Bukhari from Ibn 'Abbas, this verse is the last verse revealed to the Prophet Muhammad saw. Jibril as said to the Messenger of Allah saw, "Place this verse between the verse: *Wa in kana dzu 'usratin ....* (al-Baqarah/2:280) and the verse: *Ya ayyuhalladzina amanu idza tadayantum bi dainin...* (al-Baqarah/2:282)." The Messenger of Allah saw was still alive for 21 days after the revelation of this verse. According to another narration, he passed away 81 days later.
text.282:
With the command to spend wealth in the way of Allah, the encouragement to give charity, and the prohibition of usury, humans must strive to preserve and develop their wealth, not wasting it in accordance with Allah's provisions. This indicates that wealth is not something hated by Allah and condemned by Islam. In fact, besides giving the command for it, Allah also provides guidance and establishes general provisions and laws that regulate how to seek, preserve, use, and spend wealth in the way of Allah. Wealth obtained in accordance with Allah's provisions is the best wealth, according to the words of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him):

"The best wealth is the wealth of a righteous person." (Narrated by Ahmad and ath-Thabrani from 'Amr bin 'Ash).

What Allah hates and what Islam condemns is wealth obtained through ways that deviate from Allah's provisions, and the wealth of people who make themselves slaves to wealth. Their entire life, effort, and thoughts are devoted to accumulating wealth and enriching themselves. Because of this, traits of greed, avarice, stinginess, and miserliness arise in them, so that they do not heed the poor and neglected. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

"Woe to the slave of the dinar, woe to the slave of the dirham." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah).

In this verse, Allah commands those who believe to implement Allah's provisions whenever they engage in debt transactions, completing them with evidence, so that it can be used as a basis for resolving disputes that may arise later.

The evidence can be in the form of written proof or the presence of witnesses.

1. Written Proof

"Written proof" should be written by a "scribe," who writes the contents of the agreement that has been agreed upon by both parties. The conditions for the scribe are:

a. A just person, not biased towards either party to the agreement, so as not to benefit one party and harm the other.

b. Knowledgeable about Allah's laws, especially those related to the laws of agreements and transactions, so that he can provide correct advice and guidance to the parties making the agreement. Because the scribe is jointly responsible and becomes a witness between the parties making the agreement, should a dispute arise later. The scribe in the modern era is realized in the form of a notary/recorder of sale and purchase deeds and debts.

In the structure of this verse, mentioning the characteristic of "just" is prioritized over the characteristic of "knowledgeable," because the characteristic of justice is more important for a scribe. Many people are knowledgeable, but they are not just, therefore the truth of the guidance and advice they give is doubtful. A just person, even if his knowledge is lacking, can be expected to give correct and unbiased advice and guidance.

The scribe's task is to write down the provisions that have been agreed upon by the parties making the agreement. The way to do this is for the debtor to dictate to the scribe about what he has borrowed, the method and implementation of the agreement, and so on. The purpose of dictating the contents of the agreement by the party making the agreement is so that what is written is an acknowledgment from the debtor, because writing alone without a statement made by the debtor cannot be used as an acknowledgment.

Allah warns the person making the agreement to always fulfill his promise well. He should fear Allah, and be committed to the promise he has made. He should be grateful to Allah who has softened the heart of the person who has helped him in difficulty. If he is grateful, Allah will always protect, preserve, and guide him to the easy path and the path to happiness.

If the person making the agreement is of weak intellect or he himself is unable to dictate, then the right to dictate is transferred to the guardian concerned. The guardian should be a just person and knowledgeable about the laws related to muamalah. Guardians should be careful in carrying out their guardianship duties.

What is meant by "a person of weak intellect" is a person who is not yet capable of maintaining and using his wealth. A person who is unable to dictate is like a mute person, a stutterer, and so on.

2. Witnesses

"Witnesses" are people who see and know the occurrence of an event. Testimony is one of the pieces of evidence (bayyinah) that can be used as a basis for resolving a dispute or case.

According to this verse, testimony in muamalah should be given by at least two men, or if there are no two men, it may be given by one man and two women.

Regarding the conditions for "men" who will become witnesses are as follows:

a. The witness should be a Muslim. This opinion is based on the words *min rijalikum* (from men among you) contained in the verse. From these words, it is understood that the witness should be a Muslim. According to some scholars: being a Muslim is not a condition for a witness in muamalah. Because the purpose of testimony in muamalah is to have evidence, should a dispute or case arise between the parties involved later. Therefore, people who are not Muslim are allowed to be witnesses as long as the purpose of giving testimony can be achieved.

b. The witness should be a just person, not biased so that the purpose of giving testimony is achieved, according to Allah's word:

... and have witnesses, two just men from among you ... (ath-Thalaq/65: 2)

Furthermore, this verse distinguishes between the testimony of men and the testimony of women. One male witness can be replaced by two female witnesses. The scholars differ on why Allah distinguishes the number of male witnesses from the number of female witnesses. The reason that is in accordance with reason is that men and women were each created by Allah with advantages and disadvantages. Each has a greater ability and capability in a matter than the ability of the other party. In the field of muamalah, men have more abilities compared to women. In general, muamalah is mostly done by men. Because women's attention is somewhat less compared to men's attention in the field of muamalah, their thoughts and memories in this field are also somewhat less. If testimony is given by a woman, she may forget, therefore there should be another woman who participates as a witness who can remind her.

According to Sheikh Ali Ahmad al-Jurjani: men use their minds more in weighing a problem they face, while women use their feelings more. Therefore, women are weaker in their will, use their minds less in complex matters, especially when they are in a state of hatred and anger, they will be happy or sad because of a small thing. It is different with men, they are able to be steadfast and patient in enduring difficulties, they do not determine a matter, except after thinking about it carefully. )

The field of muamalah is a field that uses more thought than feeling. A witness in muamalah also functions as a peacemaker between the parties making the agreement if a dispute arises later. Based on the explanation of Sheikh Ali Ahmad al-Jurjani and other explanations, it is suspected that this is among the wisdom of why Allah equates one male witness with two female witnesses.

According to Imam asy-Syafi'i: The acceptance of a witness's testimony should be with an oath. He reasoned with the sunnah of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) who ordered witnesses to take an oath before giving their testimony. Meanwhile, according to Abu Hanifah: the acceptance of someone's testimony does not need to be accompanied by an oath.

In this verse it is mentioned "and let not the witnesses refuse when they are called upon." The meaning is:

1. A person should be willing to be a witness in an event or incident, if the testimony is needed.

2. A person should be willing to be a witness if a case occurs, while he is the person who knows the occurrence of the event.

3. A person should be willing to be a witness to an event that occurs, if there is no one else who will be a witness.

It is narrated by ar-Rabi' that this verse was revealed when a man was looking for witnesses among the people to ask for their testimony, but no one was willing.

According to one opinion, what is meant by "let them not refuse" is: let them not refuse to accept the request to become a witness and carry it out. Refusing to do both is haram. The law of giving testimony is fardu kifayah.

Then Allah explains His command, so that those who believe should not be lazy and should not be bored of writing down the agreement they will make, whether small or large, and the conditions and time are explained. In this verse, Allah prioritizes mentioning "the small" over "the large", because most people always take lightly and easily agreements related to trivial (small) matters. A person who underestimates agreements related to trivial (small) matters will certainly take lightly agreements related to primary (large) matters. From this verse, it can also be understood that Allah warns humans to be careful in matters of rights and obligations, even if the rights and obligations are related to secondary/trivial matters.

Allah mentions the wisdom of the commands and prohibitions contained at the beginning of this verse, which is to uphold justice, uphold testimony, to create confidence and eliminate doubts. If trade is done in cash, then there is no sin if it is not written. From this verse, it is understood that even though there is no sin if you do not write down cash trade, the best thing is to always write it down.

Even though it is not obligatory to write down cash trade, Allah commands to bring witnesses. The command here is not obligatory, it only gives the meaning of sunnah. The goal is so that humans are always careful in muamalah.

Furthermore, Allah warns that scribes, witnesses, and people who make agreements should make it easy for the other parties, not make it difficult and not let one party act in a way that results in harming the other party. Because the agreement is carried out well if each party has good intentions towards the other party.

And do not forget graciousness between you. (al-Baqarah/2: 237)

If someone makes it difficult or harms other people, then such an act is the act of a wicked person, and does not obey the provisions of Allah.

At the end of this verse, Allah commands humans to be pious to Him by maintaining themselves to always carry out His commands and stay away from His prohibitions. He teaches humans everything that is useful for them, namely how to maintain wealth and how to use it, so that it creates peace for themselves and the people who help them in the effort to seek and use that wealth. Allah knows everything that humans do, and He will give rewards according to that deed.
text.283:
This verse explains about *muamalah* (transactions) that are not conducted in cash, which are carried out during travel and there is no scribe to write it down.

In the case of *muamalah* that is not in cash, carried out during travel and there is no scribe to write it down, then there should be collateral (guarantee/security) that is handed over to the creditor. Unless they trust each other and surrender themselves to Allah, then the *muamalah* can be carried out without handing over collateral.

This verse does not stipulate that collateral is only permissible on the condition that it is during travel, the *muamalah* is not in cash, and there is no scribe. But this verse only states that in such circumstances, *muamalah* can be carried out using collateral. In other situations, it is also permissible to use collateral in accordance with the hadith narrated by al-Bukhari that the Prophet Muhammad saw once pawned his armor to a Jew in Medina.

In the previous verse, Allah warned that people should not be reluctant to become scribes or give testimony when asked. Then in this verse, Allah reaffirms not to conceal testimony. Such affirmation indicates that writing and testimony help people in protecting their wealth, and do not neglect to do both. Likewise, the owner of the wealth is not troubled because he lends his wealth, and is not paid on time.

With the above explanation, it does not mean that all *muamalah* agreements must be written by a scribe and witnessed by witnesses, but the intention is that Muslims should always pay attention to and examine the *muamalah* they are about to carry out. If the *muamalah* is a common transaction carried out every day, such as buying and selling in the market and does not cause undesirable consequences later on and is based on mutual trust, then such *muamalah* does not need to be written and witnessed. Conversely, if the *muamalah* is suspected to cause undesirable things later on, then the *muamalah* must be written and witnessed by two witnesses.
text.284:
From this verse, we can derive an understanding of the perfection of Allah's oneness in the following aspects:

1. Oneness in His power.

2. Oneness in knowing everything that happens in this universe.

Allah is One in possessing all creatures. Allah alone creates, nurtures, develops, and owns this entire universe; nothing is associated with Him.

Allah is One in knowing everything in this universe. Allah knows the great and the small, the visible and the invisible to humans. Everything that happens, that exists in this universe, is not beyond Allah's knowledge; nothing escapes His knowledge.

Allah is One in His power. What happens in this universe is according to Allah's will; nothing can change His will. If He wills something to exist, it will certainly exist. Conversely, if He wills something to disappear, it will disappear. Only He can know the deeds of His servants, and forgive or punish them, and just decisions are only in His hands.

What exists in the hearts of humans is of two kinds. First: Something that exists in the heart, which comes spontaneously, moves without anything moving it, flashes in the heart by itself. Such movement is not based on *iradah* (will) and *ikhtiyar* (choice) of humans, it only arises in the heart. Such a thing is not judged and accounted for by Allah SWT, unless it is followed by *iradah*, intention, and *ikhtiyar*.

Second: Something that exists in the heart that arises with effort, thought, the result of contemplation, and so on. Such movement turns into strong ideals and desires, so that *iradah*, intention, and *ikhtiyar* arise to carry it out. It is this kind of movement of the heart that is accounted for and used as a basis in determining the reward for human deeds.

Therefore, Allah commands that humans always monitor, examine, and feel what is in their hearts. If what is in their hearts is in accordance with Allah's commands and not contrary to His prohibitions, then preserve it and nurture it, so that it can manifest good deeds. Conversely, if what is in the heart is contrary to Allah's commands or encourages someone to commit His prohibitions, erase it immediately and banish it, so that it does not lead to sinful actions. Humans should be wary of the possibility of bad intentions or feelings in their hearts, which could lead to sinful actions.

An example is: jealousy, which initially grows because of dislike for someone. That feeling increases when seeing that person's success; this success nurtures the feeling of dislike. Then anger, resentment, the desire to retaliate, and so on arise. If that is the feeling, it is difficult to eliminate it immediately. It is even feared that it can lead to sinful actions. But if that feeling is extinguished when it begins to grow, then jealousy will not arise, and even if it does arise, it can be easily eliminated.
text.285:
Narrated by Ahmad and Muslim from Abu Hurairah, he said, "When Allah revealed verse 284 to the Messenger of Allah (saw), the companions felt their burden had become heavier. So they came to the Messenger of Allah (saw) and said, "We have been burdened with deeds that we are able to do, namely prayer, fasting, jihad, charity, and now this verse has been revealed, which we are unable to fulfill." Then the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "Do you want to say as the People of the Book before you said, "We hear and we disobey"? Say, "We hear and we obey, we seek Your forgiveness, O our Lord, and to You is the return."

When the Messenger of Allah recited this verse to them, their tongues followed it. Then the next verse was revealed, verse 285 of al-Baqarah. Abu Hurairah said, "When the companions had done that, Allah removed their anxiety about that verse and He revealed the next verse:

Allah does not burden a soul beyond that it can bear. (al-Baqarah/2: 286)

The hadith above illustrates the companions' fear of Allah's punishment. The companions used to live, be educated, and grow up in the environment of the Arab jahiliyyah (ignorance). The thoughts, hearts, beliefs, and customs of jahiliyyah had greatly influenced them. Some of them were even leaders of the Arab jahiliyyah. After the Prophet Muhammad (saw) was sent, they followed the Prophet's call and entered Islam wholeheartedly. Nevertheless, traces of the influence of Arab jahiliyyah beliefs and culture still remained in their souls. These beliefs and culture gradually disappeared and were erased, with each verse of the Qur'an being revealed and each explanation of the message he brought to them.

They themselves always tried to ensure that the traces of bad influence would immediately disappear from themselves. When this verse was revealed, they were worried that Allah (swt) would not forgive their sins, as a result of the traces of Arab jahiliyyah beliefs and culture that still existed in their hearts and souls, even though they had tried their best to eliminate them. Because of this anxiety and worry, they immediately asked the Messenger of Allah (saw).

The feeling of anxiety about being punished by Allah (swt) is reflected in 'Umar bin al-Khaththab's question to Huzaifah. He once asked Huzaifah, "Do you (Huzaifah) find in me any of the signs of a hypocrite?" So, to eliminate that anxiety and reassure their hearts, a verse was revealed as quoted above (al-Baqarah/2:286).

With the revelation of this verse, the hearts of the companions felt calm and peaceful, because they were convinced that all of Allah's prohibitions and commands were in accordance with the limits of human ability. There are no commands and prohibitions that humans cannot do or stop. Only those who deny Allah feel it is difficult to stop His prohibitions. They were also convinced that the bad deeds that crossed their minds and that they hated, they had tried to eliminate, therefore they would not be punished. Allah says:

Allah will not call you to account for what is unintentional in your oaths, but He will call you to account for what your hearts have earned. And Allah is Forgiving and Forbearing. (al-Baqarah/2: 225)

Furthermore, Allah explains that He reckons (calculates) what is in the hearts of humans, whether hidden or revealed, and with His reckoning, He repays human deeds fairly, because the reckoning and repayment are based on Allah's attribute of being Most Merciful to His servants.

Then Allah affirms that by His grace He forgives His servants and punishes them justly and gives manifold rewards to those who do good deeds.

Finally, Allah declares that "He is All-Powerful over all things". From this verse, it is understood that Allah is All-Powerful over all things, so ask for His help, so that you can carry out His commands and stop His prohibitions, ask for His taufik (divine guidance) and hidayah (guidance).

The beginning of Surah Al-Baqarah begins by explaining that there is no doubt in the Qur'an and also explaining the attitude of humans towards it, namely some believe, some disbelieve, and some are hypocrites. Then the laws of prayer, zakat, fasting, hajj, marriage, jihad, riba, the law of agreements and so on are mentioned. This verse is the closing verse of Surah Al-Baqarah which affirms the nature of the Prophet Muhammad (saw), and his followers towards the Qur'an. They believe in it, making it a guide to life to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter. This verse also affirms the greatness and truth of the Prophet Muhammad, and those who believe, and affirms that the laws mentioned are true laws.

With this verse, Allah (swt) declares and establishes that the Messenger of Allah (saw) and those who believe, truly believe in the Qur'an, they do not doubt it at all and they believe in the truth of the Qur'an. Allah's statement is seen in the Messenger of Allah (saw) and the personalities of the believers, seen in the purity and cleanliness of their hearts, the height of their ideals, the endurance and steadfastness of their hearts in accepting trials in conveying the religion of Allah, their attitude when achieving victory and facing defeat, their attitude towards enemies who have been controlled, their attitude when captured and their attitude when entering areas outside the Arabian Peninsula.

Such attitudes and character are attitudes and character generated by the teachings of the Qur'an, and obedience to carrying out Allah's law. This is what is meant by 'Aisha r.a.'s answer when asked about the character of the Prophet Muhammad (saw), she answered:

"Do you not always read the Qur'an?" He answered, "Yes". 'Aisha said, "Then indeed the character of the Prophet is in accordance with the Qur'an." (Narrated by Muslim)

If the Prophet Muhammad (saw) did not truly believe in the teachings he brought, and did not hold on to the truth in carrying out his duties, then he and his followers would not have such a character. He would hesitate in carrying out his ideals, hesitate in telling the stories of past people mentioned in the Qur'an, especially in facing the reactions of the Jews and Christians. Moreover, remembering that the Jews and Christians are people who have a lot of knowledge about ancient history at that time, therefore the Prophet Muhammad always thought about and remained convinced of the truth of every religious teaching that he would present to them.

The people who lived in the time of the Prophet, both his followers and those who denied him, all said that Muhammad was a trustworthy person, not a liar.

Every believer is convinced of the existence of Allah the One. Only He creates creatures, not associating with anything. They believe in the books of Allah that have been revealed to His prophets, believe in the angels of Allah, and the angel who is the liaison between Allah and His messengers, the bringer of Allah's revelation. Regarding the state of the essence, attributes and works of the angels, it is included in the knowledge of Allah, only Allah knows best. Believing in angels is proof of believing in Allah.

The position of the Muslims towards the messengers is also stated, not differentiating between the messengers of Allah; they believe that all the messengers are the same in believing in them.

Allah (swt) says:

Say, "We have believed in Allah and in what has been revealed to us and what has been revealed to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, and the Descendants, and in what was given to Moses and Jesus and to the prophets from their Lord. We make no distinction between any of them, and to Him we submit." (al-Baqarah/2: 136)

In another verse it is explained that each messenger has an advantage compared to other messengers. An advantage possessed by one messenger may not be possessed by another messenger, and the other messenger also has an advantage.

Those messengers - some of them We caused to exceed others. ¦¦

(al-Baqarah/2: 253)

This verse alludes to the superiority of the Muslim ummah over other ummahs who differentiate between the messengers of Allah. Some of them they believe in and some they do not believe in. Even some of the messengers during their lifetime were ridiculed by them. Meanwhile, the Muslim ummah does not treat them like that.

Allah explains again other characteristics possessed by Muslims. That is, when they hear a command or prohibition of Allah, they listen with full attention, carry out the command, and avoid His prohibition. They feel the greatness and power of Allah, and are convinced that only Allah is worthy of being worshiped and obeyed.

Because the believers have such characteristics, they always offer prayers to Allah, namely: "Forgive us, O our Lord, and to You is the return".

Indeed, the prayer of the believers is not merely to ask forgiveness from Allah (swt) for the mistakes they have made, but also to ask Allah to always be given taufik and hidayah, so that they can carry out all His commands and leave all His prohibitions.

From this prayer, it can be understood that those who believe always try to carry out Allah's commands and leave His prohibitions after they hear and understand the command and prohibition. They realize that they are imperfect humans, not free from shortcomings. Even though their hearts and souls have promised to obey Allah's commands and prohibitions after hearing and understanding them, but without them realizing it, they often forget and are negligent, so they ignore the command and prohibition. Even though they have known that Allah will not punish humans for forgetting and being negligent, but those who believe feel obliged to ask for forgiveness and repent to Allah, so that Allah does not punish them for such actions.

The influence of such faith is seen in their behavior, nature, actions and deeds. All of that is directed and directed to the path that is pleasing to Allah. This is understood from their statement, "Only to You is our return".

This statement reveals the true essence of human life, outlines the guidelines of life and the ultimate goal that must be achieved by humans.

(286) In achieving that goal of life, humans are given burdens by Allah according to their ability, they are given rewards more than what they have strived for and receive punishment commensurate with the evil they have done.

The deeds that are burdened on someone are only those that are in accordance with their ability. The religion of Islam is a religion that does not burden humans with heavy and difficult burdens. Easy, light and not narrow are the basic principles of the religion of Islam. Allah says:

¦. and He has not placed upon you in religion any difficulty. ¦ (al-Â¦ajj/22: 78).

Allah wants to lighten for you [your difficulties]; and mankind was created weak. (an-Nisa'/4: 28).

¦. Allah intends for you ease and does not intend for you hardship. ¦. (al-Baqarah/2: 185)

Then Allah explains the results of the deeds that have been burdened and carried out by humans, namely the good deeds that they do. Then the reward will be received and felt by them in the form of rewards and paradise. Conversely, the sins committed by humans, then the punishment for committing the sin, will also be felt and borne by them, namely torment and punishment in hell.

This verse encourages humans to do good deeds and fulfill the obligations that have been established by religion. This verse gives the understanding that good deeds are deeds that are easy for humans to do because they are in accordance with their nature and character, while evil deeds are deeds that are difficult for humans to do because they are not in accordance with their nature and character.

Humans are born in a state of pure fitrah (natural disposition) and the soul of monotheism has been planted in their hearts. Even though humans are given the potential by Allah to be good and to be bad, but with the soul of monotheism that has been planted in their hearts since they were still in their mother's womb, then the nature of wanting to do good is more real in the hearts of humans compared to the nature of wanting to do evil.

The existence of a desire planted in a person to do a good job, will give him the possibility to get an easy way in doing that job. Especially if he succeeds and can enjoy his efforts, then the encouragement and enthusiasm to do other good deeds will increase in himself.

All kinds of evil deeds are deeds that are contrary to and not in accordance with human nature. They do evil deeds at first because they are forced. When he does evil deeds, then fear arises in himself, always worried about being known by others. This feeling will increase every time he commits evil. Finally, laziness arises, a feeling of guilt in himself and feels that he is hated by others. The Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

"Goodness is good character, and sin is everything that scratches in your heart, while you do not like others to know it". (Narrated by Muslim)

The difficulties that arise as a result of evil deeds will be increasingly felt by humans when he has begun to receive punishment, directly or indirectly from his actions.

From this verse it is also understood that someone will not receive profit or loss due to the actions of others; they will not be punished for the sins of others. They are only punished for the evil they do themselves.

That no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another; And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives; (an-Najm/53:38 and 39)

On the other hand, humans can receive profits in the form of rewards, when they die later, from the results of their efforts during their lifetime. Including human efforts are his pious children who pray for him, the ongoing charity he gives and the useful knowledge he teaches. The Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

When a person dies, his deeds are cut off (the reward) except for three things, namely: pious children who pray for him, ongoing charity, and useful knowledge. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

After mentioning the characteristics of those who believe and mentioning the grace that Allah has bestowed upon His servants, namely not burdening servants with what they cannot do, then Allah teaches prayers to always be asked of Him to be forgiven from all sins because of doing forbidden deeds due to forgetting, being wrong or unintentional.

The prayer that is taught to us is not merely to be read and repeated in its words, but rather the intention is that the prayer is read with sincerity with all our heart and soul, in addition to carrying out all His commands and avoiding His prohibitions, according to the ability of the servant himself.

Prayer is closely related to actions and deeds. Actions and deeds are also closely related to knowledge. Therefore, a person who prays cannot be said to be praying, if he does not do the deeds that must be done and avoid the prohibitions that must be left. Doing and practicing must be based on knowledge. There are deeds that can be done and there are deeds that cannot be done, there are deeds that are done perfectly and there are also deeds that cannot be done perfectly. To perfect this deficiency, Allah teaches prayer to His servants. In other words; prayer perfects deeds that cannot be done perfectly.

From that prayer, it is understood that in essence, forbidden deeds that are done because of forgetting or being wrong and unintentional, there is also punishment. The punishment is imposed on the perpetrator. Therefore, Allah teaches that prayer to His servants so that he is spared from that punishment.

After being taught a prayer to ask for forgiveness from Allah from all the deeds he did because of forgetting and unintentionally, then another prayer is taught to ask that he not be burdened with a heavy burden as has been burdened on the people of the past. Then another prayer is taught to ask that he not be burdened with a burden that he cannot bear.

Among the prayers of those who believe are as follows: "O Allah, erase our sins and mistakes, both intentional and unintentional, and do not punish us for the sins of the deeds we have done. Do not punish us for it, give us taufik and hidayah in all our deeds, so that we can carry out Your commands easily".

We have been given guidelines in praying to Allah, asking for His help in facing the disbelievers.

The help requested here is help to achieve victory. What is meant by victory is victory in this world and the hereafter, not just victory in war.
